The species has not been recorded in the elasmobranch bycatch of the Northern Prawn Fishery and the Torres Strait Prawn Fishery that operate across northern Australia (Stobutzki et al. 2000), likely because of its close inshore shallow water habitat that is not trawled by these two fisheries. It has been reported as a very minor component of all bycatch (<0.1%) in the Queensland East Coast Banana Prawn Trawl Fishery (Stobutzki et al. 2000). It is not utilized commercially with regulations preventing retention in Queensland, and it is discarded. At-vessel mortality (AVM) and post-release mortality for this species is unknown, although AVM it is suspected to be moderate; Stobutzki et al. (2002) found an at-vessel mortality of 53–59% for two species of stingrays captured in the Northern Prawn Fishery. In some inshore commercial fisheries, there is the practice of 'spiking' incidentally caught stingrays (using a metal bar or stick with a sharpened point attached to pierce the animal's chondrocranium and remove it from nets, sorting trays, etc.) that is source of mortality.

The species is a bycatch of inshore recreational line fishing as it readily takes cut fish baits and is thus prone to capture. Incidental capture by recreational fishers is likely a significant threat to the species as fishers often destroy any stingray catches (Pogonoski et al. 2002, P. Kyne unpubl. data 2015). The Estuary Stingray has been reported to feed voraciously on farmed oysters (Whitley 1940, Last and Stevens 2009), and is persecuted by commercial shellfish farmers in New South Wales and southern Queensland estuaries.

Habitat degradation and loss are also a threat to this species due to its occurrence in shallow inshore, riverine, and estuarine habitats. There has been significant habitat loss and alteration along parts of the Australian east coast as a result of the reclamation of large areas of shallow muddy tidal bays and mangroves for the development of urban areas, canal estates, marinas, and large-scale developments such as the Port of Brisbane and Brisbane Airport expansions. For example, over 20% of the original mangrove habitat of Moreton Bay in southern Queensland has been lost to such development since European settlement (Greenwood 1993).
population:
This species was once considered common, but there is anecdotal evidence of a decline in abundance and area of occupancy for this species in parts of New South Wales and southern Queensland (Pogonoski et al. 2002, Kyne et al. 2003). Historic accounts report that the Estuary Stingray was an extremely common species in the bays and estuaries of New South Wales and southern Queensland. It has not been reported from Port Jackson and Botany Bay, New South Wales, where it was once common, since the 1880s. In more recent years, i.e., since 2000, it has been reported on the central New South Wales coast (Pierce and Bennett 2010a). Records and occurrence appear to be very patchy, with most records from rivers, estuaries, bays and harbours (Pierce and Bennett 2010a). The species is still locally common in some southern Queensland estuaries and bays (i.e., Hervey Bay, parts of Moreton Bay) (Pierce et al. 2011). It also has been reported to persist in highly modified habitats for long periods of time (>100 years) (Pierce and Bennett 2010a). It is a very minor component of commercial prawn trawl fisheries in Queensland where an ecological risk assessment of the southern Queensland East Coast Otter Trawl Fishery assessed this species as at intermediate risk based on its level of resilience to fisheries and the fishing pressure on the species (Jacobsen et al. 2018). It is not at risk from prawn trawl fisheries across northern Australia as it is not encountered by those fisheries, likely as they do not trawl in shallow inshore habitats. However, there is no information on population trends across the northern part of its range.

Overall, historic and more recent anecdotal declines in abundance and area of occupancy have occurred in ~25% of its range (the southern part of its range) due to the combined threats of bycatch in commercial fisheries, destruction of incidental catches by recreational fishers and during some commercial fishing activities, persecution by shellfish farmers, and habitat degradation and loss due to nearshore coastal development. Across the rest of its range, bycatch mitigation measures have been in place since 2000, it is either unfished or lightly fished, and habitat degradation is less of a threat. Taking a precautionary approach and considering the historic and more recent declines in abundance and area of occupancy in the southern part of its range and that is appears to be an ecological specialist with a very patchy occurrence, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (52 years) due to levels of exploitation and a decline in area of occupancy due to habitat degradation.
range: The Estuary Stingray is endemic to northern and eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific where it ranges from Darwin, Northern Territory to Wagonga Inlet, southern New South Wales (Pierce and Bennet 2010a, Gladstone et al. 2012, Last et al. 2016b). It was previously considered to also occur across southern Papua New Guinea and Indonesian West Papua, however these records represent another species, the Merauke Stingay (Hemitrygon longicauda) (Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions for the Estuary Stingray. Elasmobranchs cannot be retained in the Queensland prawn trawl fishery or the Northern Prawn Fishery and so incidental captures are discarded. The use of Turtle Excluder Devices (TEDs) is mandated in all Australian prawn trawl fisheries and has been shown to be an effective way to reduce the catches of large rays in prawn trawls (Campbell et al. 2020); large individual Estuary Stingrays may be excluded from capture. There is a possession limit of one shark or ray for recreational fishers in Queensland. The species likely occurs in a number of marine protected areas in New South Wales and Queensland waters, although zoning plans for these parks and reserves restrict fishing activities in only small areas and do not generally protect sufficient areas of the habitat of this species. The zoning plan for the Moreton Bay Marine Park, Queensland includes closed areas representing 16% of the area of the Park. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Birdbeak Dogfish (Deania calcea) is a medium-sized (to 162 cm total length) deep-water shark known from a widespread yet patchy global distribution in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific Oceans. It occurs on continental and insular shelves and slopes at depths of 60–1,600 m, with most individuals recorded at depths >400 m. The species is caught as both targeted and incidental catch in midwater and demersal trawl, demersal longline, and gillnet fisheries operating across most its known range, but the species may find some refuge at depth. There has been a number of management measures implemented in recent years, both species-specific and more generally for deep-water sharks. There is high distribution overlap with intensive fishing pressure, reported declines in part of its range but increasing trends in others, and a lack of species-specific management across its entire range. The Birdbeak Dogfish is estimated to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (90 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Birdbeak Dogfish occurs on continental and insular shelves and slopes at depths of 60–1,600 m, with most individuals recorded at depths >400 m (Neat et al. 2015, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 162 cm total length (TL) (Weigmann 2016). Males mature at 73–94 cm TL and females mature at 94–106 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with litter size of 6–12 pups and size-at-birth is 28–34 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). There are slight regional differences in age parameters. In the Northeast Atlantic, female age-at-maturity is 25 years and maximum age is 35 years; resulting in a generation length of 30 years (Clarke et al. 2002). In the Southwest Pacific, female age-at-maturity is 21.5 years and maximum age is 37 years; resulting in a generation length of 29.25 years (Irvine et al. 2012).
threats:
The Birdbeak Dogfish has been taken as both targeted and incidental catch across its range in midwater and demersal trawl, demersal longline, and gillnet fisheries.

This species was previously reported in trawl, longline and gillnet fisheries targeting mixed deep-water sharks along the continental slope of the Northeast Atlantic (Gordon 1999), and was historically exploited commercially. Trawl survey records indicate peak depth distribution of the species is also at depths >800 m (Neat et al. 2015). Despite a number of management measures to reduce deep-water shark fishing mortality, the species is still captured in considerable quantities in demersal fisheries (e.g. Fauconnet et al. 2019). At vessel mortality is high, and post release mortality is likely to be high as well (Rodríguez-Cabello and Sanchez 2017).

Between 1950–1998, there was an apparent increase in reported landings of deep-water sharks and dogfishes across the East Central Atlantic region (e.g. Vasconcellos and Watson 2004). Deep-water sharks were first exploited in Senegal during World War II, and have been reported in landings from Cape Verde since the 1950s (Diop and Dossa 2011). More recent targeted longline fisheries for deep-water sharks have been identified in countries such as Mauritania and Ghana (FAO 2016). In Mauritania and Namibia, deep-water sharks have been reported as bycatch from black hake (Merluccius senegalensis and M. polli) fisheries (Fernández et al. 2005, Kainge et al. 2010) and unidentified deep-water sharks are also reported from regional and distant water shrimp trawlers (FarFish 2017). Accurate species-specific catches are difficult to determine and likely underestimated due to on-board processing as deep-water sharks are rarely landed whole (Fernández et al. 2005). Deania spp are occasionally reported (annual catch of <1 t between 2010–12) in demersal inshore and offshore hake trawl fisheries off South Africa (da Silva et al. 2015), and in hake fisheries operating off Chile (SUBPESCA 2017).

Deep-water sharks have been targeted in demersal longline and gillnet fisheries operating in areas managed under the Southern Indian Ocean Fisheries Agreement (SIOFA); the latter of these fisheries ceased in 2015 (Georgeson et al. 2019). An ecological risk assessment framework for deep-water sharks found the Birdbeak Dogfish to have extreme vulnerability to midwater trawl and demersal longline fisheries in Southern Indian Ocean, and extreme vulnerability to demersal trawl and demersal longline in South Pacific Ocean fisheries (Georgeson et al. 2019).

In the Indo-Pacific, the Birdbeak Dogfish is one of the most deep-water shark species reported as bycatch from offshore deep-water fisheries in New Zealand (Francis 2015), with trawl survey records indicating peak depth distribution at depths >800 m (Anderson et al. 1998). In the Australian Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF), total shark catches from the eastern and western deep-water shark fisheries peaked in 1998 at 330 t and 400 t, respectively, before declining to <25 t in each zone by 2007 (Patterson et al. 2018). A qualitative risk assessment for New Zealand's chondrichthyans ranked this species as one of the highest species at risk from industrial fishing that is not managed by the Quota Management System (QMS) (Ford et al. 2018), and a semi-quantitative risk assessment for chondrichthyan bycatch species taken in the SESSF ranked this species with low risk from current industrial fishing as fishing effort has been reduced and the species likely has refuge at depth (T. Walker, unpubl. data 2019). Any Deania spp caught in Taiwanese fisheries is likely retained and sold locally (Liu et al. 2013).
population:
Population size and trends for this species across its entire range are unknown. Population genetics have indicated some genetic variability between populations (Keggin 2017). Taxonomic uncertainty and identification issues have led to some confusion over the occurrence of dogfishes, often leading to this group reported under a generic category (e.g. Deania spp). Species-specific population trend data are available from two sources: (1) nominal catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) in the Northeast Atlantic (F. Neat unpubl. data 2019), and (2) relative abundance in the Southwest Pacific (Walker and Gason 2007, Francis et al. 2016, Stevens et al. 2017, Stevens et al. 2018, O’Driscoll et al. 2018). The trend data from each source were analyzed over three generation lengths (90 years for the Northeast Atlantic and 87.8 years for the Southwest) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

First, in the Northeast Atlantic, relative abundance estimates of Deania spp (Birdbeak Dogfish and Arrowhead Dogfish, Deania profundorum) from Spanish and Scottish trawl survey series suggest fluctuating trends since 1983 and 1998, respectively, with some indication of increasing CPUE since 2009 (F. Neat, unpubl. data 2019, ICES-WGEF 2018). Trend analysis of Scottish trawl survey data from 1998 to 2019 revealed an annual rate of increase of 12%, consistent with an estimated increase of 100% over the past three generation lengths (90 years), with the highest probability of no major reductions in population over three generation lengths. Industrial landings of the Birdbeak Dogfish in Europe (EU) and non-EU waters peaked at ~195 t in 2004–05, before rapidly declining to 3 t by 2010 in response to reduced abundance and restrictive management measures (ICES-WGEF 2018). Deania spp were often the most abundant deep-water shark in research surveys (ICES-WGEF 2018).

Second, relative biomass were combined from southeast Australia and surveys from New Zealand Chatham Rise and Sub-Antarctic (Walker and Gason 2007, Francis et al. 2016, Stevens et al. 2017, Stevens et al. 2018, O’Driscoll et al. 2018). The combined relative abundance data indicated declines from 1991 to 2003 followed by an increase in abundance. This increase likely follows the implementation of management measures, including improved reporting. The trend analysis revealed an annual rate of increase of 0.07%, consistent with an estimated increase of 7.2% over the three generation lengths (87.8 years), with the highest probability of no major reductions in population over three generation lengths. In Australia, significant reductions (>95%) in the catch of dogfishes (mainly Centrophorus spp and Squalus spp) from 1976–77 to 1996–97 on the upper slope trawl fishery off New South Wales (NSW), Australia, have been documented by fishery-independent surveys (Graham et al. 2001). Catches of Deania spp were reported from the Australian Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF), with a mean annual catch estimate of 257 t between 2000–2006 (Walker and Gason 2007). In New Zealand, the Birdbeak Dogfish is considered to have a relatively large sized population (Ford et al. 2015).

In the east Atlantic, reported fish landings from distant water fleets increased from 600,000 t to 4.5 million t between 1950 and 2000 (Alder and Sumaila 2004). Between 1984–2001, landings of the most reported squalid sharks in the Mauritania hake fishery, including the Birdbeak Dogfish, declined steadily from 158 t to 37 t, with a minimum catch of 3.5 t reported in 1999 (Fernández et al. 2005), amounting to a reduction in squalid landings of >99% over three generations. Causes of these declines have been attributed to changes in the fishing fleet, economics, and likely over-exploitation of both the target species and bycatch (Fernández et al. 2005). Many regional fisheries are now characterised by severe over-exploitation and declines in abundance of marine resources (e.g. Gascuel et al. 2007). The total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). Despite documented declines in marine resources, fishing effort is on the rise. In Ghana and Senegal, for example, artisanal total fishing effort increased by 10-fold between 1950 and 2010; industrial effort decreased since the 1990s, with total fishing CPUE declining by a third since 1950 (Belhabib et al. 2017).

In Taiwan, landings data showed a 52% decline of all combined shark species over 63 years from 1953 to 2015. The annual landings rose from ~8,300 t annually in the 1950s to a peak of 32,400 t in 1975, then declined steadily to 4,023 t in 2015 (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Across Taiwan, both industrial and artisanal fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s (Kuo and Booth 2011, Liao et al. 2019). Industrial effort did decline after the 1990s, however there remains considerable industrial and artisanal fishing effort. These long-term declines in abundance of sharks can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s of industrial fisheries effort. This represents a 65% decline when scaled to the past three generation lengths (87.8 years) for the Birdbeak Dogfish, and although not species-specific, is informative for inferring the possible levels of reduction of this species in Taiwan.

The Birdbeak Dogfish population is estimated to have increased in the Northeast Atlantic and Southwest Pacific and is suspected to have declined in the Northwest Pacific and West Africa. To estimate a global population trend, the estimated three generation population trends for the Northeast Atlantic and Southwest were weighted according to the relative size of each region. The overall estimated median increase was 62.7%, with the highest probability of no major reduction over three generation lengths (90 years). Trends were estimated to be reflective of ~80% of its known range. Overall, a population reduction of 20–29% is estimated over the last three generations, based on abundance data and levels of exploitation. Therefore, the species is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
range: The Birdbeak Dogfish has a widespread, yet patchy, global distribution in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific Oceans (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The species has historically been utilized for its flesh and liver oil (sold as "pearl shark" or "deepsea flake" in Australia). Fins from Deania spp have been reported in the international fin trade in low quantities (Fields et al. 2018).
conservationActions:
Further information is required on population size and trends of the Birdbeak Dogfish, as well as interactions with fisheries across its range, particularly around Africa and South America. There are some species-specific and general management arrangements of relevance in place in the Northeast Atlantic and the Southwest Pacific. Elsewhere, targeted deep-water shark fishing is not permitted in the South East Atlantic Fisheries Organization (SEAFO) Convention Area or under the Southern Indian Ocean Fisheries Agreement (SIOFA) (SIOFA 2019, SEAFO 2016). The species is considered a "key species of concern" within the SIOFA area (SIOFA 2019). Conservation measures are generally lacking elsewhere in the species' patchy range.

Since 2010, the European Union Fisheries Council prohibited direct fishing for deep-water sharks, including the Birdbeak Dogfish, in European Community and international waters, and in 2012, no allowances for bycatch were implemented (ICES-WGEF 2018). In 2017 and 2018, a restrictive bycatch allowance (10 t) was trialled, permitting limited landings of unavoidable catches of deep-water sharks in directed artisanal demersal longline fisheries for Black Scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp). Additional management actions for this region include banned use of trawls and gillnets in waters >200 m in Azores, Madeira and Canary Islands and international waters regulated by ICES (NEAFC regulatory Area); banned use of gillnets by EU vessels at depths >600 m; maximum bycatch limits of deep-water shark in Hake (Merluccius merluccius) and Monkfish (Lophius spp) gillnet catches; area restrictions by vessel size and gear, gear restrictions (hook size, maximum number of hooks on longline gear), and a network of closed areas in Azorean waters; closure of the Condor seamount to deep-water fishing in 2010 (ICES-WGEF 2018).

In Australia, deep-water sharks, including the Birdbeak Dogfish, are assessed and managed as a multi-species stock, divided into eastern and western zone fisheries (Patterson et al. 2018). These fisheries are subject to a multi-species Total Allowable Catches (TACs). A combination of fishery closures and reduced TACs, trawling closures to protect benthic habitat >700 m in waters of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) since 2005, as well as the closure of the South Tasman Rise Fishery in 2007 (Patterson et al. 2018), may indirectly offer this species some refuge in this region.

rationale: The Sydney Skate (Dentiraja australis) is a small (to 55 cm total length) skate endemic to eastern Australia and has a relatively restricted distribution. It is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 20–325 m. The species is a bycatch of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) where it is taken in several sectors, but mostly in the trawl sector. It used to be discarded due to its small size, but in recent years some larger individuals (adults) may be retained for local markets. When discarded it is suspected to have high survival rates. Trend analysis of relative abundance from catch monitoring in the SESSF indicate an increasing population with the highest probability of no major population reductions over the past three generation lengths (21 years). Previous to the past three generation lengths, fishery independent surveys revealed that catch rates for "skates" combined, including the Sydney Skate, declined by 83% between 1976–77 and 1996–97. This indicates dramatic historic declines and that the species is susceptible to fishing pressure. Although fishing pressure has declined over the past three generation lengths and the trend data indicate an increase in population, the data are from a relatively short time series, have a high level of uncertainty, and may not be fully representative of the population trends of this species. Given the species' restricted distribution and taking a precautionary approach, it is suspected that the Sydney Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Sydney Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 20–325 m, but it mostly occurs at depths of 100–199 m (Walker and Gason 2007, Last et al. 2016b). It reaches a maximum size of 55 cm total length (TL), males mature at 43–48 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016b). Reproduction is oviparous, like other skates, but little else is known of its biology. Age parameters are inferred from a regional congener, the White-spotted Skate (Dentiraja cerva), that has a female age-at-maturity of 5 years and maximum age of 9 years, resulting in a generation length of 7 years (Treloar 2008).
threats:
The Sydney Skate is taken as bycatch in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) (Walker and Gason 2007). It is captured in several sectors, but mostly taken in the trawl sector, and was discarded rather than retained (Walker and Gason 2007) due to its small size. In recent years, some large individuals (adults) have been retained for the meat for local markets. At-vessel mortality and post-release mortality (PRM) is unknown for this species, but based on other skates, it is suspected that when discarded it has a high survival rates. At-vessel mortality for other species of trawled skates has been reported as <1% and mostly <10% (Ellis et al. 2017, Ellis et al. 2018), and short-term PRM has been reported to be low with 37–97% of skates surviving for 2–5 days after trawling, though these studies have been with skates kept in tanks rather than released to the wild (Ellis et al. 2018).

Commercial trawling on the upper slope off New South Wales began in 1968 and by the early 1980s more than 100 trawlers (15–25 m length) were operating off New South Wales in the SESSF, landing ~15,000 t of fish per year. Approximately 60 of these trawlers regularly fished on the upper slope. By the end of the 1990s, the number of trawlers regularly fishing the New South Wales slope grounds in the SESSF had reduced to about 40 (Graham et al. 2001). Since the mid-2000s there has been a further one-third decrease in trawl effort in the SESSF (Emery et al. 2020). Approximately 7.7% of the Commonwealth Trawl Sector within the SESSF is trawled annually (Pitcher et al. 2016). The Sydney Skate has refuge from regular trawling as it occupies large areas of lightly or non-trawled sea floor off central and northern New South Wales, and southern Queensland (Emery et al. 2020, K. Graham pers. comm. 10 October 2007).
population:
The Sydney Skate was the most commonly caught skate on the continental shelf of central eastern Australia (Last and Stevens 2009). Species-specific population trend data are available from relative abundance in southeast Australia (Walker and Gason 2007). The trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths (21 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List Category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information). The trawl data from the Integrated Scientific Monitoring Program (ISMP) and from fisher logbooks from 1998–2006 data indicate a rise-peak-decline in catch rates with a peak in 2003 followed by a decline, however overall there was no significant trend in catch (Walker and Gason 2007). The trend analysis of those same data revealed an annual rate of increase of 1.5%, consistent with an estimated increase of 33.3% over three generation lengths (21 years), with the highest probability of no major reductions in population over three generation lengths (21 years). The time series is relatively short, however, and there is a high level of uncertainty in the estimated change beyond the 9 years of the time series (Figure 1c, Supplementary Information).

Prior to the past three generation lengths (21 years), fishery independent surveys off southern New South Wales indicated that catch rates for "skates" combined declined by 83% between 1976–77 and 1996–97 (Graham et al. 1997, Graham et al. 2001). Eight species of skates were recorded during the survey, with Sydney Skate dominating catches at depths from 220–275 m (Graham et al. 2001). Although in the past three generation lengths (21 years) catch monitoring indicated a stable and/or increasing population, prior to that, the previous heavier fishing pressure had resulted in a dramatic decline in skates, including the Sydney Skate, indicating it is susceptible to fishing pressure. Although fishing pressure has since declined, the currently available data is from a short time series and may not be fully representative of the population trends of this species. An ecological risk assessment of the southern Queensland East Coast Otter Trawl Fishery assessed this species as at high risk based on its level of resilience to fisheries and the fishing pressure on the species (Jacobsen et al. 2018). Given its restricted distribution and taking a precautionary approach, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation.
range: The Sydney Skate is endemic to eastern Australia between Moreton Bay (Queensland) and Tathra (New South Wales) (Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: The Sydney Skate was until recently not utilized (Walker and Gason 2007) as it was previously considered too small to be of commercial value. However, there is now an increasing trend for the larger individuals (adults) to be retained for the local market (Last and Stevens 2009).
conservationActions: There are currently no specific conservation actions for the Sydney Skate. However, trawl fisheries in its range are under quota management. Fisheries management in Australia now includes ecosystem management and all fisheries now have Bycatch Action Plans, must be assessed for ecological sustainability, and are required to meet certification standards to continue operating. It may receive some refuge in marine protected areas of the Temperate and Southeast Commonwealth Marine Parks Network. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The White-spotted Skate (Dentiraja cerva) is a small (to 66 cm total length) skate endemic to southern Australia. It is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 60–470 m. The species is a bycatch of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) where it is taken mostly in the trawl sector. It used to be discarded due to its small size, but in recent years some larger individuals (adults) may be retained for local markets. When discarded it is suspected to have high survival rates. Fishery independent surveys off southern New South Wales revealed that catch rates for "skates" combined declined by 83% between 1976–77 and 1996–97. Although these declines do not apply directly to this species because its distribution begins at the southern extent of the survey area, trawling was intense and still occurs throughout the White-spotted Skate's deep-water range off southeast Australia, and it likely also underwent dramatic declines. Fishing pressure has since declined yet is still present and the species is likely highly susceptible to fishing pressure, as evidenced by historic declines in regional congeners with similar depth ranges and life history. The White-spotted Skate has refuge from fishing pressure in non-trawled parts of its southern range. It is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation, and the White-spotted Skate is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The White-spotted Skate is demersal on soft substrates on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 60–470 m, possibly shallower to 20 m (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016b). It reaches a maximum size of 66 cm total length (TL), males mature at 47 cm TL and females mature at 49 cm TL (Treloar 2008). Reproduction is oviparous with a continual reproductive cycle and a size-at-birth of 11 cm TL (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016b). Female age-at-maturity is 5 years and maximum age is 9 years, resulting in a generation length of 7 years (Treloar 2008).
threats:
The White-spotted Skate is taken as bycatch of trawl fisheries operating off southern Australia, particularly in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF). The estimated annual catch of the White-spotted Skate in the SESSF between 2000–2006 was ~37 t with <1% retained (Walker and Gason 2007). In recent years some large individuals (adults) have been retained for the meat for local markets. At-vessel mortality and post-release mortality (PRM) is unknown for this species, but based on other skates, it is suspected that it has a high survival rates. At-vessel mortality for other species of trawled skates has been reported as <1% and mostly <10% (Ellis et al. 2017, Ellis et al. 2018), and short-term PRM has been reported to be low with 37–97% of skates surviving for 2–5 days after trawling, though these studies have been with skates kept in tanks rather than released to the wild (Ellis et al. 2018).

The SESSF has operated since the 1900s and targets a number of teleost species that are under quota management, but sustainable catch levels for this skate will be much lower than for the more productive teleost species. Since the mid-2000s there has been a one-third decrease in trawl effort in the SESSF (Emery et al. 2020). Approximately 7.7% of the Commonwealth Trawl Sector within the SESSF is trawled annually (Pitcher et al. 2016). In the Great Australian Bight Trawl Sector, across southern Australia, approximately 50% of the White-spotted Skate's range was not trawled in 2019-2020, providing refuge from fishing pressure in that area (Moore et al. 2020).
population:
The species is common in the western part of its range; it is the most abundant skate on the continental shelf in the Great Australian Bight (Last and Stevens 2009). Fishery independent surveys off southern New South Wales indicated that catch rates for "skates" combined declined by 83% between 1976–77 and 1996–97 (Graham et al. 1997, Graham et al. 2001). These declines do not apply directly to this species because its distribution begins at the southern extent of the survey area (Eden and Gabo). However, trawling was intense and still occurs throughout this species' deep-water range off southeast Australia and there is no reason to suspect that it has not also suffered dramatic declines in this area.

Overall, the species is subject to fishing pressure in the southeast part of its range and although fishing pressure has declined over the past three generation lengths (21 years), the fishing pressure is still present, and the species is likely highly susceptible to fishing pressure, as evidenced by historic declines in regional congeners with similar depth ranges and life history. However, it also has refuge from fishing pressure in non-trawled parts of its more western range. It is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation.
range:
The White-spotted Skate is endemic to southern Australia from Gabo Island (Victoria) to the
Recherche Archipelago (Western Australia), including Tasmania (Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: This species has high quality meat but only a very small percentage was retained during observed catches in 2000–2006 (Walker and Gason 2007, Last and Stevens 2009). While most skates caught off southeast Australia used to be discarded, there is now an increasing trend for the larger individuals to be retained for the local market (Last and Stevens 2009).
conservationActions: Currently, there are no specific conservation actions for the White-spotted Skate. However, trawl fisheries in its range are under quota management. Fisheries management in Australia now includes ecosystem management and all fisheries now have Bycatch Action Plans, must be assessed for ecological sustainability, and are required to meet certification standards to continue operating. The species may receive some refuge in marine protected areas of the Southeast and Southwest Commonwealth Marine Parks Network. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Endeavour Skate (Dentiraja endeavouri) is a small (to 37 cm total length) deep-water skate endemic to a relatively restricted area off eastern Australia. It is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 110–370 m. The species is taken as bycatch in trawl fisheries across its entire spatial range and depth range in Queensland (Qld), and most of its depth range in New South Wales (NSW). It is discarded due to its small size and regulations preventing retention in Qld. It was reported as common across its range in 1994 but since then, there is no information on the population trend. In Qld, it represents a high proportion of the elasmobranch bycatch in the Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery and although the actual catch rates were low it had high at-vessel mortality. In both Qld and NSW, the trawl fisheries are seasonal and only fish for a few months of the year, providing significant temporal refuge for this species. Despite this temporal refuge, it has a relatively restricted range and when captured appears to have high at-vessel mortality. Taking a precautionary approach, it is suspected that the Endeavour Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (23 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Endeavour Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 110–370 m (Last et al. 2016b). It reaches a maximum size of 37 cm total length (TL), males mature at 30 cm TL and females mature at 32 cm TL (Kyne et al. 2008, Last et al. 2016b). Reproduction is oviparous and size-at-birth is 10–11 cm TL (Last et al. 2016b). Age parameters are inferred from its similar sized sister species, the Argus Skate (Dipturus polyommata), that has a female age-at-maturity of 5.1 years and maximum age of 10 years, resulting in a generation length of 7.6 years (Rigby et al. 2016).
threats:
The Endeavour Skate is taken as bycatch in trawl fisheries across its range and is discarded due to its small size and regulations preventing retention in Queensland. In Queensland, the Eastern King Prawn (Melicertus plebejus) sector (deep-water component) of the Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery operates on the outer continental shelf and upper slope to depths of 300–350 m off southern Queensland (Courtney et al. 2007). In surveys of the fishery on the outer continental shelf, the Endeavour Skate was the most common elasmobranch bycatch species comprising 36% of the elasmobranch catch by number (Kyne 2008, Kyne 2010). While the overall catch rate was low (0.029±0.007 individuals ha-1), at-vessel mortality was high (79% of individuals landed on deck were dead). It should be noted that these observations were made with fishery-independent sampling employing short trawl shots of about one hour trawl time, whereas regular commercial trawls last far longer (Kyne 2008). This fishery operates over much of the Queensland geographic range of the species but is highly seasonal, with the vast majority of effort generally occurring during the months of May to August. Outside these months, vessels fish in shallower waters where this species does not occur.

Similarly, in northern New South Wales, outer shelf depths (~100–200 m) are trawled only for a short season targeting Eastern King Prawns, and generally on fairly restricted fishing grounds (K. Graham pers. comm. 10 October 2010). Information on the bycatch of skates is lacking, but it is most probable that this species is a component of bycatch since its range overlaps with that of the fishery. Northern New South Wales receives little trawling effort in the extent of occurrence of this species on the upper continental slope (K. Graham pers. comm. 10 October 2010), and as such, it may have some refuge there at the deeper extent of its bathymetric range.
population: The Endeavour Skate was reported as common throughout its range (Last and Stevens 1994), but since 1994 there is no new information on its population trend. Trawl fisheries operate across its entire spatial range and depth range in Queensland, and most of its depth range in New South Wales. This species represents a high proportion of the elasmobranch bycatch, at least in Queensland, and though the overall catch rate was low, the at-vessel mortality was high. Both fisheries are seasonal and only fish for a few months of the year, providing significant temporal refuge for this species. An ecological risk assessment of the southern Queensland East Coast Otter Trawl Fishery assessed this species as at high risk based on its level of resilience to fisheries and the fishing pressure on the species (Jacobsen et al. 2018). Given its relatively restricted range and taking a precautionary approach, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (23 years) due to levels of exploitation.
range: The Endeavour Skate is endemic to eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific Ocean with a relatively restricted range from off Fraser Island, Queensland (25°27’S) south to near Crowdy Head, New South Wales (32°20’S) (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: This skate is not traded as it is too small to be of commercial value.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation actions are currently in place. Due to the species' small size, Turtle Exclusion Devices used in the Queensland trawl fishery are not effective at limiting catches (Kyne 2008, Campbell et al. 2020). Elasmobranchs taken as bycatch in the Queensland trawl fishery are prohibited from being retained. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Bight Skate (Dipturus gudgeri) is a large-bodied (to 184 cm total length) Australian endemic skate that occurs on muddy substrates in relatively deep waters at depths of 160-765 m (most commonly from 400-550 m) along the outer continental shelf and upper slope of southern Australia from New South Wales to Western Australia, including Tasmania. Fishery independent surveys on the upper continental slope trawling grounds off southern New South Wales have shown that catch rates have declined by 83% between 1976-77 and 1996-97 for grouped 'skates'. The Bight Skate was one of the dominant species in the catches at all three lower depth zones (330-605 m) in these surveys. This species is affected on the New South Wales trawl grounds (about a quarter of its range), but also occupies large areas of lightly trawled to non-fished grounds along the southern, southwestern and eastern coasts of Australia. Globally, it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting the criteria for Vulnerable A2bd+A4bd) on the basis of an overall population decline estimated to approach 30%, reflecting its wider distribution outside heavily fished areas off southeastern Australia. Catch levels and population trends should be closely monitored as this is a relatively large, late-maturing species that may be biologically susceptible to depletion.
habitat: The Bight Skate occurs on the outer continental shelf and upper slope on muddy substrates in relatively deep water of 160-765 m depth, but most commonly in depths of 400-550 m (Last and Stevens 2009). The species attains a maximum size of at least 184 cm total length (TL); males mature at about 120 cm TL; longevity is at least 16 years; male age at maturity is about 13 years (Treloar 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).
threats:
The Bight Skate is frequently caught on the Blue Grenadier (Macruronus novaezelandiae) grounds off Tasmania and western Victoria (Last and Stevens 2009). The species is particularly sensitive to drop lining and trawl fisheries in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery for target species such as Trevalla (Seriolella caerulea) and Blue Grenadier (P.R. Last, pers. comm. 2004). Annual catches were estimated at 88 tonnes between 2000 and 2006 (Walker and Gason 2007). 

Most skates caught off southeast Australia used to be discarded, but most of the larger ones would now be retained for the local market. More recently, increasing management of major commercial species has resulted in fishers looking for alternate species to market, including skates and rays.
population:
Fishery independent surveys on the upper continental slope trawling grounds off southern New South Wales have shown that catch rates have declined by 83% between 1976-77 and 1996-97 for grouped 'skates' (Graham et al. 1997, Graham et al. 2001). In 1996 to 1997 the survey was repeated in the same area and showed that numbers of all skate species had declined. Eight species of skates were recorded during this study, with data pooled into four depth zones. The principal species captured in the three deeper zones (330 to 605 m depth), on all trawl grounds were the Bight Skate and the Grey Skate (D. canutus). Catch data were pooled for all species. In 1976 to 1977, mean catch rates for skates were similar on all grounds (range 32 to 33 kg per hour) but were substantially lower in 1996 to 1997 (range 4-8 kg per hour) (Graham et al. 2001).

Observer data in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery showed an increasing catch-per-unit-effort from 2000 to a peak in 2004 before a decline thereafter until 2006 (Walker and Gason 2007). 

This species is commonly misidentified and incorrectly reported as the Longnose Skate (D. confusus) in fishery data, confounding attempts to calculate population trends.

Near-unexploited portions of the population exist in parts of the Great Australian Bight. The species may congregate but the extent of the distribution and therefore population is unknown (P.R. Last pers. comm. 2004).
range: The Bight Skate is endemic to southern Australia where it occurs from off Tweed Heads (New South Wales) to Geraldton (Western Australia), including Tasmania (Last and Stevens 2009).
useTrade: The species is retained for human consumption when taken as bycatch.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are currently in place. The species occurs in some marine protected areas of the Commonwealth Marine Reserve network. Collection of more reliable fishing data is recommended for this (and other) skate species. More population and distribution data is needed on this species. Improved catch data records are required throughout its distribution to better establish the status of the population. More detailed monitoring of the effects of fishing pressure and demand for skate wings is required.

rationale: The Bigeyed Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus nakamurai) is a medium-sized (to 177.8 cm total length) deep-water shark known from global yet patchy distribution in the Atlantic, including the Mediterranean Sea and Indo-Pacific Oceans (excluding the eastern Pacific Ocean). It occurs in tropical and warm temperate waters on the upper slope, shelf, and occasionally inshore at depths of 0–702 m. The species is infrequently caught incidentally in demersal industrial and artisanal  fisheries across its range, and may be more common than currently reported and misidentified with other hexanchid species. There is distributional overlap with fishing pressure, some refuge at depth, and a lack of species-specific management across its entire range. The Bigeyed Sixgill Shark is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (51 years) based on actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat:
The Bigeyed Sixgill Shark is demersal in warm temperate and tropical waters on shelves and upper slopes, and occasionally inshore at depths of 0–702 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 177.8 cm total length (TL); males mature at ~123–157 cm TL and females mature at ~142 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with litter sizes of 13–26 and size-at-birth is ~40–43 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Recent taxonomic revision and the resurrection of the Atlantic Sixgill Shark (H. vitulus, Daly-Engel et al. 2019) means that some of this information may be attributed to the Atlantic Sixgill Shark.

Maximum age and age-at-maturity are unknown; maximum age is inferred from a congener, the Bluntnose Sixgill Shark (H. griseus), with female age-at-maturity is estimated at 26.5 years and a maximum age of 80 years (COSEWIC 2007). This results in a generation length of 53 years. The Bluntnose Sixgill Shark is larger than Bigeyed Sixgill Shark (550 cm vs 180 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 17 years for Bigeyed Sixgill Shark.
threats: The Bigeyed Sixgill Shark is infrequently reported as incidental catch in demersal trawl, longline, and trotline fisheries (Megalofonou et al. 2005, Ebert et al. 2013, White and Dharmadi 2010, Uehara et al. 2019). In Indonesia, the species is landed in Tanjung Luar from demersal longlines operating at depths of 50–100 m across eastern Indonesia (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2019). Its congener, the Atlantic Sixgill Shark, has been one of the most reported deep-water sharks caught as bycatch in the Gulf of Mexico in demersal longline fisheries (Gulak and Carlson 2013). It is possible the Bigeyed Sixgill Shark may be more common than currently known and misidentified with other hexanchids.
population:
Species-specific population trends are not available and the Bigeyed Sixgill Shark is infrequently reported across much of its range including the Mediterranean (Ferretti et al. 2005), Indian Ocean (Georgeson et al. 2019), Indonesia (Blaber et al. 2009, White and Dharmadi 2010), and southeast Australia (Graham et al. 2001, Walker and Gason 2007). The species is widely distributed and likely has some refuge at depth in parts of its range.

In the Mediterranean Sea, large declines (>90%) or the altogether disappearance of other slope species have been documented across the region between 1940/50s–1990s (Aldebert 1997, Maynou et al. 2011). In the Tyrrhenian Sea, another hexanchid, the Sharpnose Sevengill Shark (Heptranchias perlo) disappeared from catches of coastal and deeper waters (Ferretti et al. 2005). The Bigeyed Sixgill Shark would likely be subject to the same fishing threat, given its spatial and depth distribution and is suspected of similar declines.

Based on documented declines of other hexanchids in part of its range (Mediterranean), overlap with fishing pressure and refuge at depth, a global population reduction of 20–29% was suspected over three generation lengths (51 years). Therefore, the Bigeyed Sixgill Shark is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Bigeyed Sixgill Shark has a global, yet patchy, distribution in the Atlantic, including the Mediterranean Sea, and Indo-Pacific Oceans (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The species is utilised for its fins, meat, and liver oil, but due to the species small size relative to other hexanchids, its products are considered of low quality (Dharmadi, unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Bigeyed Sixgill Shark. Further information is required on the biology, population size and trends of the species, as well as interactions with fisheries.

rationale:
The Purple Eagle Ray (Myliobatis hamlyni) previously was considered to be an eastern Australian endemic species, but a recent taxonomic study revealed that it is more widespread, occurring also in Indonesia, the Philippines, Taiwan, southern Japan and Western Australia.

The Purple Eagle Ray attains at least 114 cm disc width. It occurs on a narrow band of the outer continental shelf and upper continental slope at depths of 117-330 m (based on Australian records). The deeper water nature of this species is unique amongst Myliobatis species, which are generally inshore species. The small number of records of this species throughout much of its range suggests that this is a naturally rare species (or not regularly exposed to fishing gear).

Fishing pressure is high in some areas of its range, e.g. eastern Australia, and Taiwan (possibly also the Philippines), but overall the level of exploitation is not thought to be excessive throughout its known range. However, given that this species is likely naturally rare, its common occurrence in Taiwanese trawl landings may suggest that the catch of this species is unsustainable in this country and this requires investigation. The Purple Eagle Ray is assessed as Near Threatened globally based on an inferred population reduction of <30% over the last 47 years (three generations) due to locally high mortality for a naturally rare species in Taiwan and eastern Australia, nested within a larger geographic range where there are lower levels of mortality.
habitat: The Purple Eagle Ray is benthic on the outer continental shelf and upper slope, recorded from depths of 117-330 m in Australian waters (museum records and K. Graham, pers. comm., 2006) with information on depth ranges lacking from outside of Australia. This species attains at least 114 cm disc width (DW) (White et al. 2015). Two males of 48 cm DW were adolescent, and males between 56 and 80 cm DW were mature (White et al. 2015). Female size at maturity, size at birth and litter size unknown.
threats:
The Purple Eagle Ray is considered to be a naturally rare species (as indicated by the low catches throughout most of its range), and despite many decades of survey work along the east coast of Australia, it is rarely observed there. The Cape Moreton area (where the holotype is from) receives relatively significant levels of trawling for eastern king prawn by the Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery (ECTF). The Swain Reefs (Coral Sea) specimen was collected from champagne lobster trawl bycatch; this area is subject to only low fishing pressure. Its area of occurrence off New South Wales has been subject to heavy trawling activity for a considerable number of years (Graham et al. 2001). Fishing pressure is very low at the locations and habitat where the Purple Eagle Ray has been recorded from in Western Australia (Marton and Mazur 2014a, 2014b).

In Indonesia, the distribution of this species is mainly on the the outer shelf or upper slope (based on species composition of catches). No trawling occurs at those depths in these areas so although fishing pressure is very high in Indonesia in general, fishing pressure specifically on the Purple Eagle Ray appears to be relatively low. In the Philippines, seven juvenile and adult specimens were recorded from several fish markets in 1999 and 2000 (Compagno et al. 2005), but information on the fishing gear, habitats fished and ongoing threats in not known. In Taiwan, there is intensive trawling on the outer shelf and upper slope which represents a threat to this species in those waters and it is regularly seen in the landings (Ebert et al. 2013).
population:
There is no information on the population size of the Purple Eagle Ray, but it has a patchy distribution and appears to be naturally rare where it occurs. It has a deeper water habit compared to its congeners and there are no records of it forming aggregations as in some other species of eagle rays.

Given the historical high levels of fishing on the New South Wales outer shelf and upper slope and off southern Queensland, it is possible that this species was affected early on by fishing activities and now we are seeing only a depleted population in eastern Australia. However, this is speculation and given it appears to be rare throughout its patchy distribution, it is more likely that it is just a naturally rare species. Of 13 specimens taken by the New South Wales  Fisheries research vessel Kapala, nine were collected at the beginning of surveying (1976 to 1979) while four were collected in the later years of surveying (up until 1997) (K. Graham, pers. comm., 2006).
range: The Purple Eagle Ray has a patchy distribution in the East Indo-West Pacific (White et al. 2015). In Australia, the Purple Eagle Ray is known from patchy records. Off eastern Australia, it has been recorded from Swain Reefs and the type locality, Cape Moreton, in Queensland, and off Swansea and Coffs Harbour in New South Wales. Off Western Australia, it has been recorded off Forestier Island and Shark Bay. In Indonesia, it has been recorded in the landings at the Tanjung Luar fishing port in eastern Lombok and the Kedonganan fish market in southern Bali. The capture locations for these records is in local waters close to the respective landing sites. In the Philippines, it has been recorded from the Pasil fish market in Cebu City and Palapala fishing port in Cadiz City (Compagno et al. 2005). Recorded in the South China Sea by Randall and Lim (2000), but specimens are needed to confirm their identity. It has been recorded from the Da-xi (=Tashi) fish market in Yilan, Taiwan, and a single Purple Eagle Ray specimen was taken from off Okinawa, Japan. Records from Ryukyu Islands and Okinawa Trough (Okamura and Kitajima 1984, Yano 1999) possibly refer to this species but this requires verification. Specimens recorded off the Tokyo Submarine Canyon by Obara et al. (2009), as Myliobatis sp., between 150 and 500 m depth may also refer to this species, but this needs to be confirmed.
useTrade: Landed in Asia and utilized for its meat.
conservationActions: Throughout the range of the Purple Eagle Rays, more information is required on this species  to obtain more detailed information on its exploitation, habitat use and  distribution. Due to the low number of records of the Purple Eagle Ray in Australian waters, any captures of this rare species should be documented. Education for safe release of the species after recording of basic information (location, depth, size, sex, maturity) should be considered due to its naturally low abundance. The use of turtle exclusion devices in the Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery may assist in limiting catches in that part of the species' range.

rationale:
The Plain Maskray (Neotrygon annotata) is found in northern Australia from the Gulf of Carpentaria through to Western Australia, and in the Gulf of Papua (New Guinea). Its occurrence in the Torres Strait has yet to be confirmed and further investigations are required into the presence of this species in Indonesian waters. It has a limited depth range on the continental shelf of Australia (12-62 m) and is more prominent in deeper waters.

This maskray is a small batoid (attains 45 cm disc width) with a low fecundity (1-3 pups per litter). The Plain Maskray is considered to be a less abundant species when compared to the Bluespotted Maskray (N. kuhlii species-complex) and the Peppered Maskray (N. picta). Its centre of abundance is the Northwest Shelf off Western Australia, which is an area that has historically been under intensive fishing pressure, particularly from foreign demersal trawlers operating in the area from 1959 until the early 1990s. These activities more than likely had a detrimental effect on regional benthic batoid populations, although no data exist to substantiate this claim. Animals captured during a trawl event are susceptible to injury (internal and external) and post-release survival rates for this species are expected to be low.

The species continues to be caught as bycatch in Australian demersal trawl fisheries (particularly for prawns) and more information is required on current catch and mortality rates. Additional information is also required on the catch of this species in New Guinea and the effect of commercial fisheries there. This is considered to be of particular importance given that this species has a small distribution when compared to other batoids. Given this batoid's low fecundity, small depth and geographic range, and historical and current (mostly unmonitored) fishing pressures, the Plain Maskray is assessed as Near Threatened (suspected to be close to meeting the 30% threshold for Vulnerable A2d). Any increase in fishing pressure in the region could further affect the species and this situation should be monitored.
habitat:
The Plain Maskray inhabits continental shelf waters between 12 and 62 m (Last and Stevens 2009), although the species is more prominent in deeper water environments. While the species can reach up to 45 cm disc width (DW), it is more commonly encountered at smaller sizes. It is typically found in environments with sandy or soft substrates (Jacobsen and Bennett 2012).

This species likely has an annual reproductive cycle (Jacobsen 2007), producing 1-3 embryos (Jacobsen and Bennett 2010). Size at birth is 12-14 cm DW (Last and Stevens 2009) with the smallest recorded free-living animal measured at 13.7 cm DW (Jacobsen and Bennett 2010). Age and size at 50% maturity is estimated to be four years and 20.4 cm DW in males and 3-4 years and 19.1 cm DW for females (Jacobson and Bennett 2010). Size at first sexual maturity is 19.2 cm DW in males and 18.4 cm DW in females (Jacobsen and Bennett 2010). Males are estimated to live to at least 9 years and females to at least 13 years, both with an estimated maximum size of 45.2 cm DW (Stobutzki et al. 2002). Generation length is calculated as 8.5 years based on the above female age at maturity and maximum age figures.
threats:
The geographic range of the Plain Maskray incorporates areas that have a long history of demersal trawl fishing activities. For example, the Northwest Shelf and the Timor Sea (centre of abundance of this species) has been the focus of demersal trawl fisheries since 1959 which on occasion included Japanese, Taiwanese and Chinese fishing fleets. The Northwest Shelf in particular has been the subject of intensive trawl fishing activities, namely from Taiwanese pair trawlers that operated in the area from the 1970s until the early 1990s. While no data on batoid catch and mortality rates is available for this period, it is highly likely these fishing activities had a negative effect on regional portions of the Plain Maskray population.

With regards to the capture of this species, the bottom-dwelling nature of the Plain Maskray (as with a number of batoids) makes it highly susceptible to demersal trawl fishing activities. Furthermore, the Plain Maskray is a relatively small species whose body frame is less robust when compared to the Bluespotted Maskray species-complex. As a consequence, the effectiveness of bycatch reduction devices including turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) will be limited as this species can pass more easily through the bars of a TED and into the codend of a trawl net. Once captured within the net the species will be at risk of incurring both internal and external injuries during the trawl event and during the net recovery phase. Given this, post-release survival rates for this species are expected to be low.

The geographic distribution of the Brown Stingray overlaps with a large proportion of the Northern Prawn Fishery (NPF) where it is caught and subsequently discarded as bycatch. Bycatch estimates for the fishery (Salini et al. 2007, Tonks et al. 2007) identified the Plain Maskray as the most abundant species of elasmobranch caught in the western region of the NPF (Joseph Bonaparte Gulf) where it comprised between 40% and 67% of the total elasmobranch catch. At a whole-of fishery level, NPF effort is focused principally on areas of the Gulf of Carpentaria, the northern coasts of Bathurst Island/Tiwi Islands (Northern Territory) and the Joseph Bonaparte Gulf. Of which, the western region of the Gulf of Carpentaria has the highest concentration of effort (Larcombe and Skirton 2014).

In addition to the above, the Plain Maskray would more than likely interact with the 'Demersal Fishery' in northern Australia; a multi-faceted commercial fishery that incorporates a range of fishing methods such as traps, lines and finfish trawl. Of these apparatuses used, the Plain Maskray would most likely interact with the finfish trawl fishery. This component of the fishery has eight licenses and effort is restricted to two defined areas; a relatively small area southwest of Bathurst Island (Northern Territory) and a larger area starting east of Darwin and extending southeast into the Gulf of Carpentaria. When compared, effort in the demersal finfish trawl fishery (980 boat days) is much smaller than the NPF suggesting the effect of this fishery on the Plain Maskray population is less. Despite this, the cumulative impact of these fisheries (NPF and the finfish trawl fishery) in the western Gulf of Carpentaria may be a factor of regional significance. However, this risk will be difficult to quantify as there is limited information on elasmobranch bycatch compositions and distributions in the demersal finfish trawl fishery.

Further west, there is potential for the Plain Maskray to be caught in the North Coast Prawn Fisheries and the Pilbara Fish Trawl Fishery which operates in the southwest margins of this species' known distribution. Again, there is limited information on elasmobranch bycatch in these (comparatively small) fisheries with the Plain Maskray yet to be reported from bycatch surveys in the area (Western Australian Government 2010). The effect of these fisheries is anticipated to be less than the NPF.

Outside of Australia, a prawn trawl fishery consisting of about nine vessels operates in the Gulf of Papua in southern Papua New Guinea. The Plain Maskray is caught in low numbers as bycatch in this fishery (W. White, pers. comm., 2015).
population: Currently there is no information available on population size or trend. However population reduction is suspected to have occurred over the last three generations (see the Rationale section for more details).
range:
The Plain Maskray is found in Australia and Papua New Guinea including the Arafura Sea and Timor Sea. The Australian distribution extends from the Gulf of Carpentaria (Queensland) through the Northern Territory to at least the Bonaparte Archipelago, Western Australia (Last and Stevens 2009). Specimens from New Guinea have also been reported from bycatch surveys in the Gulf of Papua (W. White, pers. comm. 2015). This species has yet to be recorded in the Torres Strait (Pitcher et al. 2007, Jacobsen and Bennett 2010), although the presence of this maskray in the Gulf of Carpentaria and the Gulf of Papua suggests it may inhabit these areas, albeit more sparingly. While a single Plain Maskray specimen was observed in East Java (Indonesia), the original catch location was not known (W. White, pers. comm., 2015). As such, further investigations are required into the presence of this species in Indonesia.

When compared to other maskray species, the distribution of this maskray overlaps with the Bluespotted Maskray (N. kuhlii species-complex), the Painted Maskray (N. leylandi) and the Peppered Maskray (N. picta). There appears to be no obvious depth partitioning between these species, although the Plain Maskray is rarely taken in the coastal zone and generally occurs further offshore. The extent of any overlap between the distributions of the Plain Maskray and the Ningaloo Maskray (N. ningalooensis) is currently unknown and requires further investigation.
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for the Plain Maskray. The species will derive some benefit from broader management initiatives including fisheries-based spatial and temporal closures and the use of bycatch reduction devices. However, research has shown that bycatch reduction devices including turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) are less effective for smaller species (Griffiths et al. 2006). Furthermore, the effectiveness of fisheries closures (spatial and temporal) will be dependent on their location and the proportion of the Plain Maskray population protected from fishing effort. However, this cannot be quantified from the data currently available.

The Gulf of Papua trawl the fishery is managed under national laws and regulations (PNG), and there are some seasonal closures in place; although bycatch reduction devices are not currently in place, there are plans to implement in the near future (L. Baje, National Fisheries Authority, pers. comm. 2015). Detailed species composition data for the bycatch is not currently available, but this is currently being investigated (L. Baje, National Fisheries Authority, pers. comm. 2015).

rationale:
The Prickly Dogfish (Oxynotus bruniensis) is a small-sized deepwater shark (up to 76 cm total length), known from Australia and New Zealand in the Southwest Pacific and Eastern Indian. It has been recorded on the upper continental slope and plateaus at depths of 45-1,067 m, but most commonly at 300-650 m.

The Prickly Dogfish is taken incidentally in deepwater benthic trawl fisheries and its core depth range overlaps with fisheries operating throughout much of its range. There are well documented collapses of upper slope deepwater sharks off southeastern Australia, with a high likelihood that the Prickly Dogfish has declined due to long histories of trawling where it occurs. This species is susceptible to capture, and mortality of discards is unknown but are considered high. Oxynotus spp are highly susceptible to population decline from fishing, and populations of other species in the Mediterranean and Northeast Atlantic have declined by an estimated 80% over three generations, or disappeared altogether, in areas with high fishing effort. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Prickly Dogfish, and it is unknown what effect, if any, current fisheries and closed area management strategies have for this species.

Based on its low productivity, susceptibility to capture, high fishing overlap through much of its range with documented upper slope shark declines in some areas, a population decline of 20-30% is inferred over the last three generations (60 years) based on actual levels of exploitation. The Prickly Dogfish is therefore listed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Prickly Dogfish has been recorded on the upper continental slope and plateaus at depths of 45-1,067 m, but most commonly occurs at 300-650 m (Francis 2003, Last and Stevens 2009). It reaches a maximum size of ~76 cm total length (TL); males mature at ~55 cm TL; females mature at 64 cm TL; size at birth 25-27 cm TL (Finucci et al. 2016). Reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous and is likely asynchronous; litter size is eight, but annual fecundity is unknown (Finucci et al. 2016). Productivity is assumed to be low (Walker et al. 2008, Finucci et al. 2016), and like other Oxynotus spp, the generation length is estimated to be 20 years (Soldo and Guallart 2015).
threats:
The Prickly Dogfish is taken incidentally in deepwater benthic trawl fisheries in both Australia (Walker and Gason 2007) and New Zealand (Francis 2015). In Australia, this species is recorded from the Great Australian Bight Trawl Fishery (GABTF) and South East Trawl Fishery (SETF) (Walker and Gason 2007), which were amalgamated into the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark fishery (SESSF) in 2003. In volume, the SESSF is the largest Commonwealth fishery, and fishing overlaps heavily with the depth range of Prickly Dogfish (Georgeson et al. 2015). Its unique body morphology may increase its susceptibility to capture (Finucci et al. 2016, Soldo and Guallart 2016), and while mortality from capture is unknown, it is considered high (Walker and Gason 2007).

Most records of Prickly Dogfish in New Zealand are from Chatham Rise (Francis 2003), an area of major commercial importance (O’Driscoll et al. 2011). From 1989/90 to 2010/11, approximately 85% of trawl effort within New Zealand waters occurred at depths of 0-800 m (Black and Tilney 2015), which overlaps with the core depth range of Prickly Dogfish in New Zealand waters. It was estimated that this species is susceptible to fishing across 45-60% of its New Zealand range most of the year (Ford et al. 2015).

The Prickly Dogfish has a highly specialized diet of chondrichthyan eggs, and modification of the habitat of its prey species by deepwater fishing or mining may heighten its threat level (Leduc et al. 2015, Finucci et al. 2016). A qualitative risk assessment for New Zealand's chondrichthyans ranked this species at moderate risk (Ford et al. 2015), and a semi-quantitative risk assessment for chondrichthyan bycatch species taken in the Australian SESSF ranked this species with moderate risk from commercial fishing (Walker et al. 2008).
population:
Accurate population size and trends are unknown for this species. In New Zealand, Prickly Dogfish is considered to have a moderate population size (Ford et al. 2015). Biomass estimates from trawl survey indices in New Zealand are poorly estimated, show no clear trends, and catch rates are low (O'Driscoll et al. 2011, Bagley et al. 2013). In Australia, this species is considered to be of moderate relative abundance (Walker et al. 2008). However, catch rates of this species have been, and continued to be, low despite complete depth distribution overlap with the main trawl grounds of the Commonwealth Trawl Sector (CTS) of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) (K. Graham, pers. comm., Knuckey et al. 2015). Biomass data from fisheries-independent surveys in the SESSF indicate that only a few individuals are caught in each survey, and these cannot be used to show any trends (data provided by Australian Fisheries Management Authority 18/08/2017). Over a 20 year period (1976/77-1996/97), substantial declines (in some cases >90%) of relative abundance of deepwater chondrichthyans on the upper slope of southeast Australia have been previously reported (Graham et al. 2001). Species-specific trends for Prickly Dogfish during this time are not available, but it is inferred that this species has declined off southeast Australia.

Oxynotus spp are highly susceptible to population decline from fishing, and populations in the Mediterranean and Northeast Atlantic have declined by an estimated 80% over three generations (60 years), or disappeared altogether, in areas with high fishing effort (Soldo and Guallart 2015, Soldo and Guallart 2016). With the core depth distribution of Prickly Dogfish subject to trawling across most of its range, the extent of decline is inferred to be 20-30% over the last three generations (60 years) based on actual levels of exploitation, and documented declines in a variety of upper slope species.
range: The Prickly Dogfish is known from southern Australia and New Zealand waters in the Southwest Pacific and Eastern Indian. In Australia, it has been recorded from Newcastle in New South Wales to the western Great Australian Bight (Last and Stevens 2009). In New Zealand, it is widespread throughout mainland New Zealand and Stewart Island-Snares Island Shelf, Chatham Rise, Challenger Plateau, and Campbell Plateau (Roberts et al. 2015). One specimen was filmed from the summit of the Rumble V Submarine Volcano, southern Kermadec Ridge (Gordon 2013).
useTrade: This species is not likely to be utilized, and has historically been discarded (Walker and Gason 2007, Ministry of Fisheries 2008).
conservationActions:
Further information is required on the life history, population, and fisheries interactions of Prickly Dogfish. Although no species-specific management is in place, some management arrangements in New Zealand and Australia are relevant to this species.

New Zealand has had a Quota Management System (QMS) in place since 1986 to provide for the sustainable management of its fisheries. Prickly Dogfish is a non-QMS species, meaning that there is no species-specific management in place for the species (MPI 2013). New Zealand has a system of Benthic Protected Areas (BPAs), however they are unlikely to provide any major refuge for this species given the spatial occurrence of the BPAs (see Black and Tilney 2015). This species has been recorded from the Kermadec Ridge where no benthic trawling occurs (Ford et al. 2015).

In Australia, trawling closures in most of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) waters deeper than 700 m since 2005 (Patterson et al. 2016) may indirectly offer this species some refuge in this region. However, this is beyond the core depth range of the species. The species may also receive some refuge in closed areas of the Australian Commonwealth Marine Reserve network.

rationale: Edmunds' Spurdog (Squalus edmundsi) is a small-sized shark (to 115 cm total length) known from Western Australia and eastern Indonesia in the Eastern Indian Ocean. It has been recorded on the upper continental slope at depths of 204-850 m (mostly 300-500 m). In Australia, there is minimal deepwater fishing across the distribution of Edmunds' Spurdog, however, the species is captured in relatively large numbers by demersal longline fisheries in Indonesia. These fisheries operate throughout the depth range at which this species is most common and fishing pressure is only likely to increase and expand into deeper waters in the future. Catch landings at one site have indicated that the regional population is being over-fished and there is some anecdotal evidence to suggest squaloid shark catches have already declined rapidly over a 10 year period elsewhere in Indonesia. Given its low productivity (litter size of 5-6 pups) and documented declines of squaloid sharks in part of its range, it is suspected that a population reduction of 20-30% has occurred over the last three generations (66 years) due to actual levels of exploitation in Indonesia. A further population reduction is suspected over the future three generation lengths (2018-2084) based on current levels of exploitation and a lack of species-specific management in Indonesia. As such, the species is assessed listed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d+3d).
habitat: Edmunds' Spurdog has been recorded on the upper continental slope at depths of 204-850 m (mostly 300-500 m) (Last et al. 2007). The species attains at least 115 cm total length (TL); male maturity has been reported at 54 cm TL from Australia (Last et al. 2007), and 49-64 cm TL from Indonesia (White and Dharmadi 2010, Fahmi and Sentosa 2017); females mature at ~73 cm TL; size at birth is ~22-23 cm TL (White and Dharmadi 2010). This species is lecithotrophic viviparous with asynchronous reproduction and litters of 5-6 pups (White and Dharmadi 2010). Age data are not available for this species, but data from the Piked Spurdog (Squalus megalops) from Rigby et al. (2016) can be used to estimate a generation length of 22 years.
threats:
The Australian distribution of the species falls within the fishing grounds of the Commonwealth-managed North West Slope Trawl Fishery and Western Deepwater Trawl Fishery. However, fishing effort is low with only a limited number of active vessels (Patterson et al. 2017). Although details on bycatch are currently unavailable, these fisheries are unlikely to be impacting upon the population. 

In eastern Indonesia, the expansion of deepwater fisheries in the region is underway, and squaloid sharks (Squalus spp.) are some of the most commonly caught deepwater sharks (Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). Edmund's Spurdog is caught in large numbers by deepwater demersal longline fisheries in Indonesia (White et al. 2006b, White and Dharmadi 2010, Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). Indonesian deepwater fisheries operate throughout most of the depth range at which this species occurs (White et al. 2006b).
