Species-specific catch data in Indonesian fisheries are unavailable as all squaloid sharks are currently recorded together (Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). Thus, the degree of fishing pressure on Edmund's Spurdog cannot be determined at this time.
population: The population size of Edmunds' Spurdog is unknown, however, there are some information upon which population trends can be inferred. Catch landings at Tanjung Luar have indicated that catch rates are exceeding the maximum exploitation level, suggesting the regional population is being over-fished (Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). Elsewhere in Indonesia, there is some anecdotal evidence to suggest squaloid shark catches have already declined rapidly over a 10 year period at one landing site (Cilacap, Java), despite it being only a relatively restricted fishery (White et al. 2006a). It is suspected that Edmunds' Spurdog has been subject to population decline in part of its range (Indonesia) over the past three generations (66 years), equating to a global population decline of 20-30% (since declines are not suspected for its range in Australia). With no current management action in place, it suspected that these declines will continue in the future over the next three generations (2018-2084).
range: Edmunds' Spurdog is known from the Eastern Indian Ocean, where it has been recorded off Western Australia (Fremantle to Rowley Shoals) and eastern Indonesia (Kedonganan, Bali and Tanjung Luar, Lombok) (Last et al. 2007). The species may also be present off Papua New Guinea (White et al. 2017).
useTrade: In Indonesia, the species is utilized for its meat, fins, and high value liver oil (White et al. 2006b, Fahmi and Sentosa 2017).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place for Edmunds' Spurdog. In Australia, the North Coast Bioregion and North-West Marine Parks Network includes several marine reserves and marine management areas which are closed to trawling (Fletcher et al. 2017), and may indirectly provide some refuge in this region. Further information is required on the life history, population size, and trends of Edmunds' Spurdog, as well as interactions with fisheries.

rationale: The Eastern Longnose Spurdog (Squalus grahami) is a small-sized shark (to 73 cm total length) endemic to eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific, where it occurs off New South Wales and Queensland. It has been recorded on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 148-504 m. Over a 20 year period to 1996/97, population declines of up to ~97% were documented for dogfishes off New South Wales, including the Eastern Longnose Spurdog. Almost all trawlable ground on the continental slope off central and southern New South Wales is regularly fished by multigear and multispecies fisheries. However, this area represents ~20% of the known range of the Eastern Longnose Spurdog, with the remainder of the range to the north where fishing effort is currently minimal. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for the species, but management strategies for other upper slope dogfish in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery may indirectly offer some protection in the region. Based on documented declines and actual levels of exploitation, it is estimated and suspected that the species has been subject to ~20% population reduction over the last three generations (66 years). Thus, the species is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Eastern Longnose Spurdog has been recorded on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 148-504 m (mainly 220-450 m) (Last et al. 2007). The species attains at least 73 cm total length (TL); males mature at ~52 cm TL; females mature at ~63 cm TL; size at birth is ~22-23 cm TL (Graham 2005, Last et al. 2007). Litters of 1-5 pups have been recorded (Graham 2005). Age data are not available for this species, but data from the Piked Spurdog (Squalus megalops) from Rigby et al. (2016) can be used to estimate a generation length of 22 years.
threats: The Eastern Longnose Spurdog is caught incidentally in trawl fisheries (Graham et al. 2001), and has also been reported from experimental demersal longlines (McLean et al. 2015). Almost all trawlable ground on the upper continental slope off central and southern New South Wales is regularly fished by multigear and multispecies fisheries in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) (Patterson et al. 2017). The species is possibly taken as bycatch in the Queensland Deepwater Fin Fish Fishery that uses droplines and trotlines, where dogfishes have been recorded but not identified to species (Sumpton et al. 2013). In southern Queensland, a developmental deepwater trawl fishery at 250-800 m may take the Eastern Longnose Spurdog as bycatch (Department of Environment 2016). In northern Queensland and in the Commonwealth-managed Coral Sea Fishery, there is minimal deepwater trawling with no trawl operations reported in the Coral Sea Fishery since the 2006/07 fishing season (Patterson et al. 2017).
population:
Over a 20 year period (1976/77 to 1996/97), fisheries-independent surveys reported documented declines of ~97% of "greeneye dogsharks" (comprising the Shortspine Spurdog (Squalus mitsukurii), and the Eastern Longnose Spurdog between the Sydney (central New South Wales, NSW) and Eden-Gabo Island area (southern NSW/northern Victoria) (Graham et al. 2001). This area represents ~20% of the known range of the Eastern Longnose Spurdog. Based on actual levels of exploitation and documented declines, it is estimated and suspected that the species has been subject to ~20% population decline over the last three generations (66 years).

Total catches of "greeneye dogsharks" in these survey areas at depths of 220-605 m (much of the known depth range of the two species) declined from a mean of 44.8 kg/h in 1976/77 to a mean of 1.2 kg/h in 1996/97 (Graham et al. 2001). In 1976/77, the two species were caught in approximately equal numbers off Sydney and Ulladulla, thus, it is a fair assumption that the decline was roughly equal for both species in these areas. The 1976/77 Eden data suggested 75% or more of the "greeneye dogshark" catch in the southern area comprised of the Shortspine Spurdog and thus, a relatively small proportion of the Eastern Longnose Spurdog. However, in 1996/97, no Eastern Longnose Spurdog were caught off Eden-Gabo Island, suggesting that trawling to the north may have prevented recruitment of the species into southern NSW.
range: The Eastern Longnose Spurdog is endemic to eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific Ocean, where it has been recorded from off Bermagui (New South Wales) to Cape York (Queensland) (Last et al. 2007, Last and Stevens 2009).
useTrade: The species has historically been discarded due to its small size (Graham 2005).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place for the Eastern Longnose Spurdog. The species has been recorded within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Ceccarelli et al. 2014), which may indirectly provide some refuge in this region. The Upper-Slope Dogfish Management Strategy outlines a combination of management strategies for other dogfish species caught in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery, including a network of spatial closures, limited entry, gear restrictions, and regulated handling practices (AFMA 2012). These practices may also indirectly provide some benefit for the Eastern Longnose Spurdog. Further information is required on the life history of Eastern Longnose Spurdog, and interactions with fisheries should be monitored.

rationale: The Western Longnose Spurdog (Squalus nasutus) is a small-sized shark (to 64 cm total length) known from the Indo-West Pacific, where it has been recorded from Australia, Indonesia, the Philippines, and possibly the Solomon Islands. It occurs on the upper continental slope at depths of 300-850 m. Nothing is known about the species' population size or trends. There is minimal deepwater fishing in its Australian distribution. In eastern Indonesia, the Western Longnose Spurdog is infrequently recorded by demersal longline fisheries, however, the expansion of deepwater fisheries in this region is likely an ongoing and future threat to the species. Species-specific catch data in Indonesian fisheries are unavailable, and thus, the degree of fishing on the species cannot be determined at this time. Given anecdotal evidence of rapid declines of squaloid shark catches in Indonesia and uncertainty of the extent of threat, it is suspected that a population reduction of 20-30% has occurred over the last three generations (66 years) due to actual levels of exploitation in areas outside Australia. A further reduction is suspected over the future three generation lengths (2018-2084) based on current levels of exploitation and a lack of species-specific management in areas outside Australia. As such, the species is assessed listed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d+3d).
habitat: The Western Longnose Spurdog has been recorded on the upper continental slope at depths of 300-850 m (Last et al. 2007). The species attains at least 64 cm total length (TL); males mature at ~46 cm TL (White et al. 2006b). Nothing else is known of its biology, however, Squalus spp. are known for life histories resulting in low productivity. Age data are not available for this species, but data from the Piked Spurdog (Squalus megalops) from Rigby et al. (2016) can be used to estimate a generation length of 22 years.
threats: The Australian Commonwealth-managed Western Deepwater Trawl Fishery and North West Slope Trawl Fishery, which operate at depths >200 m, are unlikely to impact the Western Longnose Spurdog at this time as fishing effort is low with only a limited number of vessels (Patterson et al. 2017). In eastern Indonesia, the expansion of deepwater fisheries in the region is underway, and squaloid sharks (Squalus spp., including the Western Longnose Spurdog) are some of the most commonly caught deepwater sharks, predominately recorded by demersal longline fisheries (Blaber et al. 2009, Dharmadi et al. 2017, Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). Species-specific catch data in Indonesian fisheries are unavailable as all squaloid sharks are currently recorded together (Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). Thus, the degree of fishing pressure on the Western Longnose Spurdog cannot be determined at this time.
population: There is no species-specific information on population size or trends. In Indonesia, there is anecdotal evidence of rapid declines of squaloid shark catches over a 10 year period at one landing site (Cilicap, Java), despite it being only a relatively restricted fishery (White et al. 2006a). It is suspected that the Western Longnose Spurdog has been subject to population reduction in part of its range (Indonesia) over the past three generations (66 years), equating to a global population decline of 20-30% (since declines are not suspected for its Australian range). With no current management action in place, it is suspected that these declines will continue in the future over the next three generations (2018-2084).
range: The Western Longnose Spurdog is known from the Eastern Indian and Western Central Pacific Oceans, where it has been recorded from northwestern Australia (Rottnest Canyon to Rowley Shoals), Indonesia, the Philippines, and possibly the Solomon Islands (White et al. 2006b, Last et al. 2007, Hylton et al. 2017).
useTrade: In Indonesia, this species is utilized for its meat, fins, and its high value liver oil (White et al. 2006b).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place for the Western Longnose Spurdog. The Australian North Coast Bioregion and North-West Marine Parks Network includes several marine reserves and marine management areas which are closed to trawling (Fletcher et al. 2017), and may indirectly provide some refuge in this region. Further information is required on the life history, population size, and trends of the Western Longnose Spurdog, as well as interactions with fisheries, particularly in Indonesia.

rationale: The Common Stingaree (Trygonoptera testacea) is a small ray (to at least 52 cm total length) endemic to eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific Ocean. It has been recorded from the intertidal zone to depths of 135 m on the continental shelf, but is most common at <60 m depth. Stingarees have limited biological productivity (annual or biennial reproductive cycles with small litter sizes). Population size and trends are unknown, although this species is considered abundant. The Common Stingaree is a regular component of the bycatch of estuarine, inshore, and shelf trawl fisheries, as well as other fishing gear. It is generally discarded and post-release survivorship from trawling is low. Based on overlap with well-established trawl fisheries, significant catches, low post-release survivorship, and low biological productivity, it is suspected that the population has undergone a reduction of ~20–30% over the last three generations (30 years) and is therefore assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d). Reduced fishing effort in some parts of its range, and some shallow waters (<20 m) not subject to the trawl fisheries, may provide refuge and allow a reassessment of Least Concern in the future.
habitat: The Common Stingaree has been recorded from estuaries, sandy substrates, and reefs from the intertidal zone to the continental shelf at depths to 135 m, but is most common at depths of <60 m (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 52 cm total length (TL); male maturity is ~35 cm TL; female maturity is 40 cm TL; size at birth is ~12 cm TL; fecundity is low (1–2 pups/litter) (Last and Stevens 2009, Kyne et al. 2016). Age data are not available for this species, but data from the similar-sized Masked Stingaree (Trygonoptera personata) from White et al. (2002) can be used to estimate a generation length of 10 years.
threats:
Parts of the geographic and bathymetric range of the Common Stingaree are under relatively significant pressure from inshore trawling activities as well as other fishing gear. The Common Stingaree is a regular discarded bycatch of otter trawlers and Danish seiners in the southern part of its range in the Commonwealth-managed Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) (Walker and Gason 2007). In southern Queensland, the northern extent of the species' range, it is taken as bycatch in the Eastern King Prawn (EKP) sector of the Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery (ECTF). This is one of the most common elasmobranch bycatch species in this sector of the fishery and catch data indicates that the species aggregates with nursery areas overlapping with trawling grounds (Kyne et al. 2002, 2016, P. Kyne unpublished data). In New South Wales, the species is a bycatch of the Ocean Prawn Trawl Fishery, as well as in inshore and estuarine trawl fisheries, estuarine prawn seine fisheries, and beach seine fisheries (Gray et al. 1990, Gray and Kennelly 2003, Gray et al. 2003). Given its inshore occurrence, this species is occasionally taken by recreational beach anglers (P. Kyne pers. obs.).

Where the species is taken as bycatch, a concern is the demonstrated low post-release survivorship of trawl caught individuals (Campbell et al. 2018), and the fact that urolophids frequently abort pups upon capture and handling; even if gravid females survived capture, their reproductive output can be lost (White et al. 2001, Trinnie et al. 2009, Adams et al. 2018). 


The effects of inshore and coastal habitat degradation on this species are unknown but it may be less affected through habitat modification than other species (for example, the Estuary Stingray Hemitrygon fluviorum) as it is still common in relatively degraded areas (i.e., areas around Sydney).
population:
No data are available on population size and structure of the Common Stingaree, but this species is considered abundant across its range. Trend from standardized catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) from the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) between 2001 and 2006 was indeterminable (Walker and Gason 2007). Fishery-independent trawl surveys comparing chondrichthyan bycatch between 1976/77 and 1996/97 off the upper slope of New South Wales documented an overall decline in the catch rate of urolophids of ~66%, and up to ~90% on one survey ground (Graham et al. 2001). Although these surveys were deeper than the occurrence of the Common Stingaree, it demonstrates the susceptibility of stingarees to population reduction on eastern Australian trawl grounds. 

The species' distribution overlaps with significant trawl fisheries in both the south (Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery) and north (Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery) of its range, as as well as a variety of fisheries in between. There is a long history of trawling in these areas, with the Common Stingaree caught in significant numbers (Walker and Gason 2007, Kyne et al. 2002, 2016). Combining this with known high trawl-induced mortality (Campbell et al. 2018) and low biological productivity (1–2 pups/litter; reproductive cycle most likely to be annual based on other Trygonoptera species), it is suspected that the population has undergone a reduction of ~20–30% based on overlap with fishing over the last three generations (30 years). Reduced fishing effort in some parts of its range, and some shallow waters (<20 m) not subject to the trawl fisheries, may provide refuge and allow a reassessment of Least Concern in the future, if data can be collected to show a stable population.
range: The Common Stingaree is endemic to eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific Ocean where it is known from a restricted range from southern Queensland to Cape Howe, New South Wales (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized and is discarded when taken as bycatch in commercial fisheries (e.g. Gray and Kennelly 2003, Walker and Gason 2007).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Common Stingaree. State and Commonwealth marine protected areas may provide some refuge for this species. While Turtle Exclusion Devices are deployed on nets in the Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery, these are not effective at excluding stingarees due to their small size. Bycatch should be monitored and reduced in fisheries which interact with the species.

rationale: The Kapala Stingaree (Urolophus kapalensis) is a small-sized ray (to 52 cm total length) endemic to eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific Ocean. It has been recorded from the continental shelf at depths of 10-130 m. Stingarees have limited biological productivity (annual or biennial reproductive cycles with small litter sizes). A considerable proportion of the species' relatively restricted distribution overlaps with trawl fishing, both from Commonwealth and State-managed fisheries. Fishery-independent trawl surveys comparing chondrichthyan bycatch between 1976-77 and 1996-97 off the upper slope of New South Wales documented an overall decline in the catch rate of urolophids of ~66%, and up to ~90% on one survey ground. Although these surveys did not cover the depth range of the Kapala Stingaree, they demonstrate the susceptibility of stingarees to population decline where there is substantial overlap with fisheries. It is suspected that the Kapala Stingaree has exhibited some declines (20-30%) over the last three generations (30 years) based on actual levels of exploitation (bycatch) as several fisheries operate across its relatively restricted range, and the species is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Kapala Stingaree has been recorded from the continental shelf at depths of 10-130 m (Last and Stevens 2009). It reaches a maximum size of 52 cm total length (TL); male maturity is 31 cm TL; size at birth is ~15 cm TL; litter size is low (1 pup/litter) (Last and Stevens 2009, Kyne et al. 2016). Age data are not available for this species, but data from the similar-sized Masked Stingaree (Trygonoptera personata) from White et al. (2002) can be used to estimate a generation length of 10 years.
threats:
A considerable proportion of the species' relatively restricted distribution overlaps with trawl fishing. The Kapala Stingaree is infrequently caught as bycatch in the Commonwealth Trawl Sector of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) (Walker and Gason 2007). This species is of no commercial value and is discarded when caught (Walker and Gason 2007). 

It is a frequent bycatch in the Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery (ECTF; Eastern King Prawn Sector), where it is often caught in small aggregations. It is also taken in the New South Wales Ocean Prawn Trawl Fishery.

Where the species is taken as bycatch, a concern is the demonstrated low post-release survivorship of trawl caught stingarees (Campbell et al. 2018), and the fact that urolophids frequently abort pups upon capture and handling; even if gravid females survived capture, their reproductive output can be lost (White et al. 2001, Trinnie et al. 2009, Adams et al. 2018).
population: No data are available on population size, trends, and structure of the Kapala Stingaree. Fishery-independent trawl surveys comparing chondrichthyan bycatch between 1976-77 and 1996-97 off the upper slope of New South Wales documented an overall decline in the catch rate of urolophids of ~66%, and up to ~90% on one survey ground (Graham et al. 2001). Given this documented susceptibility to population decline from overfishing, it is suspected that the Kapala Stingaree has exhibited some declines (20-30%) over the last three generations (30 years) based on actual levels of exploitation (bycatch) as several fisheries operate across its range.
range: The Kapala Stingaree is endemic to eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific Ocean where it is known from Cape Moreton, Queensland to Disaster Bay, New South Wales (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized commercially, and is discarded when taken in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) off eastern Australia (Walker and Gason 2007).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Kapala Stingaree. State and Commonwealth marine protected areas may provide some refuge for this species. Further information is required on its distribution, ecology, and life history. Bycatch should be monitored and reduced in fisheries which interact with the species.

rationale: Caracanthus typicus is known only from the Hawaiian Islands, where it is found in association with coral reefs, especially Pocillopora meandrina. Its estimated area of occupancy is 2,095 km², based on the area of coral reef in the Hawaiian Islands, which is close to meeting the threshold for Vulnerable under criterion B2. Its coral reef habitat is experiencing local declines in coral cover due to overfishing, climate change, pollution and invasive species; it is therefore inferred that there is a continuing decline in habitat quality. Based on the primary threat of habitat degradation, it is assumed that there are 2-6 locations. Therefore, C. typicus is listed as Near Threatened.
habitat: Caracanthus typicus is a tropical, benthic, reef-associated fish typically found among the branches of the coral Pocillopora meandrina (Greenfield 2003, Mundy 2005).
threats: This species is associated with coral reefs, specifically found among the branches of the coral Pocillopora meandrina (e.g., Cole 2003, Greenfield 2003). Globally, coral reefs are in decline; local and global pressures, including overfishing, climate change, pollution, and coastal development are affecting more than 75% of reefs (Burke et al. 2011). More than 65% of the reefs in the Pacific Ocean were classified as threatened, with the highest concentrations of threatened reefs in Melanesia, Hawaii, Samoa and the Society Islands (Burke et al. 2011). Since 1999, no statistically significant trend in coral cover across the Main Hawaiian Islands could be detected, but local declines approaching 20% have occurred in some areas, most often in the central archipelago (Friedlander et al. 2008b, Rogers et al. 2015). Although a substantial portion of this species' distribution overlaps with the Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument, some areas within the national monument are experiencing bleaching events (e.g., Friedlander et al. 2008a) that are likely to negatively affect the habitat quality of this species.
population: There are 112 museum records for Caracanthus typicus in the Hawaiian Islands (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2015-04).
range: Caracanthus typicus has been recorded only from around the Hawaiian Islands, including Midway Atoll (Mundy 2005). The species has been recorded from about 0 m to 25 m (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2015-04). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,095 km², calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013. It is estimated that this species occupies 2-6 locations, based on the primary threat of coral habitat degradation caused by overfishing, climate change, pollution, and invasive species (e.g., Friedlander et al. 2008a,b; Burke et al. 2011; Rodgers et al. 2015).
useTrade: No use and trade information is available for Caracanthus typicus.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place. Based upon the distribution of C. typicus, this species does overlap with some marine protected areas in the Hawaiian Islands (Accessed from www.hawaiihumpbackwhale.noaa.gov, 2015-01-27).

rationale: Verified records of Sebastapistes coniorta are known only from the Hawaiian Islands and Johnston Atoll, where it is relatively common. It is found in association with coral reefs, especially Pocillopora meandrina. Its estimated area of occupancy is 2,170 km², based on the area of coral reef in the Hawaiian Islands and Johnston Atoll, which is close to meeting the threshold for Vulnerable under criterion B2. Its coral reef habitat is experiencing local declines in coral cover due to overfishing, climate change, pollution and invasive species; it is therefore inferred that there is a continuing decline in habitat quality. Based on the primary threat of habitat degradation, it is assumed that there are 2-6 locations. Therefore, S. coniorta is listed as Near Threatened. Efforts to verify records from the Line Islands, New Caledonia and Wake Atoll should be undertaken; if the range of this species is found to extend beyond the current known distribution, its conservation status may need to be re-evaluated.
habitat: This benthic species lives within the branches of corals, especially Pocillopora meandrina (Greenfield 2003, Mundy 2005). It feeds on crabs and shrimps, and can reach a maximum length of 10 cm total length (Randall 2007).
threats: Speckled Scorpionfish is associated with coral reefs, where it is specifically found among the branches of the coral Pocillopora meandrina (e.g., Greenfield 2003, Mundy 2005). Globally, coral reefs are in decline; local and global pressures, including overfishing, climate change, pollution, and coastal development are affecting more than 75% of reefs (Burke et al. 2011). More than 65% of the reefs in the Pacific Ocean were classified as threatened, with the highest concentrations of threatened reefs in Melanesia, Hawaii, Samoa and the Society Islands (Burke et al. 2011). Since 1999, no statistically significant trend in coral cover across the Main Hawaiian Islands could be detected, but local declines approaching 20% have occurred in some areas, most often in the central archipelago (Friedlander et al. 2008b, Rogers et al. 2015). Although a substantial portion of this species' distribution overlaps with the Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument, some areas within the national monument are experiencing bleaching events (e.g., Friedlander et al. 2008a) that are likely to negatively affect the habitat quality of this species.
population: This species is common (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015). There are 445 specimens of S. coniorta in museum collections (Accessed through Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 2015-01).
range: Sebastapistes coniorta is known only from the Hawaiian Islands and Johnston Atoll (Randall 2007). Records from the Line Islands, New Caledonia and Wake Atoll are likely based on misidentification and need verification (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015). The species has been collected from 1 to 33 m (Mundy 2005). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,170 km², calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013. It is estimated that this species occupies 2-6 locations, based on the primary threat of coral habitat degradation caused by overfishing, climate change, pollution and invasive species (e.g., Friedlander et al. 2008a,b; Burke et al. 2011; Rodgers et al. 2015).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures. The range of Sebastapistes coniorta may coincide with the marine protected areas of the Hawaiian Islands and Johnson Atoll (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC).

rationale:
This widely distributed species inhabits nearshore soft bottoms and can be especially common and abundant in estuaries. It is heavily exploited by trawl and other net fisheries in much of its range. It is considered over-fished in Pakistan, western India, Bangladesh and China and is fully exploited/in decline in at least part of Indonesia. It is likely also impacted by widespread degradation of estuaries. 
When calculated over a three generation period (10 years), data represent a decline in global landings of c.30%. Given that effort is either increasing or stable across much of the fished range, there is evidence of growth overfishing, and data shows severe historic declines, the actual decline in global population of this species highly likely to be close to Vulnerable thresholds under Criterion A2. This species is therefore assessed as Near Threatened. Improvements in fisheries management are needed to reduce fishing effort, especially increasing mesh size of trawl nets and protecting juveniles from capture.
habitat: This species inhabits nearshore muddy and sandy bottoms, and can form large shoals in estuaries. It migrates to offshore waters during winter months and returns to nearshore waters to spawn otherwise (Ghosh 2014). Its maximum total length is 40 cm, but typically occurs to 25 cm. Estimated natural mortality in Bangladesh is 1.86 (Sarker et al. 2017), 1.73 in Saurashtra, India (Ghosh et al. 2009) and 1.53 in West Bengal (Behera et al. 2016). Size at first maturity is 20.7 - 21.5 cm (Ghosh et al. 2009, Sharma 2014). This is a fast-growing, short-lived species with an age at first maturity of about 1 year and longevity of 3.5 to 5 years (Ghosh et al. 2009, Nugroho et al. 2015). When applying an age at first reproduction of 1 year and longevity of 5 years, its estimated generation length is 3 years based on the following equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: Age at first reproduction + (Age at last reproduction – age at first reproduction)/2.
threats: This species is overfished in several parts of its range, including Pakistan, western India, Bangladesh and China (Kalhoro et al. 2013, Sarker et al. 2017, Liang and Pauly 2017). It is also impacted by estuarine degradation (i.e., pollution and coastal development), which occurs throughout its range (Sun et al. 2015, Hasin 2016). It has been found with high concentrations of heavy metals in Digha, India (Kumar et al. 2012).
population:
This species can be common and abundant in estuaries through much of its range (Nugroho et al. 2015). Landings data for 'Bombay Duck' have been reported to the FAO by Malaysia, Bangladesh, Pakistan, India and Indonesia, with India reporting the large majority overall. From 1950-2016, landings have generally been on an increasing trend over the entire time period; however, landings declined by 24% in the most recent years available from 277,119 tons in 2013 to 211,004 t in 2016. Over the entire time series, landings reached a peak in 2008 at 280,396 t and declined over the three subsequent years until peaking again in 2013, which may indicate that landings fluctuate somewhat, but may continue on an overall increasing trend into the near future given that effort is also known to be increasing, or may maintain a declining trend as several stocks are now considered overfished. Landings from China are apparently reported to FAO lumped with other lizardfish species, which peaked in 1992 at 20,010 t and declined thereafter to 5,280 in 2016, which is a 74% decline over a 24-year period. 

Indian Ocean: In Pakistan, this species has been heavily exploited along the Sindh coast by commercial trawl fisheries since at least 1985, and since the 1960s by subsistence fishers (Krishnaya 1968). It is currently considered overfished in Pakistan, where from 1995-2009 (a 14-year period), catch peaked at 101 tons in 1996 and declined to 44 t in 2009, which represents a 56% decline. Catch per unit effort during that same time period declined by 65%, from 0.0091 in 1996 to 0.00.32 in 2009 (Kalhoro et al. 2013). This species can be common and abundant in the Sundarbans (Mukherjee et al. 2013), and is very important to fisheries along the northwest and northeast coasts of India. The stock on the west coast is thought to be separate from the east, where there are two stocks (Pazhayamadom et al. 2015). In 2013, overall catch of this species in India was 124,509 tons, which comprised 4-5% of the annual marine landings across the country (Behera et al. 2016). It has been exploited by commercial fisheries in the Saurashtra region of India since at least 1947 (Fernandez and Devaraj 1996), where it comprised 24% of total fisheries catches from 1980-1984 and 13% from 2002-2006 (Ghosh 2014). It is currently considered overfished in the Saurashtra region of India, where from 1997-2011 (a 15-year period), catch peaked at 78,000 tons in 1998 and declined to 25,000 t in 2009, which represents a 68% decline. Catch per unit effort during that same time period declined by 73%, from 45 kg/h-1 in 1997 to 12 kg/h-1 in 2009 (Ghosh et al. 2009, Mohammed Koya et al. 2017). Fishing effort in Saurashtra expanded to deeper waters over time as the inshore areas were overfished (Ghosh 2014). It is also considered overfished in the Kakdwip region of West Bengal (Behera et al. 2016). By comparison, the fishery for this species in east India developed later than that on the west coast, and catch has been increasing with effort from at least 1960 to 2006 with no indications of decline as of yet (Vivekanandan and Krishnakumar 2010). According to stock assessments, this species has been overfished in Bangladesh since at least the early 1990s (Mustafa et al. 1994, Islam 1995, Mustafa et al. 1998), or over about the past three decades (Sarker et al. 2017). The large quantities of juveniles captured in the fishery also contributes to overfishing (Sarker et al. 2017, Mohammed Koya et al. 2017). For example, in the Sunderbans, 59% of the catch of this species comprised immature individuals (Sharma 2014). Fishing effort has increased considerably in recent years (Hasin 2016). 

Western Pacific Ocean: Growth overfishing is also occurring for this species in China's coastal seas (Liang and Pauly 2017), where catches are now dominated by 0-1 year old fish (Chen et al. 2012). It is common and abundant off the coast of Zhejiang, China in the East China Sea (Shan et al. 2011, Sambou et al. 2016) and in the Pearl River Estuary of South China (Sun et al. 2015). Annual national catch of this species in Indonesia has been recorded since 1976, and catch peaked in 1983 at about 17,000 tons and declined thereafter by about 79% to 3,500 t in 2012, which is a period of 29 years (Nugroho et al. 2015). In North Kalimantan, Indonesia, this species has been heavily exploited since the 1990s, and there are anecdotal reports from the fishing industry that landings and body size of individuals in the catch has been declining since the early 2000s (Prasetyo et al. 2014). Currently, the stock is considered fully exploited in that area, and further increases in fishing effort would likely lead to overfishing (Nugroho et al. 2015).
When calculated over a three generation period (10 years), data represent a decline in global landings of c.30%. Given that effort is either increasing or stable across much of the fished range, there is evidence of growth overfishing, and data shows severe historic declines, the actual decline in global population of this species highly likely to be close to Vulnerable thresholds under Criterion A2.
range: This species is known from scattered localities in the Indo-Pacific from the Arabian Sea (Pakistan) to the Bay of Bengal to Indonesia, the South and East China Seas and the Yellow Sea. Its depth range is 0-70 m (Ghosh 2014, Mohammed Koya et al. 2017).
useTrade: This species is taken in commercial trawl, gill net and fixed net fisheries in Pakistan, India and Bangladesh and is a highly esteemed food fish there (Kalhoro et al. 2013, Sarker et al. 2017, Mohammed Koya et al. 2017, Bhakta et al. 2018). Catch from India is also exported in dried form (Hasin 2016). It is also taken in the commercial trawl fisheries that operate in the coastal areas of China (Liang and Pauly 2017). Subsistence and small-scale commercial trawl fisheries also exploit this species in Riau East Sumatra, East Kalimantan and West Papua, Indonesia (Nugroho et al. 2015). It is taken as bycatch in trawl fisheries off southwestern Taiwan, and its market value has been increasing there since 2007 (Liao et al. 2014).
conservationActions: No formal fishery management for this species is in place in Pakistan or India (Kalhoro et al. 2013, Pazhayamadom et al. 2014). Conservation actions are needed in Pakistan, India and Bangladesh to reduce fishing effort, including regulating fishing gear, prohibiting take during spawning season and protecting estuarine nursery grounds (Kalhoro et al. 2013, Sarker et al. 2017, Mohammed Koya et al. 2017). Improvements are also needed in fishery management in China and Indonesia, especially increasing the mesh size in fishing nets (Nugroho et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017).

rationale: This species is restricted to Clipperton Island reefs, and has an area of occupancy of less than 10 km². Regional experts support the plausible threat of the increased duration and frequency of ENSO events that can cause severe and rapid declines for restricted-range, shallow-water species in this region of the Eastern Tropical Pacific. Because it is found in deeper water and therefore is not expected to decline as quickly as more shallow-water species, it is listed as Near Threatened under criterion D2.
habitat: This species inhabits coral reefs and associated calcareous rock habitat (Allen 1991) to depths of 100 m. It is omnivorous, feeds on benthic microalgae, sessile crustacea and worms and mobile benthic crustacea.
threats:
In the Eastern Tropical Pacific, severe localized fish species declines have occurred after strong ENSO events that result in shallow waters that are too warm and nutrient poor for extended periods of time (Grove 1985, Edgar et al. 2009). The frequency and duration of ENSO events in this region of the Eastern Tropical Pacific (e.g. the up-welling zone off the coast of Peru, Ecuador, Colombia, Panama and the offshore islands) appears to be increasing (Glynn and Ault 2000, Soto 2001, Chen et al. 2004). Given this species’ restricted distribution and shallow water habitat, oceanographic environmental changes, such as those associated with future ENSO events, may have detrimental effects on the survival of this species.

However, this species is found in deeper waters and declines for this species may not be as severe as for other more shallow-water species.
population: According to Robertson and Allen (1996), this species was relatively commonly at the Clipperton Atoll.
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Pacific, and is only found in the Clipperton Atoll (to France) in association with its four km² area of reefs, and therefore has an estimated area of occupancy of less than 10 km².
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures known for this species.

rationale: This species is restricted to Clipperton Island reefs, and has an area of occupancy of less than 10 km². Regional experts support the plausible threat of the increased duration and frequency of ENSO events that can cause severe and rapid declines for restricted-range, shallow-water species in this region of the Eastern Tropical Pacific. Because it is found in deeper water and was observed to be common during at least one El Niño event, this species is listed as Near Threatened under criterion D2.
habitat: This is a reef-associated cryptic species that is found in coral reefs from 10-100 m depth. The diet consists of mobile benthic crustaceans and bony fishes.
threats:
In the Eastern Tropical Pacific, severe localized fish species declines have occurred after strong ENSO events that result in shallow waters that are too warm and nutrient poor for extended periods of time (Grove 1985, Edgar et al. 2009). The frequency and duration of ENSO events in this region of the Eastern Tropical Pacific (e.g. the up-welling zone off the coast of Peru, Ecuador, Colombia, Panama and the offshore islands) appears to be increasing (Glynn and Ault 2000, Soto 2001, Chen et al. 2004). Given this species' restricted distribution and shallow water habitat, oceanographic environmental changes, such as those associated with future ENSO events, may have detrimental effects on the survival of this species.

However, this species is found in deeper waters, and was observed to be common after at least one El Niño event in 1997-1998 (Robertson pers. comm.), so declines for this species may not be as severe as for other more shallow-water species.
population: There is no population information for this species. This species is common, but cryptic.
range: This species is endemic to Clipperton Island reefs (to France), and has an area of occupancy of less than 10 km².
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures for any species on Clipperton Island.

rationale:
Balistes vetula is widely distributed and inhabits a variety of habitats, including rocky bottoms, reefs, and shallow sandy or grassy areas. It is also an important commercial fish in Brazil with declines reported from 2001-2006. Due to similarities in size and habitat requirements, we infer B. vetula has similar life history characteristics as Balistes capriscus, therefore a generation length of 4-8 years was used for this assessment.

Population declines of up to 99% over about 20 years are reported in the Gulf of Guinea and up to 90% from 2001-2006 in parts of Brazil. We infer populations are also declining in West Africa and the Caribbean based on fisheries catches in those regions. Traditionally, the Queen Triggerfish has been underutilized by fisheries off the southeastern continental U.S.A., but it is more abundant in the Caribbean and comprises a considerable portion of reef fish landings in the U.S. Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. Since a large part of its range occurs off northeastern North America, where fishing pressure is suspected to be lower, we infer that global population declines are less than, but likely approaching, what was recently observed for B. capriscus (31-32% over three generation lengths). It is therefore assessed as Near Threatened as it nearly meets the 30% reduction threshold for the VU category under criterion A2bd.
habitat:
This species is found over rocky bottoms and is often associated with reefs. It is also found on shallow sandy or grassy areas (Randall 1967) to the upper slope of the deep reef (100 m) (Aiken 1975). It forms schools but may also be observed solitary over sandy and grassy habitats. The Queen Triggerfish is found in depths from 2-275 m, however it is more commonly seen at 10-98 feet (3-30 m). It displays marked movement from the shallows to deeper water with increasing size (Aiken 1975). Diadema antillarum has been reported to be the primary prey item for this species, after mass mortality of the sea urchin in the Caribbean, crabs and chitons were recorded to replace the sea urchin (Reinthal et al. 1984). Prey items include macroalgae, bivalves, crabs, starfish, sea cucumbers, shrimp, and polychaetes. Male Queen Triggerfish establish territories of approximately 10 m in diameter, attracting several females. Nests are built in the sand by moving fins rapidly or creating a current by blowing water with the mouth near the bottom to create sand bowls. The eggs are released into these bowls after a courtship ritual. The nest is defended by the mating pair, reproduction occurs year-round, peaking in the fall and again in the winter. In Jamaica, fishes with ripe gonads were reported in February and May (Munro et al. 1973). Ripe fishes were collected all through the year except in April and June. Maxima of spawning were found between January and February and the period August to October. Most of the species specimens were small maturing individuals, suggesting movement into deeper water in maturation (Aiken 1975). There is indirect evidence of this species forming spawning aggregations from the Netherlands Antilles, St. Croix, and Puerto Rico (Hughes et al. 2013).

The maximum length: 60.0 cm (TL), (Randall 1968); mean length at 1st maturity: 23-27 cm (FL) (Aiken 1975); maximum age: 7 years (Manooch and Drennon 1987); 16 years in Central Brazil (Albuquerque et al. 2011). In Jamaica (Aiken 1975) size at 1st maturity (males): 17.5 cm (FL); size at 1st maturity (females): 16.5 cm (FL); size at full recruitment: 23-24 cm (FL).

In Brazil, growth parameters: L∞ = 50.4 cm, K = 0.76 (1/year). The natural mortality coefficient (M) = 1.15, while the fishery mortality coefficient (F) =1.49. The exploitation rate estimated (0.56) for this study indicate that this species was under fishery pressure since the fishery exploitation coefficient was superior to what this population can stand, in spite of the fact that the growth parameters were bigger now than in previous studies done in the central region of Brazil (Freitas Netto and Madeira di Beneditto 2010). Maximum age determined by marginal increment analysis of dorsal spines off the Central Coast of Brazil was 16 years, with maximum fork length of 460 mm (Albuquerque et al. 2011).

The generation length for this species was based on that of Balistes capriscus, which was estimated at 4-8 years. Thus, the time window for calculating population declines is 12-24 years.
threats: The species is taken as bycatch in commercial long-line and vertical line fisheries in the Gulf of Mexico. There is evidence of population declines from fishing observed in Brazil (Freitas Netto and Madeira di Beneditto 2010). It has also been recorded in the diet of the invasive Lionfish, Pterois volitans (Bejarano et al. 2014).
population:
Gulf of Mexico
Relatively little species-specific quantitative population data in the Gulf of Mexico are available to us at this time. It is taken in small numbers as bycatch in the Gulf of Mexico Reef Fish Fishery; it most frequently is taken by long-line, but also by hand-line (Scott-Denton et al. 2011). In deep-reef surveys in the northwestern Gulf of Mexico, this species co-occurred with the commercially important B. capriscus (which was among the top 25 most abundant species) at deep reefs with live coral cover ranging in depths from 45-85 meters (Weaver et al. 2006). In the Campeche Bank, this species occurred in 3.3% of underwater visual censuses of reef areas (n=120: H. Pérez-España, unpublished data).

Southeast U.S.
Reef fish assemblage structure was assessed in 2006-2007 in Biscayne National Park, Florida, USA, and compared with data collected from 1977 to 1981. The percent frequency of occurrence from 1977 to 1981 was 3.5, while from 2006-2007 it was 0.0. This species is not targeted by fisheries in this region (Kellison et al. 2012).

Caribbean Sea
Traditionally, the Queen Triggerfish has been underutilized by fisheries off the southeastern continental U.S.A., but it is more abundant in the Caribbean and comprises a considerable portion of reef fish landings in the U.S. Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. Although the species is taken by both traps and hook and line, 95% of all Queen Triggerfish landings from the U.S.Virgin Islands in 1983-1984 were taken in traps. The Queen Triggerfish comprises ~ 22% by weight of the total trap catch of the Islands and 10-15% of the total landings (Manooch and Drennon 1987). Traps in algal plains in the U.S. Virgin Islands contained the most fish, and 50% of censused B. vetula (Garrison et al. 2004).

In Jamaica, the highest catch rate was at the Pedro Cays between 11 to 20 m depth where it comprised nearly 60% of the total catch by number and 52.41% by weight. In general, this species comprised, by both number and weight, the most abundant of all species caught in traps at all parts of Pedro Bank. A very rough estimate of numerical CPUE in unexploited areas averaged in terms of depth zones amounts to 2,900 fishes/1,000 hexagonal trap-nights. If natural mortality rate is 2.6, the mean recruitment index, R, for Pedro Bank is about 7,500 fish (Aiken 1975).

Commercial catches from the U.S. Virgin Islands ranged from approximately 90,000 to 130,000 lbs from 2000 to 2008. In Puerto Rico, commercial catches ranged from approximately 33,000 lbs to 122,000 lbs from 1988 to 2009, averaging 70,000 since 2000. It is taken as by-catch in commercial long-line and vertical line fisheries, and is a component of small-scale fisheries (Heyman et al. 2012). It is also harvested in recreational fisheries.

Brazil
In small villages of Brazil, parts of this fish are used in traditional medicine in the treatment of asthma, ear aches, and stroke victims. In Brazil, capture production for this species occurs in the states of Ceara and Espirito Santo, with the latter comprising the biggest national harvest at 4,225 tons/year. Fishery statistics report by IBAMA (Brazilian Environmental Agency) indicate a decrease in the national production between the years 2001 (7,774 tons/year) and 2006 (732 tons/year) (IBAMA 2006). Despite the decrease in landings, effort has increased by 25% in Espirito Santo and by 16.5% in Bahia State (Santos 2005). The exploitation rate estimated (0.56) for this study indicates that this species was under fishery pressure since the fishery exploitation coefficient was superior to what this population can stand, in spite of the fact that the growth parameters were bigger now than in previous studies done in the central region of Brazil (Freitas Netto and Madeira di Beneditto 2010).

Eastern Atlantic
Triggerfish catch drastically declined from 18,610 tonnes in 1986 to two tonnes in 1995 in Ghanaian waters, and recent reports from CECAF capture production (FAO 2008) show that the annual catches of triggerfishes show two separate peaks between 1972 and 2003. The first peak (12,563 tons) occurred in 1979, and the second peak (17,250 tons) in 1986/87. Between 1979 and 1986/87, triggerfish catch fell to ‘regular or stable’ annual levels (5,000-8,000 tons/year). Catch sharply declined in 1988 to 2,862 tons. The continued decline indicates that inshore triggerfish catch generally increased with inshore effort (Aggrey-Fynn 2007). The triggerfish biomass was highest in 1985 and decreased afterwards up to 1991. The biomass decrease was quite significant from 1987-89 at virtually the same effort; and 1989-91 there was virtually no biomass of the triggerfish resource in Ghanaian coastal waters (Koranteng 1998, Aggrey-Fynn 2007).
range: Balistes vetula is widely distributed in the Atlantic. In the eastern Atlantic it is known from Ascension Island, the Cape Verde Islands, the Azores, and along West Africa from Morocco to southern Angola. In the western Atlantic it is known from Newfoundland (Canada) south along the U.S., Bermuda, the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys north to Tampa (Florida), on offshore banks/reefs in the northern Gulf, and off Mexico from Tuxpan along the Yucatan Peninsula, to Cuba, throughout the Caribbean Sea, and along South America to Cabo Frio, Brazil including Trinidade Island (Simon et al. 2013). Its depth range is 0-275 m.
useTrade: Balistes vetula is an important food fish in parts of its range (i.e., Brazil, Caribbean, Bermuda). It is primarily exploited by fisheries in the Caribbean, where catch data are limited. Catches are generally grouped to include all triggerfish and filefish (CFMC 2011), but most fishes in this group are Queen Triggerfish (CFMC 2005). It is taken as bycatch in commercial long-line and hand-line fisheries, and is also a component of small-scale fisheries (Heyman et al. 2012). It is also harvested in recreational fisheries. In small villages of Brazil, parts of this fish are used in traditional medicine in the treatment of asthma, earaches, and stroke victims. Although the species is taken by both traps and hook and line, 95% of all queen triggerfish landings from the U.S. Virgin Islands were taken in traps (Manooch and Drennon 1987). It is also a component of the aquarium trade with online prices ranging from $129.99-$149.99 depending on size.
conservationActions: Queen Triggerfish is managed under the Reef Fish Fishery Management Plan within the filefish and triggerfish Fishery Management Unit (FMU) (Federal Register, Vol. 50, No. 167: 34850-34855) in the waters of the U.S. Caribbean, which includes Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Species-specific landings have only recently begun to be available. It is a component of Commercial and Recreational fisheries in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. It is impacted by management efforts impacting other fisheries, including seasonal area closures, closed areas, and seasonal closures for reef fishes as well as construction and mesh-size requirements for Spiny Lobster and Reef Fish Traps. According to NOAA’s Stock Sustainability Index the triggerfish and filefish Fishery Management Unit is not considered to be undergoing over-fishing and is not over-fished, therefore no rebuilding plan was designed. However, accurate estimates of stock abundance/biomass could not be developed due to data limitations (SEDAR 30 - U.S. Caribbean Queen Triggerfish Stock Assessment Report 2013).

rationale: Epinephelus aeneus is a large sex-changing grouper species with an estimated generation length of 11 years. It is widely distributed and occurs in estuaries, but more generally over rocky reef and soft substrate in marine habitats. Historically it has been heavily exploited through most of its range, including in the southern and eastern Mediterranean Sea and along the Atlantic coast of West Africa, and is highly valued as a food fish in both domestic and international markets. Stock assessments have concluded that overfishing has been and currently is occurring in Senegal and Mauritania. Based on quantified data (commercial and small-scale fishery landings, catch per unit effort, and research survey catches) estimated declines of between 79 to 99% have been recorded in Greece, Senegal and Western Sahara. Therefore, this species' global population is suspected to have declined by an average of at least 24% over the past 30 years. Other countries with known high fishing effort, but which lack reliable quantified data, include Mauritania, Turkey and Tunisia. It is also exploited in other countries, but effort and long-term catch data are not available there (e.g., for Portugal, Israel, Malta, Ivory Coast, and Ghana). Due to the high market value of this species and the lack of effective fishery management measures, effort has been increasing on the remaining viable populations. Total landings reported to FAO have increased significantly in recent years, though this may be reflective of past non-reporting by several countries. In addition, the capture of immature individuals in most fisheries is frequent, which contributes to growth overfishing. Based on these data, we suspect that global-level declines are approaching 30% over the past three generation lengths, which is estimated as 33 years (equivalent to the time period from about 1980 to 2015). This species is listed as Near Threatened since it nearly meets the threshold for Vulnerable A2bd. Further research should be directed to refine life history parameters and compile long-term population data such as species-specific catch, effort and biomass. Conservation measures that reduce fishing effort and improve enforcement are imperative to prevent further population decline.
habitat: Adults of this species occur on rocky or mud-sand bottoms down to depths of 200 m, and juveniles have been taken in coastal lagoons and estuaries (Heemstra and Randall 1993). Seasonal latitudinal migrations take place along the entire Mauritanian coast, specifically among adults (Domain 1980, Bruslé 1985). These migrations can vary interannually depending on the upwelling intensity, with intense upwelling events leading to favourable conditions for reproductive success. Cury and Worms (1982) also suggested that a seasonal migration of this species occurs from Mauritania to Senegal. The maximum length of this species is 120 cm and Bianchini et al. (2007) reported a fish of 34.4 kg from Sicily, which appears to be the maximum known weight. This species is reportedly a protogynous hermaphrodite and females reach maturity at 50 to 60 cm total length (Bruslé and Bruslé 1976, Bouain et al. 1983, Bruslé 1985). In south-eastern Tunisia, Epinephelus aeneus spawns in June and July (Bouain and Siau 1983). In Iskenderun Bay, Turkey, it spawns from around the beginning of June until the end of August (Gökçe et al. 2003 in Özgür Özbek et al. 2013). The largest fish measured in a Tunisian study was 115 cm total length, 25 kg, and estimated to be 17 years old. In the same study, females reached maturity at five to seven years and sex change occurred at 10 to 13 years (Bouain et al. 1983). Based on a longevity of 19 years, age of first maturity of 5 years, and applying the mean generational turnover formula in Depczynski and Bellwood (2006), one generation length is estimated to be 11 years.
threats: Overfishing is a major threat to this species. Fishing effort across all fisheries sectors is excessive, frequently unrecorded, and often illegal in West Africa (Polidoro et al. 2016). Similarly, in the Eastern Mediterranean, the high economic value of E. aeneus, has caused an increase in fishing pressure and even the rise of illegal fishing and a black market (Ünal et al. 2009).
population:
Glamuzina and Skaramuca (1999) described E. aeneus as frequently occurring in North African Mediterranean waters, significantly rare in central Mediterranean areas, and absent in the northern Mediterranean Sea. Much of the population information on this species is from north-west Africa and the Mediterranean, where it has been/is highly exploited. Species-specific landings for E. aeneus are reported to FAO by some countries, and other countries also exploit this species, but only report it in mixed grouper catches. Some of the data sets present conflicting evidence which is difficult to interpret. Global FAO landings ranged between ca. 1,000 and 2,000 mt from 1965 to 2008, and increased steeply thereafter to ca 7,500 mt in 2014. This may represent a genuine increase in catch, but may also reflect improved reporting in some countries, greater fishing effort or countries reporting catches made in adjacent countries (see below). For example, Sierra Leone did not report catches of this species until 2014. That first report of ca 3,000 mt constituted 40% of the global catch.

Grouper species have been fished for centuries along the north-west African coast. Since the 16th century, small-scale canoe fisheries have been targeting these resources in Senegal and Mauritania. During this time period, European fishers also started fishing off the north-west African coastline (Chauveau 1989 in Thiao et al. 2012). At the beginning of the 20th century, E. aeneus was described as a target species for artisanal fishers based in Saint-Louis, which was the main fishing centre in northern Senegal. Despite the fishing effort for this species, the resource was not considered to be overexploited until the Second World War (Postel 1950 in Thiao et al. 2012). Following Senegal’s independence in 1960, the catch reached 3,570 mt in 1964 (Lourdelet 1996 in Thiao et al. 2012) and represented almost 20% of the Senegalese fish catch taken by handlines. At the end of the 20th century, the fishery underwent dramatic changes. In 1994, the development of an export market for high-quality demersal species such as groupers was enhanced by the 50% devaluation of the local currency. At present, most of these high-value species are directly exported to European and Far Eastern markets (Swartz et al. 2010). During this period, the development of the Senegalese small-scale fisheries was strongly supported by external aid and public subsidies, which enabled the small-scale fleet to double in size from 1985 to 2005, and it is continuing to increase (Thiao et al. 2012). The situation appears similar in Mauritania, where there was an eight-fold increase in the numbers of artisanal fishing boats from the 1980s to ca 2010 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015), which is further evidenced by the increasing trend in FAO landings (see Table 1 in the Supplementary Information). Effort probably substantially increased further since 2010. Given the data presented below, this species' global population is suspected to have declined by an average of at least 24% and likely approaching 30% over the past three generation lengths, which is estimated as 33 years.

Mediterranean: Epinephelus aeneus was apparently previously a relatively abundant species in the Mediterranean Sea, but has declined significantly in many parts.

Greece: Previously, the catches reported by Greece to FAO made it the greatest global contributor – in fact, Greece was the only country that reported catches until 1984, when Mauritania commenced reporting (see Table 1 in the Supplementary Information). Greece began reporting in 1958, reached a peak catch of 2,100 mt in 1968, and subsequently generally declined significantly until the early 1980s. By 1984, the catch was only 593 mt and it continued a steady decline until 2011 when a zero catch was reported. Zero catch was also reported from 2012 to 2014, which represented a decline in the Greek catch of over 99% since 1968 (a 47 year period). Relatively lower catches of an average of 9 mt were reported in recent years by Portugal (from 1995 to 2013), Israel (from 2009 to 2014) and Malta (from 2010 to 2013). Portuguese catch peaked at 34 mt in 2005, and declined to 1 mt in 2014 (Table 1 in the Supplementary Information), but catches by Israel and Malta showed no particular trends.

Italy: A study by Bianchini et al. (2007) in the Strait of Sicily, reported that the total catch of grouper species across 3,557 trawl hauls was low both in number and weight. Out of the five grouper species recorded (totalling 27 specimens), six specimens were identified as E. aeneus and these were captured during three hauls at depths of around 50 m, with the largest specimen weighing 34.4 kg.

Turkey: Of grouper landings by the small-scale longline fishery of Gökova Bay from September 2002 to August 2003, E. aeneus constituted the highest proportion by weight (41%) for a total landed catch of 106 kg for 187 individuals. About 50% of the E. aeneus catch was under the 30 cm size limit, and presumably immature (Akyol et al. 2007). In 2006, the total catch of groupers (Epinephelus spp.) in Turkey was 481 mt, and the most common species caught was E. aeneus. In 2006, the E. aeneus total catch from Gökova Bay was 2,905 kg, and comprised 11% of total fish landings there. About 13.3% of groupers in the Turkish fishery were immature, and 85% of those captured in Gökova Bay were immature (Ünal et al. 2009). The high catchability rate of this species in Cyprus and Turkey shows that trawling is a risk for populations of this species (Özgür Özbek et al. 2013).

Tunisia: Bouain et al. (1983) reported that E. aeneus comprised 90% of the landings of fish at the port of Sfax. In Tunisia, more than 90% of female individuals collected between 1970 and 1973 weighed between only three and nine kilograms (Bruslé and Bruslé 1976), which is well below its potential maximum weight of about 25 kg.

Morocco: It is unknown whether the Moroccan catches are from the Atlantic or Mediterranean coasts, or both, but probably mainly from the former. In the 1950s, E. aeneus was reportedly abundant along the south coast of Morocco (Furnestin et al. 1958). Morocco reported to FAO for relatively brief periods (from 2000 to 2014), and catch was at a relatively low levels (average of 2 mt).

West Africa: FAO landings in some north-west African countries show a substantial increase in recent years. Cote d’Ivoire reported zero catches from 1970 to 1988, followed by catches mostly between zero and 10 mt until 2009, and an increase to an average of 900 mt from 2010 to 2014. Ghana reported for relatively brief periods (from 2005 to 2009), and catch was at relatively low levels (average of 52 mt). Meissa et al. (2013) reported that the lack of reliable stock assessments for numerous exploited fish stocks in West Africa was due to poor-quality data, high multi-specificity of captures and the heterogeneity of exploitation methods.

Mauritania: FAO landings reported by Mauritania for this species commenced in 1984, and peaked at ca 1,800 mt in 1988, followed by catches of around 500 mt from 1989 to 2007 (see Table 1 in the Supplementary Information). From 2008 onwards, catches increased significantly to ca 1,600 mt in 2014. This increase could be ascribed to increasing effort in both the artisanal and industrial fishing sectors (Labrosse et al. 2010 in Meissa and Gascuel 2015). In Mauritania, the probability of catching this species declined from 60% in 1995 to 10% in the late 2000s (Meissa 2008 in Thiao et al. 2012). On the adjacent Western Saharan Bank, E. aeneus accounted for 5.3% of the mean total abundance of fish during research trawl surveys in 1942, but declined to only 0.001% by 1974 (> 99% decline over a 33 year period); E. aeneus was not recorded during a fisheries research cruise there in 1990 (Balguerías et al. 2000). Epinephelus aeneus is a flagship species in West Africa that is exploited by industrial and small-scale fisheries in Mauritania, and the stock is highly overexploited (Meissa et al. 2013). Subsequently, Meissa and Gascuel (2015) estimated MSY at 1,025 mt and fMSY as a very low 0.07 yr-1, based on a ca 25 year time series of data up to 2010. Note that the FAO landings for 2014 (ca 1,600 mt) exceed this MSY by 56%, although it is not inconceivable that Mauritanian fishers also fish in adjacent countries, but report catches in Mauritania, as noted for Senegalese fishers.

Senegal: Of the countries in north-west Africa, Senegal reports the highest landings for this species to FAO. Senegal began to report catches to FAO in 2003, when it recorded a catch of 685 mt (see Table 1 in the Supplementary Information). Catch increased steadily to 2,142 mt in 2014, and the annual average catch from 2003 to 2014 was 1,383 mt. Although these relatively recent catch data could be indicative of a developing fishery, other longer-term indicators (see below) indicate that this species has long been overfished in Senegalese waters. For example, the Senegalese small-scale fishery landed 3,570 mt in 1964 (Lourdelet 1996 in Thiao et al. 2012) and total catch of E. aeneus across small-scale and industrial fisheries was 1,851 mt in 1991 (Gascuel and Ménar 1997). Overall Senegalese landings of this species reported by Ndiaye et al. (2013) were ca. 2,200 mt in 1981, peaked at ca. 4,900 mt in 1983 and declined to ca. 850 mt in 2008, which constitutes a 79% decline over a 26 year period. As reported earlier, FAO landings contrast with these data (see Supplementary Material). Contributing to this discrepancy may be Senegalese fishers buying licenses to fish E. aeneus in Guinea and Sierra Leone where the stock is more abundant (Thiao et al. 2012), but presumably reporting their catches in Senegal, thereby reflecting an apparent increase in FAO landings for Senegal. Catch data collected from three artisanal fishing sites in northern Senegal also recorded a precipitous decline of about 95% from a peak of ca. 1,300 mt in 1975 to 64 mt in 2006 (i.e., over a 32 year period) (Thiao et al. 2012). The catch per unit effort (CPUE; kg/trip) also declined by 95% over this period. CPUE in research trawls also declined by about 20% from 1987 to 2004 (an 18 year period). FAO working groups (FAO 2006, 2012 in Thiao et al. 2012) recommended a moratorium on catches of E. aeneus in Senegal and Mauritania due to the expected extirpation of the species otherwise. Gascuel and Ménar (1997) classified E. aeneus in Senegal as an overexploited species based on fishing effort in 1991, this being 2.7 times greater than the fMSY and MSY was estimated as ca. 3,000 mt a year, which was exceeded by the artisanal fishery alone between 1984 and 1986 (Gascuel and Ménar 1997). As a result, catch declined and reached a low at 1,135 mt in 1998 (Martial et al. 2002). A range of stock assessment approaches showed a decline in biomass in Senegal of 80 to 90% from 1971 to 1999 (over 29 years) due to excessive fishing effort (Laurens et al. 2002, 2003). According to Froese (2004), the Senegalese stock of E. aeneus was overfished based on a decline in the percentage of mature E. aeneus individuals in the catch from about 80% in the early 1990s to about 38% in 1999. During the same period, percentages of E.  aeneus individuals at optimal length and of ‘mega-spawners’ (i.e. fish >100 cm TL) had decreased from about 35% to less than 20%. Ndiaye et al. (2013) repeated the approach of Froese et al. (2004) and reiterated that the stock was overexploited; however, there is significant uncertainty surrounding the age and growth parameters used to determine optimal length. A 40% decline of the mean length of individuals in the catch has also occurred: from 68 cm in 1974 to 42 cm in 2010. The optimal length of capture to maintain fishery sustainability was 96 cm, but only 0.03% of captured individuals were of this length, and most of the catch consisted of juveniles. Thiao et al. (2012) suggested that the collapse of the E. aeneus fishery in Senegal is linked to the booming small-scale fishery sector benefiting from increasing foreign demand in a globalised market, and a favourable economic context for fishers who benefit from public subsidies to purchase fishing gear, etc.
range: This species is distributed in the southern and eastern waters of the Mediterranean Sea, the southern Atlantic coasts of Portugal and Spain, and southwards along the Atlantic coast of West Africa as far as southern Angola, including the islands of the Gulf of Guinea. It has been considered to be absent north of 44°N in the Adriatic Sea before 1992 (Dulcic et al. 2006, Dulcic and Grbec 2000), but Glamuzina et al. (2000) suggested that this species was more recently beginning to colonize new areas in the northern Mediterranean and Adriatic Seas. It was also considered to be absent from Spain to central Italy in the central Mediterranean, but two specimens were caught in July 2012 off Corsica, France (Ruitort 2012), and a third specimen was captured in January 2014 off Monaco (P. Gilles and P. Francour pers. comm. 2016). Records from the Canary Islands, Spain are unsubstantiated (Heemstra and Randall 1993), as are also those for Madeira (P. Francour pers. comm. 2016). Its depth range is 20 to 200 metres.
useTrade: This species is highly esteemed and economically valued as a food fish throughout its range, and is typically caught with hook-and-line and in trawls (Maigret and Ly 1986, Heemstra and Randall 1993). In Senegal, it is mainly exploited by artisanal fishers, but also by localised industrial scale fisheries for export (Cury and Worms 1982). This is also an important species in European markets, with most of the marketed catch likely imported from elsewhere, such as Senegal. It is also valued in Turkey (Ünal et al. 2009). Illegal spear-fishing for this species is also reported in the eastern Mediterranean by professional divers using lights at night (Ünal et al. 2009, Özgür Özbek et al. 2013).
conservationActions:
In north-west Africa, attempts to reduce fishing pressure on this species by implementing seasonal closures and marine protected areas have been ineffective due to a lack of enforcement (Thiao et al. 2012). It is critical to address and mitigate pressure from small-scale fisheries in west Africa, especially Mauritania and Senegal, to prevent further declines (Thiao et al. 2012).

In Turkey, prior to 2016, the legal size of groupers (Epinephelus aeneus included) was 30 cm, longline grouper fishing using hooks smaller than No. 9 was prohibited between 15th June and 31st July, and targeting groupers with longline hooks smaller than No. 14, spearguns, fish traps and fyke nets was strictly prohibited. The recent 2016-2020 Amateur and Commercial Fisheries Circular adopted a prohibition on fishing, collecting, transferring and selling E. aeneus and also E. marginatus in Turkey.

In Tunisia, all grouper individuals below 35 cm standard length must be released and spearfishing for groupers is totally prohibited (Journal officiel de la République Tunisienne 1994, 1995). However, these prohibitions are generally ineffective due to insufficient enforcement (E. Ben Lamine pers. comm. 2016).

This species has been reported from three small marine protected areas in Spain (Planes et al. 2006). Attempts to grow this species in aquaculture are complicated by problems in broodstock management and larval culture (Gorshkova et al. 2002). However, some positive results for aquaculture of E. aeneus have been achieved in Israel (Hassin et al. 1997, Cnaani et al. 2012).

rationale: This species has a small range that is restricted to rocky reef habitats from Eastern Cape Province, South Africa to southern Mozambique. Its highest natural abundance occurs in KwaZulu Natal Province, and spawning only occurs north of Durban (KwaZulu-Natal to southern Mozambique), which constitutes less than half of its full range. It is generally a minor component of reef fish fisheries throughout its range, but can comprise up to 60% of the aggregated grouper landings in the commercial skiboat fishery of KwaZulu-Natal. Catch per unit effort in the KwaZulu-Natal shore-based recreational fishery declined by 67% over approximately 34 years (1975-2009), and may have declined in the boat-based recreational and commercial skiboat fishery by 38 to 50% over an approximately 15-year interval (1994-1996 to 2008-2009). Catch per unit effort in the southern Mozambique semi-industrial linefishery declined by 75% over approximately five years (2009-2014). Its aggregating behaviour during spawning season can cause this species to be particularly susceptible to high fishing pressure. Therefore, it is suspected that global-level population declines of nearly 30% have occurred over the past three generation lengths (22.5 years; 1993-2016). There have been some conservation measures implemented to reduce fishing effort, including bag and size limits and a limit on numbers of commercial fishing licenses in South Africa; however, compliance with some regulations has been in decline. There are also at least two large, relatively well-managed marine protected areas in KwaZulu-Natal and southern Mozambique that provide some protection to the population in offshore areas of the protected areas (i.e., beyond the reach of subsistence shorefishers). However, it is unlikely that fishing effort has been reduced over the entire range of this species to allow recovery. This species is listed as Near Threatened since it nearly meets the threshold for Vulnerable A2bd. Further research should be directed to refine life history parameters and compile population data such as catch, effort and biomass. Conservation measures that reduce fishing effort and improve enforcement are imperative to prevent further population decline.
habitat: This species is closely associated with shallow rocky reefs, and is rarely recorded on coral reefs (Chater et al. 1993, Chater et al. 1995). Adults undertake pioneering behaviour or small migrations, likely in search of available habitat that has been vacated by other predatory fishes and adults of this species are often among the first species to arrive on newly-created artificial reefs or shipwrecks (Maggs 2012, S. Chater pers. comm. 2016). Juveniles migrate from nursery habitat on surf-zone reefs to deeper offshore reef habitats with increasing size and age (Mann et al. 2015). Results from tagging studies indicates the species exhibits a high degree of site fidelity, and generally do not undergo substantial migrations as adults, although some pre-adults undertake movements greater than 400 km (Maggs 2012, Maggs et al. 2013b, Mann et al. 2015, Mann et al. 2016a, Mann et al. 2016b); of 2,320 individuals tagged in South Africa in 30 years, 22% have been recaptured, and moved an average distance of 5 km (Oceanographic Research Institute unpublished data). There is likely northward movement of pre-adults from southern to northern KwaZulu-Natal, as no spawning occurs south of Durban; although considerable numbers of reproductively inactive fish are caught there (Mann et al. 2015). Spawning only occurs north of 30°, and not all mature individuals spawn every year (Fennessy 2000). There is some evidence for spawning-related localised increases in abundance (i.e., aggregations) during summer (January to March, and large catches have been recorded (S. Fennessy unpublished data). The species is a relatively slow-growing, diandric protogynous hermaphrodite (i.e., some males are derived from functional females, but some develop from the juvenile phase), so the sex ratio is not female-biased as in monandric protogynous hermaphrodites. Size and age at first maturity are slightly greater for females (49 cm, 3.9 years) and males (43 cm, 2.7 years) and it has been aged to at least 11 years (Fennessy 2000, Fennessy and Sadovy 2002). Based on a longevity of 11 years, age of first maturity of 4 years, and applying the mean generational turnover formula in Depczynski and Bellwood (2006), one generation length is estimated to be 7.5 years. Longevity may be longer than is currently understood. Its maximum length is 90 cm.
threats: Overfishing is a major threat to this species over most of its range (excluding the offshore portions of marine protected areas in KwaZulu-Natal and southern Mozambique).
