In addition, a species distribution modelling study by Coppinger (2013) that applied sea surface temperature projections under climate change forecasts predicted a 16% decline in habitable waters for this species by 2030 due to a contraction in the northern part of its range due to higher temperatures, and in the south due to lower temperatures.
population:
This species is relatively common in South Africa, particularly in KwaZulu-Natal province. It is relatively abundant only between Folokwe in Eastern Cape Province north to Quissico Province (32°15'S and 24°50'S). A genetics study reported some evidence for subpopulations, albeit with conflicting findings from nuclear and mitochondrial DNA (Coppinger 2013), but for the purposes of this assessment, it is considered to be comprised of a single population across South Africa and Mozambique. Based on catch per unit effort (CPUE) data, this species is suspected to have declined by nearly 30% over the past three generation lengths (22.5 years; 1993-2016).

South Africa: According to observations during underwater surveys conducted on deeper (~15 m) coral reefs in the iSimangaliso marine protected area (MPA), this species is not common (Floros 2010). It was the sixth most commonly caught species (~5% of total catch by number) in research shore angling catches in iSimangaliso from 2001 to 2013 (Mann 2016). This species comprises a relatively low portion (~3% by weight) of the offshore skiboat fishery catch in South Africa (Dunlop 2011). It also only contributed about 1% to spearfishing catches in the mid-1990s (Mann et al. 1997a) and more recently contributes about 0.3% to recreational shorefishing catches (Dunlop 2011). Catch per unit effort of this species in the KwaZulu-Natal recreational boat fishery declined by 50% over a 15 year interval from 0.54 in 1994-1996 to 0.27 fish per boat day in 2008-2009, and by 38% in the commercial sector of this fishery from 3.23 to 2.01 fish per boat day during the same time period (Mann et al. 1997b, Dunlop 2011); however, these declines are not based on a continuous time series (i.e., it is based on two individual snapshot surveys). Though this species is a relatively minor component of shore catches, catch per unit effort in the Kwa-Zulu Natal shore-based recreational fishery declined by 67% over about 34 years from 0.003 fish/angler/day in 1975-1977 (Joubert 1981) to 0.001 in 2008-2009 (Dunlop 2011, Dunlop and Mann 2012, Dunlop and Mann 2013). The only continuous South African long-term catch data available is from mostly unverified compulsory commercial catch records from KwaZulu-Natal submitted by skippers to the national fisheries department. This species comprises about 60% of the aggregated grouper landings in the KwaZulu-Natal commercial skiboat fishery, and from 1987 to 2013, catch declined by 53% from 1993 to 2013 (from about 75 to 35 tons). However, fishing effort was reduced by about 50% in 2003 due to a reduction in numbers of commercial fishing licenses. Standardized catch per unit effort for aggregated grouper catches from 1987 to 2013 remained stable at about 8 kg/boat/day (H. Winker unpub. data 2016). In contrast, the co-occurring seabreams (Sparidae), which are the main target of this fishery (~80% of catch weight versus 5% for groupers), have shown an increase in catch per unit effort after the 2003 effort reduction. There is some conflict between the information from the two independent snapshot surveys (1994-1996 and 2008-2009), which suggest declines over this period, versus that from the continuous information submitted by the commercial fishery, which suggests stability (albeit for aggregated grouper landings). Based on spawner biomass per recruit analyses of data from the mid 1990s for this species, the exploitation rate was assessed as optimal (~40% of pristine spawning biomass per recruit; Fennessy 2000), but this assessment is considerably outdated.

Mozambique: This species was not commonly observed during underwater surveys in the Ponta do Ouro marine protected area in southern Mozambique (Pereira and Fernandes 2014). It comprised less than 1% by number and less than 2% by weight of the overall catches of the southern Mozambique semi-industrial linefishery from 2002 to 2014. Catch per unit effort in this fishery declined by 75% from about 6 kg/boat/day in 2009 to 1.5 in 2014 (R. Mutombene unpub. data 2016), although this trend may be distorted by changes in fleet spatial fishing effort. Similarly, the relative contribution of this species to overall catch appears to have declined since the mid-1990s when the fishery underwent rapid development, although there is some uncertainty about the relative contribution of groupers prior to 2002 due to sampling biases. Fleet dynamics could also affect the apparent contribution, as groupers are not the main target of the fishery.
range:
This species is distributed from eastern South Africa (KwaZulu-Natal and Eastern Cape provinces to 34°05'S) northwards to Quissico in southern Mozambique (24°50'S). It has recently been recorded further south in the De Hoop marine protected area (34°30’S, 20°40’E) in Western Cape, South Africa (C. Attwood pers. comm. 2016). Reports of this species occurring in Madagascar are dubious (McKenna and Allen 2003), and recent work suggests it is either rare or absent there (S. Fennessy unpublished data 2016). Its depth range is zero to 100 metres, but typically occurs shallower than 70 metres.

The area within the generalized distribution polygon clipped to the zero to 100 metre isobath, which is the best estimate of area of occupancy (AOO), is 27,310 km². This species is closely reef-associated, and this is therefore an overestimation of its AOO, but no spatial data are available to calculate a total area of rocky reef habitat in this region. The area within the minimum convex polygon drawn around the boundaries of its AOO, which is the best estimate of extent of occurrence (EOO), is 248,463 km².
useTrade: Apart from the offshore portions of the protected areas, this species is caught in local artisanal and small-scale commercial fisheries throughout its range.
conservationActions: This species occurs in several large, well-enforced marine protected areas in South Africa (e.g., the iSimangaliso World Heritage Site in northern KwaZulu-Natal), and in the adjacent Ponta do Ouro marine protected area (MPA) of southern Mozambique. The total area of these MPAs is ~1,400 km², although much of this extends beyond the depth range of this species; subsistence shore fishing (subject to recreational size and bag limits) occurs in these MPAs in South Africa. Additional MPAs in the range of this species in South Africa are to be promulgated shortly (as of 2018). Previously, there was fairly good compliance with bag and size limitation regulations owing to an active conservation agency in KwaZulu-Natal; however, as of July 2016, adherence to compliance measures has been considerably reduced with the removal of the agency’s mandate by the national department of fisheries. Mann (2016) found a larger mean size of individuals of this species in a previously exploited area compared to a no-take sanctuary area in the South African iSimangaliso MPA, and Maggs et al. (2013a) found a greater abundance of this species in the adjacent exploited area compared to the no-take zone of the Pondoland MPA some 400 km to the south. This is suspected to be attributable to this species' pioneering behaviour. In South Africa, fishing regulations that apply to this species include a minimum size limit of 50 cm total length and a recreational and commercial bag limit of five fish per person per day. Commercial fishing effort in the South African skiboat fishery was substantially reduced in 2003 upon the withdrawal of ca 50% of fishing permits. A general recreational bag limit of four serranid fish applies in Mozambique, but is seldom enforced. In summary, about 30% of its Mozambican range (using coastline length) falls into a reasonably well-managed MPA (only pelagic fishing allowed) in southern Mozambique. In South Africa, around 30% of the range of reproductively active individuals is relatively well-protected in an MPA (adjacent to the southern Mozambique MPA). An additional large MPA occurs well to the south providing further protection for non-reproductively active individuals, but there is evidence that some individuals move from this MPA to join the reproductively active part of the population in the north. None of the MPAs provide full protection as they all have some subsistence fishing from the shore. The MPA in southern Mozambique and the adjacent one in northern South Africa are not ideal habitat for this species - the reefs there are mainly coral and this is not a coral reef species - but still offer some protection, at least from boat-based fishing (S. Fennessy pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Epinephelus daemelii is a large grouper species that inhabits nearshore rocky reef habitat. Its range is relatively small, extending mainly only from New South Wales in Australia, northern New Zealand and the Kermadec Islands. It is a very high quality eating fish, and its territorial and inquisitive nature causes it to be easily captured by recreational (spear and line) and commercial line-fishers. In addition, intrinsic biological characteristics cause it to be highly susceptible to rapid population decline. As a result of heavy fishing pressure throughout much of its range in the past, its populations, and most probably also fish size, declined severely throughout the greater part of its distribution since early in the 20th century. Anecdotal evidence from the 1950s through the 1970s also documented that overfishing by recreational line-fishers and spear-fishers had continued, as large specimens were by then considered to be rare in New South Wales. However, current population trends are difficult to determine from the data currently available, as there are no catch records available for it. A fishing ban that is relatively well-enforced has been in place throughout its range except for southern Queensland for at least the past 30 years (since the 1980s). It has, however, shown no signs of any population recovery since it has been protected. Its abundance still remains very low, except in a few very remote regions and in some isolated no-take marine protected areas. Given that its population is suspected to have remained at a very low level following very severe historical declines, and protective measures have not yet allowed for population recovery to occur, this species is listed as Near Threatened based on is high dependence on ongoing conservation actions being in place, particularly as it is considered that the removal of any of the existing conservation measures would quickly cause this species to qualify for a threatened category under criterion A (A3 or A4) within 10 years. In addition to population monitoring and the continuance of fishing bans, it is recommended that research on life history parameters and reproductive biology is conducted.
habitat: This species inhabits nearshore caves, ledges and rocky reefs to depths of over 50 metres. Sub-adults have been observed in estuaries (Hutchins and Swainston 1986, Harasti et al. 2004), and recently settled juveniles are found in coastal rock pools along the southern New South Wales coastline (Hutchins and Swainston 1986, Griffiths 2003, Harasti et al. 2004). This species exhibits aggressive territorial behavior: each adult individual generally has its own cave or 'hole' that it occupies for life (Heemstra and Randall 1993, Harasti et al. 2004). It has been observed sharing its cave with several other reef fishes, including the Red Moki in New Zealand (Doak 1978). High habitat complexity may be important to this species, as it may prefer a wide variety of structure that provides refuge and a suitable habitat in which to seek and ambush prey. Larger individuals generally occur further offshore and smaller fish appear to prefer shallower waters around inshore reefs and islands (Harasti et al. 2004). The species is most active at dusk and during the night (Kuiter 1993). Adults prey mainly on fishes and crustaceans (McCulloch 1922 cited in Harasti et al. 2004) and juveniles generally feed on smaller crabs and smaller fish species (Heemstra and Randall 1993). Spawning aggregations have not been observed in the North Island, New Zealand (Stewart 1999). Observations of small aggregations of up to twelve fish in New South Wales, could suggest it gathers at particular times of the year; however, it is not known whether these aggregations are for spawning purposes or not (Harasti et al. 2004). Very little research has been conducted on its reproductive biology in Australian waters (Harasti et al. 2004).The average age at first maturity is probably less than 20 years for females and more than 30 years for males and longevity is possibly up to 65 years, however, uncertainty in the data indicates that further investigation is needed (Francis et al. 2015). This species has a maximum total length of 180 cm and weight of over 80 kg. Sizes in New Zealand are typically between 40 and 80 cm and reports of individuals up to 200 cm in length (e.g., Paulin and Roberts 1992) have been revised downward through work by Francis et al. (2015). This species initially grows rather rapidly, to ~75 cm total length in the first 10 years, then growth slows  ~100 cm total length around 20 years of age and past 30 years, it may grow relatively little (Francis et al. 2015). Further research is needed to confirm if this species is a protogynous hermaphrodite, and life history data remains highly uncertain (M. Craig pers. comm. 2017).
threats: Overfishing was a major threat to this species in the past. It suffers mortality when captured as bycatch by commercial fishers in deeper (~50 to 100 m) waters off northern New South Wales due to severe barotrauma stress (Pogonoski et al. 2002). Degradation of estuarine nursery habitats may impact juvenile survivability (Fishnote 2002).
population:
Historically this species was targeted by recreational and commercial fishers, and experienced significant population declines (possibly greater than 90%) as a result. It has been largely protected from fishing since the early 1980s, but the lack of quantitative data prevents an understanding of population trends. Intrinsic biological characteristics (e.g., extended longevity, presumed late age at maturity, suspected protogynous hermaphroditism, etc.), together with the territoriality of this large and once highly sought after grouper species, causes it to be highly susceptible to rapid population decline due to fishing pressure. Despite fishing bans in place since the 1980s, its abundance still remains low with no indications of recovery, except in very remote regions and in some no-take marine protected areas (Francis et al. 2015). It is possibly still declining in some areas (e.g., at Elizabeth and Middleton Reefs), and certainly does not appear to be increasing from its long-term depleted and ongoing low baseline condition which prevails in most areas of its distribution. Population increases may be possible given a longer time period for recovery from fishing, especially if a fishing ban is enforced in remaining unprotected areas of its range.

Australia: In Australia, this species is mainly found along the entire New South Wales coast and is most common (especially as adults) in waters off northern New South Wales. It is considered to be naturally uncommon in southern Queensland (Harasti et al. 2004). There is a single population in New South Wales: eggs and larvae of this species are transported southwards via the East Australian Current, and early stage juveniles recruit to intertidal rock pools mainly in the southern part of the state. Sub-adults and/or small adults later presumably migrate northwards to spawn in the northern half of the state, where the larger male fish (>110 cm total length) occur (Harasti et al. 2004, Francis et al. 2015). Juvenile specimens are also commonly found along the southern coastline of New South Wales in eastern Australia, and also around Lord Howe, Norfolk and the Kermadec Islands (Paulin and Roberts 1992). Roughley (1916) reported that E. daemelii was "at one time ... fairly plentiful in the vicinity of Port Jackson", but that it had already become very scarce due to fishing pressure there by the early 1900s; and McCulloch (1922) reported it was once quite common in New South Wales but had become very scarce in “recent years” (i.e., presumably prior to the early 1920s). It then continued to be depleted well into the second half of the 20th century due to commercial and recreational fishing pressures. Historical evidence (pre-1908) also indicated that a decline in abundance and possibly size had already occurred in New South Wales by around the turn of the 20th century, especially near large towns or cities. Anecdotal evidence from in various fishing and diving magazines published in the 1960s and 1970s documented that overfishing by New South Wales recreational line fishers and spear-fishers had occurred, as large specimens were then considered to be rare and a prized catch. Individuals captured during spearfishing competitions in New South Wales in 1976 averaged a weight of only 2.4 kg (Lincoln-Smith et al. 1989), though this species can grow to over 80 kg. It has been protected in Australia since 1983. A formal population monitoring program has been in place since about 2012 (about five years) in northern New South Wales that includes regular underwater visual censuses conducted by NSW Fisheries staff (Harasti and Malcolm 2013). Given the short time period that this program has been in place, measurable changes in this species’ population are not yet know; however, initial evidence indicates that both the size and abundance of this species are greater in the more northerly parts of its New South Wales range (Francis et al. 2015).

New Zealand/Tasman Sea: This species is common in the northern Tasman Sea, including the Lord Howe and Norfolk Islands and Elizabeth and Middleton Reefs (Leadbitter 1992, Harasti et al. 2004, Oxley et al. 2004, Pratchett et al. 2011). It is also common in the Kermadec Islands north of New Zealand, and also relatively common in the Three Kings Islands, but generally naturally rare in North Island, New Zealand (Paulin and Roberts 1992, Francis 1993, Harasti et al. 2004). Fish in northern New Zealand may have their origins in source populations originating from Lord Howe, Norfolk or the Kermadec Islands, and thus, North Island probably represents a population sink (Francis et al. 2015). Small juveniles (down to about 5 cm) have been observed in tidepools in the Kermadec Islands, indicating that there could possibly be some self recruitment there (T. Trnski pers. comm. 2016). Underwater surveys conducted at Elizabeth Reef recorded the abundance of this species as four fish per hectare, with no significant change in abundance between surveys in 1987 and 2003; although mean size of fish increased slightly over this ~15 year period (maximum size in 2003 was 150 cm), possibly due to its full protection enforced since the late 1980s (Oxley et al. 2004). Surveys conducted in the Elizabeth and Middleton Reefs in 2006 and 2011 recorded the average abundance of this species as 2.31 fish per hectare, and between the surveys, abundance declined significantly at four out of the eight sites surveyed, but the cause of the decline is not fully understood (Pratchett et al. 2011).
range: This species is distributed in warm temperate and subtropical waters of the south-western Pacific Ocean, mainly between ~ 28 to 35°S. It occurs in Australia from far southern Queensland (Flinders and Saumarez reefs) to just across the New South Wales-Victorian border (Harasti et al. 2004). A specimen from Kangaroo Island, South Australia is suspected to be a misidentification or represent another species of Epinephelus (Gomon et al. 2008). It also occurs in the Lord Howe and Norfolk Islands, around the Elizabeth and Middleton Reefs (offshore reefs north of Lord Howe Island), in the northern Tasman Sea and the more northerly parts of North Island, New Zealand and the Kermadec Islands (Paulin and Roberts 1992, Oxley et al. 2004, Harasti et al. 2004). Juvenile specimens have been collected as far south as Hawkes Bay (near Napier) in New Zealand and also occasionally range as far south as Cook Strait (one has been recorded off Westland on the South Island), but they are rare south of East Cape in New Zealand. This species occurs from zero to about 50 metres depth, but at least one record has been taken at a depth of over 100 metres.
useTrade: Previously this species was heavily targeted by both recreational and commercial fisheries; however, a fishing ban for this species has been in place throughout its range for at least the past 30 years. There may be some unknown level of illegal fishing and unintentional bycatch during both commercial and recreational fishing activities (Pogonoski et al. 2002). Non-consumptive use includes its high value for ecotourism, especially to recreational diver underwater photography enthusiasts.
conservationActions: This species remains unprotected from fishing in southern Queensland, but is mostly not currently targeted elsewhere in its range due to fishing bans specifically for this species. Take of this species has been prohibited (considered 'totally protected') in New South Wales since 1983. It has also been listed as a Vulnerable Species under the New South Wales Fisheries Management Act since 1999, and its take by fishing operations other than by scientific permit has been illegal since 1991. A recovery plan was prepared for this species by New South Wales Fisheries (NSW Department of Primary Industries) in 2012, with the main emphasis of this plan concentrated on further research and population monitoring. A monitoring program is currently in place in northern New South Wales that includes regular underwater visual censuses conducted by NSW Fisheries staff (Harasti and Malcolm 2013). As this monitoring program has only been in place for a short period of time, no evidence has been obtained of any measurable changes in this species’ population status. These surveys have, however, shown that both the size and abundance of this species are greater in the more northerly parts of its range along the New South Wales coastline (see Francis et al. 2015). It is also a Totally Protected Species in New Zealand and the Kermadec Islands under the New Zealand Wildlife Act 1953. It also occurs in several marine reserves and protected areas throughout its range (Pogonoski et al. 2002). Enforcement of the fishing ban and no-take zones within protected areas is considered relatively effective since they are generally well-managed and policed. In some, however, such as those at Elizabeth and Middleton Reefs, this may not be the case. Outside strict fishing no-take (sanctuary) zones, which generally make up only a small proportion of many of these protected areaa, and in those areas of such reserves where some fishing is allowed, any black cod that may be caught incidentally as by-catch from deeper waters (i.e., those >25 m) probably do not survive capture due to barotrauma, even if the fish may have been released.

rationale: This widely distributed species inhabits deeper, soft and hard bottom habitats along much of the West African coastline. Data are very limited on its population, fisheries catch statistics and life history. It is taken by fisheries throughout its range and is a highly regarded food fish. Species-specific catch statistics available from Sierra Leone indicate a decline in annual landings over the past 18 years of 69% (1999-2017). Relatively higher catches, however, were reported from Senegal in recent years (2012-2015), though only three years of data are available. Considering that fishing pressure is known to be high and driving declines in grouper populations in most other West African countries (e.g., for Epinephelus aeneus), it is suspected that this latter species has experienced declines of nearly 30% over the past three generation lengths (about 30 years, or since the 1980s) due to continuing overfishing, and this species is listed as Near Threatened because it nearly meets the thresholds for criterion A2bd. Further research on E. goreensis is therefore strongly recommended to resolve data gaps in its life history and reproductive biology as well as harvest trends and population status. Improved fisheries monitoring and management is also needed. The change in status from the previous assessment reflects an improved application of the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria, as well as a better understanding of available data.
habitat: This species inhabits a variety of demersal habitats including rock, mud and sand. Adults reside in relatively deeper waters than immature individuals (Maigret and Ly 1986). It primarily consumes fish, crustaceans and cephalopods (da Silva Monteiro 1998). Its maximum total length is 140 cm, but more commonly to 50 cm in fisheries catches. Its reproductive biology and life history are poorly known, but its longevity may be about 15 years or more considering what is known on other grouper species of similar size. Data are lacking to estimate generation length at this time, as such, Epinephelus aeneus, which is similar to this species, is applied as a proxy. Based on a longevity of 19 years, age of first maturity of 5 years, and applying the mean generational turnover formula in Depczynski and Bellwood (2006), one generation length is estimated to be 11 years for E. aeneus. Therefore, it is likely that the generation length of E. goreensis is around 10 years.
threats: Overfishing is a major threat to this species. Fishing effort across all fisheries sectors is excessive, frequently unrecorded, and often illegal in West Africa (Polidoro et al. 2016).
population:
Population data are limited for this species. Despite the likelihood that this species is taken at some level in fisheries throughout its range, the only species-specific catch statistics reported to the FAO global fisheries database are from Sierra Leone, and more recently from Senegal. Potentially, this is due to catches of this species being reported by most countries as part of a more "mixed-species" grouper catches. Fishing pressures in most countries within its range, however, would probably be generally similar to that in Sierra Leone; therefore, declines on a global-level are suspected to be similar to those observed in Sierra Leone.

Reports of catches of Dungat Grouper from Sierra Leone to FAO began in 1994 at 120 tonnes, increased to a peak of 290 t in 1999, and declined thereafter to 89 t in 2015 (FAO FishStatJ 2017; see Table 1 and Figure 1 in the Supplementary Information). This represents a catch decline of 69% over a 16 year period, with some uncertainty associated with catches reported over the past 8 years. Catches of this species have only been reported to FAO by Senegal in recent years (289 t in 2012, 277 t in 2014 and 394 t in 2015), and these are comparably similar to catch levels in Sierra Leone during the peak of catch there which occurred in 1999 at 290 t (FAO FishStatJ 2017; see Table 1 and Figure 1 in the Supplementary Information). Epinephelus aeneus, which is a generally similar-sized species caught by the same methods over roughly the same depths and throughout a similar geographical range from Mauritania southwards, is a flagship species in West Africa that is exploited by industrial and small-scale fisheries, and the stock is highly overexploited (Froese 2004, Meissa et al. 2013). A range of stock assessment approaches showed a decline in biomass in Senegal of 80 to 90% from 1971 to 1999 (over 29 years) due to excessive fishing effort (Laurens et al. 2002, 2003). Overall Senegalese landings of E. aeneus declined from ca. 4,900 mt in 1983 to ca. 850 mt in 2008, which constitutes a 79% decline over a 26 year period (Ndiaye et al. 2013). Catch and catch per unit effort in northern Senegalese artisanal fisheries also declined over a 32 year period by about 95% from a peak of ca 1,300 mt in 1975 to 64 mt in 2006 (Thiao et al. 2012). Epinephelus aeneus is probably targeted more than E. goreensis because it is a more common and abundant species, but it is likely that E. goreensis is experiencing declines alongside E. aeneus as it is exploited by the same fisheries; therefore, it is suspected that the global population of E. goreensis has declined by nearly 30% over the past three generation lengths (about 30 years; 1986-2016).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Atlantic from Mauritania to southern Angola, including Cabo Verde [Cape Verde] and the islands of the Gulf of Guinea (Maigret and Ly 1986, Heemstra and Randall 1993). It is suspected, but not yet confirmed, to possibly also occur in the Canary Islands. Its depth range is 80-300 metres.
useTrade: This species is taken in handline, bottom trawl and trammel net fisheries throughout its range, and is of at least minor importance to fisheries there (Heemstra and Anderson 2016). It is a highly regarded food species in West Africa.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures, and there are no known marine protected areas within its range. It is critical to address and mitigate pressure from small-scale fisheries in west Africa to prevent further declines (Thiao et al. 2012). Research on its life history and reproductive biology is needed, as well as improved monitoring of harvest trends and population status.

rationale: This primarily deep-living, relatively large grouper species inhabits hard bottoms across a relatively small distribution in south-eastern Australia. It is highly valued by both commercial and recreational fisheries throughout its range, and is particularly susceptible to overexploitation due to its slow-growth, likelihood to form spawning aggregations and large body size. Catch data indicate that this species declined by 69% and 80% over recent 8 and 15 year periods in the two separate jurisdictions in which it is fished. Due to increasing fishing effort in deep waters, these declines are expected to continue in to the future. There are several fishery regulations implemented by New South Wales (NSW) and Queensland state fisheries authorities, but enforcement in the offshore grounds where these fisheries operate is not considered sufficient. In addition, uncertainty surrounding key data on life history parameters and catch and effort has prevented the development of a sustainable fishery management plan. Therefore, this species is suspected to have undergone global-level declines approaching 30% over most of the past generation length, which is estimated to be about 23 years, and this decline is expected to continue in to the future over the next two generation lengths. It is listed as Near Threatened since it nearly meets the thresholds for Vulnerable A4bd. Reducing fishing effort on this species as well as conducting research on its age and growth are strongly recommended. Further research is also needed on spawning behaviour and to resolve taxonomic confusion with Hyporthodus octofasciatus.
habitat: This species inhabits deeper rocky reefs and hard bottoms on the continental shelf and upper slope. Juveniles and smaller individuals occur in shallower water than adults and/or larger individuals. It primarily consumes fish, crustaceans and molluscs (Pogonoski et al. 2002). Its maximum recorded total length is 157 cm and weight 66 kg, although individuals landed by fishers closer to 180 cm and well over 100 kg have been reported (Sumpton et al. 2013). This species is a protogynous hermaphrodite, and females mature between 70 and 80 cm in length and 6 to 8 kg in weight (Rowling 1994). It may form spawning aggregations in deep water, but this requires further study (Pogonoski et al. 2002, Sumpton et al. 2013). The longevity and age at maturity of this species are poorly understood due to the lack of studies conducted on offshore species such as this, but the oldest aged individual to date was 28 years (Sumpton et al. 2013). However, its actual longevity is likely to be greater than this (M. Craig and D. Pollard pers. comm. 2018). According to Wakefield et al. (2015), Hyporthodus octofasciatus, which is similar to this species, has an estimated longevity of 47-56 years off Western Australia and an age at first sexual maturity of 6 years. Based on these data and general knowledge of deep-water grouper life history, we suspect an age at first maturity of around 6 years and a longevity of about 40 years for H. ergastularius, and one generation length is therefore estimated to be around 23 years (D. Pollard pers. comm. 2018).
threats: This species is susceptible to overexploitation, especially considering its intrinsic biological and life history characteristics that include the probable formation of spawning aggregations, large body size, late maturity onset and long-life span (Sumpton et al. 2013).
population:
The majority of the global population of this species is concentrated over only about 1,000 km of the south-eastern Australian coastline. The stock of this species is currently managed across two separate jurisdictions, and it is not known if this stock may represent genetically separate populations (Sumpton et al. 2013). Up to around 2000, about 95% of the overall catch of this species was taken by the New South Wales deepwater dropline fishery where it is the dominant species in that fishery (Yearsley et al. 1999). The species began to be targeted more intensively from around 1990, and for the first decade (1990-2000) catches in the dropline fishery fluctuated between 12 and 28 metric tonnes per year, before attaining a peak of around 34 mt between 2001 and 2003. Annual catches then declined rapidly over the following four years to a low of around 8 mt by 2006-2007, and have remained at an average of only about 10.5 mt over the eight year period since then and up to 2014. This represents an estimated decline of 69% over the 15 years up to 2014. The species is considered to be very susceptible to hook and line fishing, and "reasonable" catch rates were only maintained by fishing previously unexploited grounds or grounds which had been “rested” from fishing for some time, which possibly explains the fluctuations in catches prior to 2001-2003 (Rowling 1996). In addition, the New South Wales stock may experience fluctuations in recruitment strength from year to year (Rowling 1995) and the high proportion of immature individuals in the overall catch of this species is cause for concern (Rowling 1996). For example, female sexual maturity is estimated to occur at lengths of between 70-80 cm, but the majority of the landed individuals were between only 40-70 cm in length, with most of the smallest individuals likely being taken as trap and trawl by-catch (Rowling 1994). Recreational catches in New South Wales were estimated to have totalled less than ~10 mt in the past, though catch and effort may be increasing. 

This species is also the main target of the southern Queensland deepwater linefishery, where it is considered to be the species “most at risk of overexploitation” (Sumpton et al. 2013). Concerns about the sustainability of Queensland’s deepwater fisheries have been highlighted for many years and both commercial and recreational fishery sectors are believed to have increased fishing effort in deeper water. From 1992-1999, annual landings in the Queensland deepwater line fishery ranged from 0 mt to about 16 mt (Pogonoski et al. 2002, Sumpton and Ryan 2004), continued to fluctuate between 2 and 15 mt up to 2007, peaked at about 50 mt in 2008 and then rapidly and continuously declined to about 10 mt by 2011 (Sumpton et al. 2013), and this decline may likely be continuing to the present day. This represents a decline of about 80% over the 8 years up to 2011. Catch per unit effort appears to follow the same trends as the catch, although much uncertainty is associated with the reporting of these data, and there is evidence that spawning aggregations may be or have been targeted at least in the southern Queensland fishery. This species is known to be significantly under-reported in commercial logbooks (Sumpton et al. 2013). 

Overall, this species is therefore estimated to have undergone 69% and 80% declines over recent 8 and 15 years periods in New South Wales and Queensland, respectively, due to overexploitation. Since effort is known to be increasing, it is likely that this decline will continue into the future. Considering the uncertainty in the data, it is suspected that this species has declined globally by nearly 30% or more over most of the past generation length, which is estimated to be about 23 years, and without significant improvements to fisheries management this decline is expected to continue into the future over the next two generation lengths.
range: This species is endemic to southeastern Australia from Lady Musgrave Island, southern Queensland, south to Eden, southern New South Wales (OZCAM database accessed February 2018). There are outlying records to the south from Bass Strait off Victoria and to the north from Dunk Island off northern Queensland (though see taxonomic notes re H. octofasciatus for further comments on the unlikelihood of its presence in the latter area). Specimens reported from the Lord Howe and Norfolk Ridges in the Tasman Sea (Bray 2018) are also more likely to be H. octofasciatus. Reports of two large specimens from a fish market in Western Samoa require verification, but are also likely to be misidentifications of Hyporthodus octofasciatus (Pogonoski et al. 2002). Its generally accepted depth range is 15-370 metres, though a small juvenile was recently photographed in Nelson Bay, Port Stephens (NSW) at a depth of 7 metres (Bray 2018).
useTrade: This is a highly-valued species in both commercial (mainly deep water line) and to a lesser extent recreational fisheries throughout its range (Sumpton et al. 2013, D. Pollard pers. comm. 2016). Smaller individuals can be taken as by-catch in fish traps and prawn trawls in shallower waters. Some of the catch from south-eastern Queensland is reportedly now being exported to Asia (D. Pollard pers. comm. 2016).
conservationActions: This species is a component of managed fisheries in both New South Wales and southern Queensland, which includes limited commercial entry, total allowable catch limits, gear restrictions and closed areas where fishing is not permitted (Sumpton et al. 2013). There is a recreational bag limit of fivefish in possession in New South Wales, but there is no minimum legal size. In southern Queensland, there is a bag limit of five groupers (of any species), and a size limit of 35 cm for all grouper species. However, compliance with fishing regulations is an issue as these fishing grounds are relatively remote, which causes enforcement to be more difficult to implement (Sumpton et al. 2013). Rowling (1995) suggested that reducing the catches of smaller fish would be beneficial to the stock. If spawning aggregations are located, then they should be protected from fishing (Pogonoski et al. 2002). It is recommended that catch trends be carefully monitored over coming years, and especially to improve estimates of catch per unit effort. There seem to be few or no marine protected areas which include the adult populations of this species, particularly as it occurs in deep water. More research is urgently needed on its biology and ecology, and especially on its age and growth (Sumpton et al. 2013, D. Pollard pers. comm. 2018).

rationale:
This is an amended version of the 2005 assessment. The assessment has been amended to reflect newly available information which places this species in the genus Raja (formally Malacoraja). 
This assessment is based on the information published in the 2005 shark status survey (Fowler et al. 2005).

This demersal batoid is one of the most abundant elasmobranchs in the Northeastern Atlantic. The Thornback Skate (Raja clavata) is widespread, although the taxonomy of specimens from South Africa requires additional study. There is some limited evidence of a decline in landings in the northern part of the East Atlantic range of this species and management of the fishery is required. However, declines have not been as serious as reported for other large rajids.
habitat: The Thornback Skate is a demersal coastal species which inhabits a variety of substrates, including mud, sand, shingle, gravel and rocky areas, in water down to 300 m, although it is most abundant in 10-60 m of water off coastal areas (Wheeler 1969, Stehmann and Buerkel 1984). Rousset (1990a) studied the elasmobranch assemblage off the coast of Brittany and found that R. clavata was the most abundant rajid due to the fact that it was able to inhabit this range of benthic habitats. Thornback Skate is the second most important species, after the Smallspotted Catshark (Scyliorhinus canicula), in the demersal elasmobranch assemblage in the northern Bristol Channel and constitutes between 7.4-8.8% of the elasmobranch biomass (Ellis unpubl.). The age and growth of this species have been studied by examining the vertebrae of fish caught in the Bristol Channel (Ryland and Ajayi 1984), although Brander and Palmer (1985), using length-frequency analysis, have indicated inconsistencies for the smaller sized fish used in this work. Ryland and Ajayi (1984) gave maximum age and length of 12 years and 1,047 mm (k = 0.090). Vertebral growth rings have been shown to be annual (Holden and Vince 1973). Growth has also been estimated from tagging studies (Holden 1972). Validated age studies of specimens from the southern North Sea have shown thornback skates to have a maximum length of 118 cm for females and 98cm for males (Walker 1998). The size at maturity for females and males have been estimated at 45-50 cm disc width (DW) and 38-44 cm DW (Fitzmaurice 1974); 85 cm total length (TL) (54 cm DW) and 75 cm TL (48 cm DW) (Capapé 1976); 45 cm DW and 42 cm DW (Nottage and Perkins 1983) and 59 cm TL and 60 cm TL (Ryland and Ajayi 1984). Walker (1998) estimated length at 50% maturity to be 77 cm TL for males and 68 cm TL for females. The corresponding ages at 50% maturity were eight and seven years. It has been reported that R. clavata first spawn in their fifth year (Ryland and Ajayi 1984). Eggs are laid during a protracted breeding season from February to September (Holden 1975), with a peak in May and June. However, this is for the population as a whole and the egg-laying period for individual fish may be shorter. Ellis and Shackley (1995) maintained one female in captivity and reported that egg laying lasted six weeks, with a mean egg-laying rate of 1.07 eggs per day, a pair of eggs being laid on alternate days. These data concur with the observations of Holden (1971). Development lasts 16-20.5 weeks (Ellis and Shackley 1995), although this period may vary with temperature. The young hatch at a length of 10-13 cm. The nursery areas used are coastal, estuarine and tidal flat areas (e.g., the Wash and Thames estuary in the UK). The fecundity of R. clavata in British waters has been estimated at 150 eggs per year (Holden 1971), 140 eggs per year (Holden 1975) and 100 eggs per year (minimum of 62-74) (Ryland and Ajayi 1984). Capapé (1976, 1977a) estimated a fecundity of 70-167 eggs per year in Tunisian waters, although it may be as low as 48 (Ellis and Shackley 1995). The feeding habits have been well documented from many areas over its geographical range, including British waters (Holden and Tucker 1974, Ajayi 1982, Ellis et al. 1996), Ireland (Fitzmaurice 1974), France (Du Buit 1968, 1978-79, Quiniou and Andriamirado 1979), Portugal (Marques and Re 1978, Cunha et al. 1986), the Mediterranean (Capapé 1975, 1977; Abdel-Aziz 1986), the Southeast Atlantic waters off Namibia (Macpherson 1986) and southern Africa (Ebert et al. 1991). Young and juvenile R. clavata predominantly eat small crustaceans, such as shrimps, mysids, amphipods and small crabs. Larger specimens prey on larger crustaceans, including prawns and crabs and will also consume fish. The migratory habits have been studied by Steven (1936) who found that very little movement occurred, especially in young fish, with 71% of tagged fish moving less than five miles. Fish tagged in the southern North Sea also showed a sedentary pattern, with 80% being recaptured within 40 nautical miles of their release position (Walker et al. 1997). The recapture percentage was nearly 30%. Fitzmaurice (1974) studied the populations within two bays in Ireland and reported a sex ratio of 1:1 and, of 71 tagged, eight (11.3%) recaptures. Rousset (1990b) observed that mature females were more common in exposed areas and juveniles and mature males were more common in more sheltered areas.
threats: Thornback Skate is a very important component of demersal fisheries in most European waters and is taken by trawl and gillnet, particularly as bycatch. There is or has been limited directed longlining and netting for the species. Landings of this species are not known, as landings of all rajids are combined in the records (ICES 1958-1987). Holden (1963) looked at the species composition of rajids landed by commercial trawlers at Milford Haven and Fleetwood, UK, during 1961 and 1962 and R. clavata accounted for 34.9% and 12.72% respectively. There is no evidence of severe population depletion, as has been documented for the Common Skate (Dipturus batis), although landings are considered to be in decline and a management strategy is required. Thornback Skates are also regularly caught by recreational anglers, although mortality from this source of fishing pressure will be of little impact for the population as a whole, particularly in areas where catch and release is practised.
range: The Thornback Skate, or roker, is one of the most abundant rajids in north European coastal waters and can be the dominant rajid in commercial landings and research vessel catches (Rousset 1990a, Ellis unpubl.). It is widely distributed from Iceland and Norway (south of the Arctic Circle), to the North Sea (where it is now less abundant in south-eastern areas (Walker 1998), the Mediterranean, the western Black Sea, Madeira, the Atlantic coasts of Africa, and as far south as South Africa and the south-western Indian Ocean (Stehmann 1995). The status of this species in West and South African waters, and its relationship with Raja (Raja) cf. clavata, which is reported from the waters off Namibia and southern Africa (Macpherson 1986, Ebert et al. 1991, Smale and Cowley 1992) needs further research.
conservationActions: Several of the UK's local Sea Fisheries Committees have by-laws for a minimum landing size (e.g., 40 cm DW in the Southern and the Kent and Essex Sea Fisheries Districts). Such localised management initiatives will not, however, be of significant effect in conserving regional populations. Due to European rajid fisheries being a component of multispecies fisheries, which also target several species of flatfish and gadoid, gear restriction using mesh size is not a viable management measure. Minimum landing sizes have been implemented in some areas of the UK by Sea Fisheries Committees.

rationale:
This is an amended version of the 2006 assessment to accommodate recent taxonomic revision of the genus Rhinobatus.

This is an apparently rare coastal rhinobatid endemic to Zanzibar, Tanzania, but known only from the type specimens. It is a large species of guitarfish, reaching at least 205 cm total length. Survey work has failed to locate other individuals in and around Zanzibar, the adjacent Tanzanian coast and the wider East African region. Coastal rhinobatids are susceptible to capture in a variety of fishing gear including trawl, gillnet, line and seine net and their occurrence along inshore areas of the continental shelf makes these rays an easy target for such fisheries. Target fisheries for guitarfish currently exist in several countries particularly in the Indo-West Pacific and declines in some species have been documented. When taken, flesh is utilized and the fins of larger species (possibly including A. zanzibarensis) enter the international fin trade for the Asian market. Coastal waters of Zanzibar are consistently fished by artisanal fishers mostly using traditional vessels. A wide variety of gear is employed including drag nets, spear, handline, seine nets and fish traps. Rays are known to be caught and retained and shark fin is marketed. If A. zanzibarensis is restricted to the inshore continental shelf around Zanzibar, the majority of its available habitat would be fished by a variety of gear. Various regulations govern gear use in Zanzibar, but there are issues with enforcement and so illegal and sometimes destructive fishing activities still occur. The present level of fishing in coastal areas of Zanzibar is of concern for this large, rare and limited range guitarfish. If however, the species is found to have a wider range into deeper waters, it may presently persist due to the limited range of traditional fishing vessels. Fishing pressure outside coastal areas is minimal at present in Tanzania. Although a little known species, given its large size, rarity, and restricted range as presently known, the species is assessed as Near Threatened. There is an equal possibly that the species may no longer exist in the wild, or that remnant populations presently exist beyond the range of traditional fisheries operating around Zanzibar. Further research (including continued market and fishing surveys) is required to document habitat, distribution and to locate any remnant populations.
habitat:
A rare, little known coastal species. A large species, Norman (1926) reporting a female of 205 cm TL.

Like other rhinobatids, aplacental viviparous, but biology is unknown. Studied Rhinobatos species have an annual reproductive cycle with litter sizes of 2 to 16 pups.

Life history parameters
Age at maturity (years): Unknown.
Size at maturity (total length cm): Unknown.
Longevity (years): Unknown.
Maximum size (total length): 205 cm TL (Norman 1926).
Size at birth (cm): Unknown.
Average reproductive age (years): Unknown.
Gestation time (months): Unknown.
Reproductive periodicity: Unknown.
Average annual fecundity or litter size: Unknown.
Annual rate of population increase: Unknown.
Natural mortality: Unknown.
threats:
Coastal rhinobatids are susceptible to capture in a variety of fishing gear including trawl, gillnet, line and seine net and their occurrence along inshore areas of the continental shelf makes these rays an easy target for such fisheries. Target fisheries for guitarfish currently exist in several countries particularly in the Indo-West Pacific and declines in some species have been documented. When taken flesh is utilized and the fins of larger species enter the international fin trade for the Asian market. It is probable that the fins of A. zanzibarensis enter the international market, as the large wedgefish Rhynchobatus djiddensis is commercially exploited for its fins in Tanzanian waters in bottom-set gillnets, when taken in prawn trawls and possibly also by spearfishermen (Barnett 1997), suggesting that R. zanzibarensis, as a large guitarfish, is also a desirable catch.

Coastal waters of Zanzibar are consistently fished by artisanal fishers mostly using traditional vessels (Jiddawi and Öhman 2002). A wide variety of gear is employed including drag nets, spear, handline, seine nets and fish traps (Jiddawi and Öhman 2002). Rays are known to be caught and retained and shark fin is marketed (Jiddawi and Öhman 2002). If A. zanzibarensis is restricted to the inshore continental shelf around Zanzibar, the majority of its available habitat would be fished by a variety of gear. Various regulations govern gear use in Zanzibar, but there are issues with enforcement and so illegal and sometimes destructive fishing activities still occur (Jiddawi and Öhman 2002). The present level of fishing in coastal areas of Zanzibar is of concern for this large, rare and limited range guitarfish. If however, the species is found to have a wider range into deeper waters, it may presently persist due to the limited range of traditional fishing vessels. Fishing pressure outside coastal areas is minimal at present in Tanzania (Jiddawi and Öhman 2002).
population: As presently known, an extremely rare species, known only from a few specimens. Survey work has failed to locate other individuals in and around Zanzibar, the adjacent Tanzanian coast and the wider East African region. There is no knowledge of population size or structure.
range: Extremely limited range in the Western Indian, only reported off Zanzibar Island, Tanzania. Narrow range supported by the fact that efforts to find additional specimens in fish markets and in underwater surveys in other areas have failed to produce any other individuals.
conservationActions:
Further research (including continued market and fishing surveys) is required to document habitat, distribution and to locate any remnant populations. Elasmobranch catches in Zanzibar artisanal fisheries need documenting, including the degree of finning.

The development and implementation of management plans (national and/or regional e.g., under the FAO International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks: IPOA-Sharks) are required to facilitate the conservation and sustainable management of all chondrichthyan species in Tanzania. At the time of writing, Tanzania had not made progress towards developing a National Plan of Action.

rationale:
This is an amended version of the 2014 assessment to accommodate recent taxonomic revision of the genus Rhinobatus.

The Shovelnose Guitarfish (Pseudobatos productus) is a medium-sized guitarfish that inhabits shallow coastal waters in the Eastern Central Pacific from central California (USA) to the southern Gulf of California (Mexico). This species is typically found at depths <12 m, but has been recorded to 91.5 m. This guitarfish has a generation length of 9 years and exhibits an annual reproductive cycle with litters of 1-16 pups.

In Mexican waters, this species is taken in directed artisanal elasmobranch fisheries in both the Gulf of California and on the Pacific coast of Baja California, and is also retained as bycatch by demersal trawls and gillnets. This guitarfish is the most heavily targeted batoid in north Pacific Mexico. Catches of the Bahía Almejas fishery in Baja California Sur declined severely following a large increase in effort during the mid- to late 1990s. In Californian waters, recreational fishing derby data from Elkhorn Slough, central California suggest that this species has declined by 74% over three generations. Landings in California have also declined, although these declines do not necessarily correspond to population declines. In 2012, an annual seasonal closure on elasmobranch fishing was implemented from May 1 to July 31 along the Mexican Pacific coast, and other recent monitoring and management changes have been made in Mexico. Nonetheless, given ongoing target and bycatch fisheries for this species in Mexico, an absence of species-specific data in Mexican logbooks, and recreational fishing derbies in the United States, the Shovelnose Guitarfish is is assessed as Near Threatened, as we suspect that this species has declined by nearly 30% over the past three generations.
habitat:
The Shovelnose Guitarfish commonly inhabits sandy or muddy shallow waters of bays, sloughs, and estuaries, typically in coastal waters shallower than 12 m, but also to depths of 91.5 m (Feder et al. 1974, Love 1996). This species also occurs commonly in intertidal waters (<1 m depth) to feed (J. Bizzarro, pers. comm. 2016). In Baja California, gravid females come during the spring and summer to give birth in shallow bays and estuaries (Villavicencio-Garayzar 1993, Márquez-Farías 2007). Based on fisheries landings, males arrive in late summer to mate and then all individuals depart in the fall (Bizzarro et al. 2009).

Considerable information on reproductive biology and age-growth has been gathered for this species from both the west coast of Baja California Sur (BCS) in Mexico (Villavicencio-Garayzar 1993, González-García 1998, Downton-Hoffmann 2001, Márquez-Farías 2007) and from Californian waters in the USA (Miller and Lea 1972, Eschmeyer et al. 1983, Timmons and Bray 1997). Life history parameters of Shovelnose Guitarfish can be quite different based on the location that the samples were taken, and the method of measuring the parameters.

This species is aplacental viviparous (bears live young nourished from a yolk sac) and has a continuous reproductive cycle. Gestation takes 4 to 5 months (Márquez-Farías 2007). Pregnant females may contain uterine capsules and large ripe ova in both ovaries at the same time, but the reproductive cycle is annual with a single litter per year (Villavicencio-Garayzar 1993, Márquez-Farías 2007). Fecundity has been reported as 1 to 10 pups/litter (average five; Márquez-Farías 2007) and 6 to 16 pups/litter (Villavicencio-Garayzar 1993), with a 1:1 sex ratio at birth (Márquez-Farías 2007). Size at birth ranges from 20 to 24 cm TL (in San Quintin Bay, Baja California, Mexico; Villavicencio-Garayzar 1993), 15 cm TL (in Almejas Bay, Baja California Sur, Mexico; Eschmeyer et al. 1983), and 17.5 cm TL (in Sonora, Mexico; Márquez-Farías 2007). Multiple estimates also exist for size at maturity ranging from 57–99 cm TL for females (Timmons and Bray 1997, Villavicencio-Garayzar 1993, Downton-Hoffman 1996, Márquez-Farías 2007) and <63–110 cm TL for males (Timmons and Bray 1997, Villavicencio-Garayzar 1993, Downton-Hoffman 1996, Dubois 1981, Talent 1985, Márquez-Farías 2007). Age at maturity is estimated at 7 years for females and 7 to 8.4 years for males (Timmons and Bray 1997). Maximum size is estimated at 156 cm TL for females (Baxter 1966) and 114 cm TL for males (Downton-Hoffman 1996). Longevity is estimated at 11 years (Timmons and Bray 1997). Generation length is estimated to be 9 years (Timmons and Bray 1997).
threats:
The primary threat to the Shovelnose Guitarfish is most likely the directed artisanal fisheries in Mexico (Bizzarro et al. 2007). Pregnant females are frequently caught in the artisanal gillnet fishery on the west coast of Baja California (Salazar-Hermoso and Villavicencio 1999, Bizzarro 2005) and the coast of Sonora, Gulf of California, Mexico (Márquez-Farias 2002). Gillnet selectivity analysis revealed that mature individuals were most susceptible to capture in the fishery (Márquez-Farías 2005, Márquez-Farías 2011). Neonates and small juveniles are much less abundant in the directed fishery (Bizzarro et al. 2009, Cartamil et al. 2011).

The Shovelnose Guitarfish is also taken as bycatch in demersal trawls (especially shrimp trawlers), and gillnets in Mexican waters. The high catches of mature individuals either by the directed artisanal fishery or in indirect landings most likely are having an effect on the population structure as well as the overall abundance of guitarfish (Bizzarro et al. 2007, Márquez-Farías 2011). In the Bahía Almejas summer batoid fishery, this species is the most abundant in June landings (ca. 51% of catch, catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) = 21.8 individuals/vessel/day) landings and third most abundant in August landings (ca. 13%, CPUE=2.8 individuals/vessel/day). Catches of the fishery in Bahía Almejas, Baja California has steeply declined after greatly increased effort in the mid to late 1990s and its abundance has almost surely declined in this region as a result of fishing pressure. In Sonora, Mexico, the Shovelnose Guitarfish is the most abundant batoid landed in the artisanal elasmobranch fishery (Márquez-Farías 2002, Bizzarro et al. 2009). In addition, the fishing derbies of Elkhorn Slough seem to have similarly drastically reduced the abundance of Shovelnose Guitarfish (Carlisle et al. 2007).

In the United States, this species is taken by recreational anglers to a limited extent and occasionally sold in local Asian markets in southern California.

The second largest threat to the Shovelnose Guitarfish is habitat modification. Many embayments and estuaries in the northwest Pacific region of Mexico are being modified for shrimp farming. Since this species uses these areas for feeding and reproduction, this could have a detrimental impact on its abundance in affected areas. In United States waters, many of the bays and estuaries have been modified, degraded or destroyed, restricting the coastal areas that can be used by the Shovelnose Guitarfish. It is unclear, however, whether this would significantly impact the survival, fecundity or population resilience of the species.
population:
There is little information on the population status or trend for this species. Along the coast of northwest Mexico, including the Pacific coast of Baja California and around the Gulf of California, the Shovelnose Guitarfish is the most commonly landed elasmobranch species in the artisanal fisheries (Márquez-Farias 2002, Smith et al. 2009, Cartamil et al. 2011, Ramirez-Amaro et al. 2013). In Bahía Almejas, Baja California elasmobranch fisheries reportedly targeted aggregations of this species. Despite this, researchers did not observe any negative effects on this species at the time of these surveys (1991-1995; Salazar-Hermoso and Villavicencio-Garayzar 1999). The Shovelnose Guitarfish was also the elasmobranch species most captured in the upper Gulf of California (Marquez-Farias 2002, Bizzarro et al. 2009, Smith et al. 2009). It should be noted, however, that catch data reported as the Shovelnose Guitarfish may also include catches of Banded Guitarfish (Zapteryx exasperata). High fishing pressure recorded in this species could cause population declines, so this species should be monitored closely (Ramirez-Amaro et al. 2013).

Mexican logbooks from fisheries targeting elasmobranchs group guitarfish under a general category, and these data show that reported guitarfish catches have ranged from >1,000 metric tonnes (mt) live weight in 2007, 2009, 2010, and 2014; to between 846 and 937 mt in 2006, 2008, 2011, 2012, and 2013 (CONAPESCA 2006-2014). Changes in Mexican fishing effort are difficult to detect, but effort is estimated to be relatively stable. Because all guitarfishes are grouped under a general category, population declines for this species may go undetected.

Landings of the Shovelnose Guitarfish are monitored in Californian waters, and have declined from 9.26-10.31 tonnes (t) in 2000-2002 to 0.13–1.05 t in 2012–2014 (California Department of Fish and Wildlife 2000-2014). This is likely due to the reduction and redistribution of fishing pressure in the range of this species, and thus may not be correlated with a decline in abundance in Californian waters. In Elkhorn Slough, California, historical data from fishing derbies indicate that catches of the Shovelnose Guitarfish declined by 78% over three generations from the 1950s to the 1970s, and by the mid-1990s catches had undergone a 92% decline from 1950s levels (Carlisle et al. 2007). However, these declines were recorded at the northern extent of this species range, and may be the result of changing environmental conditions, rather than a population decline driven by fishing. In southern California, the Shovelnose Guitarfish was found to be abundant in a small, restored coastal habitat (Farrugia et al. 2011) as well as in San Diego Bay (Allen et al. 2002).
range: This species is reported in coastal waters from San Francisco Bay, California to the southern Gulf of California, Mexico (Miller and Lea 1972, Eschmeyer et al. 1983).
useTrade: This species is utilized for its meat and fins.
conservationActions:
There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place in United States or Mexican waters.

In Mexico, a moratorium on the allocation of additional elasmobranch fishing permits was enacted in 1993, but no formal management plan has been implemented for the Shovelnose Guitarfish specifically. Mexico implemented a National Plan of Action (NPOA) in 2004, and began reporting some species-specific data to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). However, only 10% of catches were reported to species level in 2010, with most being grouped by order and above. The United States implemented a NPOA in 2001, with 25% of catches being reported to species level (Fischer et al. 2012). In 2007 Mexican officials approved Regulation NOM-029 which required fisheries targeting sharks to establish a logbook system, regulate fishing gear for small and medium sized fleets, and define areas where fishing is restricted. This species is recorded in these target fisheries, along with other guitarfish species, under the general category of "pez guitarra". In 2012 Mexico also developed a fishing ban on the Pacific Coast that takes place from May 31 to July 31. These efforts should help improve species-specific data, and provide an essential basis for detecting fishery trends and are needed throughout the species’ range.

In Californian waters, a network of 29 marine protected areas (MPAs) were implemented in 2007 under California's Marine Life Protection Act, representing approximately 204 square miles (~18%) of state waters in the central coast region (California Department of Fish and Wildlife 2000–2014). Due to these MPAs, most trawlers are restricted to operating in deeper waters, and only in central and northern California. As a result, fishing effort in the California trawl fishery has been reduced, and catches of this species have also likely been reduced (D. Ebert pers. obs. 2007). Finally, restoration of coastal habitats along the California coast provides areas for Shovelnose Guitarfish to feed, breed and escape predators, and there is evidence that these restored habitats are being used by this species (Farrugia et al. 2011).

rationale: The Merauke Stingray (Hemitrygon longicauda) is a small (to at least 37 cm disc width) ray that occurs in southern Papua New Guinea and West Papua, Indonesia in the Western Central Pacific Ocean. It is demersal in shallow water, possibly to a depth of 40 m. It is taken as bycatch in subsistence, artisanal, and commercial fisheries with trawl, gillnet, and line gear and retained for human consumption. Moderate inshore fishing pressure is present throughout this species' range, although no adults are captured in the PNG trawl fishery, and it has some refuge from fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Merauke Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (32 years) due to actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Merauke Stingray is benthic on soft substrate mainly nearshore in shallow water, possibly to a depth of 40 m (Last et al. 2016b, Weigmann 2016, White et al. 2019). It reaches a maximum size of at least 37 cm disc width (DW), possibly larger as adults have not been recorded (Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is likely viviparous and size-at-birth is ~12 cm DW (Last et al. 2016b, White et al. 2019). Little else is known about it's biology. Generation length is inferred from a similar sized ray that occurs in in similar latitude and habitats, that is, the Speckled Maskray (Neotrygon picta), that has a generation length of 10.8 years (Jacobsen and Bennett 2010).
threats:
The Merauke Stingray is captured in trawl, gillnet, and line fisheries and retained for human consumption.There is little unfished area within its distribution (M.I. Grant and A. Sianipar unpubl. data 2020). The Merauke Stingray's eastern distribution overlaps with the Gulf of Papua Prawn Trawl Fishery (GOPPTF) in Papua New Guinea (PNG). This species is caught incidentally in the GOPPTF, and elasmobranch bycatch survival in general for this fishery is reported as low, at ~4% (White et al. 2019). This species is the 4th most common ray landed in the GOPPTF, with only immature individuals captured, including neonates (White et al. 2019). In artisanal fisheries in the Western Province, there is heavy inshore gillnetting around Daru where this species is observed in local markets (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2020). In the Gulf Province, PNG, artisanal and subsistence fisheries mostly operate in low salinity waters of river estuaries, and very little interaction with this species is observed (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2020). This species may also be impacted by future proposed developments in the Gulf of Papua, PNG. There is presently inshore sand mining interest in the northeastern Gulf of Papua and intent to build a dam in the Wabo River within the Purari River basin (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2020, GDW 2020). 

In the Indonesian part of its range, the Merauke Stingray overlaps entirely with a large demersal gillnet fishery (A. Sianipar unpubl. data 2020). This fishery operates throughout the depth range and distribution of this species, which uses small mesh sizes in which the Merauke Stingray would likely be caught (A. Sianipar unpubl. data 2020).
population: There is no population trend data for this species. Immature individuals are commonly landed in the Gulf of Papua Prawn Trawl Fishery, (GOPPTF) in Papua New Guinea (PNG) with no adults captured (White et al. 2019). Actual levels of exploitation are moderate across the range of this species and it has refuge from fishing pressure in parts of its range. It is suspected that the Merauke Stingray has undergone a 20–29% population reduction over the last three generation lengths (32 years) and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Merauke Stingray is endemic to southern New Guinea from Dolok, Indonesia to Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea in the Western Central Pacific (Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: The flesh of the Merauke Whipray is used fresh or salted and dried for human consumption (Last et al. 2010). In Papua New Guinea, almost all elasmobranch bycatch is retained for consumption or sale in local markets (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions: No specific conservation measures are in place. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Red Stingray (Hemitrygon akajei) is a medium-sized (to 90 cm disc width) ray endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from Russia to China. It is demersal on the continental shelf from estuarine inshore waters to a depth of 100 m. The species is a target and bycatch of multiple fishing gears including trawl, set net, gillnet, and longline and retained for human consumption; it is an economically important species in Japan. It is common in Japan, abundant in South Korea, and commonly landed in Taiwan and China, although anecdotally there has been a slight decrease in landings in China in the past 10 years. Reconstructed catches of this species in Taiwan indicate a decline of 65% over the past three generation lengths (36 years), however, it is difficult to infer a population trend as the decline in catches coincided with a decline in fishing effort. Historic and current fishing pressure is high across the species' entire range, yet it is still common and abundant. This species has a very high biological productivity, which would provide resilience to fishing pressure and may account for its continued high abundance in areas where it is commercially targeted. Despite this abundance, there are some declines in landings of this species and the high levels of fishing pressure across its entire range and overfishing in parts of its range are a cause for concern. It is suspected that the Red Stingray is close to reaching the population reduction threshold due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Red Stingray is demersal on the continental shelf on sandy habitats at depths of 0–100 m (Last et al. 2016b, A. Yamaguchi, and S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). It can tolerate fluctuating salinities in estuaries and migrates in winter to deeper waters of 50–100 m depth (Zhang et al. 2010, Furumitsu et al. 2019, A. Yamaguchi, and S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). It reaches a maximum size of 90 cm disc width (DW); males mature at 32 cm DW and females mature at 50 cm DW (Taniuchi and Shimizu 1993, Last et al. 2016b, Furumitsu et al. 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with lipid histotrophy, and it has litter sizes of 7–25 pups, an annual reproductive cycle, and size-at-birth of 11 cm DW; this fecundity is the highest reported for any batoid species with this reproductive strategy (Furumitsu et al. 2019). Ages are inferred from the related Kuhl's Maskray (Neotrygon kuhlii) that has a verified female age-at-maturity of 6.5 years and a maximum age of 17 years, resulting in a generation length of 12 years (Jacobsen and Bennett 2010).
threats:
The Red Stingray is subject to fishing pressure across its spatial and depth range. It is taken as target and bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears, including trawl, set net, gillnet, and longline and is retained for human consumption. It is an economically important species in Japan where it is targeted in some Prefectures, such as Saga and Fukuoka, usually with longline and sometimes gillnet and mostly in shallow estuarine waters. Mature females are retained as they are valued meat and males, which are often smaller, are discarded (Furumitsu et al. 2019). Post-release survival may be high as the species is considered hardy, with species retained live for market densely packed in tanks (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019).

In Ariake Bay, Japan, this species is the most commonly captured stingray taken by gillnet, demersal trawl, and longline (Furumitsu et al. 2019). It is also taken as part of a predator control program implemented in Ariake Bay in 2001 to protect shellfish. However, catch data are not available to assess the impact of the predator control program on this species (Furumitsu et al. 2019). Across Japan, demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019).

In South Korea, fishing effort has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). It increased markedly from the 1970s and in the 1990s, when the number of fishing boats increased to 75,000 in 1996 and 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive demersal trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s, the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the EEZ, and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ rose from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ peaked in 1989 at 15,900, and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The artisanal fishing effort has steadily and markedly declined for non-powered sampans but remains steady for fishing rafts (H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019).

Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation with dramatic levels of habitat loss evident in the region. In the Yellow Sea and Bohai Sea, intensive coastal development, that includes ongoing land reclamation, has led to widespread and significant loss of 35% of all intertidal habitat since the 1980s with 65% loss of tidal flats since the 1950s (Murray et al. 2014). In both the East and South China Seas, reclamation has contributed to a dramatic reduction in coastal and mangrove wetlands, with a loss of 70% of mangroves in the last 70 years in the South China Sea, where there has also been modification of up to 50% of seagrass beds (Heileman and Tang 2009, Heileman 2009).
population:
The Red Stingray is common in Japan and abundant in South Korea (Furumitsu et al. 2019, C-H Jeong unpubl. data 2019). It is commonly landed from demersal fisheries in Taiwan (Ebert et al. 2013). In China, this species is common, although anecdotally there has been a slight decrease in landings in the past 10 years (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/09/2020).

In Taiwan, the catches of the Red Stingray have been reconstructed for the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Catches showed a 65% decline from 1984 to 2014, that is, over the past three generation lengths (36 years). It is difficult to infer a population trend as the decline in catches coincided with a decline in fishing effort.

Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the spatial and depth range of the Red Stingray, yet it is still common and abundant. This species has a very high biological productivity, which would provide resilience to fishing pressure and may account for its continued high abundance in areas where it is commercially targeted (Furumitsu et al. 2019). Despite its abundance, the high levels of fishing pressure across its entire range and overfishing in parts of its range are a cause for concern and some declines in landings are noted, although it is difficult to ascertain the population trend. It is suspected that the Red Stingray is close to reaching the population reduction threshold for Vulnerable A2bd.
range: The Red Stingray is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from Russia to China, including Japan, North and South Korea, and Taiwan (Dyldin 2015, Last et al. 2016b, A. Yamaguchi and S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019).
useTrade: This species is used for human consumption, and is retained live for sale in Japan and China to increase the market value (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019, J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). In some Japanese Prefectures, such as Aichi, the market value of the liver is higher than that of meat (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions:
No specific measures are in place.
