There has been, and still is, a currently rising trend in fish consumption throughout the country and ~85% of this comes from within the Malaysian EEZ (Fowler et al. 2002, A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020).

In the Philippines, inshore demersal stocks are considered overexploited with growth overfishing apparent (Palomares and Pauly 2014, FAO 2020). Demersal stocks captured by trawl gear have declined over the past five decades with some trawl stocks nearly eliminated (FAO 2020). The commercial fleet operating in the Philippine’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1960s (2,100 vessels) to 2014 (6,400 vessels) and mostly use trawls, and ‘baby trawlers’ of ~ 3GT (Palomares et al. 2014). The small-scale fleet increased ten-fold from 1950 (~30,500 vessels) to the mid-1990s (~ 338,700 vessels) and while the fleet size has since remained relatively stable, the effort in terms of engine power has continued to rise, as has the number of subsistence vessels (Pauly et al. 2020). Across the Philippines, depending on the location, bottom trawls operate to a maximum depth of 200 m (D. Tanay unpubl. data 2020). In the Philippines, the demand for seafood has always been high with per capita fish consumption increasing over the last two decades to 34.1 kg per capita in 2013 (Helgil 2020).
population:
No data are available on the population trend of the Sulu Ring Skate. It is known mainly from research surveys in the 1990s and is occasionally caught by trawlers in eastern Borneo (Last and Lim 2010). Despite the lack of species-specific data, landings data are available on all combined sharks, rays, and skates in Sabah, Malaysia and from all combined ray species within the Philippine Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased.

In Sabah, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates showed a 37% decline from a peak of ~27,000 t in 1998 to 17,000 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Whipray (Dasyatidae) catches in Sabah showed a 48% decline from a peak of ~11,550 t in 1995 to ~6,000 t in 2014, despite constant effort (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing pressure has been increasing since the 1950s and thus the declines can be used to infer reductions in these populations in Sabah. In the Philippines, during 1976–2006, the landings of all combined ray species from municipal and commercial fisheries decreased by 76% over 16 years from 1991 to 2006. The annual landings rose from 4,160 t in 1976 to a peak of 10,990 t in 1991, then declined to 2,600 t in 2006 (NFRDI 2017). These declines in landings of rays can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort was increasing during the period of the declines in landings (Palomares and Pauly 2014).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Sulu Ring Skate (31 years), they represent declines of 60% and 66% in Sabah and 95% in the Philippines, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is moderate across the spatial and known depth range of the Sulu Ring Skate. Yet, the species is mainly known from research surveys with only occasional capture by fisheries, which suggests interactions with fisheries may be limited. The depth range is not well-defined and it may occur deeper which would provide refuge from fishing pressure. Although the Sulu Ring Skate is reported to be only occasionally captured and there is no evidence to suspect this species has declined, the ongoing fishing pressure on this species is a cause for concern. It is suspected that the Sulu Ring Skate population is close to reaching the population reduction threshold.
range: The Sulu Ring Skate is endemic to the Western Central Pacific where it is found in the Sulu Sea in eastern Borneo and the Philippines (Last and Lim 2010, Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: In eastern Borneo, Malaysia, this species is sold opportunistically (Last et al. 2010) likely for the meat for human consumption.
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In the Philippines, active fishing gears, including trawlers, were prohibited in 1998 within municipal marine waters (<3 nautical miles from shore). Trawlers within commercial waters have been required since 2010 to use Juvenile and Trashfish Excluder Devices under the Fisheries Administrative Order 237 series of 2010. (D. Tanay unpubl. data 2020), which may reduce the retention of rays (Brewer et al. 2006). Further research is needed on population size and trends, and life history, and catches should be monitored.

rationale: The African Angelshark (Squatina africana) is a small demersal shark (to 122 cm total length) that inhabits shelf and upper slope waters to 500 m depth in the Western Indian Ocean from South Africa to Somalia including Madagascar, and possibly the Gulf of Aden. This species is caught and retained as bycatch in several fisheries including industrial crustacean trawl and small-scale gillnet fisheries throughout most of its range. While the population trajectory is stable at the southern end of its range in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, it is suspected to be declining throughout the rest of its range as a result of largely unregulated trawl and gillnet fisheries. In Zanzibar, this species was reportedly the most common elasmobranch present in small-scale landings reported in 96% of fisher interviews in the mid-1990s. Later work including a recent year-long survey of 21 landings sites in Kenya, Zanzibar, and northern Madagascar did not record any individuals. Although the species may have some refuge at depth and in South Africa (where management exists and the population trajectory is suspected to be stable), a reported severe reduction in landings in Zanzibar, combined with the intensity and expanding nature of fisheries in other parts of its range, the overall susceptibility of angel sharks to population depletion due to their life-history characteristics, and declines in many other angel sharks globally in areas with similar fisheries, it is suspected that a population reduction in mature individuals of 20-30% has occurred over the past three generations (69 years) for this species. The African Angelshark is therefore assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d). Monitoring should be undertaken to ensure that this species does not become threatened in the near future.
habitat:
The African Angelshark is a demersal species that is found on the continental shelf and upper slope on sand and mud substrates, from the surf line to 494 m depth, although most specimens have been taken from 60-300 m (Compagno 1984, Ebert et al. 2013). Individuals caught in the prawn trawl fishery over the Thukela Banks have been identified as juveniles and therefore there may be a nursery area nearby (Fennessy 1994). The occasional catch (25 per annum; G. Cliff unpubl. data 2018) of this species in the KZN shark nets (east coast of South Africa) comprised mainly mature individuals of both sexes and 44% of the mature females examined were pregnant (Shelmerdine and Cliff 2006).

The species is lecithotrophic viviparous and gives birth to live young that are 28-30 cm total length (TL) with a gestation length of approximately one year and litter sizes of around six (range 1-12) (Shelmerdine and Cliff 2006). Males mature at 77-95 cm TL and females at 82-107 cm TL. Maximum known size is 122 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Although the generation length of the African Angelshark is unknown, it is suspected to be similar to the congeneric Pacific Angelshark (Squatina californica), which has a generation length of 23 years (Cailliet et al. 1992).
threats:
The African Angelshark is caught in subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries.

In South Africa, demersal trawling for prawns off the Thukela Banks, KZN overlapped with a potential nursery ground of this species (Fennessy 1994). For economic reasons this trawling has not been operational since 2010. However, similar trawling for the same target prawn species at the same depth range (<50 m) occurs in Mozambique, Kenya, Tanzania, and Madagascar, thus if these areas also serve as nurseries for African Angelshark, juveniles occurring there will be caught. Deep-water trawling effort off KZN has declined, with only two vessels regularly operating. The species has been recorded as being occasionally taken by recreational shore anglers (Bass et al. 1975, ORI unpubl. data 2018). In the KZN shark control program shark nets, the species is caught in low numbers with a significant proportion released alive (although post-release mortality is unknown).

There are no catch data for the species in either the shallow-water or deep-water prawn trawl fisheries in Mozambique; trawl fishing effort has declined slightly for the shallow-water sector but has increased considerably in the deep-water sector in recent years.

Catches recorded on the Saya-de-Malha Bank (northeast of Madagascar) were from research trawls; the (then) USSR did develop some commercial fisheries there but the rapid depletion of resources resulted in their closure, with no known commercial trawl ventures since the late 1970s (E. Romanov CAP RUN, La Réunion, pers. comm. July 2017).

The African Angelshark is taken in the shallow-water prawn trawl fishery in Tanzania and Kenya (Narriman Jiddawi, Institute of Marine Sciences, Zanzibar, pers. comm. 2003). Tanzania closed its shallow-water prawn trawl fishery in 2008 (Silas 2011), but it re-opened in 2018. The species is also caught in deep-set gillnet fisheries in Tanzania (N. Jiddawi pers. comm. 2003). Although the Tanzanian deep-water crustacean fishery closed soon after 2006 (Kizska and Van der Elst 2015), a deep-water crustacean trawl fishery has recently commenced in Kenya. Kenyan shallow-water trawling effort has varied, with several closures. Several individuals have been caught in experimental shallow and deep-water trawls in Malindi-Ungwana Bay in central Kenya (e.g. Kimani et al. 2010, Kiilu and Ndegwa 2013).

In Somalia, there has been very little survey effort, but it is likely that this species is taken by international fleets operating in Somali waters and by artisanal fishermen.
population:
In South Africa, the population is low and stable as indicated by catches in the KwaZulu-Natal (KZN) shark nets and catches in the commercial fishery. Catches in the KZN shark control nets have averaged 25 individuals per annum, with approximately 10 individuals released per year for the period 1978-2017 (G. Cliff unpublished data 2017). There was no trend in the catch of this species in these nets from 1980-2017 (N. Nakabi unpublished data 2018; see the attached Supplementary Information). In the KZN shallow water (<50 m) prawn trawl fishery on the Thukela Bank, 11 individuals were caught in 169 observed trawls from May 1989 to June 1992 when fishing was year-round. The fishery was subsequently closed from September to February inclusive. From 2003 to 2009, 52 individuals were caught in 235 observed trawls. On the deep (300-500 m) crustacean trawl grounds from 2003 to 2012, the species was recorded in 42 of 749 observed trawls (94 individuals). Catch rates were variable (0.01-0.45 individuals/trawl) and an estimated 700 individuals were caught per year in 2004 based on fishing effort at the time.

In Mozambique, during research surveys on the Dr Fridjtof Nansen, only one individual was recorded in 308 trawls from 1977 to 1983, although elasmobranchs may have been inconsistently recorded as the focus was on commercially important species; in 1990, 31 individuals were recorded in 4 of 256 observed trawls, and from 2007 to 2014, 19 individuals were recorded in 51 of 219 observed trawls. Depth range of trawls in which this species occurred ranged from 84-323 m (IMR unpubl. data 2018). The species' absence from shallower research trawls is puzzling and concerning.

In Madagascar, there were five individuals caught in three research trawls in 2009 (Alvheim et al. 2009).

African Angelsharks were commonly caught in commercial deepwater trawls off Tanzania between 2003 and 2006, although this fishery is now closed (Kizska and Van der Elst 2015). In 2012, a deep-sea (>200 m) exploratory survey was conducted off Tanzania and no individuals were encountered (TAFIRI unpubl. data 2018).

In Zanzibar, this species was reportedly the most common species of elasmobranch present in small-scale landings reported in fisher interviews in the mid-1990s, reported by 96% of fishers (Shehe and Jiddawi 1997). Later work examining small-scale landings in Zanzibar has not reported any individuals (Schaeffer 2004, Barrowclift et al. 2017). 

The species occurs in the shallow water prawn trawl grounds and in deep water off Kenya (Kimani et al. 2010, Aura et al. 2011, Kiilu and Ndegwa 2013). 
A recent year-long survey of 21 landings sites in Kenya, Zanzibar, and northern Madagascar did not record any individuals of this species (A. Temple unpubl. data 2018).

Due to reported declines in Zanzibar and the intensity of unregulated small-scale fisheries that are likely to catch the African Angelshark as bycatch across most of its range, it is suspected that this species has undergone a decline of at least 20-30% over three generation lengths (69 years). Although it has probably declined more in some parts of its range, the species does not appear to be declining in South Africa where fisheries management measures are in place, and it likely has some refuge there.

Due to reported declines in Zanzibar and the intensity of unregulated small-scale fisheries that are likely to catch the African Angelshark as bycatch across most of its range, it is suspected that this species has undergone a decline of at least 20-30% over three generation lengths (69 years). Although it has probably declined more in some parts of its range, the species does not appear to be declining in South Africa where fisheries management measures are in place, and it likely has some refuge there, as well as in deeper parts of its range elsewhere.
range: The African Angelshark occurs in the Western Indian Ocean and is currently the only species of Squatina recorded in the region. Published records of this species have been taken from waters off Somalia to Eastern Cape, South Africa, and from western Madagascar (IMR 1975, Compagno 1984, Strømme 1984, Alvheim et al. 2009, Kimani et al. 2010, Humber et al. 2017). Unpublished Soviet trawl data indicate this species' presence in the Gulf of Aden, and from the Saya-de Malha Bank northeast of Madagascar and partially within the EEZ of Mauritius (E. Romanov unpubl. data July 2017). There are further unconfirmed records from Mauritius (Fricke 1999). The provenance of a recent record from a fish landing site in India (Ambily et al. 2018) is unclear. While this paper states that the specimen was caught off Lakshadweep, Indian fishing fleets range widely in the Western Indian Ocean (south to the Chagos Archipelago and west to Africa), and hence it seems more plausible that the individual was captured outside of the Indian Exclusive Economic Zone.
useTrade: This species is likely taken and retained in artisanal, subsistence, and industrial fisheries.
conservationActions:
Currently there are no species-specific conservation measures in place for the African Angelshark. Its soft-sediment habitat falls within some extensive marine protected areas (MPAs) on the east coast of South Africa, which are closed to fishing and which are generally well policed. The release of these animals from trawl fisheries using Turtle Exclusion Devices should be implemented where possible.

Monitoring should be undertaken through field surveys and landing site surveys in order to determine population size and trends in abundance. Harvest management should be undertaken to ensure sustainable use of this species.

rationale: Lophius vomerinus has been assessed as Near Threatened because the reduction in population does not appear to be as large as 20-25%. The current rate of harvest is thought to be above the maximum sustainable yield, but there is no recent available data on how this is impacting the population numbers of this species. During the 1990s, fishing effort increased due to improved efficiency of vessels; landings also increased. More recent data is needed to determine how landings over the proposed MSY of 12,000 t has impacted the total stock. Further research and monitoring of the harvest levels and population size is needed.
habitat:
Lophius vomerinus is found on muddy substrates on the deep continental shelf, upper slopes, and subtidal zone. It feeds on small fish, including Cape Hake (Merluccius capensis) and Herring (Etrumeus whiteheadi). It ranges from depths of 150 m to around 400 m.

Lophius vomerinus is a long-lived, slow-growing species with a life span in excess of 10 years in Namibia (Maartens et al. 1999).

Spawning occurs in September in the South African subpopulation (Walmsley et al. 2005).

Distribution data indicate that individuals move into deeper water as they grow, and on the south coast of South Africa, this offshore migration is also accompanied by an eastward migration (Walmsley et al. 2005).
threats:
Lophius vomerinus is an important commercial species for Namibia. Landings of L. vomerinus contribute approximately 90% of the total Namibian Lophius landings (Walmsley et al. 2007). In 1998, Lophius spp. were the fourth most landed catch in the region, at 17,000 t. This species is also often caught as a by-catch species of the Hake fishery (Maartens and Booth 2001a).  A large number of juveniles are captured each year (Maartens et al. 2002) and models of future catches suggest that catches greater than 12,000 t per year will probably be unsustainable (Maartens and Booth 2001a).

In 1990, the annual catch of Lophius was approximately 1,500 t. This increased to more than 12,000 t in 1994. Between 1995 and 1997, this decreased to around 10,000 t, but then peaked in 1998 at 17,000 t, falling to 16,000 t in 1999 (Maartens and Booth 2001a). During the 1990s, there was an improved efficiency in fishing vessels and an increase in the number of vessels targeting this species (Maartens and Booth 2001a).
population: Fishery models (age structure production model and length-based cohort analysis model) provide evidence that Lophius vomerinus resources are over-exploited, with harvesting levels higher than those concomitant with sustainable yields (Maartens and Booth 2001a).
range: Lophius vomerinus occurs from northern Namibia (below 21° S latitude), around the southern coast of South Africa, up to Durban (Walmsley et al. 2005).
useTrade: Lophius vomerinus is an important commercial species for Namibia
conservationActions: There are some catch limitations for Lophius species off the coast of Namibia (Maartens and Booth 2001b). Management of the Monkfish fishery (which also includes L. budegassa) has involved imposing effort limits, including limited access and a restriction of 800 horse power on fishing vessels (Maartens and Booth 2001b). Further research and monitoring of the harvest levels and population size of this species is needed.

rationale: This species is uncommon in the Eastern Pacific region. It is strongly associated with mangroves, a habitat undergoing continual decline from coastal development and extraction throughout this species' distribution. Although generation length is not known for this species, there has been at least 28% decline in mangrove habitat over the past 20-25 years, the majority of which has likely occurred since the early 1990s. It is therefore listed as Near Threatened. More research is needed on this species population status and biology.
habitat: This species occurs in reduced salinity areas such as mangroves, estuaries, and mouths of rivers, on muddy and sandy substrata, to depths of 20 m. Exact generation length is not known, but based on similar species, longevity is estimated to be less than three years (Retzer 1991).
threats: The Earspot Cusk Eel is associated with mangrove habitat, which is under serious threat in many parts of its range (Jiménez 1994, Vega and Villarreal 2003). Huge mangrove areas in Panama and Costa Rica (representing at least a third of this species' range) have been completely devastated due to uncontrolled urbanization and high impact tourism in Pacific coastal areas. Surveys in other regions show that the reduction of mangroves can drive some fish species to extinction, with uncommon species more vulnerable (Ferreira et al. 2005). According to FAO (2007) there has been at least a 28% decline in mangrove area within this species' range based on country declines reported from Costa Rica, Panama, Colombia and Ecuador over the past 20-25 years, the majority of which has occurred since the early 1990s.
population: There is no population information available for the Earspot Cusk Eel. This species is poorly known and is regarded as uncommon.
range: The Earspot Cusk Eel (Ophidion fulvum) is endemic to the eastern tropical Pacific, and is found from Costa Rica to northern Peru.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for the Earspot Cusk Eel, and no marine protected areas are known to overlap with this species' range. Establishment of mangrove habitat marine protected areas is needed in the eastern tropical Pacific, including within this species' distribution. Further research and monitoring of the population size and habitat trends of this species is needed.

rationale: Hetereleotris georgegilli has been assessed as Near Threatened. This species has an extent of occurrence less than 20,000 km² and is only known from two small oceanic islands. It is unlikely to be undergoing continuing significant population declines. At present there are no known major threats for this species, although its intertidal nature could mean it is impacted by water pollution and coastal development. The number of occupied sites is unknown, but may be fewer than 10; with the potential threats from coastal development and pollution, it is inferred that there are fewer than 10 locations.  However, since there is no information to confirm continuing decline in range or habitat quality, the species does not fully qualify for a Vulnerable assessment, and is therefore it is listed as Near Threatened. Further research into the abundance of this species and its threats is needed.
habitat: Hetereleotris georgegilli is a demersal goby found on a range of substrates including coral, rock, sand and silt. It is found in the intertidal zone to a maximum depth of 10 m. It appears to be restricted to shallow, high-energy habitats (Gill 1998).
threats: Hetereleotris georgegilli is an intertidal species and is likely to be undergoing localized declines due to coastal development and water pollution.
population: There is no population information available for Hetereleotris georgegilli.
range: Hetereleotris georgegilli is found only around the Mauritian and Réunion Islands. The area in which this species occurs is less than 20,000 km² (approximately 5,572 km²). This species is only known from a few specimens. On Mauritius, is was found at three sites (Gill 1998). It was later recorded on Réunion, but information on the number of occupied sites is not available.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Hetereleotris georgegilli. However, its distribution may cover a number of marine protected areas. Further research on the abundance of this species and its potential threats is needed.

rationale: Parupeneus prophyreus is a reef-associated species endemic to the Hawaiian Archipelago, where it is found to depths of about 140 m. It is a highly prized species in a variety of fisheries, and was historically exploited by native Hawaiians. There is evidence of localised depletion in some areas and of a clear trend between human population and fish size, a proxy for fishing mortality. Recreational and commercial landings reported by the state are variable; however, the catch per unit effort of two fisheries (gill net and spear) have declined by about 33% over the past 10 years in the main Hawaiian Islands. Although about two-thirds of its distribution overlaps with marine protected and managed areas, this is in the northern part of its range, where its density is naturally low. Therefore, we infer that the population decline is less than, but approaching, the 30% threshold for listing as Vulnerable under criterion A2b. Therefore, this species is conservatively assessed as Near Threatened. Monitoring of harvest and population trends is recommended.
habitat: This species inhabits lagoon and seaward reefs, and occurs in small groups under ledges or among corals by day, dispersing at night to feed among rocks and corals on benthic crustaceans. Spawning appears to be year-round with the peak from December to July; females may spawn more than once a year (Randall 2004).  The maximum reported length is 51 cm TL (Randall 2004) and maximum age is 6 years (Moffit 1979). First reproduction occurs at about 26 cm or about 1 year, based on the age-length relationship (Moffit 1979). Age-specific fecundity is not available. The generation length is estimated at 2-3.5 years.
threats: This is a highly valued reef fish in Hawaii. Average lengths decreased, and therefore presumably fishing mortality increased, along the human population gradient in the Hawaiian islands (Nadon et al. 2015). Overexploitation is the likely cause of localized depletion in some areas (I. Williams pers. comm. 2015).
population:
There is evidence that this species has been locally depleted in some areas, particularly in shallow waters (I. Williams pers. comm. 2015).

Historical fisheries data show declines in catch per unit effort (CPUE) of this species in the lay gillnet and spear fisheries over the past 30-40 years. Gillnet landings decreased steadily from a CPUE of roughly 1.0 around 1970 to nearly 0.1 in the mid-2000s. CPUE of the spear fishery declined from 2.5 to 0.1-0.2 since the early 1980s. Trends in the commercial catch were more variable; landings increased from the beginning of the time series in 1966 to the early 1980s, declined steadily until around mid-2000s, and then increased in the most recent years (Friedlander et al. 2014). Recreational landings (in numbers harvested) were variable, and the declining trend was driven primarily by the first year of reported data, 2003 (NOAA 2016). The data recording methods have changed over time; however, these changes are not thought to be substantial over the past 10 years. Thus, we infer that the declines in CPUE in the gillnet and spear fisheries of about 33% over the past 10 years represent a population decline approaching 30%.

NOAA surveys found this species to have a density of 3.3/ha around the main Hawaiian islands and a density of 1.1/ha around the northwestern Hawaiian islands (NOAA unpublished data).
range: Parupeneus porphyreus is found throughout the Hawaiian Archipelago to depths of up to 140 m (Randall 1996, 2004, 2007).
useTrade: Parupeneus prophyreus is a preferred, targeted species of goatfish (I. Williams pers. comm. 2015), and is taken using handlines, spear and gill nets. This species represented 0.42 percent of the total fisheries catch in Hawaiian coastal fisheries (Friedlander 2004).
conservationActions: This species is found in marine protected areas throughout its range. Even small marine reserves are effective at protecting this species (Meyer et al. 2000).

rationale: This species is a shallow water species that is restricted to Fiji in the western Pacific Ocean. It has a maximum estimated Area of Occupancy of 2,619 km². It's population is likely severely fragmented, given the fragmented nature of the Fiji Islands, and that this species does not appear to be common or abundant. Due to its affinity with coral reefs, we infer that this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. It is also likely impacted by coastal development, and is collected for the aquarium trade. Given that the maximum Area of Occupancy for this species approaches the threshold for Vulnerable B2ab(iii) and there is evidence of continued habitat decline, we assess this species as Near Threatened.
habitat: This species is found among hard corals at the faces of drop-offs at reef edges or in deep pools inside reef crests. Juveniles form schools, while adults typically occur in pairs. It feeds on seaweeds and the maximum size is about 25 cm TL (Woodland 2001).
threats: There have been no confirmed population declines in this species; however, because of its affinity with coral reefs, it is inferred that this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. It is also likely impacted by coastal development in parts of its range, and is collected for the aquarium trade.
population: The population of this species is likely severely fragmented, given the fragmented nature of the Fiji Islands, and that this species does not appear to be common or abundant. The mean density from underwater visual census surveys conducted in Fiji was 29.5/ha (S. Jupiter, unpublished data).
range:
This species is known only from Fiji (Woodland 2001), with unconfirmed strays recorded to New Caledonia (Randall 2005), likely based on mis-identifications. The reported depth range for this species is 3 to 20 m depth (R. Myers pers. comm. 2015).

This species has a maximum estimated Area of Occupancy of 2,619 km² based on coral habitat estimates (UNEP-WCMC et al. 2010).
useTrade: This species is mainly caught in drive-in nets for the aquarium trade (Woodland 2001).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place; however, it has been observed in the Shark Reef Marine Reserve, Fiji (Brunnschweiler and Earle 2006).

rationale: David's Angelshark (Squatina david) is a small (to 79 cm total length) demersal shark that inhabits soft substrates on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 100-326 m in the southern Caribbean from Panama to Suriname. This species is caught in gillnets, trawls, and longlines, all of which are increasing in effort. Based on the level of fishing intensity across its range, combined with the species' suspected life history traits, and severe declines in other angel sharks globally, it is suspected that a population reduction in David's Angelshark of 20-30% has occurred over the past three generations (69 years). Therefore, this species is listed as Near Threatened, close to meeting the threshold for Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: David's Angelshark is a demersal shark that inhabits soft substrates on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 100-326 m (Paramo et al. 2015, Acero et al. 2016). This species is lecithotrophic viviparous and gives birth to live young. Size and age at maturity are unknown, but some males were mature at 78.7 cm total length (TL) (Acero et al. unpubl. data 2017). Maximum recorded size is 79 cm TL (Acero et al. 2016). Although the generation length of David's Angelshark is unknown, it is suspected to be similar to that of the congeneric Pacific Angelshark (Squatina californica), which has a generation length of 23 years (Cailliet et al. 1992).
threats:
Small-scale artisanal and commercial fisheries operate in the region, and sharks such as this species are likely taken as valuable bycatch.

In Colombia, this species is not known from shallow-water fisheries, and currently there are no deepwater fisheries in operation there.

In Venezuela, this species is caught in gillnets, trawls, and longlines (O. Lasso pers. comm. 01 June 2018). These fisheries have intensified over past decades and in the Gulf of Paria there were over 450 artisanal vessels which caught a peak of over 10,000 t of fish by the 1990s (Manickchand-Heileman et al. 2004). Industrial trawling for shrimp and demersal species was introduced in the 1940s and increased rapidly from the 1960s until the 1980s when there were 450 registered vessels (Mendoza 2015). Efforts to address over-exploitation and conflicts with artisanal fisheries led to a reduction to only 260 vessels in 2006, and an industrial trawl ban went into effect in 2009 (Mendoza 2015). Deepwater fisheries began in 2000 and have expanded geographically, and some stocks have collapsed (O. Lasso unpubl. data 2018).

The situation is likely similar in Guyana and Suriname, as fishers from Venezuela and Brazil are known to often venture into those waters. Further research in these countries is needed.
population:
This species has recently been described and there have not yet been efforts to estimate population size or structure. Surveys aboard shrimp trawling vessels in Colombia in 2009-2010 located four specimens between 262 and 326 m depth, with a frequency of occurrence of 7.4% (Paramo et al. 2015). 

Due to the intensity of unregulated trawl, gillnet, and longline fishing within its range, it is suspected that a reduction of 20-30% over the past three generations (69 years) has occurred.
range: David's Angelshark occurs in the southern Caribbean from Panama to Suriname (Acero et al. 2016). It may have a wider occurrence in the region to northwest Brazil but further research is needed in order to confirm this (Vaz and Carvalho 2018, G. Rincon unpubl. data 2018).
useTrade: Very little is known about use and trade of David's Angelshark. The species is not known to be targeted in fisheries, but is caught as incidental bycatch and likely to be retained and utilized for meat and fins in small-scale artisanal and commercial fisheries.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for David's Angelshark. Monitoring is needed to ensure that this species doesn't become threatened in the near future.

rationale: Eviota indica is only known from Reunion, Mauritius, St. Brandon's, and the Seychelles in the Western Indian Ocean. It is a shallow reef dependent species, a habitat that is declining due to pollution, tourism, climate change, and other local impacts. The AOO for this species is calculated as 3,000 km2. While this is not below the threshold for a threatened category under criterion B2 it is close to meeting this threshold. In addition, the species' distribution is likely to comprise around five locations based on the threat of coral reef degradation (with a variety of proximate causes, including increased temperatures due to climate change causing coral bleaching), and there is continuing decline in quality and extent of habitat. Therefore this species is listed as Near Threatened, nearly meeting VU B2ab(iii). However, it is important to note that it is unknown if this species can adapt to dead coral habitat which may make up a portion of the area calculated.
habitat: Eviota indica is a marine, reef dependent species that is extremely data poor. No information relating to its life history or ecology is available.
threats: This species is dependent on shallow reefs within its range. These reefs are threatened by pollution, tourism, climate change, and other local impacts.
population: There is no population information for this species. This species may be common where found.
range: Eviota indica is distributed in the Western Indian Ocean from Reunion and Mauritius to Cargados Carajos (St. Brandons) and the Seychelles (Fricke 1999). It is a shallow water species known to occupy depths of 2-10 m.
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place, however, parts of its range overlap with existing marine protected areas (IUCN-UNEP 2017).

rationale:
The Cyrano Spurdog is a small deepwater shark (to 77 cm total length), endemic to the Western Central Pacific, where it is known from only two locations off Éfate and Espiritu Santo, Vanuatu. It occurs on the upper insular slope at depths of 320-400 m. The species is known only from specimens included in the original species description, and there is a lack of contemporary information. Original collections suggest that it may, however, be locally common. The species is a probable bycatch of the targeted deepwater benthic snapper fishery around Vanuatu which operates over the depth range of the Cyrano Spurdog, although this shark occurs at the deeper limits of the fishery.

The species' extent of occurrence (EOO) is possibly <20,000 km², and at present it is known from only two locations (although further surveys may show it is more widely distributed, at least locally). There is a lack of available data to infer a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals from the deepwater snapper fishery, but with a reported litter size of 1-3 pups, the species is likely susceptible to population depletion. On the basis of its restricted geographic range and ongoing fishing pressure, the Cyrano Spurdog is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable B1ab(v)). Improved monitoring and data collection of bycatch in the deepwater snapper fishery is required.
habitat: The Cyrano Spurdog is known from the upper insular slope at depths of 320-400 m (Fourmanoir and Rivaton 1979, Ebert et al. 2013). Maximum size is 77 cm total length (TL); females mature at ~65 cm TL; size at birth ~24 cm TL; litter size of 1-3 pups (based on two gravid females) (Fourmanoir and Rivaton 1979).
threats: The species is a probable bycatch of the targeted deepwater benthic snapper fishery around Vanuatu (Amos 2007). That fishery is a significant component of fisheries production in Vanuatu, and operates over the depth range of the Cyrano Spurdog, although this shark occurs at the deeper limits of the fishery (Amos 2007).
population: A reasonable number of specimens were collected from the two locations where the species is known during initial surveys (28 from off Éfate and nine from off Espiritu Santo; Fourmanoir and Rivaton 1979), suggesting that the species may be locally common.
range: The Cyrano Spurdog is endemic to the Western Central Pacific where it is known from only two locations off Éfate and Espiritu Santo, Vanuatu (Fourmanoir and Rivaton 1979, Ebert et al. 2013). The species' extent of occurrence is possibly <20,000 km².
useTrade: No details are available on utilization of this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Further information is required on its distribution, ecology, life history, and in particular, bycatch levels in the deepwater snapper fishery.

rationale: This species has a fairly large extent of occurrence (EOO) of 29,157 km<sup>2</sup>, but it is known currently from only 11 locations and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of the habitat and population size due to a variety of threats. This species is, therefore, listed as Near Threatened as it almost qualifies for a threatened listing under criterion B1ab(iii,v).
habitat: It occurs in brackish waters and inhabits the burrows made by mud shrimps in sandy and muddy sand flats.
threats: The main threat is habitat loss through reclamation of tidal flats, shore protection, dredging and construction of weirs.
population: There is no information on population size but the population is thought to be declining slowly.
range: This species is endemic to Japan occurring at Ise Bay, along the Inland Sea of Seto and the southwestern part of the Sea of Japan and the Ariake Sea.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species. It is listed in the 2014 Red Data Book as Endangered (Ministry of the Environment Government of Japan 2015).

rationale: This species is endemic to the Ryukyu Archipelago in Japan. It has a large extent of occurrence (EOO) but a restricted area of occupancy (AOO). The known AOO is 32 km<sup>2</sup> but the true value is likely to be higher and is estimated at a maximum of 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>. There is continuing decline in habitat quality due to changes in stream habitats, and this is suspected to be causing a population decline. No other subcriteria are met. Therefore, this species is assessed as Near Threatened.
habitat: This species inhabits the gravel bottom of rapids from the upper reaches of the brackish water areas to the lower reaches of the freshwater area of streams (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015).
threats: Habitat destruction, caused by dredging, stream channelisation and land development for roads and agriculture around streams, is the main threat (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015).
population: This species is relatively abundant in streams where both natural and anthropogenic disturbances are not very extreme (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015, Red Data Book of Okinawa 2017). However, the population is thought to be in decline.
range: This species is endemic to the Ryukyu Archipelago, ranging from Amami-oshima, Kakeroma, Okinawa, Kume, Ishigaki and Iriomote islands (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015, Red Data Book of Okinawa 2017).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There is no information on conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: This species has only been recorded in Okinawa, Miyako, Ishigaki and Iriomote Islands in the Ryukyu Islands, Japan. It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 17,000 km<sup>2</sup> and there are continuing declines in habitat and population size due to environmental degradation caused by river channelisation, road construction and water pollution. No other subcriteria are met. Therefore, this species is assessed as Near Threatened.
habitat: The species inhabits muddy-sandy bottoms in undamaged river mouths and adjacent inlets (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015)..
threats: The main threat to this species is environmental degradation caused by river channelisation, road construction and water pollution (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015).
population: There are no quantitative data available on the population size but population is decreasing.
range: This species has only been recorded in Okinawa, Miyako, Ishigaki and Iriomote Islands in the Ryukyu Islands, Japan (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There is no information on conservation actions for this species.

rationale: The Yellowspotted Catshark (Scyliorhinus capensis) is a small (to 122 cm total length) catshark endemic to southern Africa in the Southeast Atlantic Ocean from southern Namibia to the Eastern Cape, South Africa. It inhabits the continental shelf and upper slopes over soft and rocky substrates at depths of 26–695 m, although it is most typically found on rocky reefs at 200–400 m depth. Little is known of its biology. The species is a bycatch of trawl and line fisheries, with a likely low post-release mortality. Trend analysis of research trawl surveys in fished areas of South Africa over 27 years from 1991–2017 indicate a population reduction of 58% over the past three generation lengths (75 years), although there was a high level of uncertainty in this estimate. Analyses of additional trawl and longline surveys in South Africa revealed a reduction in biomass of 44–50% from 2000–2007, although there were gear changes during that period that reduce the certainty that these estimates reflect a change in actual abundance. Some of the estimated population reduction in both of the surveys is possibly a result of an increase in the depth range of the Yellowspotted Catshark associated with climate change that may have moved some of the species' distribution away from the fishing grounds. Overall, due to the estimated population reductions along with the uncertainty in the estimates, combined with the potential that some of the estimated reduction could be due to a shift away from fishing grounds, and considering that there has been a reduction in trawl effort in South Africa in recent decades, it is suspected that the Yellowspotted Catshark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (75 years) due to actual levels of exploitation (bycatch), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Yellowspotted Catshark is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope on soft and rocky substrates at depths of 26–695 m, although it is most typically found over rocky reefs at 200–400 m depth, and deeper in warmer waters (Ebert et al. 2013). It reaches a maximum size of 112 cm total length (TL), males mature at 60 cm TL and females mature at 72 cm TL (Compagno et al. 2004, Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is oviparous, with egg cases laid in pairs, reproductive periodicity is unknown, and size-at-birth is 16 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Age-at-maturity and maximum age are unknown. Catsharks are difficult to age and the most reliable age estimates to date are from the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) that has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and maximum age of 21 years, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011). The Blacktip Sawtail Catshark is smaller than the Yellowspotted Catshark (48 cm vs 112 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 25 years for the Yellowspotted Catshark.
threats: The Yellowspotted Catshark is a bycatch of trawl and line fisheries (da Silva et al. 2015). Trawl fishing effort in South Africa has decreased substantially over the past two decades (S. Fennessy, pers. comm., 20 April 2018). It is reportedly common on trawl grounds (Ebert et al. 2013), although its habitat preference for rocky reefs may provide the Yellowspotted Catshark with some refuge from trawling. The species was reported as a minor bycatch of hake trawl research surveys in 2010 in Namibia (Kainge et al. 2010). Some parts of southern Namibia are remote and may offer refuge from fishing pressure (Belhabib et al. 2015). There would be less refuge from the South African commercial line fishery targeting hake that commenced in 1998, as it can operate in rocky habitat and fishes at depths of 100–600 m (Petersen 2008). The Yellowspotted Catshark is discarded, and the post-release mortality is likely low, based on generally very low at-vessel and post-release mortality for catsharks (Ellis et al. 2017). The species has been shown to move deeper, by about 4 m/year, within South Africa and Namibia over the period 1985–2010, under the influence of climate change warming effects on the Benguela Current (Yemane et al. 2014). This may affect the overlap of fisheries and the depth distribution of the species, likely by providing the species with more refuge, although it is unknown if this shift represents a loss of habitat to the species.
population:
There are no estimates of population size for the Yellowspotted Catshark. Population trend data of annual density estimates (kg per nm² area swept) were available from demersal research trawl surveys conducted over 27 years in fished areas of South Africa during summer along the west coast (1991–2017) and autumn and spring along the south coast (1991–2016) by the Fisheries Branch of the South African Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF, unpubl. data, 2018). The trend data were analysed over three generation lengths (75 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Winker and Sherley 2019). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

The trend analysis revealed an annual rate of reduction of 1.3% over the trawl grounds, consistent with a median reduction of 57.6% over the past three generation lengths (75 years), with the highest probability (33.4%) of <20% reduction over three generation lengths but also with a high probability (29.7%) of a 50–79% reduction over three generation lengths. The 27 years of abundance data fluctuated greatly and led to a high degree of uncertainty in the modeled abundance index, and also required extrapolation to a long period of three generations (75 years). This combined to produce a probability distribution with contrasting probabilities of extinction risk. 

Further to the above trend analysis, a study of fisheries-independent surveys of the demersal longline and trawl fisheries targeting hake (Merluccius spp.) off South Africa reported that from 2000 to 2007, the biomass of Yellowspotted Catshark declined by 44% on the west coast and by 50% on the south coast (Petersen 2008). The observed declines in biomass begin a few years after commencement of the commercial hake longline fishery, although there were also changes in the survey gear during 2000–2007 that may confound the biomass trends (Petersen 2008), reducing the certainty in the estimated declines. Some of the estimated population reduction in both of the surveys is possibly a result of an increase in the depth range of the Yellowspotted Catshark associated with climate change (Yemane et al. 2014) that may have moved some of its distribution away from the fishing grounds. There is no information on population trends for this species in Namibia, however, fishing pressure is suspected to be minimal in the Namibia portion of this species' range. 

Overall, due to the estimated population reductions along with the uncertainty in the estimates, combined with the potential that some of the estimated reduction could be due to a shift away fishing grounds, and a reduction in trawl effort in South Africa in recent decades, it is suspected that the Yellowspotted Catshark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (75 years) due to actual levels of exploitation (bycatch).
range: The Yellowspotted Catshark is a southern African endemic occurring from the Karas Region of southern Namibia to Waterloo Bay, Eastern Cape, South Africa in the Southeast Atlantic Ocean (Soares and de Carvalho 2019).
useTrade: The Yellowspotted Catshark has not been recorded in trade, and is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this species. Recreational anglers in South Africa are restricted to one shark per species per day (maximum of 10 individuals per day) (da Silva et al. 2015), although enforcement is an ongoing issue. A number of protected areas occur within its range, including the West Coast National Park, South Africa. Further research is needed on population size and trends, life history, and catch rates.

rationale:
The Starry Smoothhound (Mustelus asterias) is a small (to 140 cm total length) shark found in the Northeast and Eastern Central Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea (but absent from the Black Sea) from Scotland and southern Norway down to Western Sahara and the Canary Islands. It is demersal on the continental shelf from inshore to a depth of 199 m. The Northeast Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea are considered different stocks, based on differences in reproductive biology, limiting potential for external recruitment in the event of population depletion. The species is caught in demersal trawl, gillnet, trammel net, and longline fishing gear.

In the northern parts of the Northeast Atlantic it has little market value and is often discarded. In the Mediterranean Sea and Eastern Central Atlantic, smoothhounds (Mustelus spp.) are valued for human consumption and are often retained and marketed. No reliable species-specific fisheries catch data are available because landings data often refer to all smoothhounds combined with Tope (Galeorhinus galeus) or spurdogs (Squalus spp.). Abundance trends in fishery independent survey data from Northwestern Atlantic are estimated to be increasing.

In the Mediterranean Sea, abundance trends in fishery independent trawl survey data show that this stock of Starry Smoothhound has been declining in both the Gulf of Lions and the Adriatic Sea over the past 50 years. It should however be noted that the situation in the Mediterranean Sea may be worse than estimated given the grouping of smoothhounds in landings data and consequent masking of species-specific population trajectories. No information is currently available on subpopulation trends in the southern Mediterranean Sea and northwestern coasts of Africa, although the Starry Smoothhound is also caught and landed there in relatively intensive coastal fisheries. Taken together this species is estimated to be increasing in the Northeast Atlantic and inferred to have undergone a population reduction of ~70% % of the past three generation lengths (39 years) in the Mediterranean Sea and Black Sea. Due to similarly high fishing pressure along the continental shelves of the Eastern Central Atlantic it is suspected that this species has also undergone a similar level of population reduction there.

Assuming the Northeast Atlantic region comprises two-thirds of the range of Starry Smoothhound, it is suspected that overall this species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (39 years) due to actual levels of exploitation and this species is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Starry Smoothhound is demersal on sandy and gravelly substrates on the inner continental shelf from the surface to a depth of 199 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 140 cm total length (TL), males mature at 72 cm TL and females mature at 83 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous with a biennial reproductive cycle, litter sizes of 6–18 pups, and a size-at-birth of 28 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Female age-at-maturity is 6 years and maximum age is 20 years; generation length is therefore 13 years (Farrell et al. 2010a,b). The natural mortality rate of this species in the Northeast Atlantic was estimated at 0.219 per year and the intrinsic rate of population increase at 0.079 per year (Dureuil 2013).
threats:
The Starry Smoothhound occurs in coastal waters where fishing pressure is substantial through a large portion of its range. In the Northeast Atlantic, this species is caught seasonally as bycatch in trawl, gillnet, and longline fisheries, some of which discard or land the species, depending on market demands (ICES 2012). ICES landing statistics combine dogfish and smoothhounds together, so there are little accurate data on Northeast Atlantic landings, and levels of bycatch are largely unknown. There are areas of local abundance of the Starry Smoothhound throughout its range. Preliminary analyses of bycatch data indicate that juveniles are typically discarded, but no evaluation of discard survival rate has been undertaken (ICES 2012). Fishing mortality was estimated from the catch ratio from surveys of the Northeast Atlantic across the sub-adult and adult age classes (5–13 years). Since 1992, the fishing mortality has been variable, but overall has declined from 0.25 to 0.15. Nonetheless, the current level may still be slightly above the fishing mortality that produces maximum sustainable yield (FMSY = 0.11; Dureuil 2013).

This species may be landed for human consumption, and is used as bait for the inshore whelk fishery in England and Ireland. It is also an important sport angling fish in some areas, where most fish are returned to the sea, and often tagged. These areas include the Bristol and English Channels, the United Kingdom, the eastern and western Irish Sea, and off the coast of the Netherlands (ICES 2012).

In the Mediterranean Sea, there is a high level of exploitation on the continental shelf and upper slope to about 800 m depth (Massuti and Moranta 2003, Ferretti et al. 2005). Smoothhounds are captured by demersal trawls, trammel nets, gillnets and longlines in this region (Bauchot 1987). Semi-industrial fisheries in the Adriatic Sea, off Sicily, Spain, and Cyprus are known to take these species, and also artisanal fisheries elsewhere. Smoothhounds are retained and used in the Mediterranean Sea, where they are regularly sold for human consumption in many areas (Fischer et al. 1987).
population:
Although species-specific data are limited, data for all smoothhounds (Mustelus spp.) provides a good proxy for trends in landings and relative abundance of this species. The Starry Smoothhound occurs in three regions: the Northeast Atlantic, the Mediterranean Sea and Black Sea, and northwest Africa. The Mediterranean Sea is considered a separate stock from the Atlantic based on differences in reproductive biology, which limits potential for external recruitment in the event of population depletion.

First, in the Northeast Atlantic, the Starry Smoothhound is the most frequently encountered smoothhound species (ICES 2013). In the Bay of Biscay, landings have increased markedly from 151 to 499 t from 1996 to 2004, and have remained stable in Portuguese waters since an initial peak in 1999 (ICES 2007). Fishery independent surveys of the Celtic Seas, southern North Sea, English Channel, and Irish Sea all suggest increasing trends in nominal catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) (ICES 2010, 2013). For example, a fishery independent survey in the eastern English Channel and southern North Sea also found an increase in CPUE from about 0.1–0.3 individuals per hour in the early to mid-1990s to around 1.0–1.3 individuals per hour in 2009–2011. Martin et al. (2010) found that the mean density of Starry Smoothhound more than doubled between 1988 and 2008 throughout the English Channel. Similar trends were reported from various trawl surveys in the Northeast Atlantic between 1992 and 2012, where the highest increase in abundance was observed in French surveys (Dureuil 2013).

A relative abundance survey conducted by the Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Science (Cefas) in the Celtic Sea recorded a peak in 2000 and again in 2004 over a 17-year time series, although the year 2000 peak was not found in a concurrent French survey (ICES 2007). Nonetheless, a United Kingdom beam trawl survey also found an increase in smoothhound relative abundance and frequency of occurrence (ICES 2011). The trend of the population in the Northeast Atlantic is therefore of an increase. Based on these increases in abundance the Starry Smoothhound is estimated to be increasing and of Least Concern in the Northeast Atlantic. However, there has been a corresponding increase in reported landings from this region, and given the absence of effective species-specific management for this subpopulation, abundance trends and catch volumes must be carefully monitored.

Second, in the Mediterranean Sea and Black Sea, the Starry Smoothhound is less common than the Common Smoothhound (Mustelus mustelus), although the potential for misidentification should be noted. In the western, central, and eastern Mediterranean Sea, the International Bottom Trawl Survey in the Mediterranean (MEDITS) showed a very low frequency of occurrence, with this smoothhound recorded in only five of 6,336 hauls conducted from 1994 to 1999 at 10–800 m depth (Baino et al. 2001). The occurrence of this species also decreased in trawl surveys conducted in 1948 and 1998 in the Adriatic Sea (Jukic-Peladic et al. 2001). Aldebert (1997) reported a clear decrease in abundance of smoothhounds (Mustelus sp.) in comparable surveys in the Gulf of Lions, southern France, from 1970 to 1995. In Hvar trawl surveys conducted in 1948 in the Adriatic Sea, occurrence of the Starry Smoothhound was about 1.0 (frequency log-transformed), compared to about 0.1 in comparable MEDITS surveys conducted in the same area in 1998, which shows a decline of 90% from 1948 to 1998. A population reduction of ~70% is inferred for the three generation length of 39 years. Most recently, between 2006 and 2008, Fortuna et al. (2011) examined trawl fisheries in the Adriatic Sea, and found that this species was rarely caught as bycatch, with a catch rate of 0.0048 individuals per haul. In 2009, two specimens were caught in the southwestern Black Sea (Eryılmaz et al. 2011).

Catch data should be examined with caution as the catches reported as smoothhounds often consist of an aggregation of small-sized demersal sharks. Data reported to the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations show that smoothhound landings steadily increased between 1950 and 1978 to 14,000 t, after which they fluctuated between about 6,500 and 14,000 t from 1978 to 1994 (FAO 2008). After 1994, landings dropped significantly to 2,980 t in 1997 and did not exceed 2,200 t from 2001 to 2006 (FAO 2008). It is likely that this species has never been very abundant in the Mediterranean Sea. However, the available information on landings (although not species-specific) combined with the more detailed information derived from fishery-independent trawl surveys, suggest that this particular species has declined in abundance in the Mediterranean Sea. In some cases, as in the northern Tyrrhenian Sea, this species can be considered locally extinct due to overfishing (Ferretti et al. 2005, Ferretti et al. 2008).

Third, little is known of the status in the Western Central Atlantic, but status along the continental shelf of Morocco and Mauritania is likely to be similar to that of the Mediterranean Sea and Black Sea. There may be refuge for a small population in the Canary Islands as trawling was banned there in 1980 (Lawson et al. 2020). 

Taken together this species is estimated to be increasing in the Northeast Atlantic and inferred to have undergone a population reduction of ~70% % of the past three generation lengths (39 years) in the Mediterranean Sea and Black Sea. Due to similarly high fishing pressure along the continental shelves of the Eastern Central Atlantic it is suspected that this species has also undergone a similar level of population reduction. Assuming the Northeast Atlantic region comprises two-thirds of the range of Starry Smoothhound it is suspected that overall this species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (39 years) due to actual levels of exploitation and this species is assessed as Near Threatened, close to meeting Vulnerable A2d.
range: The Starry Smoothhound is found in the Northeast and Eastern Central Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea (but absent from the Black Sea) from Scotland and southern Norway down to Western Sahara and the Canary Islands (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The Starry Smoothhound is commercially valuable in the Mediterranean Sea and northwestern Africa, where the meat is utilized fresh, frozen, or salted and dried for human consumption. It is regularly present on the Adriatic, Tyrrhenian, Tunisian and Turkish markets; and sold fresh, frozen, refrigerated or salted-dried (Fischer et al. 1987). It is often discarded by commercial fisheries in the Northeast Atlantic, but the species is important for recreational fisheries in some areas of this region.
conservationActions:
In the Northeast Atlantic, there is currently no restriction on catch of this species. Based on its approach to data-limited stocks, ICES advised in 2012 that 2013–2014 catches should be reduced by 4%. Despite this advice and commitments to manage commercial fisheries, there are currently no European Union limits on landings or proposals for management.

The European Community Council Regulations 850/98 for the ‘conservation of fishery resources through technical measures for the protection of juveniles of marine organisms’ details the minimum mesh sizes that can be used to target fish. Smoothhounds would be classed under ‘all other marine organisms’ and so can only be targeted in fixed nets of more than 220 millimeters (ICES 2012).

In the Mediterranean Sea, there is currently no restriction on catch. Species-specific management measures are necessary to prevent further declines in this region, including improved data collection to species level for commercial landings. The Starry Smoothhound is listed in Appendix III of the Barcelona Convention, which suggests it should be afforded regulations regarding exploitation in the Mediterranean Sea (Recommendation GFCM/36/2012/1). The listing directs the recording and reporting to national authorities of all encounters with the species (including catch, bycatch, and discard) and encourages improved data collection and scientific monitoring. However, compliance with this directive has been poor, and thus Mediterranean data on this species remains seriously lacking. The Balearic Island Marine Reserves offer minimal protection to smoothhounds, as they are protected within the waters of the reserve. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
The Coral Catshark (Atelomycterus marmoratus) is a small (to 70 cm total length) shark that occurs in the Eastern and Western Indian, Western Central Pacific, and Northwest Pacific Oceans from Pakistan to China. It inhabits shallow rocky and coral reef habitats at depths of 5–100 m.

The species is a bycatch of a range of artisanal and industrial gears including demersal trawl, longline, and gillnet and is retained for human consumption. Reconstructed catches of all sharks, skates, and rays from the Bangladesh, Malaysia, Philippines, Viet Nam, and China Exclusive Economic Zones can be used to infer population reductions of 54–99% over the past three generation lengths (45 years). Further, a population reduction of 60% was inferred based on a 50% decrease in fisheries-independent research survey catch rate of elasmobranchs (all species combined) between 1978–80 and 2013 in Myanmar. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline of elasmobranchs in the region.

Fishing pressure is high across much of the spatial and depth range of this species, yet it is still commonly landed in parts of its range. The relative proportion of this species in shark landings has increased over recent decades in the region, which may be in response to the overfishing of large sharks resulting in meso-predator release of the Coral Catshark. Alternatively, the increase in landings may imply some resilience to, or refuge from, fishing pressure. This species spends much of its time on coral and rocky habitats where many fishing gears are unlikely to be deployed. The rocky and coral habitat and inshore and seasonal trawl bans in China may afford the species refuge from fishing pressure over the majority of its range.

This species is not targeted in any part of its range and if landed is likely as done so as bycatch. It is likely that this species has not declined to the same degree as other sharks and rays in the region. It is suspected that the Coral Catshark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (45 years) due to declines in habitat quality and levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2cd).
habitat: The Coral Catshark is found on complex coral and rocky reefs at depths of 5–100 m (Weigmann 2016). This species reaches a length of at least 70 cm total length (TL) (Ebert et al. 2013) with males maturing at 47–62 cm TL and females maturing at 49–57 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is oviparous with size-at-birth is reported to be 10–13 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Catsharks are difficult to age and the most reliable age estimates to date are from the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) that has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and maximum age of 21, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011). The Coral Catshark has a similar longevity (~20 years in captivity, Hövel et al. 2010) as the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark and thus, the generation length is inferred as 15 years for the Coral Catshark.
threats:
The Coral Catshark is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is regularly taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including by demersal inshore trawl, gillnet and line, and retained for human consumption (SEAFDEC 2016, Psomadakis et al. 2019). Fishing effort and power has been increasing in the Asian region and is generally unregulated and unmanaged (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013).

India has an intensive fishing fleet of trawlers and gillnetters throughout the Bay of Bengal (>23,000; K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). In India, shark fisheries peaked in the 1980s as the demand for meat and fins grew across Southeast Asia (Karnad et al. 2019). There is a high level of fisheries exploitation with most stocks fully exploited (FAO 2020a). There were about 6,600 trawlers operating in the Indian state of Gujarat in the early 2000s (Zynudheen et al. 2004). This number increased to 11,582 trawlers in 2010 (CMFRI 2010). Trawling is also intense elsewhere with 3,678 trawlers in Kerala and 5,767 trawlers in Tamil Nadu waters, with severe declines in fish stocks, including elasmobranchs (Raje et al. 2002, Mohanraj et al. 2009, CMFRI 2010, Karnad et al. 2014). In Sri Lanka, fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 14,000 vessels in 1950 to 63,745 vessels in 2014, with most of the increase since 2000 and >90% of the fleet subsistence and artisanal fisheries operating in coastal fisheries on the continental shelf (Pauly et al. 2020). The coastal fisheries are likely to be increasingly overfished due to the high fishing effort with offshore fisheries increasing in effort since the early 1980s (Samaraweera and Amarasiri 2004, Dissanayake 2005). Bangladesh has a substantial artisanal fishing fleet that has been increasing in recent decades with 67,669 vessels reported to be operating in 2017–2018 (DoF 2018, Pauly et al. 2020). The artisanal fishing fleet operates at depths of 0–40 m on average but can operate down to 80 m (Hoq et al. 2014). Artisanal shark landings have increased from 2,000 t in 1986 to 6,234 t in 2001 (Ullah et al. 2014). Industrial shark landings have increased three-fold from 400 t in 1986 to 1,247 in 2001 (Ullah et al. 2014).

In Myanmar, fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 2,000 vessels in 1950 to 125,222 vessels in 2014, with >80% of the fleet subsistence fisheries operating in coastal waters on the continental shelf (Pauly et al. 2020).

Sharks and rays are an important resource in Indonesia and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). A 165% increase in fishers occurred from 1951 to 1967, beginning the dramatic and ongoing increase in Indonesian fisheries production (Tull 2014). Small-scale fisheries comprise a high majority (~90%) of fisheries production in Indonesia (Tull 2014). There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the Viet Nam range of the Coral Catshark. Most marine stocks in Viet Nam have been declining since the 1990s and are now considered fully or over-exploited with a lack of adequate enforcement leading to essentially unregulated fisheries (Teh et al. 2014, FAO 2020b). The motorized fishing fleet has been increasing since the 1950s and rapidly expanded in the mid-1980s to 2000s when Viet Nam moved towards a market-orientated economy (Teh et al. 2014). The fleet is dominated by small-scale artisanal and subsistence fisheries that have accounted for 60–85% of the fleet since the 1950s (Teh et al. 2014, Pauly et al. 2020). Most marine stocks in Viet Nam have been declining since the 1990s and are now considered fully or over-exploited with a lack of adequate enforcement leading to essentially unregulated fisheries (Teh et al. 2014, FAO 2020b).

The northern South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since the 1990s in the South China Sea, more than 70% of the catch is of low-value fish and juvenile fish (Pauly and Liang 2019). In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive demersal trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012).

The Coral Catshark is likely to have some refuge from the majority of fishing activity throughout its range. This species spends much of its time on coral and rocky habitats where many fishing gears are unlikely to be deployed. This species is not targeted in any part of its range and if landed is likely as done so as bycatch.

Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include habitat destruction and degradation, and pollution (e.g. heavy metals) (Heileman and Tang 2009, Heileman 2009, MacKinnon et al. 2012). In the South China Sea, there has been degradation of significant areas of coral reef habitat in the last 70 years (Heileman and Tang 2009, Heileman 2009). In Viet Nam, dynamite and cyanide fishing, and sedimentation have caused widespread destruction of coral reefs, which this species relies on heavily (Jameson et al. 1995, FAO 2020b). Global climate change has already resulted in large-scale coral bleaching events with increasing frequency causing worldwide reef degradation since 1997. Almost all warm-water coral reefs are projected to suffer significant losses of area and local extinctions, even if global warming is limited to 1.5ºC (IPCC Report 2019).
population:
There is no species-specific trend information available for the Coral Catshark. Surveys of landing sites indicate that the Coral Catshark makes up nearly 9% of shark catch by number and 0.6% of shark catch by weight which is an increase since 2006 (SEAFDEC 2006, 2016). This increase may be due to declines in large sharks and increased targeting and retention of the remaining smaller species (Lam and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2011). Despite the lack of species-specific trend data, catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the Bangladesh, Malaysia, Thailand, Cambodia, Viet Nam, and China Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ), based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased.

In the Western Indian Ocean and Bay of Bengal, this species is considered uncommon, likely due to the lack of available habitat in the region (A.B. Haque unpubl. data 2020). In Bangladesh, reconstructed landings data showed a 34% decline in catch over 15 years from 2000 to 2014. Catches gradually rose from 195 t in 1950 to 7,540 t in 1973 then declined to the 3,500 t in the mid 1980s, then rose steeply to a peak of 10,909 t in 2000 followed by a fluctuating decline to 7,163 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020).

In Myanmar, reconstructed catch data, from 1950 to the late 1990s, varied between 15,000 t to 35,000 t annually with no substantial trend. From the late 1990s to 2014 landings increased to around 40,000 t per year which was concurrent with an increase in fishing effort (Pauly et al. 2020). This infers there has been no significant reduction in the shark and ray populations as landings have increased as effort has increased. However, surveys in recent years have revealed reductions in some shark and ray populations (San San Khine 2010, Krakstad et al. 2014). Trawl surveys by the Norwegian research vessel "Dr Fridtjof Nansen" showed a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs over the 33 years between surveys in 1978–80 and 2013 and a shift from larger long-lived species to smaller short-lived species (Krakstad et al. 2014). Market surveys reveal a decline in landings of 49% over a four-year period (2006–2010) despite no reduction in fishing effort and increasing domination by small, short-lived species (San San Khine 2010).

In Malaysia, landings data collected ﻿from six fishing ports across Peninsular and East Malaysia during October 2014–July 2017 recorded 122 individuals representing 2% of total catch for that period (Arai and Azri 2019). More recently, landings data collected across eight landing sites in Sarawak state from October 2017 – June 2019 recorded three individuals (one in 2017, two in 2018), representing 0.4% of total recorded catch for that period (WCS Malaysia unpubl. data 2020). In Malaysia, reconstructed shark and ray catches declined by 30% on the east coast of Malaysia from 1999 to 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Similarly, on the west coast of Malaysia, reconstructed catches declined by 18% over the same period. These declines can be inferred to represent shark and ray population reductions, as fishing effort was increasing during the period of declines in catch (Pauly et al. 2020). In the Gulf of Thailand, reconstructed shark and ray catch showed a 74% decline over 12 years from 2003 to 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Historically, catches fluctuated since 1950–1998 at 5,000–13,000 t then rose steeply to a peak catch of 20,340 t in 2003 followed by a sharp decline in catches to 5,380 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). It is difficult to infer a population trend as the steep decline in catches from 2003 to 2014 coincided with a decline in fishing effort.

In Indonesia, landings data collected in Lombok from 2014-2015 indicated that 10 individuals of this species were caught by surface and bottom longlines in 2014 (0.1% of total catch from Jan 2014 – Dec 2015), but no others have been recorded since 2014 (Yulianto et al. 2018, WCS Indonesia unpubl. data 2020), while landings data collected in East Java from August 2017–March 2018 recorded seven individuals, making up 0.4% of total catch for that period (Winter et al. 2020). In Indonesia, net and trawl fisheries (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). While species-specific data on long-term declines in elasmobranchs in the Southeast Asian region are limited, declines of the Coral Catshark in Southeast Asia and elsewhere in the Indo-West Pacific are inferred given the widespread historical and continuing declines of demersal fisheries in this region (Stobutzki et al. 2006).
