This species is considered common in the area and is not targeted in Indonesia (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020).

In the Philippines, reconstructed shark and ray catches declined 84% from 1993 to 2016 (Pauley et al. 2020). Historically, catches of sharks and rays increased from 647 t in 1950 to 8,510 t in 1975 then declined to 2,561 t in 1990. Catches then rose steeply to a peak of 12,980 t in 1993 before declining to 2.132 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020).  These declines can be inferred to represent shark and ray population reductions, as fishing effort was increasing during the period of declines in catch (Pauly et al. 2020).

In Viet Nam, reconstructed shark and ray catch declined by 97% over 29 years from 1986 to 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Historically, catches gradually rose from 1,560 t in 1950 to ~44,000 t per year in the mid-1960s, fluctuated and then rose steeply during the early-1980s to a peak of 466,445 t in 1986 followed by a fairly steady decline to 14,750 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially during the period of a decline in catch (Pauly et al. 2020). In China, reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline over the 65 years from 1950 to 2014. The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to bottom trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019). Additionally, in China, anecdotal reports suggest a decrease in the size of sharks and rays captured (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019), which reflects the broader trend across all fish stocks of smaller sized fish being landed in China as a result of fishing down the ecosystem; a consequence of intensive fishing that changes the size composition of the catch (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these reconstructed catches are scaled to three generation lengths of the Coral Catshark (45 years), they represent declines of 74%, 55%, 99%, 97%, and 54% in Bangladesh, Malaysia, Philippines, Viet Nam, and China respectively. In Myanmar, a population reduction of 60% was inferred based on a 50% decrease in research survey catch rate of elasmobranchs between surveys in 1978–80 and 2013. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region.  The relative proportion of the Coral Catshark in shark landings has increased over recent decades in the Indo-Malay region and this species may have benefited from meso-predator release due to the overfishing of large sharks. The species is considered common in Cambodia, Thailand, Viet Nam, and Indonesia but is uncommon in the Indian Ocean (L. Seyha unpubl. data 2020, Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). This species likely has some refuge from fishing activity in rocky and coral reef habitats throughout its range. Because this species is increasing in landings and is still considered common in many parts of its range, it is suspected that it has not declined to the same degree as other sharks and rays in the region. Overall, it is suspected that the Coral Catshark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (45 years).
range: The Coral Catshark occurs in the Western and Eastern Indian, Western Central and Northwest Pacific Oceans from Pakistan to southern China, including New Guinea and the Philippines (Ebert et al. 2013, Psomadakis et al. 2019, Arai and Azri 2019).
useTrade: This species is retained, if caught, and the meat is consumed and traded locally with a value of USD $0.81 per kg (Thailand; SEAFDEC 2006). This species is also targeted and bred for the aquaria trade (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place. In Myanmar, two shark reserves were designated in the Myeik Archipelago in 2004 where targeting sharks and rays is prohibited (Notification 2/2004) (Howard et al. 2015). In 2008, a nationwide ban on the targeting of sharks was announced. Despite the nationwide ban, sharks and rays continue to be captured in large numbers, partly because there is little or no enforcement, and little knowledge of the ban in fishing communities (T. MacKeracher pers. comm. 02/04/2020). In Thailand, all commercial fishing vessels greater than 10 gross tonnes are prohibited to fish within three nautical miles from the shore (DoF 2015). Throughout Malaysia there are 51 Marine Protected Areas making up 5,462 km² that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020). In Indonesia, trawls were banned from use in 1980, however, mini trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country (Chong et al. 1987). Research is required to better define the population size and trends, and life history of the Coral Catshark, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Shorttail Fanskate (Sympterygia brevicaudata) is a small (to 55 cm total length) skate found in the Southeast Pacific Ocean from Ecuador to central Chile. It is demersal on the inner continental shelf at depths of 8–100 m and possibly beyond, as it has been captured in hake and deepwater crustacean fisheries which operate down to 500 m depth. This species is taken as bycatch of artisanal and industrial shrimp fisheries in Ecuador and Peru, but it is rarely captured in Chile but presumably taken as bycatch of the hake trawl fisheries there. Catches of this species have risen rapidly between 2001 and 2011 in Peru and a decline is suspected in the southern part of its distribution in Chile. This species is fished throughout its depth range and much of its geographic range, while it is small-bodied and likely to be resilient to moderate fishing pressure. Landings are increasing in Peru and declines are inferred in at least part of its range due to levels of exploitation. Overall, the Shorttail Fanskate is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (34.5 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Shorttail Fanskate is demersal on the inner continental shelf and upper slope; it has been confirmed from depths of 8–100 m (Last et al. 2016, X. Velez-Zuazo unpubl. data 2019) but the lower depth extent is unknown as it has been captured in hake and deep-water crustacean fisheries which operate to 500 m depth (Acuña et al. 2005, Céspedes 2013). It reaches a maximum size of 55 cm total length (TL) and males mature at 35–40 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous. Generation length is assumed to be 11.5 years, based on comparison with that of another small-bodied closely related skate Bathyraja kincaidii (Perez et al. 2011).
threats: This skate is more commonly reported and taken as bycatch of artisanal and industrial shrimp fisheries in Ecuador and Peru, but it is rarely captured in Chile. In Ecuador, it is taken as bycatch in the multi-purpose research fishery, which captures Brown and Pink Shrimp (Farefantepenaeus californiensis and F. brevirostris) and these shrimps have a depth range of 10–110 m (A. Cevallos pers. comm. 2020; Acuerdo Nro. MAGAP-DSG-2015-0192-A, Ministerio de Agricultura y Ganadería). Off the central coast of Peru, there are intensive artisanal inshore fisheries with shore-based longlines and gillnets (Alfaro-Shigueto et al. 2010). There has been a ten-fold increase in the landings category called 'Psammobatis brevicaudatus' (which represents catches of S. brevicaudata) from approximately 600 kg in 2001 to 8,000 kg in 2010 mainly from the central north of Peru, reported at the ports of Pimentel, Huacho, Pucusana, and Eten (Instituto del Mar Del Peru, IMARPE; X. Velez-Zuazo, pers. comm., 2019). In Chile, this species is probably taken as bycatch in embayments by inshore bottom trawls and gillnet fisheries, and is frequently captured in the deep-water bottom-trawl fishery for South South Hake (Merluccius gayi); it is occasionally captured in the deep-water crustacean fisheries (Acuña et al. 1989, 2005).
population: There are no population estimates for this skate. The population trend is suspected to be declining because much of this species' depth range is shallow (8–100 m) and it is likely to be captured in intense artisanal and industrial fisheries throughout the bulk of its depth and geographic range in Ecuador and Peru. It may have some refuge from fishing mortality in northern Chile in the southern part of its range, although there is evidence of decline in Coquimbo Bay, central Chile (Acuña et al. 2005). Although the gears used in the surveys are different, population reduction can be inferred from a comparison of scientific surveys over time. From May 1986 to July 1988, 100 juveniles from 10–27 cm disc width (DW) were captured in 27 months of research bottom trawls (81 hauls) at depths down to 40 m (Acuña et al. 1989). A decade later, in 2009, four juveniles averaging 25 cm DW in 20 gillnet sets in the same location (Lamilla et al. 2009). None were found in 52 trawl hauls on a research survey in a similar area in 2006 (Bustamante et al. 2014). Overall, it is suspected that the population of this skate has been reduced by at least 20–29% over the past three generations (34.5 years).
range: The Shorttail Fanskate is found in the Southeast Pacific from Ecuador (3°S) to central Chile (33°S) (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This skate is taken as bycatch and it has been landed in Peru as 'Psammobatis brevicaudatus' in increasing volume from 2001 to 2011 (Instituto del Mar Del Peru, IMARPE; X. Velez-Zuazo unpubl. data 2019); elsewhere it is not typically utilised or traded.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place. The scale of exploitation of this species will depend heavily on hake and crustacean trawl fisheries regulations. Further research is needed on population size and trend.

rationale: The Spotted Legskate (Anacanthobatis marmorata) is a small (to 29 cm total length) southern African endemic skate with a restricted distribution in the Western Indian Ocean from KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa to southern Mozambique. It is demersal on soft substrates of the continental shelf break and upper slope at depths of 200–435 m, though it may also be semi-pelagic as some legskates have been noted swimming in mid-water off Africa. Little is known of its biology. The species is likely a bycatch of deep-water demersal trawl fisheries that operate across its entire range, and although effort has substantially declined in some of the deep-water fisheries since 2007, some fishing effort remains. Overall, due to levels of fishing pressure across its entire range that were historically high (but have mostly substantially declined in recent years), it is suspected that the Spotted Legskate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (36 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Spotted Legskate is demersal on soft substrates of the continental shelf break and upper slope at depths of 200–435 m (Last et al. 2016). It may also be semi-pelagic as other species in this genus have been recorded swimming in mid-water off Africa (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 29 cm total length, and both sexes mature at ~ 23 cm total length (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous, with the number of egg cases, reproductive periodicity, and size-at-birth unknown (Last et al. 2016). Age-at-maturity and maximum age of this species are unknown and are poorly-known from the legskate family. Age-at-maturity is inferred from the smallest deep-water skate with known ages and similar depth range, the Sandpaper Skate (Bathyraja kincaidii) that has a female age-at-maturity of 6 years and a maximum age of 17 years, resulting in an inferred generation length of 12 years for the Spotted Legskate (Perez et al. 2011).
threats: The Spotted Legskate is likely a bycatch of deep-water demersal trawl fisheries. It is probably discarded when captured due to its small size. A crustacean trawl fishery operates off Durban, South Africa, and extends northwards into southern Mozambique. This deep-water fishery operates at depths of 100–600 m (Fennessy and Groenveld 1997), thus overlapping entirely with the species' depth range. Effort, however, has been declining substantially since 2007; the 2016 effort level was half the 2012 level, which in-turn was only 30% of that in the early 1990s. Currently, there are 2–3 vessels operating at any one time, for a total of around 1,000 trawls per year (S. Fennessy unpubl. data 2018). Other trawl fishing in parts of southern Mozambique (Jacquet et al. 2010, Benkenstein 2013) may threaten this species.
population: There are no estimates of population size or trend for the Spotted Legskate. This species' entire range overlaps with trawl fisheries, and although deep-water trawl fishing effort has substantially declined in some sectors since 2007 (i.e. South Africa), some effort still remains. Due to levels of fishing pressure across its entire range that were historically high (but have mostly substantially declined in recent years), it is suspected that the Spotted Legskate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (36 years).
range: The Spotted Legskate is a southern African endemic with a restricted distribution from KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa to southern Mozambique in the Western Indian Ocean (Smale 2004, Last et al. 2016). The Spotted Legskate has an extent of occurrence (EOO) that is close to, but not <20,000 km².
useTrade: The Spotted Legskate has not been recorded in trade and is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place. This species occurs in several Marine Protected Areas (MPAs), including the iSimangaliso MPA, South Africa that may provide some refuge for this species, as the park extends offshore to a depth of 400 m. Further research is needed on life history, population size and trends, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Balloon Shark (Cephaloscyllium sufflans) is a small (to 110 cm total length) demersal catshark that occurs in the Western Indian Ocean from KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa to Mozambique, as well as in southwest Madagascar and Comoros at depths of 40–605 m. Little is known of its biology. This species may be caught as bycatch in deep-water trawl, longline, and artisanal fisheries across much of its range. Steep declines of 82% over 4 years are inferred in South African commercial trawl catches, and although effort in those fisheries have declined substantially over the last two decades, intense fisheries operate in other parts of its range. It may have some refuge from trawlers, as it has a preference for rocky habitat, though it could still be captured by other fishing gear. It will also have refuge in well-enforced marine protected areas across its range, and in deeper waters. A response to fishing pressure cannot be surmised from congeners, as it is highly variable. Overall, due to steep inferred declines in catches balanced with its likely refuge in marine parks across its range, on rocky habitats, and at depth, it is suspected that the Balloon Shark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (75 years) due to actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Balloon Shark is demersal on mainly rocky habitats, though it also occurs on sand and mud substrates (Robinson and Nel 2004, D. Ebert, unpubl. data, 2018). It is present on the continental shelf and upper slope in warm-temperate and subtropical waters at depths of 40–605 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016, D. Ebert, unpubl. data, 2018). It reaches a maximum size of 110 cm total length (TL); males mature at 89 cm TL; and, females mature at 82 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is oviparous with one egg case per oviduct and size-at-birth of 20 cm TL, although the frequency of egg-laying is unknown (Ebert et al. 2013). Age-at-maturity and maximum age are unknown. Catsharks are difficult to age and the most reliable age estimates to date are from the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) that has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and maximum age of 21 years, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011). The Blacktip Sawtail Catshark is smaller than the Balloon Shark (48 cm vs 110 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 25 years for the Balloon Shark.
threats: The Balloon Shark is likely a bycatch of deep-water trawl, longline, and artisanal fisheries in South Africa, Mozambique, and Madagascar (Jacquet et al. 2010, Benkenstein 2013, Cripps et al. 2015, S. Fennessy, Oceanographic Research Institute, unpubl. data, 2018). Fisheries operate throughout its range, but in South Africa, east coast trawl fishery effort has decreased substantially over the past two decades (S. Fennessy, Oceanographic Research Institute, unpubl. data 2018). Intense small-scale and trawl fisheries operate in southern Mozambique (Jacquet et al. 2010, Benkenstein 2013) and deep-water trawl effort is increasing in Madagascar waters (Cripps et al. 2015, R. Bennett, unpubl. data, 2018). The species may have refuge in a number of marine protected areas across its range, and possibly at depth.
population:
There are no population size or trend estimates for the Balloon Shark. Observer data from commercial crustacean trawl catches off the east coast of South Africa (300–500 m depth) suggest nominal average catch rates of Balloon Shark individuals/trawl of 0.5 from 2004–2007 and 0.09 from 2008–2011 (S. Fennessy, Oceanographic Research Institute, unpubl. data, 2018). This represents a steep decline of 82% over 4 years, although there was a decline in commercial fisheries effort over that period and without concurrent effort data it is not possible to determine how much of the decline represents an actual decline in abundance. Effort has since stabilized, but there have been no observers on board since 2011 and hence catch rates in that fishery are currently unknown (S. Fennessy, unpubl. data, 2018). This species was not recorded in research trawl surveys off Madagascar (RV Dr Fridjtof Nansen surveys in 1983, 2008, and 2009), nor off Tanzania (surveys in 1982, 1983, and 2018), and one specimen was recorded off Mozambique (surveys from 1977 to 2018) but this lack of records may be partly due to Balloon Shark's preference for rocky habitats which is not habitat suitable for trawl gear (S. Fennessy, unpubl. data,  2018).

Two congeners heavily fished by trawls in southeast Australia exhibited contrasting responses to fishing pressure: the Whitefin Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium albipinnum) had steep population declines of 75% over 12 years, while the Australian Swellshark (C. laticeps), a commonly caught bycatch, showed no decline in abundance over the same period (Walker and Gason 2007). The Australian Swellshark has low discard mortality as it is extremely resilient to capture and handling out of water (Frick et al. 2009). The Balloon Shark's response to fishing pressure cannot be surmised from congeners, as it appears to be highly variable.

Overall, a steep decline in commercial catches of the Balloon Shark is inferred, and fisheries operate across much of its range, yet the species likely has refuge in a number of marine parks across its range, in rocky habitats, and in deeper waters. The Balloon Shark is therefore suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (75 years) due to actual levels of exploitation (bycatch).
range: The Balloon Shark occurs in the Western Indian Ocean from KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa to Mozambique, as well as in Southwest Madagascar, and Comoros (Ebert et al. 2013, Fricke et al. 2018, D. Ebert unpubl. data 2018). There is an unconfirmed record from Tanzania, and a record from the Gulf of Aden is questionable and is likely another species (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade, and is not known to be utilized for meat. It is occasionally retained by trawler crew for sale to traditional medicine practitioners (S. Fennessy, Oceanographic Research Institute, unpubl. data, 2018).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this species. A number of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) occur across its range, including: iSimangaliso MPA and the uThukela MPA in South Africa, Ponta do Ouro Partial MPA in southern Mozambique, and Moheli Marine Park in Comoros. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Blackspot Skate (Dipturus campbelli) is a small (to 66 cm total length) demersal skate endemic to southern Africa in the Western Indian Ocean with a relatively restricted distribution from Durban, South Africa to southern Mozambique. It inhabits the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 137–403 m. Little is known of its biology. The species is likely a bycatch of deep-water demersal trawl fisheries that operate across its entire range, and although effort has substantially declined in some of the deep-water fisheries since 2007, some fishing effort remains. Overall, due to past and ongoing (albeit reduced) fishing pressure across its entire range, it is suspected that the Blackspot Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (21 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Blackspot Skate is demersal on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 137–403 m (Compagno and Ebert 2007, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 66 cm total length (TL); males mature at ~57 cm TL and females mature at ~64 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous, with the number of egg cases, reproductive periodicity, and size-at-birth unknown (Last et al. 2016). Age-at-maturity and maximum age are unknown and are inferred from a skate of similar size and depth range, the White-spotted Skate (Dentiraja cerva), that has a female age-at-maturity of 5 years and maximum age of 9 years (Treloar 2009); generation length is therefore inferred as 7 years for the Blackspot Skate.
threats: Although there is a lack of available information, the Blackspot Skate is suspected to be a bycatch of deep-water demersal trawl fisheries due to the overlap with its range. A crustacean trawl fishery operates off Durban, and extends northwards into southern Mozambique. This deep-water fishery operates on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 100–600 m (Fennessy and Groenveld 1997). Effort, however, has been declining substantially since 2007; the 2016 effort level was half the 2012 level, which in-turn was only 30% of that in the early 1990s. Currently there are 2–3 vessels operating at any one time, for a total of around 1,000 trawls per year (S. Fennessy pers. comm. 24 April 2018). Other trawl fishing in southern Mozambique (Jacquet et al. 2010, Benkenstein 2013) is also suspected to catch this species.
population: There are no estimates of population size or trend for the Blackspot Skate. The species is known from seven localities recorded by demersal research trawl surveys from 1985 to 1996 (Compagno and Ebert 2007).  This species' entire range overlaps with trawl fisheries, and although deep-water trawl fishing effort has substantially declined in some sectors since 2007, the species is still exposed to some deep-water trawl effort. Overall, due to past and ongoing (albeit reduced) fishing pressure across its entire range, it is suspected that the Blackspot Skate has  undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three  generation lengths (21 years).
range: The Blackspot Skate is a southern African endemic with a relatively restricted, and possibly patchy, distribution in the Western Indian Ocean from Durban, South Africa to Ponta da Barra Falsa, southern Mozambique (extent of occurrence ~131,390 km²) (Smale 2004, Compagno and Ebert 2007).
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of the Blackspot Skate.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place. A number of marine protected areas (MPAs) occur within the species' range including iSimangaliso MPA in South Africa that may offer some refuge as it occurs to a depth of 400 m. Further research is needed on life history, population size and trends, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Chilean Round Ray (Urotrygon chilensis) is a small (to ~43 cm total length) ray which occurs from the Gulf of California, Mexico to northern Chile in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific. It inhabits shallow coastal and continental shelf waters from inshore to 60 m depth. This species is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries and a variety of other artisanal fisheries across its range and is one of the most abundant elasmobranch bycatch species in some areas such as Costa Rica and is common in Guatemala. In contrast, it is rarely encountered in some other countries such as Colombia. It is generally discarded although round rays may be used as bait or fishmeal by artisanal fishers. In the Tehuantepec Gulf, Mexico, demographic models suggest population declines of the Chilean Round Ray under some scenarios, but not under other scenarios; overall the model results were not conclusive to ascertain population trend. Tropical Eastern Pacific round rays have very early age-at-maturity (4 years for the Chilean Round Ray) and life history parameters that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore some resilience to fishing mortality. Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, balanced with high biological productivity, it is suspected that the Chilean Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (20 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Chilean Round Ray inhabits shallow coastal and continental shelf waters from inshore to 60 m depth (Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of ~43 cm total length (LT) and size-at-maturity of ~25 cm TL (Guzmán-Castellanos 2015, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is viviparous with a short gestation period of 3–4 months and litter sizes of 1–5 pups (Guzmán-Castellanos 2015). Female age-at-maturity is 4 years and maximum age is 14 years, with an estimated generation length 5.8–7.6 years following Guzmán-Castellanos (2015). For the purposes of this assessment, generation length is taken as the mid-point (6.7 years).
threats:
This round ray is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries and a variety of other artisanal fisheries across its range. In Costa Rica, it is an abundant species in the industrial shrimp trawl fishery, although not as common as the Spinytail Round Ray (Urotrygon aspidura) (Clarke et al. 2016, Clarke et al. 2018). There are some remote areas of the northern coast of Costa Rica where the species aggregates in very shallow waters for reproduction where there are no fishing activities, providing the species with some refuge. Shrimp trawl survey data shows that it is common on trawl grounds off Guatemala (Ixquiac-Cabrera et al. 2010). In El Salvador, catches in the industrial shrimp trawl fishery are at low levels (Fuentes and Hernández 2004). In Panama, it has been recorded in small-scale fisheries (Del Cid 2011), but limited data is available on catches (J.M. Morales-Saldaña unpubl. data 2019). In Colombia, it is generally rarely encountered by fisheries (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2011). In Ecuador, it is caught in beach seine fisheries and it is also caught in artisanal and industrial fisheries (trawling and longline).

Overall, there is high spatial overlap with fisheries (which generally lack management or effective enforcement of regulations across most of its range), and given the geographic and depth range of the species, it has little refuge from fishing activities that operate across its range.
population:
The Chilean Round Ray is one of the most abundant elasmobranch bycatch species in some areas such as Costa Rica (Clarke et al. 2016, Espinoza et al. 2018) and is common in Guatemala (Ixquiac-Cabrera et al. 2010) and Mexico (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016). In contrast, it is rarely encountered in some other countries such as Colombia (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2011, 2019).

In the Tehuantepec Gulf, Mexico, demographic models suggest population declines of the Chilean Round Ray under some scenarios, but not under other scenarios; overall the model results were not conclusive to ascertain population trend (Guzmán-Castellanos 2015).

Age data from tropical Eastern Pacific round rays show very early age-at-maturity (4 years for Chilean Round Ray; Guzmán-Castellanos 2015) and life history parameters that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore some resilience to fishing mortality.

The Chilean Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge. Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, balanced with high biological productivity, it is suspected that the Chilean Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years).
range: The Chilean Round Ray occurs from the Gulf of California, Mexico to northern Chile in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Round rays are of little commercial value due to their small size. They are often discarded when caught, although there may be some retention in small-scale (artisanal) fisheries for meat, fish meal, or bait.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific measures in place for the Chilean Round Ray. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki pers. comm. 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Benthic trawling and mechanized beach seines have been prohibited in the coastal zone of Peru (to 5 nm from shore) since 2001 (Regulation: DS-012-2001-PE) and manual beach seines from 2009 (Regulation: RM-112-2009-PRODUCE ). This has likely reduced the catch of inshore elasmobranchs in Peruvian coastal waters.

Further research is needed on life history, the level of mortality due to fisheries, and population size and trend. Both small- and large-scale fisheries should be monitored for bycatch at the species level.

rationale: The Hooktooth Dogfish (Aculeola nigra) is a common small shark (to 67 cm total length) which occurs off Peru to central Chile in the Southeast Pacific. It is demersal or bentho-pelagic on or over the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 110–735 m, but most commonly at 200–500 m. It is a regular bycatch of deep-sea crustacean trawl fisheries off central and northern Chile where it is the most common chondrichthyan bycatch species by weight. These fisheries generally operate <500 m depth, so the species has some refuge at the deeper end of its depth range. Overall, given the level of fisheries occurring across much of its range balanced with some refuge in deeper waters, it is suspected that the Hooktooth Dogfish has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (51 years) based on levels of exploitation (bycatch), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Hooktooth Dogfish inhabits the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 110–735 m, although more commonly at depths of 200–500 m (Ebert 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 67 cm total length (TL), males mature from 38 cm TL, females from 39 cm TL, and size-at-birth is 13–17 cm TL (Gatica and Acuña 2011, Ebert 2016). Reproduction is viviparous with litter size of 3–19 pups (average: 10) (Acuña et al. 2003, Gatica and Acuña 2011, Ebert 2016). Age data are not available for this species, but generation length can be estimated as 17 years based on data from the Giant Lanternshark (Etmopterus baxteri) (aged by examination of internal bands on dorsal spines; specimens examined up to 69 cm TL and therefore of a similar size to the Hooktooth Dogfish; Irvine et al. 2006).
threats: In Chile, the Hooktooth Dogfish is a bycatch in the deep-sea crustacean trawl fishery for Red Squat Lobster (Pleuroncodes monodon), Yellow Squat Lobster (Cervimunida johni), and especially the deep-sea shrimp (Heterocarpus reedi) off northern and central Chile which operate at depths of 259–498 m depth (González 2001, Acuña and Villarroel 2002, Acuña et al. 2005). In these fisheries it is the most important chondrichthyan species by weight, comprising about 5% of the bycatch (Acuña and Villarroel 2002, Acuña et al. 2005). These fisheries generally operate <500 m depth, so the species has some refuge at the deeper end of its depth range. It is only a minor bycatch of fisheries off Peru (e.g. Quiroz et al. 1994).
population: Population structure is unknown for the Hooktooth Dogfish. This species is common across its range (Ebert 2016). Overall, given the level of fisheries occurring across much of its range balanced with some refuge in deeper waters, it is suspected that the Hooktooth Dogfish has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (51 years) based on levels of exploitation (bycatch).
range: The Hooktooth Dogfish occurs in the Southeast Pacific from Peru to central Chile (Ebert 2016).
useTrade: This species is not utilised and is discarded dead when caught as bycatch.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Hooktooth Dogfish. Management measures of Chilean deep-sea fisheries would benefit this species. Further information is required on this species' ecology and life history, and bycatch levels should be monitored.

rationale: The Pacific Cownose Ray (Rhinoptera steindachneri) is a medium-sized (to 70 cm disc width) bentho-pelagic ray that occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from northern Mexico to northern Peru, including the Gulf of California and the Galápagos Islands. It occurs over the continental shelf from inshore to 65 m depth. This ray is captured in artisanal gillnet fisheries, and demersal shrimp and hake trawl fisheries. Although hake fisheries are patchy across its range, gillnet fishing is intense and unmanaged throughout most of its range and shrimp trawling occurs in many areas. Some of these fisheries, such as the Gulf of California artisanal gillnet fishery, have driven declines in various pelagic marine species; others have been noted for overcapacity, poor governance, and declining catches. However, in the northern portion of its range, it is suspected that the population has been stable over the past 20–25 years. Further south though, it is suspected that the species is declining due to intense levels of generally unmanaged fishing pressure. Balancing these trends, combined with its limited biological productivity and some refuge (e.g. Galápagos Marine Reserve), it is suspected that the Pacific Cownose Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (21 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Pacific Cownose Ray is benthopelagic over the continental shelf from inshore to 65 m depth (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 104 cm disc width (DW); females mature at 70–72 cm DW and males mature at 69–70 cm DW; reproduction is matrotrophic viviparous with an annual reproductive cycle and females give birth to a single pup that is 38–43 cm DW after a gestation period of 10–12 months (Bizzarro et al. 2007, Last et al. 2016, Burgos-Vázquez et al. 2019). Median age-at-maturity is 3.8 years and maximum age is 9.8 years (Burgos-Vázquez 2018), giving a generation length of 6.8 years.
threats: The Pacific Cownose Ray is captured in artisanal gillnet fisheries, and demersal shrimp and hake trawl fisheries. In San Felipe, Baja California, Mexico, it makes up a large portion of the catch in the hake trawl fishery and may be overfished there (Godínez-Padilla and Castillo-Geniz 2016). It is one of the most common batoid species landed in artisanal fisheries in both the northern Gulf of California and in Bahía Almejas, Baja California Sur, Mexico (Bizzarro et al. 2007). These fisheries have caused notable declines in turtles, marine mammals, and pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004). On the Mexican Pacific coast, including the Gulf of California, shrimp trawl fisheries declined from 1,552 boats in 1990 to 757 boats in 2017 (CONAPESCA 2017). Off Mazatlán, the shrimp trawl fishery is noted for its overcapacity, poor governance, and declining catches (Foster and Vincent 2010). In Guatemala, this ray made up over 54% of the biomass of ray bycatch in the industrial demersal shrimp trawl fishery (Ixquiac-Cabrera et al. 2010). In Costa Rica, it is caught in trawls and has a moderate susceptibility (Clarke et al. 2018). Artisanal gillnet fisheries are increasing and unmanaged in areas further south, and there are inadequately managed trawl fisheries in Colombia and Ecuador that are likely to catch this species. Their aggregative behaviour may make them susceptible to being captured in large numbers at one time. Although this species is not very productive, catches are patchy and their continued relative abundance suggests they may be able to withstand some fishing pressure.
population: Catches of the Pacific Cownose Ray in Gulf of California artisanal fisheries were relatively stable between 1997 and 2010 and increased until 2014, likely due to a shift in fishing effort (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016). On the western coast of Baja California, catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) was low between 2000 and 2010 (Ramirez-Amaro et al. 2013). In the northern portion of its range, it is suspected that the population has been stable over the past 20–25 years. Further south though, it is suspected that the species is declining due to intense levels of generally unmanaged fishing pressure. Overall, due to the level of intense unmanaged fishing pressure throughout much of its range, combined with its continued relative abundance in the northern part of its distribution, it is suspected that the Pacific Cownose Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (21 years).
range: The Pacific Cownose Ray occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from northern Mexico to northern Peru, including the Gulf of California and the Galápagos Islands (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This ray is retained and the meat is salted for sale locally and is sometimes used as bait (Bizzarro et al. 2007).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this ray. There is a closed season for targeting elasmobranchs in the Mexican Pacific from May 1st to July 31st, although enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Additionally, targeted industrial fishing of sharks and rays is prohibited in Colombia, with set bycatch limits (up to 35% of bycatch in the national territory; Resolution 1743 of 2017); however, surveillance and compliance requires strengthening. The Galápagos Archipelago is covered by the 133,000 km² Galápagos Marine Reserve which prohibits industrial fishing but allows artisanal fishing (Davos et al. 2007). However, the enforcement of regulations is limited and illegal fishing is prevalent, particularly for sharks (Hearn et al. 2014). Management is needed to ensure that this ray does not become threatened in the near future. Monitoring of landings in artisanal fisheries and of bycatch in trawl fisheries is needed. Further research is needed on life history, and population size and trends.

rationale: The Dwarf Sicklefin Chimaera (Neoharriotta carri) is a medium-sized deep-water chimaera (to at least 120 cm total length) known from the southern Caribbean Sea in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean from Guatemala to Venezuela. It has been recorded from the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 90–600 m. The Dwarf Sicklefin Chimaera is not known to be targeted in commercial fisheries but is occasionally reported as bycatch by demersal fisheries and the effect of fishing, if any, is unknown. Intensive deep-water fishing operations exist in Venezuela, which is about half of its distribution. Elsewhere, the species appears to be abundant off Central America where there are limited to no deep-water fisheries presently. Given the high fishing effort and spatial overlap with the species' range off Venezuela, a population reduction of 20–29% is suspected over the last three generations (45 years) based on actual levels of exploitation, thus meeting Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Dwarf Sicklefin Chimaera has been recorded from the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 90–600 m. It reaches a maximum size of at least 120 cm total length (TL) (O. Lasso-Alcalá, unpubl. data, 2019). Maturity is estimated at ~60 cm TL and 65 cm TL for males and females, respectively. Like all chimaeras, it is oviparous. Generation length is estimated at ~15 years based on ageing data from the larger Rabbitfish (Chimaera montrosa) (Calis et al. 2005).
threats:
The Dwarf Sicklefin Chimaera is not known to be targeted in commercial fisheries, but is occasionally reported as bycatch by demersal trawl, trammel net, gill net, and longline (Benavides et al. 2014, Polanco-Vásquez et al. 2017, O. Lasso-Alcalá, unpubl. data, 2019). 

In Venezuela there are three deep-water fisheries in operation. The first fishery is on the central coast which has a very narrow continental shelf, and where for the last 20 years there have been at least two main deep-water fishery landing sites with varying number of boats operating longline, seines, and traps at depths of 200–800 m, 4–6 days a week. These fisheries target demersal and pelagic bony fishes. The second fishery has been operating off northeast Venezuela on the continental slope of Margarita and La Blanquilla Islands at depths ranging from 200 to 600 m for the past 12–15 years, five days a week. Demersal chondrichthyans are not targeted but are encountered as bycatch. Finally, the third fishery operates on a smaller scale with gillnets and longlines in eastern Venezuela on the Paria Peninsula shelf near Trinidad and Tobago with fewer than 30 boats which are used for a variety of activities including fishing. This is the most recent deep-water fishery to develop and has only been operational for the past 5 years (O. Lasso-Alcalá, unpubl. data, 2019). 

There is increasing interest in developing deep-water fisheries in the Caribbean (e.g. Paramo et al. 2017) and the development of any fishery should be monitored as this species may be susceptible to being caught as bycatch.
population:
No data are available on population size, trends, and structure of the Dwarf Sicklefin Chimaera. A scientific survey conducted in 2011 along the continental shelf on the Caribbean coast of Central America at depths to 1,500 m found that the Dwarf Sicklefin Chimaera was one of the most abundant deep-water chondrichthyans sampled. The species accounted for 16% of chondrichthyan catch, however, sample sizes were relatively small (n=62) (Benavides et al. 2014). 

With part of its distribution subject to intensive fishing pressure (Venezuela, accounting for approximately half of its distribution), a population decline of 20–29% over the last three generations (45 years) is suspected based on actual levels of exploitation.
range: The Dwarf Sicklefin Chimaera is known from the southern Caribbean Sea in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean, from Guatemala to Venezuela (Didier 2002, Benavides et al. 2014).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Dwarf Sicklefin Chimaera. Further information is required on its distribution, ecology, and life history, and the impact of fisheries in the Caribbean Sea.

rationale: The Sicklefin Chimaera (Neoharriotta pinnata) is a medium-sized deep-water chimaera (to at least 150 cm total length) with a wide but patchy distribution in the Eastern Atlantic (primarily off West Africa) and the Northern Indian Oceans. It has been recorded from the upper continental slope at depths of 200–760 m. In India, a local population reduction of 20–29% is suspected over the last three generations (45 years) based on actual levels of exploitation. Across West Africa, there is high uncertainty regarding the effect of regional fishing, but considerable numbers of distant water fleets have operated in the region since the 1960s and a reduction is suspected there also. Further information is required on the distribution, ecology, and life history of the Sicklefin Chimaera, as well as continued monitoring of catch landings in India and interactions with fisheries across West Africa. Given the high spatial overlap with fishing across much of its range, a population reduction of 20–29% is suspected over the last three generations (45 years) based on actual levels of exploitation, thus meeting Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Sicklefin Chimaera is generally recorded from the upper continental slope at depths of 200–622 m (Ebert 2014). The single specimen from the Bay of Biscay was recorded at a depth of 760 m (Diez and Mugerza 2017). It reaches a length of at least 150 cm total length (TL)/58 cm body length (BDL) (Akhilesh et al. 2011, Ebert 2014) and smallest free-swimming individuals were 13–23 cm TL (Ebert 2014). Like other chimaeras, it is oviparous. Generation length is estimated at 15 years based on ageing data from Rabbitfish (Chimaera montrosa) (Calis et al. 2005).
threats: The Sicklefin Chimaera is a major bycatch of deep-water trawl, longline, and gillnet fisheries off India (Akhilesh et al. 2011, Jabado et al. 2017). In this region, fishing pressure is intense across the depth range of this species, and it is landed in significant quantities (Jabado et al. 2017). Outside India, the Sicklefin Chimaera has occasionally been reported by demersal trawls (Krakstad et al. 2011, Ebert 2014). In the Eastern Atlantic, considerable numbers of distant water fleets have operated off West Africa since the 1960s (Alder and Sumaila 2004). The effect of regional fishing on this species in unknown, but is of concern, given the high fishing effort and overlap with the species' known regional distribution.
population:
No data are available on population size, trends, and structure of the Sicklefin Chimaera. It is likely that the Atlantic and Indian Oceans are distinct subpopulations (Jawad et al. 2012).

In Cochin, India, changes in directed deep-water fishing effort resulted in a decline in landings of the Sicklefin Chimaera from 57.9 t to 5.8 t between 2008 and 2011 (Akhilesh and Ganga 2013, Akhilesh 2014). A local reduction of 20–29% is suspected over the last three generations (45 years) based on actual levels of exploitation (Jabado et al. 2017).

Across West Africa, reported landings from distant water fleets increased from 600,000 t to 4.5 million t between 1950 and 2000 (Alder and Sumaila 2004). No commercial data are available for the Sicklefin Chimaera, however, in recent decades, there has been an increase in, or appearance of, reported landings of other deep-water chondrichthyans across the central Atlantic region (e.g. Vasconcellos and Watson 2004). Research surveys conducted across waters off northwest Africa (Guinea to Morocco) reported the species in low abundance (<2% of catches when caught), although these surveys did not sample beyond 500 m (Krakstad et al. 2011). Given the high fishing effort and high spatial overlap with the species' range, it is suspected that the Sicklefin Chimaera has undergone some population reduction (20–29%) over the last three generations based on actual levels of exploitation.
range: The Sicklefin Chimaera is known from off the west coast of Africa (Western Sahara to Namibia) in the Eastern Atlantic Ocean, as well as across the northern Indian Ocean (Gulf of Aden to southeast India and Sri Lanka) (Ebert 2014, Jabado et al. 2017). A single specimen was collected from the southern Bay of Biscay in the Northeast Atlantic (Diez and Mugerza 2017) and this species was also recently reported from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands (Ravi et al. 2018).
useTrade: In India, the species is utilized for its flesh locally and its liver oil is traded internationally, but is considered inferior to deep-water squaliform sharks (Bineesh K.K., unpubl. data). No data on use or trade outside India are available.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for the Sicklefin Chimaera. India has a seasonal ban on mechanised fishing (2 months) which is unlikely to provide much benefit to chondrichthyans given its short duration. Further information is required on the distribution, ecology, and life history of the Sicklefin Chimaera, as well as continued monitoring of catch landings in India and interactions with fisheries across West Africa.

rationale: Mitsukuri’s Chimaera (Hydrolagus mitsukurii) is a medium-sized deep-water chimaera (to at least 79 cm total length) known from a widespread but patchy distribution in the Western Central and Northwest Pacific, from Japan to Papua New Guinea. It has been recorded from the continental slope and deep bays and troughs at depths of 325–710 m. Mitsukuri’s Chimaera is not known to be targeted but is caught as bycatch in artisanal and commercial fisheries. The species' range has high overlap with fishing activities and it does not have refuge in deeper water beyond fishing like some other chimaera species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Mitsukuri’s Chimaera and monitoring of landings across its range is required. Given the high spatial overlap with fishing across much of its range, a population reduction of 20–29% is suspected over the last three generation lengths (45 years) based on actual levels of exploitation, thus meeting Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: Mitsukuri’s Chimaera has been recorded from the continental slope and deep bays and troughs at depths of 325–710 m. It reaches a maximum size of at least 79 cm total length (TL)/37 cm body length (BDL). Maturity occurs ~42 cm BDL for males and ~37 cm BDL for females (Hui-Ling 2005). Size-at-birth is 8–9 cm TL (Cheng 2011). Like other chimaeras, it is oviparous. Generation length is estimated at 15 years based on ageing data from Rabbitfish (Chimaera montrosa) (Calis et al. 2005).
threats: Mitsukuri’s Chimaera is not known to be targeted but is caught as bycatch by commercial bottom trawlers in Taiwan in considerable numbers (Hui-Ling 2005, Cheng 2011). In Japan, chimaeras are caught by set net, dropline, or demersal trawl and may either be discarded at sea or landed. Deep-water demersal trawl fishing occurs off eastern Honshu, and the species is a possible bycatch. A deep-water dropline fishery for Splendid Alfonsino (Beryx splendens) that operates around the islands and seamounts south of Sagami Bay at depths of 400–800 m may take this species as bycatch. Other chimaeras (e.g. the Silver Chimaera, Chimaera phantasma) are commonly observed as landed catch from the trawl fisheries in the East China Sea (A. Yamaguchi, pers. comm., 29/08/2019), where fishing intensity is high (Szuwalski et al. 2016). In the Philippines, fishing for other deep-water chondrichthyans dates back to the 1960s (Flores 2004). Chimaeras (also referred to as 'silversharks') have been collected from local landing sites in the region, but catches are not reported (BFAR 2017). No catch data are available for this species, but its range has high overlap with fishing activities and it doesn't have refuge in deeper water beyond fishing like some other chimaera species.
population:
No data are available on population size, trends, and structure of Mitsukuri’s Chimaera. The species' distribution includes areas of extensive fishing pressure (e.g. Teh et al. 2017) and there is a high degree of overlap between the species' range and fisheries. In Taiwan, landings data on all combined shark species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) showed a 52% decline in all shark species combined over 63 years from 1953–2015 (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics, unpubl. data 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In the Philippines, municipal and commercial shark fisheries production peaked around 1990 (19,049 mt reported collectively); between 1996–2005, municipal fisheries declined at a rate of ~50% and between 1997–2006, commercial fisheries declined ~90% (BFAR 2017). 

Based on actual levels of exploitation, it is suspected that Mitsukuri’s Chimaera has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% across its range over the last three generations (45 years).
range: Mitsukuri’s Chimaera is known from a widespread but patchy distribution in the Western Central and Northwest Pacific, from Japan to Papua New Guinea (White et al. 2017).
useTrade: This species is likely to be marketed and consumed locally when landed.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for Mitsukuri's Chimaera. Further information is required on the distribution, ecology, and life history, and interactions with fisheries and monitoring of catch landings is needed.

rationale: Ogilby’s Chimaera (Chimaera ogilbyi) is a medium-sized deep-water chimaera (to at least 104 cm total length) known from Australia, Indonesia, and Papua New Guinea in the Eastern Indian-Western Pacific Ocean. It has been found on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 139–872 m (most common at 200–500 m). Fishery-independent surveys on the New South Wales (Australia) upper slope between 1976–77 and 1996–97 documented significant declines in catch rate (the equivalent of >99.9% over the last three generations) as a result of intensive trawl fishing on the narrow continental slope. More recently, however, standardized catch-per-unit-effort exhibited no trend for Ogilby’s Chimaera between 1994–2006 suggesting that the population may have stabilized at low levels due to changes in fisheries management. This region is estimated to represent ~10% of the species' known global range. Elsewhere in its wide Australian range, fishing pressure on the upper slope is generally low, and the population reduction recorded in the southeast is not considered representative of the whole Australian range of the species. Although no species-specific data are available from Indonesia, indications that catch rates of other deep-water chondrichthyans are exceeding the maximum exploitation level can be used to infer some population reduction in that part of its range due to levels of exploitation. Given the balance of heavy fishing pressure in some areas with areas of limited threat, a population reduction of 20–29% is suspected over the last three generations (56 years) based on actual levels of exploitation and documented declines, thus meeting Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: Ogilby’s Chimaera has been recorded on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 139–872 m (most common at 200–500 m) (Finucci et al. 2018). It reaches a maximum size of 104 cm total length (TL)/60 cm body length (BDL). Male maturity occurs at ~63 cm TL. Female maturity is unknown, however mature females have been reported at 72 cm TL (without filament; Kyne 2008, C. Rigby unpubl. data). Size-at-birth is ~14 cm TL (White et al. 2017). A generation length of 18.6 years can be estimated from the Rabbitfish (Chimaera monstrosa), which reaches a similar maximum size (Calis et al. 2005). Like other chimaeras, it is oviparous.
threats:
In Australia, a number of demersal fisheries operate in this species' area of occurrence and this species is likely taken as bycatch in these fisheries, however, limited information is available on bycatch levels outside of southeast Australia. Within the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF), Ogilby's Chimaera is considered to have a high catch susceptibility to otter trawl, a medium catch susceptibility to auto hook gear, and a low susceptibility to shark gillnet, shark hook, and trap/pot gear (Walker et al. 2008). Some fisheries operating with the species' range have low effort, particularly the Western Deepwater Trawl Fishery (WDWTF) and the North West Slope Trawl Fishery (NWSTF) (Patterson et al. 2019). An Ecological Risk Assessment of the Great Australian Bight Trawl Sector (GABTS) of the SESSF identified Ogilby's Chimaera as at low risk in the fishery (AFMA 2008). Improved information on the catches of Ogilby's Chimaera in the GABTS should be available in the future as the 2014–2016 Bycatch and Discarding Working Plan for this fishery states that Integrated Scientific Monitoring Program is to include reporting of chondrichthyan catches at species level to enable a time-series of catch to be constructed (AFMA 2014).

Observer and fishery-independent surveys have shown the species to be a bycatch in the Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery (deep-water component of the eastern king prawn sector). This sector does not generally operate beyond 200 m depth and so is at the upper limit of the depth range of Ogilby's Chimaera, although when caught the mortality rate was high (Kyne 2008, C. Rigby, unpubl. data). Outside of this fishery, there is very little other fishing pressure over the species' geographical and bathymetrical depth range off Queensland. Off Western Australia, fishing effort is low, with only a few boats operating in the NWSTF and the WDTF (Patterson et al. 2019).   

In eastern Indonesia, the expansion of deep-water fisheries in the region is underway, and Indonesian deep-water fisheries operate throughout much of the depth range at which this species occurs. Ogilby’s Chimaera is often caught in demersal longline fisheries in parts of Indonesia (White et al. 2006). In Cilacap, Central Java, the species was reported to make up ~8% of chondrichthyan landings (Prihatiningsih and Chodrijah 2018).
population:
The species is likely one population across its geographic range (Finucci et al. 2018).

In Australia, significant declines in the catch of Ogilby’s Chimaera (reported as ‘silver ghostshark’) between 1976–77 and 1996–97 from the upper slope trawl fishery off New South Wales (NSW) have been documented by fishery-independent surveys (Graham et al. 2001). Catches declined from a mean catch rate of 8.3 kg/hour to 0.3 kg/hour in the 20-year period, equating to a decline of >99.9% over three generations (~56 years). Reductions are even more striking when data are broken down into regions, with the mean catch rate off Eden-Gabo Island (northern NSW/southern Victoria) declining from 17.4 kg/hour in 1976–77 to <0.1 kg/hour in 1996–97, equating to a decline of >99.9% over three generations (~56 years). The relatively narrow continental slope off northern/central NSW, including most of the depth range of Ogilby’s Chimaera, is intensively fished and there is continued pressure in this area. More recently, however, standardized catch-per-unit-effort by depth exhibited no trend for Ogilby’s Chimaera between 1994–2006 (Walker and Gason 2007). This suggests that the population may have stabilized at low levels due to changes in fisheries management. This region is estimated to represent ~10% of the species' known global range. Elsewhere in its wide Australian range, fishing pressure on the upper slope is generally low, and the population reduction recorded in the southeast is not considered representative of the whole Australian range of the species. 

In Indonesia, there are no species-specific data on population trends for the species. For other deep-water chondrichthyans, catch landings at Tanjung Luar have indicated that catch rates are exceeding the maximum exploitation level, suggesting regional populations are being over-fished (e.g. Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). The extent of decline in the region is suspected to be 20–30% over the last three generations based on actual levels of exploitation. With no current management action in place, it is suspected that these declines will continue in the future (although in terms of the global population, not at a level triggering the application of Criterion A3).

Globally, it is suspected that Ogilby's Chimaera has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over three generations (~56 years) based on actual levels of exploitation and documented declines in a part of its range.
range: Ogilby’s Chimaera occurs in Australia, Indonesia (Central Java, Bali, and Lombok), and Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) in the Eastern Indian-Western Pacific Ocean (Finucci et al. 2018).
useTrade: The flesh of Ogilby's Chimaera is considered low value, but is utilized (White et al. 2006, Last and Stevens 2009).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Ogilby’s Chimaera. The Upper-Slope Dogfish Management Strategy outlines a combination of management strategies for dogfish species caught in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery, including a network of spatial closures, limited entry, gear restrictions, and regulated handling practices (AFMA 2012). These practices may indirectly provide some benefit for the species. In Indonesia, further information on emerging deep-water fisheries across the species’ range and monitoring of catch landings is needed.

rationale:
The Whitespotted Bambooshark (Chiloscyllium plagiosum) is a small (to 95 cm total length) nocturnal shark with a broad distribution in the Indo-West Pacific ranging from southern India to southern Japan including the Indo-Malay Archipelago and Papua New Guinea. It inhabits shallow coastal inshore and coral reef habitats to a depth of 50 m. The species is a bycatch of a range of artisanal and industrial gears including demersal trawl, longline, and gillnet. It is subject to intense and largely unmanaged fisheries across its range and is landed and utilized for food (although it is of low value) often in high numbers.

Fishing pressure is intense across the range of this species, yet it is still commonly landed in parts of its range; it is the most abundantly caught shark in parts of Taiwan, Malaysia, and Indonesia. There is no long-term trend data on the populations; general long-term shark population trends have shown declines of 37–99% over the past three generation lengths (27 years). The relative proportion of bamboosharks in shark landings has increased significantly over recent decades in the region, which may be in response to the overfishing of large sharks resulting in meso-predator release of this species. It is a relatively productive species and has not declined to the extent that other species have in the region. It is suspected that the Whitespotted Bambooshark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (27 years) based on actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Whitespotted Bambooshark occurs in shallow coastal inshore coral reef habitats; it is nocturnal, resting by day in reef crevices (Compagno 2001). This species reaches a maximum size of 95 cm total length (TL); males mature at 50–60 cm TL and females mature at 65 cm TL (Compagno 2001, Ebert et al. 2013a). Reproduction is oviparous, with information on reproduction only available from captivity (Masuda and Teshima 1994, Miki 1994, Masuda 1998). The maximum laying season reported by Miki (1994) of 87 days yielded 26 eggs from one individual, 11 of which failed to develop. Size-at-birth was reported as 9.8 cm TL by Compagno (2001) but an average of 16.6 cm TL in captivity (Miki 1994, Masuda 1998). In the wild, age-at-maturity is 4.5 years, longevity is estimated at 12.6–14.2 years (Chen et al. 2007), and generation length is estimated at 9 years. This species has been reported to live to 25 years old in captivity (Michael 1993).
threats:
The majority of the distribution of the Whitespotted Bamboo Shark is under substantial, generally unregulated and unmanaged fishing pressure. The species is taken regularly by demersal inshore trawl and gillnet fisheries and despite its low value, is landed and utilised (Compagno 2001, White et al. 2006, Last et al. 2010). It has little refuge from exploitative activities as it has a relatively narrow inshore occurrence, except potentially for some more remote areas of the Indo-Malay Archipelago. Fishing effort and power is continuing to increase in the Asian region (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013) which will continue to place pressure on inshore species.

India has an intensive fishing fleet of trawlers and gillnetters (>23,000; K.K. Bineesh pers. comm. 28/04/ 2020). There is high level of fisheries exploitation with most stocks fully exploited and severe declines in fish stocks, including elasmobranchs (Raje et al. 2002, Mohanraj et al. 2009, CMFRI 2010, Karnad et al. 2014, FAO 2020a). In Sri Lanka, fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 14,000 vessels in 1950 to 63,745 vessels in 2014, with most of the increase since 2000 and >90% of the fleet subsistence and artisanal fisheries operating in coastal areas on the continental shelf (Pauly et al. 2020). The coastal fisheries are likely to be increasingly overfished due to the high fishing effort with offshore fisheries increasing in effort since the early 1980s (Samaraweera and Amarasiri 2004, Dissanayake 2005).

Bangladesh has a substantial artisanal fishing fleet that has been increasing in recent decades with 67,669 vessels reported to be operating in 2017–2018 (DoF 2018, Pauly et al. 2020). The artisanal fishing fleet operates at depths of 0–40 m on average but can operate down to 80 m (Hoq et al. 2014). Most fisheries in Thailand are overexploited. Fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased dramatically from 5,900 vessels in 1950 to a peak of 82,900 vessels in 2004 and then declined steadily to 54,700 vessels in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). The current fishing effort on demersal marine fish stocks is 33% greater than Maximum Sustainable Yield by 32.8% in the Gulf of Thailand, based on recent stock assessments and catch-per-unit effort is declining for the majority of fisheries in the Gulf of Thailand (DoF 2015, Derrick et al. 2017).

Fishing effort in Malaysia has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has more than doubled from 22,800 vessels in 1950 to 50,150 vessels in 2014. However, the substantial increase over this period has been in engine power which has dramatically increased by ~30 fold (Pauly et al. 2020). Species-specific landings monitoring from 2014–2017 in Peninsular Malaysia (4 sites), Sarawak (1 site) and Sabah (1 site) suggests that this species makes up ~8% of total elasmobranch catches from the South China Sea (Arai and Azri 2019). However, more recent data collected in Sarawak state alone for 2017–2019 suggests this species is now landed rarely, despite significant catches of other elasmobranchs (H. Booth, WCS-Malaysia pers. comm. 26/08/2020).

In Indonesia, fishing effort is intense and across all sectors has been increasing since 1950s with steep increases in effort since the 1980s (Tull 2014). Indonesia has the largest chondrichthyan fishery globally, and substantial catches of target and bycatch chondrichthyans (White et al. 2006). It has been among the top shark fishing nations for over 20 years (Oakes and Sant 2019). This species is the most abundant shark in the Indonesian aquarium trade (Fahmi unpupl. data 2020), though species-specific landings data from Lombok and Aceh indicate suggest the species is landed infrequently, despite relatively large landings of Grey Carpetshark (C. punctatum) and other bamboo sharks (Yulianto et al. 2018, H. Booth pers. comm. 26/08/2020).

Coastal fisheries in Cambodia are considered overexploited (Teh et al. 2014a). Fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 26,180 vessels in 1950 to 108,490 vessels in 2014, with most of the increase since the 1980s and most of the fleet artisanal fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The marine fisheries are mostly inshore and small-scale within 10 km of the shore and occur across all habitats, including coral reefs, seagrass, mangroves, and estuaries. Most marine stocks in Viet Nam have been declining since the 1990s and are now considered fully or over-exploited with a lack of adequate enforcement leading to essentially unregulated fisheries (Teh et al. 2014b, FAO 2020b). The motorized fishing fleet has been increasing since the 1950s and rapidly expanded in the mid-1980s to 2000s when Viet Nam moved towards a market-orientated economy (Teh et al. 2014b). The fleet is dominated by small-scale artisanal and subsistence fisheries that have accounted for 60–85% of the fleet since the 1950s (Teh et al. 2014b, Pauly et al. 2020).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished. The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s Exclusive Economic Zone significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive demersal trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). 

Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include habitat destruction and degradation, and pollution (e.g. heavy metals) (Heileman and Tang 2009, Heileman 2009, MacKinnon et al. 2012). In both the East and South China Seas, reclamation has contributed to a dramatic reduction in coastal and mangrove wetlands, with a loss of 70% of mangroves in the last 70 years in the South China Sea, where there has also been modification of up to 50% of seagrass beds and degradation of significant areas of coral reef habitat (Heileman and Tang 2009, Heileman 2009). In Viet Nam, dynamite and cyanide fishing, and sedimentation have caused widespread destruction of coral reefs (Jameson et al. 1995, FAO 2020b).
population:
The Whitespotted Bambooshark is an abundant inshore species. It is reported as the most abundant shark captured in north and west Taiwan, though no species-specific trend data is available (Ebert et al. 2013b). It is one of the dominant shark species landed in Thailand (Krajangdara 2019). In Sabah, Malaysia, this species is one of the most abundantly caught sharks (B.M. Manjaji Matsumoto unpubl. data 2020). While in Sarawak, Malaysia, this species is sometimes recorded in domestic fish markets, though rarely recorded at landing sites (H. Booth pers. comm. 25th August 2020). This species is thought to account for ~8% of total landings, based on catches from Malaysian vessels in the South China Sea (data collection from 4 sites in Peninsular Malaysia, 1 site in Sabah and 1 site in Sarawak)  (Arai and Azri 2019).

Monitoring of fish landing sites in Southeast Asia have shown that the relative proportion of Whitespotted Bambooshark in shark landings has increased significantly over recent decades due to declines in large sharks and retention of the remaining smaller species (Lam and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2011, Lack and Sant 2012, Arunrugstichai et al. 2018). This general trend has been seen across fish stocks across the region where smaller-sized fish are being landed as a result of fishing down the ecosystem; a consequence of intensive fishing that changes the size composition of the catch (e.g. China; Pauly and Liang 2019).

Despite the lack of species-specific trend data, catches of all sharks combined are available for the Gulf of Thailand and reconstructed catches of sharks, rays, and skates are available from 1950 to 2014 for the Bangladesh, Cambodia, Viet Nam, and China Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ), based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In the Gulf of Thailand, landings data of all sharks showed a 96% reduction over 16 years from 2003 to 2018. Catches rose steadily from 1998 to a peak catch of 9,005 t in 2003 followed by a steady decline in catches to ~400 t in 2014 (Krajangdara 2019). It is difficult to infer a population trend as the steep decline in catches from 2003–2018 coincided with a decline in fishing effort.

In Bangladesh, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates showed a 34% decline in landings over 15 years from 2000 to 2014. Catches gradually rose from 195 t in 1950 to 7,540 t in 1973 then declined to 3,500 t in the mid-1980s, rose steeply to a peak of 10,909 t in 2000 followed by a fluctuating decline to 7,163 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). In Cambodia, the reconstructed catch data showed a 91% reduction over 12 years from 2003 to 2014. Catches sharply rose from 1950 to a peak of 4,550 t in 1970, dropped sharply then rose over two decades to another peak catch of 3,914 t in 2003 followed by a sharp decline in catches to 335 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings of sharks and rays can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort was increasing during the period of a decline in landings (Teh et al. 2014a, Pauly et al. 2020). In Viet Nam, reconstructed shark and ray catch declined by 97% over 29 years from 1986 to 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Historically, catches gradually rose from 1,560 t in 1950 to ~44,000 t per year in the mid-1960s, fluctuated and then rose steeply during the early-1980s to a peak of 466,445 t in 1986 followed by a fairly steady decline to 14,750 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially during the period of a decline in catch (Teh et al. 2014b, Pauly et al. 2020). In China, reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline over the 65 years from 1950 to 2014. The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to bottom trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these reconstructed catch declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Whitespotted Bambooshark (27 years) they represent declines of 56%, 99%, 96%, and 37% in Bangladesh, Cambodia, Viet Nam, and China respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. Elsewhere, in Malaysia, the relative proportion of bamboosharks (Chiloscyllium spp.) in landings has doubled over recent years (Arshad et al. 2006, Lack and Sant 2012, SEAFDEC 2016). In Indonesia, net and trawl fisheries (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). In Taiwan, although this is reported as the most abundantly caught shark in 2013 (Ebert et al. 2013b), the landings of small demersal sharks declined by 80% over a 10-year period from 1993 to 2003 (Chen et al. 2007). The long-term declines in small demersal shark abundance can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s industrial fisheries effort.

The relative proportion of bamboosharks in shark landings has increased significantly over recent decades in the region and the Whitespotted Bambooshark may have benefited from meso-predator release due to the overfishing of large sharks (B.M. Manjaji Matsumoto and S. Fowler unpubl. data 2020). However, the fishing pressure across its range is intense and general long-term shark population trends have shown declines of 37–99% over the past three generation lengths (27 years). This species is still very abundant in many parts of its range; it is a relatively productive species, therefore it has not declined to the extent that other species have in the region. Overall, it is suspected that the Whitespotted Bambooshark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (27 years) based on actual levels of exploitation.
range: The Whitespotted Bambooshark has a broad distribution in the Indo-West Pacific ranging from southern India to southern Japan including the Indo-Malay Archipelago and Papua New Guinea (Manjaji 2002, Ebert et al. 2013a, White et al. 2017). Its presence in Myanmar is uncertain (Ebert et al. 2013a). References to the species in the southwest Indian Ocean refer to the Bluespotted Bambooshark (Chiloscyllium caeruleopunctatum).
useTrade: The Whitespotted Bambooshark is landed and widely utilized across its range for its meat or as fish meal, although it is of low-value due its small size (White et al. 2006, Last et al. 2010).
