This species is valued at roughly USD $2/kg in Malaysia but may fetch a greater value when sold as 'fish fillets' in wet markets (H. Booth pers comm 7th October 2020, B.M. Manjaji Matsumoto unpubl. data 2020). This species is also sold live in seafood restaurants in the 'Live Reef Fish Food Trade' (B.M. Manjaji Matsumoto unpubl. data 2020). It is a popular aquarium species (Ebert et al. 2013a). Fins of the genus Chiloscyllium have been reported in the Hong Kong fin trade, though they represented a small percentage of total samples (Fields et al. 2018)
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place. In Thailand, all commercial fishing vessels greater than 10 Gross Tonnage (GT) are prohibited to fish within three nautical miles from the shore (DoF 2015). Throughout Malaysia there are 51 Marine Protected Areas making up 5,462 km2 that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020). In Indonesia, trawls were banned from use in 1980, however, mini trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country (Chong et al. 1987). In Taiwan, there is a prohibition on using any net fishing gear (e.g. trawls, seine nets) in 68 reef areas (Fisheries Agency 2019). Since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 GT (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Since the mid–2000s, gillnets have been banned within 3 nm in parts of five counties with a policy of gradual removal of gillnets from within 3 nm of the entire coast and government assistance to transition to line and troll fishing (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). This species may be protected in some of the ~32 Protected Areas which cover ~38% of the Taiwan coastline and ~47% of Taiwan territorial seas, with no-entry and no-take areas accounting for accounting for 0.9% and 4.6% of the territorial seas, respectively (MacKinnon et al. 2012, Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the East and South China Sea to 12⁰N (Yu and Yu 2008). In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Some of the species range may be protected along the China coastline as it is estimated that ~20% of the coastline is included in Protected Areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012). Research is required to better define the population size and trends, and life history of the Whitespotted Bambooshark, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Atlantic Sawtail Catshark (Galeus atlanticus) is a small (to at least 46 cm total length) deep-water catshark found in the Northeastern and Central Atlantic Oceans (from Spain, Portugal, and Morocco, possibly to Mauritania) and the Mediterranean Sea around the Straits of Gibraltar. It is demersal on the continental slope at depths of 328–790 m. The Atlantic Sawtail Catshark is infrequently reported as bycatch across its range in demersal trawl fisheries and longline fisheries but is likely to be confused with the related Blackmouth Catshark (G. melastomus). Off West Africa, there are a number of European distant-water vessels using demersal trawl and longline to target demersal fish and shrimp species that reach the depth limit of the species. In the Northeast Atlantic, there are various management actions that apply to listed deep-water sharks, including a prohibited on targeted fisheries, a Total Allowable Catch (TAC) for shark bycatch in longline fisheries targeting Black Scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp), and depth limits beyond which gillnets and demersal trawl fisheries are prohibited in some areas. Overall, there is high distribution overlap with intensive fishing pressure, increasing trends in the Mediterranean, and some species-specific management across part of its range. The Atlantic Sawtail Catshark is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (45 years) based on abundance indices and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Atlantic Sawtail Catshark is demersal on the continental slope at depths of 328–790 m (Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 46 cm total length (TL) (Weigmann 2016). Males mature at 33–42 cm TL and females mature at 37–45 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is oviparious and one female was found with nine egg cases (Ebert et al. 2013). Nothing else is known of its biology. Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from a related species, the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) that has a female age-at-maturity of 9.1 years and a maximum age of 20.9 years, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011).
threats:
The Atlantic Sawtail Catshark is infrequently reported as bycatch in demersal trawl and trammel net fisheries (Moura et al. 2018, González-García et al. 2020). It is likely to be misidentified with the related Blackmouth Catshark (G. melastomus) and is more common than previously known. 

The Northeast Atlantic and the Mediterranean have been subject to extensive and intensive deep-water fishing across the entirety of the species' known depth and spatial distribution (Coelho et al. 2007). In the Northeast Atlantic, there were a number of demersal trawl and longline fisheries targeting mixed deep-water sharks along the continental slope (Gordon 1999, ICES-WGEF 2019). Despite a number of management measures to reduce deep-water shark fishing mortality, deep-water sharks are still captured occasionally in demersal fisheries (e.g. Moura et al. 2018). Off the southern coast of Portugal, the species has been regularly captured by deep-water longline fisheries targeting wreck fish (Polyprion americanus) and conger eels (Conger conger) (Coelho et al. 2007).  

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). 

There are currently three active mixed fishery bilateral agreements between the European Union and the West African nations of Morocco, Mauritania, and Guinea-Bissau (European Commission 2020). These agreements, known as Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (SFPAs) involve payments to third party countries in exchange for access to marine resources and sectorial support aimed at promoting sustainable fisheries development in the partner countries. Under SFPAs, demersal trawl and longline fisheries in southern Morocco target a number of demersal fish, including black hake (Merluccius senegalensis and Merluccius polli) and scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp). Trawl fishing there occurs mostly at depths of 500–800 m and longline fishing occurs at 100–400 m (Cervantes et al. 2018). Further information on bycatch species in these fisheries is largely unknown.
population:
Taxonomic uncertainty and identification issues have led to some confusion over the occurrence of the Atlantic Sawtail Catshark, and the species is often misidentified as the related Blackmouth Catshark (G. melastomus). Species-specific population trend data are available from relative abundance in the Mediterranean (Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2020). The trend data were analysed over three generation lengths (45 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherly et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information). The trend analysis of the relative abundance estimates from the Mediterranean International Trawl Survey (MEDITS; 2000–2015) in the Northern Alboran Sea (Spain) revealed an annual rate of increase of 7.6%, consistent with no major reductions in population over three generation lengths (45 years). While many chondrichthyans have exhibited population reduction in the Mediterranean Sea, the Atlantic Sawtail Catshark was one of two species where stability was observed in both density and standardized biomass since the early 1990s (Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2020).

Off western Morocco, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates data showed a 22% decline in landings from 1997 to 2016. Historically, landings increased from 7,192 t in 1950 to 14,553 t in 1969, fluctuated thereafter and further increased to a peak of 37,629 t in 1997 (Pauly et al. 2020). In 2016, landings were estimated at 29,189 t (Pauly et al. 2020). Declines in landings can be inferred to represent population reductions as fishing effort increased substantially during this time (Pauly et al. 2020). This represents a 45% decline when scaled to three generation lengths (45 years) of the Atlantic Sawtail Catshark. This level of decline is not species-specific but is informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in Morocco.

Across the regions, the Atlantic Sawtail Catshark was estimated to have increased in the Mediterranean and suspected to have declined in the Eastern Central Atlantic. With high levels of exploitation across its known range, a global population reduction of 20–29% is suspected over three generation lengths (45 years). Therefore, the Atlantic Sawtail Catshark is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
range: The Atlantic Sawtail Catshark is found in the Northeastern and Central Atlantic Oceans (from Spain, Portugal, and Morocco, possibly to Mauritania) and the Mediterranean Sea around the Straits of Gibraltar (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The species is not known to be utilized and is likely discarded when captured (Ebert and Stehamann 2013).
conservationActions:
In 2010, the European Union Fisheries Council prohibited direct fishing for deep-water sharks in European Community and international waters, and in 2012, no allowances for bycatch were implemented (ICES-WGEF 2019). Since 2017, a restrictive bycatch allowance (10 t) was trialled, permitting limited landings of unavoidable catches of deep-water sharks in directed artisanal demersal longline fisheries for Black Scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp). Additional management actions for this region include banned use of trawls and gillnets in waters >200 m depth in Azores, Madeira and Canary Islands and international waters regulated by ICES (NEAFC regulatory Area); banned use of gillnets by European Union vessels at depths >600 m; maximum bycatch limits of deep-water shark in Hake (Merluccius merluccius) and Monkfish (Lophius spp) gillnet catches; area restrictions by vessel size and gear, gear restrictions (hook size, maximum number of hooks on longline gear), and a network of closed areas in Azorean waters; closure of the Condor seamount to deep-water fishing in 2010 (ICES-WGEF 2019).

The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) banned demersal trawling below depths >1,000 m in the Mediterranean Sea in 2005. For European vessels fishing in Moroccan waters, there is a 5% bycatch limit for demersal sharks (European Commission 2020). Further information is required on its distribution, ecology and life history, as well as interactions with distant-water fleets fishing in African waters.

rationale: The Venezuela Skate (Rostroraja cervigoni) is a small (to at least 51 cm total length) skate that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic from eastern Colombia to Suriname, including Trinidad and Tobago. It is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 37–549 m. This skate is likely retained as utilized bycatch and consumed or sold locally, and it may also be traded internationally due to increasing demand from Asian (Korean) markets. It is captured in intense and largely unmanaged commercial and artisanal demersal trawl fisheries in at least one-third of its range. Consequently, it is suspected that the Venezuela Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (22 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Venezuela Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 37–549 m (Last et al. 2016, García 2017). This species reaches a maximum size of at least 51 cm total length (TL), and males are mature at 50 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Like other skates, it is oviparous. Generation length is suspected to be ~7.4 years, similar to that of the congeneric Roundel Skate (Rostroraja texana), which has an age-at-maturity of 5.8 years and a maximum age of 9 years (Sulikowski et al. 2007).
threats: The Venezuela Skate is captured in commercial and artisanal demersal trawl fisheries, which are intense in parts of its range. There is likely little threat in Caribbean Colombia, as there are no trawl fisheries that operate at depths inhabited by this species (A. Navia unpubl. data 2018). In Venezuela, commercial and artisanal fisheries are intense, unmanaged, and have exhibited the peaks in catches followed by declines indicative of sequential overfishing (Mendoza 2015). At least three intense artisanal fisheries operate there that catch this species. In Trinidad and Tobago, there were over 130 trawl vessels of various sizes operating off the west and south coasts of Trinidad by 2011 (Mohammed et al. 2011). Groundfish fisheries on the Brazil-Guianas shelf were already fully over-exploited by 2000; these fisheries are multi-gear, multi-species, and multinational, with vessels crossing national maritime borders (Booth et al. 2001). Although there are a lot of shrimp trawl vessels targeting Atlantic Seabob (Xiphopenaeus kroyeri) off Guyana, this fishery operates in shallower areas than this skate and does not appear to interact with it (Garstin and Oxenford 2018). The presence of deeper trawling operations there is unclear at this time. Overall, this species is subjected to intense and unmanaged fishing pressure over at least one third of its range.
population: In Colombia, this species has been very rarely reported (Grijalba et al. 2009, García and Armenteras 2015). Inadequately managed trawl fisheries are suspected to have caused unsustainable fishing mortality over at least one third of this species' range. Due to the level of unmanaged fishing pressure this species is exposed to, it is suspected that it has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (22 years).
range: The Venezuela Skate occurs in the Western Central Atlantic from eastern Colombia to Suriname, including Trinidad and Tobago (Last et al. 2016, Mejía-Falla and Navia 2019).
useTrade: This skate is likely retained as utilised bycatch and consumed or sold locally, it may also be traded internationally due to increasing demand from Asian (Korean) markets (Dent and Clarke 2015).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for the Venezuela Skate. Management measures are needed to ensure that this species does not become threatened in the near future. Further research is needed on distribution, life history, and population size and trends, and bycatch should be monitored to the species level in all fisheries.

rationale: Rogers’ Round Ray (Urotrygon rogersi) is a small (to ~46 cm total length) ray which occurs from the Gulf of California, Mexico to Ecuador in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific. It inhabits shallow inshore and continental shelf waters to at least 30 m depth. This species is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries across its range. It is the most abundant round ray in small-scale shrimp trawling in Colombia and is also abundant in the bycatch of the Costa Rican industrial shrimp trawl fishery. It is generally discarded although round rays may be used as bait or fishmeal by artisanal fishers. Tropical Eastern Pacific round rays have life history parameters including very early age-at-maturity (1 year for Rogers' Round Ray) that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality. Rogers' Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge. However, its continued abundance despite high overlap with fisheries suggests that the population may not have declined as much as that suspected for some other tropical Eastern Pacific round rays. Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, balanced with high biological productivity, it is suspected that Rogers' Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: Rogers’ Round Ray inhabits shallow inshore and continental shelf waters to at least 30 m depth (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of ~46 cm total length (TL) and males mature at ~29 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is viviparous with a continuous triannual reproductive cycle, a gestation period of 4–5 months, and a litter size of 1–3 pups (Mejía-Falla et al. 2012). Growth rates are high, female age-at-maturity is 1 year; female maximum age is 8 years (Mejía-Falla 2012, Mejía-Falla et al. 2012, 2014b); and, generation length is 4.5 years. These life history parameters result in a high population growth rate (Mejía-Falla 2012).
threats:
This species is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries across its range. In Mexico, this is a common species in the shrimp trawl fishery (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016), but is a minor proportion of artisanal batoid landings (Marquez-Farias 2002). In the Gulf of California, Saldaña-Ruiz et al. (2016) estimated that this species had a low level of catch between 1997 and 2014, with a slight increase during 2012–2014. It is the most abundant round ray in small-scale shrimp trawling in Colombia (Mejía-Falla et al. 2014a) and is also abundant in the bycatch of the Costa Rican industrial shrimp trawl fishery, although not as common as the Spinytail Round Ray (Urotrygon aspidura) (Clarke et al. 2016, Clarke et al. 2018). In El Salvador, catches in the industrial trawl fishery are in low numbers (Fuentes and Hernández 2004). Within the Gulf of Panama there are fisheries for small pelagic fishes (anchovies, herrings etc.) that operate on soft-benthic coastal habitats and which take this species as bycatch (CeDePesca 2016).

Overall, there is high spatial overlap with fisheries (which generally lack management or effective enforcement of regulations across most of its range), and given the geographic and depth range of the species, it has no refuge from fishing activities that operate across its range. Its life history however, may allow it to withstand significant levels of fishing mortality (Mejía-Falla et al. 2012, 2014).
population:
There are no available data on population trend of Rogers' Round Ray. In Mexico, it is an abundant species (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016). In Costa Rica, it is a relatively common species in the industrial shrimp trawl fishery (Clarke et al. 2016, Espinoza et al. 2018). In Panama, it is relatively frequent in shallow-water fisheries for small pelagic fishes (CeDePesca 2016). In Colombia, it is the most abundant elasmobranch caught in small-scale trawl fisheries, but is not abundant in the large-scale (industrial) trawl fishery (Mejía-Falla et al. 2014a, Navia and Mejía-Falla 2016). In El Salvador, it is encountered in low numbers (Fuentes and Hernández 2004). 

In the Tehuantepec Gulf, Mexico, demographic models suggest population declines of the related Chilean Round Ray (Urotyrgon chilensis) under some scenarios, but not under other scenarios; overall the model results were not conclusive to ascertain population trend (Guzmán-Castellanos 2015).

Biological data from tropical Eastern Pacific round rays show life history parameters, including very early ages-at-maturity (1 year for Rogers’ Round Ray; Mejía-Falla et al. 2014b), that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality (Mejía-Falla 2012, Mejía-Falla et al. 2012, 2014b).

Rogers' Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge. However, its continued abundance despite high overlap with fisheries suggests that the population may not have declined as much as that suspected for other tropical Eastern Pacific round rays. Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, balanced with the high biological productivity of tropical Eastern Pacific round rays, it is suspected that Rogers' Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years).
range: Rogers’ Round Ray occurs from the Gulf of California, Mexico to Ecuador in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific (McEachran and Notarbartolo-di-Sciara 1995, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Round rays are of little commercial value due to their small size. They are often discarded when caught, although there may be some retention in small-scale (artisanal) fisheries for meat, fish meal, or bait.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for Rogers' Round Ray. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki pers. comm. 2019). <span class="msoins0">A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Further research is needed on life history, the level of mortality due to fisheries, and population size and trend. Both small- and large-scale fisheries should be monitored for bycatch at the species level.

rationale: The Acutenose Skate (Dipturus tengu) is a medium-sized (to at least 113 cm total length) skate endemic to the Northwest and Western Central Pacific Oceans from southern Russia to the eastern Philippines. It is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 45–400 m. The species is likely a bycatch of demersal trawl and longline and is retained in Taiwan, and possibly South Korea and the Philippines, for human consumption and fish meal, and is variously retained and discarded in parts of Japan. There are no species-specific population trend data. It is considered to be a rare species, and it is infrequently captured in Japan and Taiwan, rare in South Korea, and not reported from fisheries in the Philippines. Medium to large Dipturus species are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity, which is of concern for the Acutenose Skate. However, this species has refuge from fishing pressure at depth across some of its range and although historic fishing pressure was high, the fishing pressure has declined across some of its range over the past 30 years. It is suspected that the Acutenose Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (39 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Acutenose Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope on sandy and muddy substrates at depths of 45–400 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 113 cm total length (TL); males and female size-at-maturity are unknown (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Ages are inferred from two similar-sized deep-water skates; the Yellownose Skate (D. chilensis) at 128-158 cm TL and Sharpnose Skate (D. oxyrinchus) at 100 cm TL, which have female ages-at-maturity of 14 years and 8 years and maximum ages of 21 years and 9 years, resulting in generation lengths of 17.5 years and 8.5 years, respectively (Licandeo et al. 2006, Yigin and Ismen 2010). Thus, the generation length of the Acutenose Skate is inferred as 13 years.
threats:
The Acutenose Skate is subject to fishing pressure across its spatial range. It is a rare and infrequent bycatch from deep-water demersal trawl and longline fisheries and retained for human consumption or fish meal in Taiwan, and possibly South Korea and the Philippines. It is discarded in Japanese waters of the East China Sea but is retained in the Tohoku region (ex Aomori Prefecture) (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). In Japan, this species is occasionally recorded and may be captured by demersal trawl fisheries that operate at depths of 200–800 m (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). It may also be captured by a deepwater dropline fishery for Splendid Alfonsino (Beryx splendens) that operates around the islands and seamounts south of Sagami Bay at depths of 400–800 m (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019).

In South Korea, it may be captured in trawl and longline fisheries. Fishing effort in South Korea increased markedly in the 1990s, when the number of fishing boats increased to 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean Exclusive Economic Zone (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In Taiwan, the species is often confused with the Giant Skate (D. gigas) which is observed infrequently at Da-xi fish market in the northeast (Ebert et al. 2013). It is presumed to be taken as bycatch of deep-water trawl fisheries that operate off the northeast coast of Taiwan at depths of 200–700 m; these fisheries target multiple species of shrimp with all the incidental catch retained (D.A. Ebert pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Although there are no detailed effort data, the number of trawl vessels operating in the northeast of Taiwan has remained fairly stable from 1999 to 2008 (H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The deep-water longline fisheries on the east coast of Taiwan operate at depths of 100–300 m (H. Ho and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28/08/2019) and may interact with this species.

In the Philippines, the Acutenose Skate is only known from one specimen from Boguato Island (Compagno et al. 2005). It may be encountered by trawl fisheries that operate to a maximum depth of 200 m (D. Tanay pers. comm. 24/04/2020). It may have previously been encountered in the Philippines by bottom set multiple hook-and-line gear that targeted dogfish sharks for their liver oil; the fishery was intensive from the 1960s–1980s and still operates but at an artisanal scale (Flores 2004, Gaudiano and Alava 2003, D. Tanay and J. Utzurrum pers. comm. 24/04/2020). In Cagayancillo, Palawan, Philippines, there are ~28 vessels in operation, setting demersal longlines at depths of 700–1,400 m (LAMAVE 2017) which is much deeper than the depth range of the Acutenose Skate.
population: There are no species-specific population trend data for this species. It is considered to be very rare and is infrequently encountered in commercial fisheries; it is caught occasionally in Japan and Taiwan, is noted as rare in South Korea, and it has not been reported as commercially caught in the Philippines. Medium to large Dipturus species are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity, as evidenced by population reductions of 75–88% in response to intense fishing pressure over 20–30 years (see Red List assessments: Yellownose Skate (D. chilensis) and Grey Skate (D. canutus)). The Acutenose Skate is also likely to have low biological productivity which is of concern, however it has refuge from fishing pressure at depth across some of its range. Historical fishing pressure was intense, but has declined across most of its range over the past 30 years. It is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (39 years).
range: The Acutenose Skate is endemic to the Northwest and Western Central Pacific Oceans from Sakhalin Island, Russia to the east coast of the Philippines, off Boguato Islands, including Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan (Jeong 1999, Compagno 2005, Dyldin 2015, Last et al. 2016, Dyldin and Orlov 2018).
useTrade: No information is available on use and trade; similar skates are retained in Taiwan for human consumption or fish meal.
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In Taiwan, since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In the Philippines in 1998, active fishing gears, including tuna longlines, were prohibited within municipal marine waters (<3 nm from shore). Research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catches should be monitored.

rationale: The Spinytail Skate (Bathyraja spinicauda) is a large (to 182 cm total length) skate that occurs in the North Atlantic from Rhode Island, USA to the Davis Strait, southern Greenland, Iceland, the Faroe and Shetland Islands, and the Norwegian shelf and slope north to Fugløy Bank and Svalbard. It is demersal on continental and insular shelves and slopes at depths of 140–1,650 m. Threats to this skate include capture in demersal trawl and longline fisheries, and habitat shifts due to climate change. There are no overall estimates of population size. In Canada, two available catch-per-unit-effort time-series indicate a steady slow increase on the Grand Banks, and a severe decline off the Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf into the 1990s which was followed by a slow increase since then (although the latter decline may be attributable to a habitat shift due to climate change). There are no data from elsewhere in its range, but it is likely to have some refuge from fishing at depth in other areas. Overall, due to the level of fishing mortality it is subjected to, its large size and limiting life history characteristics that make it unable to withstand unmanaged fishing pressure, possible shifts in habitat due to climate change, and its partial refuge at depth, it is suspected that this skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (68.7 years). Therefore, the Spinytail Skate is assessed as Near Threatened, nearly meeting the threshold for Vulnerable A2bcd.
habitat: The Spinytail Skate is demersal on continental and insular shelves and slopes at depths of 140–1,650 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 182 cm total length (TL), and size at maturity is unknown. Reproduction is oviparous, and young hatch at about 21 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Generation length (GL) is suspected to be about 22.9 years, based on data available for the congeneric Graytail Skate (Bathyraja griseocauda), which has a maximum size of 157 cm TL, a female age-at-maturity of 17.8 years, and a longevity of 28 years (Arkhipkin et al. 2008).
threats: This skate is captured in demersal longline and trawl fisheries. It is likely to be retained in many areas and, where it is discarded, mortality is suspected to be high. In Canadian waters, it is captured in the Greenland Halibut (Reinhardtius hippoglossoides) fishery; however, the effort and areas fished peaked in the 1970s and 1980s and declined substantially in the 1990s and since then (D.W. Kulka unpubl. data 2019). It is also captured there in the Atlantic Halibut (Hippoglossus hippoglossus) fishery off the Scotian Shelf (Hurley et al. 2019). Fishing activities in the Northeast Atlantic are moving into deeper water and effort is increasing, which is some cause for concern and requires careful monitoring. It is suspected that there is some refuge from fishing in deeper waters. Changing ocean temperatures are a concern for this species, as it has notably moved to deeper waters for extended periods of time during periods of warmer waters over the shelf and slope (Devine et al. 2006) in concert with changing conditions related to the North Atlantic Oscillation (e.g. see Pinto et al. 2012).
population:
There are no data available on the absolute global population size of Spinytail Skate. Population trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information). Population trend data are available from two sources in Canada: (1) Grand Banks (3LNOPs) spring survey catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) for 1996–2018, (2) Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf (2J3KL) fall CPUE (1977–2017) (D.W. Kulka unpubl. data 2019). 

First, the trend analysis of the Grand Banks (3LNOPs) spring survey CPUE index of mature individuals for 1996–2018 (22 years) revealed a steady annual rate of increase of 3.71%, consistent with an estimated and projected median increase of 179% over three generation lengths (68.7 years). 

Second, the trend analysis of the Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf (2J3KL) fall CPUE 1978–2017 (41 years) revealed an initial decline until the mid-1990s, followed by population stabilization. The overall annual rate of decrease of 5.3% is consistent with an estimated median decrease of 97.4% over three generation lengths (68.7 years). The time-series reveals a phase of steep decline until 1992, thereafter the population index increased in a manner very similar to the increasing abundance estimated off the Grand Banks (3LNOPs) during the same time period. This earlier decline appears to coincide with a movement by the population in 1978–1984 into deeper waters, with reduced distribution at shallower depths 500–750 m and greater relative abundance at 750–1,000 m (D.W. Kulka unpubl. data 2019). Hence, the severity of decline reflects a deepening and lower catchability rather than reflecting a population reduction.

Taken together, there had been steep population reduction on the Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf (2J3KL) that appears consistent with an assessment of Critically Endangered by the mid-1990s (Devine et al. 2006). However, this decline may at least partially reflect a reduction in catchability, as much the population deepened in response to climate change (D.W. Kulka unpubl. data 2019). Since then, however, the population index has been stable or increasing slightly on both the Grand Banks (3NOPs) and the Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf (2J3K).

There are no data from other parts of its range, but it is suspected that it likely only interacts with fisheries in the upper portion of its depth range, and that the population is thus stable in areas outside Canada.

Overall, due to the level of fishing mortality it is subjected to, its large size and limiting life history characteristics that likely make it unable to withstand unmanaged fishing pressure, along with possible shifts in habitat due to climate change and its refuge at depth, it is suspected that this skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (68.7 years).
range: The Spinytail Skate occurs in the Northwest and Northeast Atlantic from Rhode Island, USA to the Davis Strait, southern Greenland, Iceland, the Faroe and Shetland Islands, and the Norwegian shelf and slope north to Fugløy Bank and Svalbard (Dolgov et al. 2005, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This skate is taken as bycatch and may possibly be retained, with the ‘wings’ used for human consumption.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for the Spinytail Skate.

In Canada, it is not currently protected or regulated, but is a mid-priority candidate species for detailed status assessment by COSEWIC (Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada). Continued monitoring is essential to document catch, discard and retention levels. While quotas exist in Canadian waters for Thorny Skate (Amblyraja radiata), there are none in place for Spinytail Skate. The Greenland Halibut fishery in which Spinytail Skate is taken as bycatch is regulated for the target species, and as such this has a secondary effect on levels of bycatch. Effort in fishing for both Greenland Halibut and grenadier (Macrouridae spp.) has decreased in Canadian waters. The Atlantic Halibut fishery is certified by the Marine Stewardship Council, and has measures in place to reduce bycatch that include selective fishing gear, closed areas or seasons, bycatch quotas and caps, and incentive programs (although none are specific to Spinytail Skate) (O'Keefe et al. 2014, Hurley et al. 2019).

rationale: The Giant Skate (Dipturus gigas) is a large (to 186 cm total length) skate endemic to the Northwest and Western Central Pacific from southern Japan to Taiwan and to the northern Philippines. It is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 300–1,000 m. The species is likely a bycatch of deep-water demersal trawl and longline and is retained in Taiwan, and possibly the Philippines, for human consumption and fish meal, and is likely discarded in Japan. There is no species-specific population trend data. The species is rarely captured in Japan, infrequently captured in Taiwan, and not reported from fisheries in the Philippines. Large Dipturus species are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity, which is of concern for the Giant Skate. However, this species has significant refuge from fishing pressure at depth and although historic fishing pressure was high, the fishing pressure has declined across most of its range over the past 30 years. It is suspected that the Giant Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (51 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Giant Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope on sandy and muddy substrates at depths of 300–1,000 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of ~186 cm total length (TL); males are mature by 135 cm TL and females mature at 115 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous with very large egg cases of 23 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Nothing else is known of its biology. Ages are inferred from two similar-sized deep-water skates; the Yellownose Skate (D. chilensis) and Bight Skate (D. gudgeri) which have female ages-at-maturity of 14 years and 16 years and maximum ages of 21 years and 18 years, resulting in generation lengths of 17.5 years and 17 years, respectively (Licandeo et al. 2006, Treloar 2008). Thus, the generation length of the Giant Skate is inferred as 17 years.
threats:
The Giant Skate is subject to fishing pressure across its spatial range, though it has refuge at depth. It is a rare and infrequent bycatch from deep-water demersal trawl and longline fisheries and retained for human consumption or fish meal in Taiwan, and possibly the Philippines, and is likely discarded in Japan.

In Japan, records of this species are rare. It may be captured by demersal trawl fisheries that operate at depths of 200–800 m (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). It may also be captured by a deepwater dropline fishery for Splendid Alfonsino (Beryx splendens) that operates around the islands and seamounts south of Sagami Bay at depths of 400–800 m (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and there is a lack of younger people entering the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019).

In Taiwan, the species is observed infrequently at Da-xi fish market in the northeast (Ebert et al. 2013). It is presumed to be taken as bycatch of deep-water trawl fisheries that operate off the northeast coast of Taiwan at depths of 200–700 m; these fisheries target multiple species of shrimp with all the incidental catch retained (D.A. Ebert pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Although there is no detailed effort data, the number of trawl vessels operating in the northeast of Taiwan has remained fairly stable from 1999 to 2008 (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The deep-water longline fisheries on the east coast of Taiwan operate at depths of 100–300 m (H. Ho and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28/08/2019) and thus would not interact with this species, which occurs deeper.

In the Philippines, the species' upper-depth limit is beyond the reach of the trawl fisheries that operate to a maximum depth of 200 m (D. Tanay pers. comm. 24/04/2020). It may have previously been encountered in the Philippines by bottom set multiple hook-and-line gear that targeted dogfish sharks for their liver oil; the fishery was intensive from the 1960s–1980s and still operates but at an artisanal scale (Flores 2004, Gaudiano and Alava 2003, D. Tanay and J. Utzurrum pers. comm. 24/04/2020). In Cagayancillo, Palawan, Philippines, there are ~28 vessels in operation, setting demersal longlines at depths of 700–1,400 m (usually 800–1,000 m) (LAMAVE 2017). These deep-water fisheries are known for their boom-and-bust nature, given the lack of management, and collapse over short periods of time (~10 years) before effort is shifted into new regions (Flores 2004).
population: There are no species-specific population trend data for this species. It is infrequently encountered in commercial fisheries; interactions in Japan are rare, it is caught occasionally in Taiwan, and it has not been reported as commercially caught in the Philippines. Large Dipturus species are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity, as evidenced by population reductions of up to 75% in response to intense fishing pressure over 20–30 years (see Red List assessments: Yellownose Skate (D. chilensis) and Bight Skate (D. gudgeri)). The Giant Skate is also likely to have low biological productivity which is of concern, however it has significant refuge from fishing pressure at depth across its range. Historical fishing pressure was intense, but has declined across most of its range over the past 30 years. It is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (51 years).
range: The Giant Skate is endemic to the Northwest and Western Central Pacific Oceans from Choshi, Chiba Prefecture in southern Japan to Taiwan and to Hermanos Island, northern Philippines (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: No information is available on use and trade; similar skates are retained in Taiwan for human consumption or fish meal.
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In Taiwan, since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In the Philippines in 1998, active fishing gears, including tuna longlines, were prohibited within municipal marine waters (<3 nm from shore). Research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catches should be monitored.

rationale: The Round Stingray (Taeniurops grabatus) is a medium-sized (to 112 cm disc width) ray that occurs in the Mediterranean Sea and the east Atlantic Ocean ranging from France (Bay of Biscay) to Angola. It is demersal on the continental shelf from the surface to a depth of 450 m but is mostly at <100m, with a preference for shallow coastal waters at <50 m depth. This species is taken as incidental catch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple demersal fishing gears, including trawl, line gear, gillnet, and set net across its range. In the Eastern Central Atlantic, the meat is consumed locally and traded regionally salted-dried or dried and smoked. In the Mediterranean Sea, there are limited records outside the North African coast and little data available to determine catch levels or trends. In the Eastern Central Atlantic, there are no species-specific time series, and although it is still reported in landings, it is not as common as it was previously. There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across most of the range of this species which are a cause for concern. However, despite its preference for shallow coastal waters, this species might have some refuge at depth and it appears to still be relatively common in various regions, especially offshore islands. Overall, considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout most of its range, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Round Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (81 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Round Stingray is demersal on soft substrates and seagrass on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 0–450 m, but mostly from inshore to 100 m depth with a preference for shallow coastal waters (<50 m depth) (Last et al. 2016, Ben Amor et al. 2019, Ebert and Dando 2021). It reaches a maximum size of 112 cm disc width (DW) and males mature at 66 cm DW (Ali et al. 2013, Ben Amor et al. 2019). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous and little else is known of its biology. There is no information on this species' age-at-maturity and maximum age, hence, generation length was inferred based on age parameters for the Blackspotted Whipray (Maculabatis astra). The Blackspotted Whipray has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and a maximum age of 30 years, resulting in a generation length of 19.5 years (Jacobsen 2007). The Blackspotted Whipray is smaller than the Round Stingray (80 cm vs 112 cm DW), and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred to be 27 years for the Round Stingray, which is an estimate that should be used with caution.
threats:
The Round Stingray is taken as bycatch in artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is retained for human consumption. It is also likely taken in industrial fisheries operating trawls in coastal areas.

In the Mediterranean Sea, the Round Stingray is sometimes landed in fisheries as bycatch. This water body has been subject to extensive and intensive fishing across much of the species' known depth and spatial distribution with trawl fisheries operating over a wide bathymetric range (50–800 m) and targeting a variety of species (Lleonart and Maynou 2003, Tsikliras et al. 2015). Following two centuries of fisheries development, shark and ray fisheries developed in the 1950s, with catches peaking until the 1970s, after which a decreasing trend was reported along with a decline in diversity of species (Cavanagh and Gibson 2007, Davidson et al. 2016). A number of shark and ray species are now considered to be locally extinct due to overexploitation (e.g., Ferretti et al. 2008). 

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West African coastal waters and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (e.g., False Shark Ray (Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis) from the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin and the African Wedgefish (Rhynchobatus luebberti) from the Sine-Saloum Delta) (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many important commercial coastal, demersal, and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977 to 2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of demersal resources and deep sea pelagic catches of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 (mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch) (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region and which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world, and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed more than 40% of the reported legal catch (Pauly and Zeller 2016).

The shallow, inshore soft-substrate habitats preferred by rays are threatened by habitat loss and environmental degradation (Stobutzki et al. 2006, White and Sommerville 2010, Jabado et al. 2017). Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation, conversion of coastal lagoons and mangrove deforestation for agriculture (e.g., rice and salt) and aquaculture (e.g., shrimp, fish culture, and fish production); extensive oil and gas exploration, drilling, and production; the effects of rapid urban expansion from growing coastal populations and unplanned tourism development; pollution (unregulated sewage effluents, agricultural runoff, hydrocarbon, and heavy metals); sedimentation and siltation; and changes to the hydrological cycle from the building of dams leading to dramatic levels of habitat loss evident across the region (GCLME 2006, FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016). In West Africa, mangroves are harvested for fuel wood, construction timber, and charcoal with an overall mangrove forest area decline of up to 70% in some countries over the last 20 years with the highest loses recorded from Côte d'Ivoire (67%), Liberia (65%), Guinea (60%), Sierra Leone (40%), and Ghana (30%) (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016, CCLME 2016).
population:
There are a number of relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to calculate population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with high increases in the Mediterranean Sea, Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic regions (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013, Belhabib et al. 2018).

First, in the Mediterranean Sea, surveys indicate that the Round Stingray is generally uncommon and mostly recorded along the North African coast (Serena et al. 2020). A single record is reported from the northwest area where, in 1997, two individuals were captured in a trammel net off the coast of Livorno in Italy (Serena et al. 1999). One individual has been reported from a trawl survey in 1997 in Iskanderun Bay, Turkey (Başusta et al. 1998). Off the Syrian coast, three individuals were caught in 2012 using bottom longlines (two individuals) and trawl (one individual) gear (Ali et al. 2013). Little information is available on abundance, but this species is also listed on national fisheries checklists in Israel, Egypt, and Tunisia (where it appears to be the most common) (El Sayed 1994, Bradai et al. 2004, Golani 2005). In the Azores, it is considered common based on data from experimental fishing surveys and underwater visual surveys (Das and Afonso 2017).

Second, both catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria, and Ghana, and consequently population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but this does indicate rising fishing pressure. There are no other estimates of population reduction available from this region. The greatest fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries in the whole of Africa were the West African countries of Nigeria (13,238 t), Senegal (10,757 t) and Ghana (1,902 t) (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Nevertheless, given the lack of reporting in artisanal fisheries and the large number of nations fishing in African waters, actual landings are likely to be much higher. 

Overall, across the West Africa region, the average elasmobranch catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) has decreased by 71% over 1970–2015. The average elasmobranch CPUE in the region was 0.68 t/kW in 1970 and declined to 0.20 t/kW by 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch catch has increased by more than 2.5 times (250%) from 1970 to 2015. The average elasmobranch catch in the region was 3,312 t in 1970 and increased to 8,329 t in 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). This implies a dramatic increase in fishing effort as the elasmobranch catch volume has increased but the CPUE has decreased. Within countries, catches have historically increased but have peaked and begun to decline in recent years. More specifically, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates showed a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline, over 15 years from 2001 to 2016. Catches gradually rose from 3,644 t in 1950 to 20,180 t in 1972 then declined to 4,211 t in 1981 (80% decline), then rose steeply to a peak of 23,194 t in 2001 followed by a fluctuating decline to 4,734 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Cameroon, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1960s but showed a 96% decline over the years from 2007 to 2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 391 t in 1950 to 2,881 t in 1974 then showed a decline to 712 t in 1986 (75% decline). Elasmobranch catch then rose to a peak of 7,516 t in 2007 followed by a steep decline to 303 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Nigeria, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1970s but showed a 19% decline over the years from 2010 to 2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 2,419 t in 1950 to 25,144 t in 1980 then rose to a peak of 31,273 t in 2010 followed by a fluctuating decline to 25,396 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be used to infer reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has remained stable during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). This steep increase in landings coincides with a steep rise in fishing effort and an overall 44% reduction in elasmobranch CPUE from 0.107 t/kW in 1981–1983 to 0.060 t/kW in 2013–2015.

Third, contemporary patterns of landings indicate that while there are limited records of this species in the past decade from across the Eastern Central Atlantic region, it is still landed across most of this portion of its range. This species has rarely been reported in regular monitoring of fisheries landings between 2006–2018 undertaken by the Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches in the Parc National du Banc d'Arguin with five individuals recorded in 2012 and one in 2020 (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). It has however been recorded in experimental trawl fishing surveys between 1988–2007, although quantities are not available (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). During extensive landing site surveys across the Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission region between 2004–2011, this species was only recorded in Cape Verde (Diop and Dossa 2011). In Cape Verde, it is considered a relatively common species and over 30 individuals have been recorded in Baited Remote Underwater Video Surveys (BRUVS) in 220 hours of underwater footage between 2015–2017 (MarAlliance 2019; S. Pires, S. Ratão unpubl. data 2020). It was also listed in cruise reports from the "Dr. Fridtjof Nansen" surveys and represented up to 96.4% of catches with up to eight individuals in one trawl haul (Krakstad et al. 2011). In the Gambia, only one individual was recorded during landing site surveys conducted annually between 2010 and 2018 although other species of rays with similar catchability were reported in large quantities (Moore et al. 2019). In recent environmental DNA surveys across the Bijagos Archipelago in Guinea-Bissau, this species was rarely detected in water samples with only two individuals confirmed from market surveys where they were sold fresh for local consumption (G.H.L. Leurs unpubl. data 2020). It was also frequently recorded in 2019 in Côte d'Ivoire during landing site surveys (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). It has been reported from Nigerian research surveys however catch quantities are not available (A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). It was not detected in recent landing sites surveys in Western Ghana between 2019–2020 and from Angola during opportunistic landing site surveys in 2018 (I. Seidu and A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020). In Cameroon, 21 individuals have been recorded over two years of landing site surveys representing 0.9% of all shark and ray records (A. Tamo unpubl. data 2020). In São Tomé and Príncipe, a few individuals have been recorded from surveys of local markets and on BRUVS footage (G. Porriños unpubl. data 2020). There, this species is also targeted by spear fishers and small individuals are sometimes observed in catches from demersal longline and gillnet fisheries (G. Porriños unpubl. data 2020). In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, this species is still captured regularly, and it is still also recorded in artisanal fisheries landings operating in Mayumba using demersal-set gillnets with one or two large individuals recorded each day of survey (CPUE of 13.5 kg per day of fishing) (G. De Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). In the Republic of the Congo, 30 individuals were recorded during landing site surveys from January 2019 to December 2019, most of which were caught in gillnets targeting sardines close to shore between January and July (P. Doherty unpubl. data 2020).

There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across most of the range of this species which are a cause for concern. However, despite its preference for shallow coastal waters (<50 m depth), this species might have some refuge at depth, and it appears to still be relatively common in various regions, especially offshore islands. Overall, considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout most of its range, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Round Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (81 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Round Stingray is found in the east Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea (although it is absent from the Black Sea), ranging from France (Bay of Biscay) to Angola, including the Azores, Canary Islands, Cape Verde Archipelago, and São Tomé and Príncipe (Wirtz et al. 2007, Wirtz et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016, Das and Afonso 2017, Ebert and Dando 2021). In the Mediterranean Sea, it is mostly known from the northern African coast and its presence in the Red Sea requires confirmation and is likely a misidentification (Last et al. 2016, Serena et al. 2020).
useTrade: The Round Stingray is utilized for its meat. While little-species specific information is available, the meat of rays is consumed fresh across many coastal communities in the region as an important source of protein (Walker et al. 2005). It is also dried or dried and smoked and exported across West Africa to supply countries such as Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria, Mali, and Burkina Faso.
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across the region have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the Round Stingray are generally unmanaged throughout large parts of the species’ range, and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future. 

In West Africa, a number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing one (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Whilst Gabon have recently expanded marine protected area coverage to 26% of their Exclusive Economic Zone, other countries such as the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are still in the process of expanding their marine protected area networks; however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Pearl Whipray (Fontitrygon margaritella) is a small (to 34 cm disc width) ray that occurs in the Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast AtlanticOceans ranging from Mauritania to Angola. It inhabits shallow coastal waters and estuaries from the surface to a depth of 60 m. This species is taken as incidental catch in demersal trawl, line gear, set net, and trammel net fisheries across its range, and possibly coastal industrial fisheries using trawls. The meat is consumed locally and traded regionally salted-dried or dried and smoked. It is often confused with the sympatric but larger Daisy Whipray (Fontitrygon margarita) and records are likely aggregated. However, it is considered one of the most abundant rays in West Africa and is still common in landings across most of its range. This is a small species and may be relatively biologically productive compared to larger rays, which would provide resilience to fishing pressure and may account for its continued high abundance in areas where it is commercially targeted. Despite this abundance, there is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across most of the range of this species which are a cause for concern. Overall, considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its lack of refuge at depth, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, but that the species is still common and abundant, it is suspected that the Pearl Whipray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (15 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Pearl Whipray is demersal on sandy and muddy substrates in estuaries and shallow coastal waters to 60 m depth (Carpenter and De Angelis 2016, Last et al. 2016b). It reaches a maximum size of 34 cm disc width (DW), males mature at ~20–21 cm DW and females mature at ~25 cm DW (Last et al. 2016b, Moore et al. 2019, G.L.H. Leurs unpubl. data 2020). Reproduction is  yolk-sac viviparous with litter sizes of 1–3 pups (Carpenter and De Angelis 2016). There is no information on this species' age-at-maturity and maximum age, hence, generation length was inferred based on data for the Blue Stingray (Dasyatis chrysonota) that has an age-at-maturity of seven years and a maximum age of 14 years and, thus, a generation length of 10.5 years (Cowley 1990). The Blue Stingray has a larger maximum size than the Pearl Whipray (75 cm vs 34 cm DW), and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred to be 5 years for the Pearl Whipray.
threats:
The Pearl Whipray is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, line gear, gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and retained for human consumption. It is also likely taken in industrial fisheries operating trawls in coastal areas.

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West African coastal waters and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (e.g., False Shark Ray (Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis) from the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin and the African Wedgefish (Rhynchobatus luebberti) from the Sine-Saloum Delta) (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many important commercial coastal, demersal, and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977­–2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of demersal resources and deep sea pelagic catches of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 (mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch) (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region, which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed more than 40% of the reported legal catch (Pauly and Zeller 2016).

The shallow, inshore soft-substrate habitats of this species are threatened by habitat loss and environmental degradation (Stobutzki et al. 2006, White and Sommerville 2010, Jabado et al. 2017). Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation, conversion of coastal lagoons and mangrove deforestation for agriculture (e.g., rice and salt) and aquaculture (e.g., shrimp, fish culture, and fish production); extensive oil and gas exploration, drilling, and production; the effects of rapid urban expansion from growing coastal populations and unplanned tourism development; pollution (unregulated sewage effluents, agricultural runoff, hydrocarbon, and heavy metals); sedimentation and siltation; and changes to the hydrological cycle from the building of dams leading to dramatic levels of habitat loss evident across the region (GCLME 2006, FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016). In West Africa, mangroves are harvested for fuel wood, construction timber, and charcoal with an overall mangrove forest area decline of up to 70% in some countries over the last 20 years with the highest loses recorded from Côte d'Ivoire (67%), Liberia (65%), Guinea (60%), Sierra Leone (40%), and Ghana (30%) (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016, CCLME 2016).
population:
Contemporary patterns of landings indicate that this species is still relatively abundant across its range and is one of the most commonly landed species across the Eastern Central Atlantic region (Carpenter and De Angelis 2016). However, although smaller than its congener the Daisy Whipray (Fontitrygon margarita), it is important to note that these species are still confused and records are likely to be aggregated. This species was only recorded in Guinea during extensive landing site surveys across the Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission region between 2004 and 2011 (Diop and Dossa 2011). Yet, in Senegal, this species is now commonly recorded in artisanal fisheries landings along the coast (L. Badji unpubl. data 2020). Here, while rays are now commonly marketed, small species were likely to be discarded in the past due to their low commercial value but have now become utilized bycatch (L. Badji unpubl. data 2020). Similarly, in The Gambia, this previously unused ray has recently become commercially targeted in response to a declining shark fishery (Moore et al. 2019). During landing site surveys conducted annually between 2010 and 2018, this species dominated landings of rays and was intensively utilized (Moore et al. 2019). In Mauritania, it is commonly recorded in both artisanal and industrial trawl fisheries (M. Dia, R.W. Jabado unpubl. data 2020). In recent environmental DNA surveys across the Bijagos Archipelago in Guinea-Bissau, this species was detected in water samples accounting for 62% of ray DNA and was confirmed from market surveys as one of the most commonly landed ray species (G.H.L. Leurs unpubl. data 2020). Landing sites surveys in Western Ghana in 2019 and 2020 indicate that this species represents 7% of ray landings (I. Seidu unpubl. data 2020). In Nigeria, although quantities are not available, this species is very commonly captured in industrial trawl fisheries as well as artisanal fisheries (A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). It was not detected in 2019 landing site surveys in Côte d'Ivoire (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, this species along with other dasyatids (Brown Stingray (Bathytoshia lata), Marbled Stingray (Dasyatis marmorata), Common Stingray (D. pastinaca), Pearl Whipray, and Round Stingray (Taeniurops grabatus)) were considered common and represented 18.5% of rays captured in 2018 (99.9% mortality rate) and 26.5% in 2019 (100% mortality rate) (E. Chartrain and G. De Bruyne unpubl. data 2020). Overall, dasyatids in trawl fisheries represented 4.6% of trawl production in 2018 and 3.6% in 2019. This species was also recorded throughout the year from the artisanal fisheries operating in Mayumba using demersal-set gillnets and represented 1% of ray landings (E. Chartrain and G. De Bruyne unpubl. data 2020). In the Republic of the Congo, this species was not recorded during surveys undertaken between January and December 2019, however, records of the Daisy Whipray which represented up to 4% of landings might have included this species (P. Doherty unpubl. data 2020). In Cameroon, landings of the Pearl Whipray and Daisy Whipray represented up to 70% of all shark and ray records over two years of landing site surveys between 2018–2019 (A. Tamo unpubl. data 2020). Similarly, this species represented 31% of all sharks and rays reported through a citizen science network set up in Cameroon between 2019–2020 (A. Takoukam Kamla pers. comm. 07/07/2020). In Angola, 10 individuals were recorded during opportunistic landing site surveys in 2018 (A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020).

There are a number of relevant datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with high increases in the Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic regions (Anticamara et al. 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018, Watson et al. 2013).

In the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic, both overall catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark and ray fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria and Ghana, and consequently population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but this does indicate rising fishing pressure. Since the 1970s, the greatest fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries in the whole of Africa were the West African countries of Nigeria (13,238 t), Senegal (10,757 t) and Ghana (1,902 t) (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Nevertheless, given the lack of reporting in artisanal fisheries and the large number of nations fishing in African waters, actual landings are likely to be much higher. Overall, across the West Africa region, the average elasmobranch catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) has decreased by 71% between 1970–2015. The average elasmobranch CPUE in the region was 0.68 t/kW in 1970 and declined to 0.20 t/kW by 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch landings were 3,312 t in 1970 and increased to 8,329 t in 2015, an increase by more than 2.5 times (Pauly et al. 2020). This implies a dramatic increase in fishing effort as the elasmobranch landings volume has increased but the CPUE has decreased. Within countries, landings have historically increased but have peaked and begun to decline in recent years. More specifically, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates showed a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline, over 15 years from 2001 to 2016.
