Landings gradually rose from 3,644 t in 1950 to 20,180 t in 1972 then declined to 4,211 t in 1981 (80% decline), then rose steeply to a peak of 23,194 t in 2001 followed by a fluctuating decline to 4,734 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Cameroon, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1960s but showed a 96% decline over the years from 2007 to 2016. Historically, landings quickly rose from 391 t in 1950 to 2,881 t in 1974 then showed a decline to 712 t in 1986 (75% decline). Elasmobranch landings then rose to a peak of 7,516 t in 2007 followed by a steep decline to 303 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Nigeria, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1970s but showed a 19% decline over the years from 2010 to 2016. Historically, landings quickly rose from 2,419 t in 1950 to 25,144 t in 1980 then rose to a peak of 31,273 t in 2010 followed by a fluctuating decline to 25,396 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in overall shark, ray, and skate populations, as the fishing effort has remained stable during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020).

The species is exposed to intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, has a lack of refuge at depth, is susceptible to fisheries, and there are noted declines in rays in general across its range. However, the species is still relatively abundant and common across its range. It is suspected that the Pearl Whipray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (15 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation.
range: The Pearl Whipray is found in the Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic from Mauritania to Angola (Last et al. 2016b; R.W. Jabado, A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020). It has not been recorded from the Cape Verde Archipelago or São Tomé and Príncipe (Wirtz et al. 2007, Wirtz et al. 2013).
useTrade: The Pearl Whipray is utilized for its meat. While little-species specific information is available, the meat of rays is consumed fresh across many coastal communities in the region as an important source of protein (Walker et al. 2005). It is also salted-dried or dried and smoked and exported across West Africa to supply countries such as Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria, Mali, and Burkina Faso (Carpenter and De Angelis 2016, R.W. Jabado unpubl. data 2020). Furthermore, it is sometimes used as animal feed (e.g., for chickens in Ghana; I. Seidu unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across its range have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the Pearl Whipray are generally unmanaged throughout large parts of the species’ range, and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future.

A number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing a National Plan of Action (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Other countries such as Gabon, the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are in the process of expanding their marine protected areas coverage, however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020).

Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Indian Ring Skate (Orbiraja powelli) is a small (to at least 53 cm total length) skate that occurs from the Arabian Sea to the Bay of Bengal in the Western and Eastern Indian Oceans. It is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 17–462 m. The species is taken as bycatch in mainly demersal trawl, and possibly set and gillnet, fisheries and retained. There are no species-specific time series, although reconstructed landings data of all sharks, rays, and skates from the Bangladesh Exclusive Economic Zone and ray catch-per-unit-effort and elasmobranch landings from India were used to infer declines of 59–92% over the past three generation lengths (31 years). These trends are not species-specific but informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Trends could not be determined for Sri Lanka or Myanmar, although declines of ray populations are suspected in recent years in Myanmar. Inshore fishing pressure is high across the species range yet there is much lower fishing effort in the deeper part of the Indian Ring Skate's shelf distribution and refuge at depth on the upper continental slopes. It is suspected that the Indian Ring Skate is close to reaching the population reduction threshold due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Indian Ring Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 17–462 m (Last et al. 2016b, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 53 cm total length (TL); males mature at ~35 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016b). Reproduction is oviparous and a spawning ground has been identified on Wadge Bank, southwest India (Chembian 2010; misidentified as Brown Skate Raja miraletus, K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). Nothing else is known of its biology. Ages are inferred from the slightly smaller Sharpspine Skate (Okamejei acutispina) (45 cm TL) that has a verified female age-at-maturity of 7.2 years and a maximum age of 13.2 years, resulting in a generation length of 10.2 years (Joung et al. 2011).
threats:
The Indian Ring Skate is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with mainly trawl, and possibly set net and gillnet, and mostly retained for human consumption and fishmeal. In India, there is high level of fisheries exploitation with most stocks fully exploited (FAO 2020). Currently, 330 deep-water trawlers operate from Kerala and Tamil Nadu targeting deep-water resources in the Wadge Bank area, southwest India (K. K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). In more inshore waters, there were about 6,600 trawlers operating in the Indian state of Gujarat in the early 2000s (Zynudheen et al. 2004). This number increased to 11,582 trawlers in 2010 (CMFRI 2010). Trawling is also intense elsewhere with 3,678 trawlers in Kerala and 5,767 trawlers in Tamil Nadu waters, with severe declines in fish stocks, including elasmobranchs (Raje et al. 2002, Mohanraj et al. 2009, CMFRI 2010, Karnad et al. 2014). In Sri Lanka, fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 14,000 vessels in 1950 to 63,745 vessels in 2014, with most of the increase since 2000 and >90% of the fleet subsistence and artisanal fisheries operating in coastal fisheries on the continental shelf (Pauly et al. 2020). The coastal fisheries are likely to be increasingly overfished due to the high fishing effort with offshore fisheries increasing in effort since the early 1980s (Samaraweera and Amarasiri 2004, Dissanayake 2005).

In Myanmar, rays are largely taken as incidental catch in coastal gillnets, trawls, and hookah divers spearing at night (Howard et al. 2015, Mizrahi et al. 2020). These inshore fisheries are relatively small-scale, and include many subsistence level fishers. Fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 2,000 vessels in 1950 to 125,222 vessels in 2014, with >80% of the fleet subsistence fisheries operating in coastal waters on the continental shelf (Pauly et al. 2020). Bangladesh has a substantial artisanal fishing fleet that operates throughout the coastal regions and anecdotal reports indicate a steep decline in rays over the past 10 years (Ullah et al. 2014, A. Haque pers. comm. 05/05/2020). This decline is concurrent with steep increases in artisanal and subsistence fisheries effort (Pauly et al. 2020). The artisanal fishing vessels land >90% of the total marine catch and generally operate inshore at depths of 0–40 m but can operate to 80 m (Hoq et al. 2014, A. Haque pers. comm. 05/05/2020).
population:
The population of the Indian Ring Skate is estimated to have declined in Wadge Bank, southwest India by 62% over 11 years. Observed catches declined from 1,080–416 individuals from 2008 to 2018 despite increased fishing effort during that time (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). This represents a reduction of 95% over the past three generation lengths (31 years). Overall declines in batoids from intense and increasing fishing pressure on the continental shelf are also reported. For example, the annual average catch of rays landed by trawlers at New Ferry Wharf, Mumbai, between 1990–2004 was 502 t. During this period trawler hours doubled, and consequently, the catch rate declined by 63% from 0.65 kg/hr in 1990 to 0.24 kg/hr in 2004 (Raje and Zacharia 2009). Across India, landings of elasmobranchs have declined by 44% from 1998 to 2018, despite increasing effort which infers a decline in their populations (Gupta et al. 2020).

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the Sri Lanka, Myanmar, and Bangladesh Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ), based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In Sri Lanka, reconstructed landings data showed a five-fold increase over the 65 years from 1950 to 2014. Total catches have fluctuated greatly but continued to rise overall with foreign catches within the Sri Lanka EEZ increasing from the mid-1980s (Pauly et al. 2020). A population trend cannot be inferred as effort has also increased during this period.

In Myanmar, the Indian Ring Skate is rare in landing sites (A. Maung unpubl. data 2020). Reconstructed landings of all sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to the late 1990s varied between 15,000 t to 35,000 t annually with no substantial trend. From the late 1990s to 2014 landings increased to around 40,000 t per year which was concurrent with an increase in fishing effort (Pauly et al. 2020). This infers there has been no significant reduction in the shark and ray populations as landings have increased as effort has increased. However, surveys in recent years have revealed reductions in some shark and ray populations (San San Khine 2010, Krakstad et al. 2014). Trawl surveys undertaken by the Norwegian research vessel Dr Fridtjof Nansen in 1978–1980 and 2013 exhibited a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs between surveys (Krakstad et al. 2014), with a noted shift from larger long-lived species to smaller short-lived species. Catch rates declined more for rays than for sharks. Surveys of local markets from 2006 to 2010 demonstrated that landings are dominated by small short-lived species (San San Khine 2010) which is typical of over-exploited elasmobranch communities (Lam and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2011). These same surveys also reported a 49% decline in landings during this period, despite no reduction in fishing effort.

In Bangladesh, reconstructed landings data showed a 34% decline in landings over 15 years from 2000 to 2014. Catches gradually rose from 195 t in 1950 to 7,540 t in 1973 the declined to the 3,500 t in the mid-1980s, then rose steeply to a peak of 10,909 t in 2000 followed by a fluctuating decline to 7,163 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Indian Ring Skate (31 years), they represent declines of 61%, 92%, and 59% in Bangladesh, Mumbai and across India, respectively. Trends cannot be determined for Sri Lanka and Myanmar, though declines of ray populations are suspected in recent years in Myanmar. These trends are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader trends for batoids in the region. In Wadge Bank, southwest India, the species has undergone an estimated reduction of 95% over the past three generation lengths (31 years). Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the range of the Indian Ring Skate, but most of the pressure is on the continental shelf with only a relatively small level of effort in offshore fisheries and this species would have refuge at depth. Although there is a high level of fishing effort on the shallow part of this species depth range, there is much lower effort on the deeper part of its shelf distribution and refuge at depth for most of its depth range. It is suspected that the Indian Ring Skate is close to reaching the population reduction threshold.
range: The Indian Ring Skate is found from the Arabian Sea to the Bay of Bengal in the Western and Eastern Indian Oceans. It occurs in India, Sri Lanka, Myamar, and Bangladesh (Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: In India, this species is retained for fish meal (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). In Bangladesh, and possibly elsewhere, this species is likely consumed, as small rays are retained for their meat and often dried whole for local consumption and export (A. Haque pers. comm. 05/05/2020).
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Myanmar, two shark reserves were designated in the Myeik Archipelago in 2004 where targeting sharks and rays is prohibited (Notification 2/2004) (Howard et al. 2015). In 2008, a nationwide ban on the targeting of sharks was announced. Despite the nationwide ban, sharks and rays continue to be captured in large numbers, partly because there is little or no enforcement, and little knowledge of the ban in fishing communities (T. MacKeracher pers. comm. 02/04/2020). Further research is needed on population size and trends, and life history, and catches should be monitored.

rationale: The Whitebelly Skate (Rhinoraja longicauda) is a small (to 69 cm TL) deep-water skate found in the Northwest Pacific Ocean off Russia and Japan from the southern Sea of Okhotsk and southern Kuril Islands, to southern Hokkaido and Chiba Prefecture, Japan. It occurs on upper insular shelves and slopes at depths of 300–1,000 m. This species is suspected to be caught as part of a target skate fishery off Hokkaido and as bycatch of Japanese bottom trawl fisheries targeting Sailfin Sandfish (Arctoscopus japonica) and Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus) and Russian fisheries east of the Kuril Islands. Demand for skates is increasing from Korean markets, driving increased landings from the target skate fishery in Hokkaido. Risk is further increased because skate landings data have not been collected in Japan since 2006. It is suspected that some of the population occurs within the depth range and spatial extent of current fisheries, that are unmonitored, unsustainable, and without catch limits. There is some overlap of fisheries with this species across 10–20% of its range, hence, it is suspected that the Whitebelly Skate is close to reaching the population reduction threshold due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Whitebelly Skate is demersal on upper insular shelves and slopes at depths of 300–1,000 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 69 cm total length (TL). Reproduction is oviparous, size-at-birth is unknown but egg capsules measure 6–7 cm in length (Last et al. 2016).
threats:
In Russia, there are no target fisheries for sharks or skates. However, skates are taken as bycatch of longline and demersal and mid water trawl fisheries targeting Alaskan Pollock (Theragra chalcogramma), Pacific herring (Clupea pallasii), and Greenland Halibut (Reinhardtius hippoglossoides) and retained (I.V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). The demersal trawl fishery occurs from 50 to 500 m, the Greenland halibut fishery usually operates down to 650 m and therefore this species has significant refuge at depth. There are deep-water longline fisheries for grenadiers historically down to 1,000 m with the bulk of catches (up to 95% and more) consisting of grenadiers with minor bycatch of snailfishes, morids, sculpins, and skates (A. Orlov pers. obs. 2007). More recently, in the past 2–3 years, there are occasional experimental fisheries that fish down to 2,500 m (I.V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019) and thus may constitute an ongoing threat if continued or expanded into the future.

In Japan, there are directed fisheries targeting skates around Hokkaido Prefecture. As well, skates are taken as bycatch in longline and demersal and mid water trawl fisheries for Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus) (H. Ishihara unpubl. data 2019) and demersal set gillnets (Y. Semba unpubl. data 2019). Pacific Cod have been overfished since the 1970 throughout all regions of Japan and overfishing is currently occurring, or probably occurring, in all regions (Chen 2014). This species may derive some benefit of reduction in fishing mortality as a result of fisheries closures following the Great East Japan Earthquake, and resultant tsunami, on 11th March 2011, resulting in restrictions for Pacific Cod fisheries at least until the last day of 2014 (Narimatsu et al. 2016).
population: The Whitebelly Skate has a deep depth range (300–1,000 m) within reach of most demersal trawl and longlines fisheries within its distribution off eastern Honshu and Hokkaido. This species is caught as bycatch of Japanese demersal trawl fisheries targeting Sailfin Sandfish (Arctoscopus japonica) and Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus) (H. Ishihara unpub. data 2019) and Russian fisheries east of the Kuril Islands. There is some overlap of fisheries with this species across a significant fraction 10–20% of its range, hence, it is suspected that this species is close to reaching the population reduction threshold due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Whitebelly Skate is found in the Northwest Pacific Ocean from Russia to central Pacific Japan, through the southern Sea of Okhotsk and off the southern Kuril Islands, southern Hokkaido to Chiba Prefecture, Japan (Ishihara 1990, Dyldin 2015, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: In Russia, skates have been landed since 2000 and wings are most likely exported to the Republic of Korea (I.V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). In Japan, skates are of low value and while there is some domestic consumption, skate wings are most likely exported to the Republic of Korea (H. Ishihara unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation actions for this species. Research is required on its population size, distribution and trends, life histories and ecology, interaction with fisheries, including species-specific monitoring of catches. Training in species identification is needed, along with awareness and communications of status and need for research and management, to support national policy and compliance, including livelihoods and market forces.

rationale:
The Biscuit Skate (Raja straeleni) is a medium-sized (to at least 91 cm total length) skate found in the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic Ocean ranging from Morocco to South Africa. It occurs on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 43–930 m. This species is taken as bycatch of trawl and longline fisheries and, similar to other skates in the region, is either retained for consumption or discarded.

Currently, there are a number of European and Chinese distant-water vessels using trawls and longlines to target demersal fish and shrimp species that reach the depth limit of this species, especially in the northern part of its range in Morocco, Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia, and Guinea-Bissau. While species-specific data are not available, both increases (Morocco) and declines (Mauritania) in landings of combined skates and rays have been documented in the northern portion of its range. However, little information is available on fishing pressure throughout the rest of its range, south through the Gulf of Guinea. In this region, the sea floor is reported to be not trawlable at depths of 75–200 m and demersal stocks in these waters therefore reportedly remain unexploited which might provide a refuge for this species from trawl fisheries throughout the central parts of its range.

Further information is urgently needed to determine the level of impact on this species, particularly as deep-water fisheries are expanding in response to declining fish stocks in heavily exploited coastal areas. However, species-specific population trend data from relative abundance in South Africa revealed no major population reductions over the past three generation lengths (21 years). Skate species, including the Biscuit Skate, are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity, which is of concern for the Biscuit Skate. However, this species is likely to have refuge from fishing pressure across some of its core distribution and range. Yet, considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its northern range, and noted declines in landings of rays across its range, it is suspected that the Biscuit Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation in parts of its range and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Biscuit Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 43–930 m (Krakstad et al. 2011, Pascual-Alayon et al. 2017). It reaches a maximum size of 91 cm total length (TL) with males mature at ~56–68 cm TL and females mature at ~55–71 cm TL. Reproduction is oviparous with a size-at-birth of ~17 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Little else is known of its biology. There is no information on this species' age-at-maturity and maximum age, hence, generation length was inferred based on age parameters for the Spotted Skate (Raja montagui). The Spotted Skate has an age-at-maturity of 4 years and a maximum age of 7 years, resulting in a generation length of 5.6 years (Gallagher et al. 2005). The Biscuit Skate is larger than the Spotted Skate (91 cm vs 80 cm TL), and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred to be 7 years for the Biscuit Skate.
threats:
The Biscuit Skate is likely taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with mainly trawl, and multiple fishing gears including gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is retained for human consumption. Information on discards and associated mortality is not available and although there is no direct measure of mortality due to fishing for the Biscuit Skate, the descriptions below indicate an increasing threat to this species.

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). This has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West Africa and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many commercial demersal and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977 to 2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 (mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch) (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

There are currently three active mixed fishery bilateral agreements between the European Union and the West African nations of Morocco, Mauritania, and Guinea-Bissau (European Commission 2020). These agreements, known as Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (SFPAs) involve payments to third party countries in exchange for access to marine resources and sectorial support aimed at promoting sustainable fisheries development in the partner countries. Under SFPAs, there are a number of European distant-water industrial vessels using demersal trawls to capture deep-water shrimps at depths of 400–950 m in Mauritania and 150–850 m in Guinea-Bissau (Sobrino et al. 2017, Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). In Mauritania, there are demersal trawl fisheries for black hake (Merluccius senegalensis and Merluccius polli) that operate mainly at depths 500–700 m (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). In these trawl fisheries, unidentified deep-water sharks and rays have accounted for approximately 10% of landings (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019), but further information on bycatch species in these fisheries is largely unknown. As part of their tuna SFPA, The Gambia also allows three deep-water demersal trawls to fish for hake species at depths of 150–850 m (European Commission 2020). 

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region and which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed more than 40% of the reported legal catch (Pauly and Zeller 2016).
population:
Species-specific population trend data are available from relative abundance from South Africa (Fisheries Branch of the South African Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, unpubl. data 2020). The trend data were analysed over three generation lengths (21 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information). The trend analysis of standardized catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) estimates from demersal trawl surveys conducted during autumn, spring, and summer along the South Africa south coast (1991–2019) revealed annual rates of reduction of 0.7%, consistent with a median reduction of 18.3% decrease over the past three generation lengths (21 years), with the highest probability (54%) of no major reductions in population over three generation lengths (20 years) (that is, reductions <20%). Overall, in South Africa, up to 300 t of this species are recorded each year in inshore trawl, line fish, and demersal shark longline fisheries (C. Da Silva, unpubl. data 2020).

Elsewhere across the species range, there are no species-specific time-series data available for the Biscuit Skate that can be used to estimate population reduction. Despite the lack of species-specific data, there are a number of relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase substantially in the Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic region (Anticamara et al. 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018, Watson et al. 2013).

First, in the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic, both overall catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark and ray fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria, and Ghana. Population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but do indicate rising fishing pressure. Since the 1970s, the greatest African fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries were located in Nigeria, Senegal, and Ghana (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Across West Africa, the average elasmobranch catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) decreased by 71% between 1970–2015 from 0.68t/kW to 0.20 t/kw (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch landings increased by more than 2.5 times from 1970 to 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020), implying an increase in fishing effort. Within countries, landings have begun to decline in recent years. For example, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates increased from 1950 to 1972 then declined by 80% from 1972 to 1981. Landings increased again until 2001 followed by a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline from 2001 to 2016.

These declines in landings can be inferred to represent population reductions as the fishing effort has remained stable during the decline (Pauly et al. 2020). Overall, in the northwest Africa region (Morocco to Guinea-Bissau), total elasmobranch catch in the industrial sector increased by a factor of ten between 1970 and 2015 while total industrial fishing effort increased by 45% (Pauly et al. 2020). The industrial elasmobranch CPUE of the region more than doubled during this timeframe (Pauly et al. 2020). While these levels of change are not species-specific, they are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks and rays in the region. 

Second, data are sparse throughout the species range. Although other species of skates are sometimes recorded in landings, this species is relatively uncommon in landings even though many trawl fisheries operate throughout most of this species' range, especially in Morocco, Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia, and Guinea. This likely reflects its preference for deep-water habitats across its range. In Morocco, landings of all skates (family Rajidae) from the Spanish trawl and longline fishery for black hake increased from 0.7 tons in 2007 to 40.3 tons in 2017 (Cervantes et al. 2018). Between 2004–2011, this species was recorded during extensive landing site surveys in Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia, and Guinea but was absent from Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, and Sierra Leone (Diop and Dossa 2011). In Mauritania, landings of all skates (family Rajidae) from the Spanish trawl fishery for black hake operating in depths of 140–750 m, including the Biscuit Skate, fell from 18 tons in 1992 to 9 tons in 2001 (Fernández et al. 2005). This would equate to an 80% population reduction over the past three generation lengths (21 years), at fishing locations. However, it is important to note that these declines could be attributed to changes in the fishing fleet, economics, and likely overexploitation of both the target and bycatch species (Fernández et al. 2005). In Mauritania, 209 individuals were recorded during research trawl surveys carried out from 2007 to 2010, representing 0.94% of occurrence (ratio of number of fishing hauls in which the species occurred) (Pascual-Alayon et al. 2017). However, annual fisheries statistics from the Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches collected since 2010, indicate that this species is not recorded in artisanal fisheries (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). Little information is available on fishing pressure throughout the rest of its range (south through the Gulf of Guinea). It is reported that the sea floor is not trawlable at depths greater than 75 m in the Gulf of Guinea, and demersal stocks in offshore waters (i.e., 75–200 m) therefore remain under-exploited (Williams 1968, Martos et al. 1991, Mensah and Quaatey 2002). However, this species may be susceptible to fisheries operating further offshore and in deeper waters, especially as deep-water fisheries expand in response to declining fish stocks in heavily exploited coastal areas. This species was listed in cruise reports from the "Dr. Fridtjof Nansen" trawl surveys with up to 95 individuals representing 15.6% of catches in one haul captured from Morocco to Guinea, and 105 individuals representing 1.2% of catches in one haul captured Nigeria in 2004 (Krakstad et al. 2004, Krakstad et al. 2011). In Nigeria, only one individual has been reported through regular fisheries monitoring and research trawl surveys (mostly at <50 m depth) (A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, this species represented 80.9% of ray catches in 2018 and 73.1% of ray catches in 2019 along with the African Brown Skate (Raja parva) while there were few records of this species from the artisanal fisheries operating in Mayumba using demersal-set gillnets (G. De Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). In artisanal fisheries monitoring across the remaining countries, while other species of skates have been reported, this species has not been detected in landing site surveys in The Gambia, the Bijagos Archipelago, Guinea-Bissau, Côte d'Ivoire, Western Ghana, Cameroon, the Republic of the Congo, and Angola (Moore et al. 2019; P. Doherty, G.H.L. Leurs, K. Metcalfe, I. Seidu, A.L. Soares, and A. Tamo, unpubl. data 2020).

Although little information is available on fisheries operating in the central parts of the range of the Biscuit Skate, some depths remain unexploited which provide a refuge for this species from trawl fisheries. However, further information on fisheries operating in the Gulf of Guinea is urgently needed to determine the level of impact on this species, particularly as deep-water fisheries expand. Considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its northern range, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Biscuit Skate may have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
range: The Biscuit Skate is found in the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic Ocean from Morocco to South Africa (Krakstad et al. 2011, Last et al. 2016). It has not been recorded from the Cape Verde Archipelago or São Tomé and Príncipe (Wirtz et al. 2007, Wirtz et al. 2013). Its occurrence in southern Madagascar and Mauritius requires confirmation (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: The Biscuit Skate is utilized for its meat which is consumed fresh across many coastal communities in the region as an important source of protein. Like other species of skates, it is likely also dried or dried and smoked and exported across West Africa to supply countries such as Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria, Mali, and Burkina Faso (P. Doherty, R.W. Jabado, I. Seidu, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across its range have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the Biscuit Skate are generally unmanaged and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future. 

A number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing a National Plan of Action (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Other countries such as Gabon, the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are in the process of expanding their marine protected areas coverage, however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: Hortle's Whipray (Pateobatis hortlei) is a medium-sized (to 112 cm disc width) ray endemic to the Western Central Pacific and occurs in eastern Indonesia (Papua), Papua New Guinea, and northeast Australia. It is demersal on sandy and muddy substrates usually near river mouths and estuaries at depths to 10 m, and possibly 40 m. The species is taken as bycatch in trawl, seine net, and trap fisheries and retained for its meat in some areas. It was reported as common in Papua where it was first described in 2006 and has also since been reported as common in southern Papua New Guinea, part of its now broader range. There has been no reported population reduction over the 12 years since it was first described, although its population trend prior to 2006 is unknown. An ecological risk assessment found Hortle's Whipray to be at medium risk in the Gulf of Papua Prawn trawl fishery. Habitat destruction and river pollution are threats to this inshore species with a 30% reduction in mangrove area in Papua New Guinea from 1980 to 2005. It is suspected that Hortle's Whipray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (56 years) due to levels of fishing pressure and a reduction in habitat quality, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2cd).
habitat: Hortle's Whipray is demersal in coastal waters on sandy and muddy substrates usually near river mouths and estuaries to a depth of 10 m, and possibly 40 m (White et al. 2006, Last et al. 2016b, White et al. 2018). It reaches a maximum size of 112 cm disc width (DW), females mature at ~100 cm disc width (DW) and male size-at-maturity is unknown. Reproduction is viviparous with histotrophy, a pregnant female had a single pup, and size-at-birth is 16–20 cm DW (White et al. 2018). Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from the Blackspotted Whipray (Maculabatis astra) that has a female age-at-maturity of 9 years and a maximum age of 28 years, resulting in a generation length of 18.5 years (Jacobsen 2007). The Blackspotted Whipray is smaller than Hortle's Whipray (80 cm DW vs 112 cm DW) and thus this may be an underestimate of generation length and should be used with caution.
threats:
This species is captured regularly in trawl, beach seine, and trap fisheries as bycatch and sometimes is retained for its meat (White et al. 2006, White et al. 2018, White et al. 2019). Beach seine fishers in Papua try and avoid catching this species in intertidal habitats (White et al. 2006). An ecological risk assessment of elasmobranchs in the Gulf of Papua Prawn trawl fishery found Hortle's Whipray to be at medium risk based on susceptibility to capture and recovery potential (Baje 2019).

Habitat destruction and river pollution is a threat to this species. The removal of large areas of mangrove forest, and mining practices (which are intense in southern New Guinea) are most likely impacting this species' inshore habitat. The mangrove area in Papua New Guinea was reduced by 30% over 25 years from 1980 to 2005 (FAO 2007). This was caused primarily by human pressures for rural livelihoods, commercial activities, and overexploitation of mangrove forest for timber for housing and carvings (FAO 2007).
population: Initially, this species was only known from southern Papua, but it has since been found to have a wider range (White et al. 2006, White et al. 2018). When first described in 2006, it was reported to be common within its restricted known range and since then it has been found to also be common in southern Papua New Guinea (White et al. 2018). Its large size and potentially low fecundity suggest it may have low productivity and be sensitive to fishing pressure. However, there has been no reduction in population reported over the 12 years since it was first described, although its population trend prior to 2006 is unknown. It also occurs in Northern Australia where fishing pressure is relatively minor and managed. It is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (56 years) due to levels of fishing pressure and a reduction in habitat quality.
range: The Hortle's Whipray occurs in Papua (formerly Irian Jaya), Papua New Guinea, and northeast Australia (Last et al. 2006, Last et al. 2016b). In Papua New Guinea, it is known from the Western, Gulf, and East Sepik Provinces but is probably widespread around the mainland and likely absent from the outer islands (White et al. 2018).
useTrade: Where it is retained, the species is used for its meat for human consumption, and possibly for its skin and cartilage (White et al. 2006, White et al. 2018).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. In northern Australia, the use of Turtle Excluder Devices and Bycatch Reduction Devices has been mandated since the early 2000s and these have significantly reduced the capture of large (>100 cm TL) rays (Brewer et al. 2006). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray (Tetronarce formosa) is a medium-sized (to 89 cm total length) electric ray that occurs from Japan to northern Papua New Guinea, including China and Taiwan, in the Northwest and Central West Pacific Oceans. It is benthopelagic from inshore to a depth of 340 m. The species is taken as bycatch of demersal trawl and gill net, and possibly longline fisheries, and is discarded at sea in Japan and retained in Taiwan, and likely China, for fish meal. There are no species-specific population trends, although it is regularly captured in Taiwan in low numbers and the landings have remained stable for the past 19 years (at least two generation lengths). With no concurrent effort data, no population trend can be inferred, however catch-per-unit effort of all rays has remained stable in the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) over 17 years. Reconstructed catches of all sharks, skates, and rays from the Japan and China EEZs indicate declines of 82 and 34% over the past three generation lengths (24 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are indicative of the broader levels of decline in rays in the region. Fishing pressure is high across most of the range of the Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray. Seasonal fishing bans and inshore trawl bans in China and Taiwan respectively, its lack of current capture in Papua New Guinea and pelagic mobility may afford the species some refuge from fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (24 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray is benthopelagic on continental shelves and slopes mainly offshore at depths of 1–340 m (Haas and Ebert 2006, Weigmann 2016, White et al. 2017). This species may be fairly active when pelagic, similar to other Tetronarce species (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). It reaches a maximum size of 89 cm total length (TL); males mature at ~62 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous and size-at-birth is ~20–25 cm TL (Haas and Ebert 2006, White et al. 2017). Nothing else is known of its biology. Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from a closely related species, the Pacific Torpedo (Tetronarce californica) that has a female age-at-maturity of 9 years and a maximum age of 16 years, resulting in a generation length of 12.5 years (Neer and Cailliet 2001). The Pacific Torpedo is larger than the Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray (137 vs 89 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 8 years for the Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray.
threats:
The Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray is a bycatch of trawl, gillnet, and possibly longline, fisheries, It is likely discarded at sea in Japan but retained in Taiwan, and likely China, for fish meal.

There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the range of the Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray. The northern South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore, and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since the 1990s in the South China Sea, more than 70% of the catch is of low-value fish and juvenile fish (Pauly and Liang 2019).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive demersal trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). The demand for fish meal product for aquaculture is high, with the aquaculture industry in China contributing 62% of the world’s farmed fish (FAO 2019a, Rueter et al. 2019).

In response to fish stocks depletions, the Chinese national government introduced measures in the 1980s and 1990s, that have since been modified, to reduce inshore fishing effort, including a ban on motorized trawling in close inshore waters, annual closed seasons, gear regulations such as a minimum mesh size, vessel buybacks, and fishing vessel scrapping (Yu and Yu 2008, Rueter et al. 2019). However, non-compliance with these measures is high and fishing effort continues to increase, and in some areas, move offshore in response to declining inshore catches (Yu and Yu 2008, Villasante et al. 2013, FAO 2019a, Pauly and Liang 2019).

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however they began to decline in the 1980–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019b). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019b, S. Tanaka pers. comm. 01/09/2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka, pers. comm. 1 September 2019).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the EEZ, and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The artisanal fishing effort has steadily and markedly declined for non-powered sampans (8,283–239 from 1956 to 2004), but remains steady for fishing rafts (14,273–12,984 from 1956 to 2004) (H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). Fish too small for human consumption are in demand for processing into fish meal feed for the aquaculture industry that produces double the quantity of seafood taken from wild capture fisheries in Taiwan waters (NDC 2016).

In Papua New Guinea (PNG), this species is not currently captured by any commercial fisheries; it is only known in PNG from a single specimen taken off Kavieng, New Ireland on research surveys (White et al. 2017, White and Ko’ou 2018). There are no commercial trawl fisheries in Kavieng, though it may be a potential catch of the tuna longline fisheries and coastal artisanal fisheries (NFA 2020, White et al. 2020).
population:
The Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray is caught regularly in Taiwan in low numbers with little change in its observed abundance at landing sites over the last 19 years (H. Ho unpubl. data 2019), although there is no concurrent effort data from the area of the sites with which to infer population trends. In Taiwan, although there is no species-specific data, the catch-per-unit effort for all rays has remained stable over 17 years, that is, 1997–2013 (H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019).

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for Japan and China EEZs, based on landings data (Zeller and Pauly 2016). In Japan and China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 98% and 67% decline, respectively in landings over the 65 years (Zeller and Pauly 2016). In Japan, this decline was from around 1,300 t annually in the early 1950s to around 14 t annually from 2010 to 2014. Some decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of sharks, rays, and skates in the Japan EEZ.

In China, the decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to bottom trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019). Additionally, in China, anecdotal reports suggest a decrease in the size of sharks and rays captured (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019), which reflects the broader trend across all fish stocks of smaller sized fish being landed in China as a result of fishing down the ecosystem; a consequence of intensive fishing that changes the size composition of the catch (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray (24 years) they represent declines of 82% and 34% in  Japan and China, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in rays in the region. Fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across most of the range of the Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray. Seasonal fishing bans and inshore trawl bans in China and Taiwan respectively, and lack of current capture in Papua New Guinea would provide some refuge from fishing pressure. It is also likely fairly active when pelagic which could lessen the threat from fishing gear. Overall, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (24 years).
range: The Taiwanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray is endemic to the Northwest and Western Central Pacific from Japan to northern Papua New Guinea, including China (Kinmen Islands), Taiwan, and possibly the Philippines (Last et al. 2016, Bandai et al. 2017, White et al. 2017, Shao 2019).
useTrade: The meat is likely to be poor quality, similar to that of the Japanese Pelagic Torpedo Ray (Tetronarce tokionis), and thus may not be used for human consumption but for fish meal (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions:
In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the South China Sea to 12⁰N (Yu and Yu 2008). The closure times have varied over the years and between regions, but most now commence in May and are in place for 3–4 months. In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang, unpubl. data 2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen unpubl. data 2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019).

In Taiwan, since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). 

There are approximately 124 coastal marine protected areas in the southern China provinces, although only a few are documented internationally (McCook 2019). Fifty-four national marine reserves are reported by FAO (2019a) and five marine protected areas, each less than 20 km2, are reported in the World Database of Protected Areas (UNEP-WCMC and IUCN 2019). All protected areas across China have recently been nationalized (McCook 2019). It is estimated that ~20% of the Chinese coastline is included in Protected Areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012).

In Taiwan, there are ~32 Protected Areas which cover ~38% of the Taiwan coastline and ~47% of Taiwan territorial seas, with no-entry and no-take areas accounting for 0.9% and 4.6% of the territorial seas, respectively (MacKinnon et al. 2012, Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019).

In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catches should be closely monitored

rationale: The Golden Skate (Bathyraja smirnovi) is a medium-sized (to 116 cm TL) deep-water skate found in the Northwest Pacific Ocean from Russian to Japan, through the western Bering Sea and Sea of Okhotsk, down through the Kuril Islands to northern Hokkaido and the northern Sea of Japan. It occurs on continental shelves and slopes at depths of 58–1,125 m, but remains within the depth range of fisheries within its distribution. This species was collected at 600–700 m in the eastern coast of Republic of Korea where trawl fisheries routinely reach down to over 1,000 m. Further, this species is also caught as bycatch of bottom trawl fisheries targeting Sailfin Sandfish (Arctoscopus japonica) and longline fisheries for Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus), in Akita prefecture Japan. There is some overlap of fisheries with this species across 10–20% of its range, hence, it is suspected that the Golden Skate is close to reaching the population reduction threshold due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Golden Skate is demersal on continental shelves and slopes at depths of 58–1,125 m (Ishihara 1990, Last et al. 2016, A.M. Orlov pers. comm. 3/8/2020). It possibly reaches a maximum size of 116 cm total length (TL) (Ishiyama 1958, Last et al. 2016), males mature at 100 cm TL and females mature at 92 cm TL (Ishihara 1990). Reproduction is oviparous and size-at-birth is 22 cm TL (Ishihara 1990).
threats: Skates are taken as bycatch of demersal trawl and longline fisheries in the Sea of Japan targeting Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus), Spiny Dogfish and Anglerfish, and retained for human consumption. In Japan, the demersal trawl fishery occurs from 50–500 m and therefore this species has significant refuge at depth. In Akita prefecture Japan, this species is caught as bycatch of demersal trawl fisheries targeting Sailfin Sandfish (Arctoscopus japonica) and longline fisheries for Pacific Cod (H. Ishihara unpubl. data 2019). Pacific Cod have been overfished since the 1970 throughout all regions of Japan and overfishing is currently occurring, or probably occurring, in all regions (Chen 2014). In Russia, there are deep-water longline fisheries for grenadiers historically down to 1,000 m with the bulk of catches (up to 95% and more) consisting of grenadiers with minor bycatch of snailfishes, morids, sculpins, and skates (A. Orlov pers. obs. 2007). More recently, in the past 2–3 years, there are occasional experimental fisheries that fish down to 2,500 m (I.V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). This species was collected at 600–700 m in eastern coast of Republic of Korea in 2009 (C.-H. Jeong unpubl. data 2019) and trawl fisheries reach down to over 1,000 m in east Korea.
population: The Golden Skate has a deep depth range (58–1,125 m) but remains within the depth range of fisheries within its distribution. There is significant overlap of fisheries with this species across a significant fraction 10–20% of its range, hence, it is suspected that the New Golden Skate is close to reaching the population reduction threshold due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Golden Skate is found in the Northwest Pacific Ocean from Russia to Japan, through the western Bering Sea and Sea of Okhotsk, Russia, down through the Kuril Islands to northern Hokkaido and the northern Sea of Japan down to Peter Great Bay, Russia and Shimane Prefecture, Japan (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: In Russia, skate bycatch have been landed since 2000 and wings are most likely exported to the Republic of Korea (I.V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). In Japan, skates are of low value and while there is some domestic consumption, skate wings are most likely exported to the Republic of Korea (H. Ishihara unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation actions for this species. Research is required on its population size, distribution and trends, life histories and ecology, interaction with fisheries, including species-specific monitoring of catches. Training in species identification is needed, along with awareness and communications of status and need for research and management, to support national policy and compliance, including livelihoods and market forces.

rationale: The Blue Stingray (Dasyatis chrysonota) is a medium-sized (to 75 cm disc width) benthic stingray endemic to southern Africa in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans from central Angola to St. Lucia, South Africa. It occurs in shallow inshore waters in summer and moves to deeper waters on the continental shelf in winter to a depth of 110 m. It has a moderate age-at-maturity of 7 years and small litters of 1–7 pups. The species is captured by trawl, commercial and recreational line, beach seine, and gill net fisheries. It is not utilized and although previously persecuted by recreational fishers, it is now discarded alive by recreational and artisanal fishers, with variable mortality from trawling likely ranging from 17–70%. Trend analysis of research trawl data in South African commercially fished areas estimated a population reduction of 62% over the past three generation lengths (31.5 years), with the highest probability of a 50–79% reduction over the past three generation lengths. Overall, due to an estimated population reduction over some of its range likely driven by steep declines preceding a substantial reduction in fishing effort in South Africa, combined with a suspected range shift away from the trawl grounds due to climate change that likely accounts for some of the estimated reduction, minimal fishing pressure and refuge elsewhere (with a stable trend in shore-angling nominal catches), it is suspected that the Blue Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (31.5 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Blue Stingray is benthic in inshore shallow bays, estuaries, and sheltered sandy beaches in summer, and moves offshore to mid-continental shelf waters in winter to a depth of 110 m (Cowley 1990, Bianchi et al. 1999, Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 75 cm disc width (DW); males mature at ~41 cm DW and females mature at 50 cm DW (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous with litter sizes of 1–7 pups, a gestation period of ~9 months, and size-at-birth of 17 cm DW (Cowley 1990, Ebert and Cowley 2009). Female age-at-maturity is 7 years and maximum age is 14 years; generation length is therefore 10.5 years (Cowley 1997).
threats:
The Blue Stingray is captured by trawl, commercial and recreational line, beach seine, and gill net fisheries (da Silva et al. 2015). The trawl fisheries in South Africa have decreased in effort over the last decade, particularly the trawl fishery off KwaZulu-Natal (S. Fennessy unpubl. data 2018). All fisheries combined in South Africa have landed less than 1 t annually of Blue Stingray from 2010–2012 (da Silva et al. 2015). Effort in South African shore line fisheries has decreased as a result of a 2002 South African ban on all-terrain vehicles on beaches. Parts of Namibia are remote and offer refuge from fishing pressure (Belhabib et al. 2015). Since 2002, artisanal and recreational fishing pressure in a few parts of southern Angola has increased while other areas remain unfished (Beckensteiner et al. 2016). The Blue Stingray is not utilized and although 30 years ago it was persecuted by recreational fishers likely causing high post-release mortality (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019), it is now discarded alive by recreational and artisanal fishers, with mortality from trawling likely variable; at-vessel-mortality for trawled congeneric stingrays ranges from 17–70% (Ellis et al. 2017). Refuge for this species could be provided by extensive areas of the Agulhas Bank, South Africa that are untrawlable, and several inshore bays and marine protected areas along the South African coast that are closed to trawling.

The Blue Stingray has tended to move northeast within South Africa over three decades from 1981–2016, from the wide shelf area of Agulhus Bank to the narrower shelf area to the east (Currie et al. 2019). This shift is concurrent with a reduction in the probability of encounter in the DAFF research trawl surveys (Supplementary Information Figure 2). The range shift and reduction in likelihood of encounter are likely at least partially related to climate change (Rouault et al. 2010, Blamey et al. 2015). The range shift may represent a loss of habitat to this species.
population:
There are no estimates of population size for the Blue Stingray. Population trend data of annual density estimates (kg per nm² area swept) were available from demersal research trawl surveys conducted over 26 years (1991–2016) in commercially fished areas of South Africa during autumn and spring along the south coast by the Fisheries Branch of the South African Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF, unpubl. data, 2018). The trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths (31.5 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Winker and Sherley 2019). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

The trend analysis revealed an annual rate of reduction of 3.3% over the trawl grounds, consistent with an estimated reduction of 62.4% over the past three generation lengths (31.5 years), with the highest probability (51.4%) of a 50–79% reduction over the past three generation lengths. The estimated reduction is driven partly by a steep decline in catch rates during the early 1990s when fishing pressure in South Africa was substantially higher; over the last two decades the population reduction has been less dramatic. Some reduction is likely a result of a northeast range shift in abundance away from the trawl grounds from 1941 to 2016 due to climate change (Supplementary Information Figure 2; Currie et al. 2019). This geographic range shift is also supported by observed increased abundance of the Blue Stingray on the South African east coast; research trawls found this species was absent from the east coast during the 1920s–1930s and then it became fairly common and increased in abundance from the 1980s onwards (S. Fennessy, Oceanographic Research Institute, unpubl. data 2018). Further to the above trend data, monitoring of retained catches in KwaZulu-Natal recreational shore-angling from 1977 to 2012 indicated nominal catches of the Blue Stingray were stable over that period (S. Fennessy, Oceanographic Research Institute, unpubl. data 2018). Some catch data are from angling competitions that target aggregations (S. Fennessy, Oceanographic Research Institute, unpubl. data, 2018) and without concurrent effort data there is some uncertainty whether the nominal catch stability represents an actual stable population.

Overall, due to an estimated population reduction over some of its range, likely driven by steep declines preceding a substantial reduction in fishing effort in South Africa combined with a suspected range shift away from the trawl grounds due to climate change that likely accounts for some of the estimated reduction, minimal fishing pressure elsewhere (with a stable trend in shore-angling nominal catches), it is suspected that the Blue Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (31.5 years) due to levels of exploitation.
range: The Blue Stingray is a southern African endemic occurring from central Angola to St. Lucia, South Africa in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans (Cowley 1997, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: The Blue Stingray has not been recorded in trade, and is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place.  It occurs in several protected areas, including in South Africa: the West Coast National Park, the de Hoop Marine Protected Area (MPA), iSimangaliso MPA, and the uThukela MPA. Further research is needed on  population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Indonesian Speckled Catshark (Halaelurus maculosus) is a small (to 53 cm total length) catshark that occurs in eastern Indonesia and the Philippines in the Western Central Pacific and Eastern Indian Oceans. It is found on the continental shelf and possibly in reef habitats at depths of 50–80 m, but possibly occurs deeper. The species is taken as bycatch in demersal trawl and longline fisheries and is retained. There are no species-specific population trends with the only available information noting that it is caught occasionally. There is no evidence to suspect this species has declined, yet the intense and ongoing fishing pressure on this species is a cause for concern. It is suspected that the Indonesian Speckled Catshark is close to reaching the population reduction threshold due to levels of exploitation, and hence this species is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Indonesian Speckled Catshark is demersal on the continental shelf, including possibly reef habitats, at depths of 50–80 m (Weigmann 2016), but possibly occurs deeper (White 2009). The species reaches a maximum size of 53 cm total length (TL); males mature at ~40 cm TL and females are mature by 48 cm TL (White et al. 2007, Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is oviparous with 6–12 egg cases and size-at-birth of 8 cm TL (White et al. 2007, Ebert et al. 2013). Nothing else is known of its biology. Catsharks are difficult to age and the most reliable age estimates to date are from the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) that has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and maximum age of 21, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011). The Blacktip Sawtail Catshark is of a similar size to the Blackspotted Catshark (48 cm vs 53 cm TL) and thus based on size, the generation length is inferred as 15 years for the Indonesian Speckled Catshark.
threats:
The Indonesian Speckled Catshark is taken as target and bycatch of demersal trawl, longline, and gillnet fisheries. Members of the Halaelurus genus are reported as common in prawn trawl bycatch (White 2009, Ebert et al. 2013). In Indonesia, the species is noted as caught irregularly by demersal longline fisheries that operate offshore, and occasionally caught by gillnet trammel net (White et al. 2006, Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). Fishers from Tanjung Luar, Lombok target sharks from southern Bali across the Flores Sea and to the Makassar Strait and Java Sea (Simeon et al. 2019). The Indonesian Speckled Catshark was also likely taken by trawl, though trawlers were banned in 1980. Mini trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country but not in the area where the Indonesian Speckled Catshark occurs (Chong et al. 1987. Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). In Indonesia, fishing effort is intense and across all sectors has been increasing since the 1950s with steep increases in effort since the 1980s (Tull 2014). Indonesia has the largest chondrichthyan fishery globally, and substantial catches of target and bycatch chondrichthyans (White et al. 2006). It has been among the top shark fishing nation for over 20 years (Oakes and Sant 2019). Many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species in the Java Sea region have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009).

The Indonesian Speckled Catshark has been reported from several landing sites in the Philippines (White et al. 2007). In the Philippines, inshore demersal stocks are considered overexploited with growth overfishing apparent (Palomares and Pauly 2014, FAO 2020). Demersal stocks captured by trawl gear have declined over the past five decades with some trawl stocks nearly eliminated (FAO 2020). Across the Philippines, depending on the location, demersal trawls operate to a maximum depth of 200 m, and line fisheries operate to a maximum depth of 200–250 m (D. Tanay unpubl. data 2020).
population: No data is available on population trend of the Indonesian Speckled Catshark. It is reported as caught occasionally throughout its range with Halaelurus spp. common in prawn trawl bycatch (White et al. 2007, White 2009, Ebert et al. 2013). Fishing pressure is high across its distribution with inshore shark stocks considered highly exploited and to have declined by an order of magnitude in the Java Sea, Indonesia (Blaber et al. 2009). More recently, from 2014 to 2017 the catch-per-unit-effort remained stable for some sharks and rays targeted in Flores, Lombok, and Makassar Strait (Simeon et al. 2019). Demersal stocks taken by trawl in the Philippines have declined. The species possibly occurs in deeper waters than 80 m, which may provide it some refuge from fishing pressure, although the deeper depth range is unknown (White 2009). Population trend data for catsharks is limited but available data for one other species, the Tiger Catshark (H. natalensis) underwent a population reduction of 67% over three generation lengths (45 years) due to intense trawl fishing effort (R. Pollom pers. comm. 20/08/02019). Although the Indonesian Speckled Catshark is reported to be only occasionally captured and there is no evidence to suspect this species has declined, the intense and ongoing fishing pressure on this species is a cause for concern. It is suspected that the Indonesian Speckled Catshark population is close to reaching the population reduction threshold.
range: The Indonesian Speckled Catshark is found in the Western Central Pacific and Eastern Indian Oceans in eastern Indonesia off the southern coast of Java and off Bali and Lombok, and in the southern Philippines (White et al. 2007, Ebert et al. 2013, NFRDI 2017).
useTrade: The species is used for its meat which is of low value to due to its small size (White et al. 2007).
conservationActions: No specific measures in place. In Indonesia, trawls were banned in 1980, however, mini trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country and the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries permits Danish seine (Cantrang) to operate but they are spatially restricted (Chong et al. 1987). In the Philippines, active fishing gears, including trawlers, were prohibited in 1998 within municipal marine waters (<3 nautical miles from shore). Trawlers within commercial waters have been required since 2010 to use Juvenile and Trashfish Excluder Devices under the Fisheries Administrative Order 237 series of 2010. (D. Tanay unpubl. data 2020), which may reduce the retention of sharks (Brewer et al. 2006). Research is need on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
The Whitedapple Skate (Leucoraja leucosticta) is a medium-sized (to at least 80 cm total length) skate found in the Eastern Central Atlantic Ocean ranging from Mauritania to Gabon. It occurs on the continental shelf and upper slopes at depths of 70–705 m. This species is taken as bycatch of trawl and longline fisheries and, similar to other skates in the region, is either retained for consumption or discarded. There are currently a number of European and Chinese distant-water vessels using trawls and longlines to target demersal fish and shrimp species that reach the depth limit of this species, especially in the northern part of its range in Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia, and Guinea-Bissau.

While species-specific data are not available, declines in landings of combined skates and rays have been documented in the northern portion of its range. For example, a study of the elasmobranch bycatch of the Spanish trawl fishery targeting hake off Mauritania, showed that landings of rajids combined decreased by the equivalent of a 75% population reduction of the Whitedapple Skate over the past three generation lengths (18 years); if landings trends reflect decrease in abundance. However, little information is available on fishing pressure throughout the rest of its range, south through the Gulf of Guinea. In this region, the sea floor is reported to be not trawlable at depths of 75–200 m and demersal stocks in these waters therefore reportedly remain unexploited which might provide a refuge for this species from trawl fisheries throughout the central and southern parts of its range.

Further information is urgently needed to determine the level of impact on this species, particularly as deep-water fisheries are expanding in response to declining fish stocks in heavily exploited coastal areas. Skate species, including Whitedapple Skate, are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity.
