However, this species is likely to have refuge from fishing pressure across most of its core distribution and range.  Considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its northern range, and noted declines in landings of rays across its range, it is suspected that the Whitedapple Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (18 years) due to levels of exploitation in part of its range, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Whitedapple Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 70–705 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 80 cm total length (TL) with males mature at 53–59 cm TL. Reproduction is likely oviparous, similar to other skates. Little else is known of its biology. There is no information on this species' maximum age and age-at-maturity, hence, generation length was inferred from age parameters for the similar sized Cuckoo Skate (Leucoraja naevus). The Cuckoo Skate has an age-at-maturity of 4.25 years and a maximum age of 8 years, resulting in a generation length of  6 years (Gallagher et al. 2005).
threats:
The Whitedapple Skate is likely taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with mainly trawl, and multiple fishing gears including gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is retained for human consumption. Information on discards and associated mortality is not available. While there is no direct measure of mortality due to fishing for the Whitedapple Skate, the descriptions below indicate an increasing threat to this species.

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). This has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West Africa and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many commercial demersal and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977 to 2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 (mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch) (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

There are currently three active mixed fishery bilateral agreements between the European Union and the West African nations of Morocco, Mauritania, and Guinea-Bissau (European Commission 2020). These agreements, known as Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (SFPAs) involve payments to third party countries in exchange for access to marine resources and sectorial support aimed at promoting sustainable fisheries development in the partner countries. Under SFPAs, there are a number of European distant-water industrial vessels using demersal trawls to capture deep-water shrimps at depths of 400–950 m in Mauritania and 150–850 m in Guinea-Bissau (Sobrino et al. 2017, Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). In Mauritania, there are demersal trawl fisheries for black hake (Merluccius senegalensis and Merluccius polli) that operate mainly at depths 500–700 m (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). In these trawl fisheries, unidentified deep-water sharks and rays have accounted for approximately 10% of landings (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019), but further information on bycatch species in these fisheries is largely unknown. As part of their tuna SFPA, The Gambia also allows three deep-water demersal trawls to fish for hake species at depths of 150–850 m (European Commission 2020). 

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region and which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed more than 40% of the reported legal catch (Pauly and Zeller 2016).
population:
There are no species-specific time-series data available for the Whitedapple Skate that can be used to estimate population reduction. Despite the lack of species-specific data, there are a number of relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase substantially in the Eastern Central Atlantic region (Anticamara et al. 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018, Watson et al. 2013).

First, in the Eastern Central Atlantic, both overall catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark and ray fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria and Ghana. Population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but do indicate rising fishing pressure. Since the 1970s, the greatest African fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries were located in Nigeria, Senegal, and Ghana (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Across West Africa, the average elasmobranch catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) decreased by 71% between 1970–2015 from 0.68t/kW to 0.20 t/kw (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch landings increased by more than 2.5 times from 1970 to 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020), implying an increase in fishing effort. Within countries, landings have begun to decline in recent years. For example, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates increased from 1950 to 1972 then declined by 80% from 1972 to 1981. Landings increased again until 2001 followed by a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline from 2001 to 2016. These declines in landings can be inferred to represent population reductions as the fishing effort has remained stable during the decline (Pauly et al. 2020). Overall, in the northwest Africa region (Morocco to Guinea-Bissau), total elasmobranch catch in the industrial sector increased by a factor of ten between 1970 and 2015 while total industrial fishing effort increased by 45% (Pauly et al. 2020). The industrial elasmobranch CPUE of the region more than doubled during this timeframe (Pauly et al. 2020). While these levels of change are not species-specific, they are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks and rays in the region.

Second, data are sparse throughout the species range. Although other species of skates are sometimes recorded in landings, this species has largely gone undetected even though many trawl fisheries operate throughout most of this species' range, especially in Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia, and Guinea. This likely reflects its preference for deep-water habitats across the Eastern Central Atlantic. Between 2004–2011, this species was recorded during extensive landing site surveys in Mauritania and Senegal but was absent from Cape Verde, The Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, and Sierra Leone (Diop and Dossa 2011). In Mauritania, landings of all skates (family Rajidae) from the Spanish trawl fishery for black hake operating in depths of 140–750 m, including the Whitedapple Skate, fell from 18 t in 1992 to 9 t in 2001 (Fernández et al. 2005). This would equate to a 75% population reduction over the past three generation lengths (18 years), at fishing locations. However, it is important to note that these declines could be attributed to changes in the fishing fleet, economics, and likely overexploitation of both the target and bycatch species (Fernández et al. 2005). Nine individuals of this species were recorded during research trawl surveys carried out from 2007 to 2010 in Mauritanian waters, representing 0.04% of occurrence (ratio of number of fishing hauls in which the species occurred) (Pascual-Alayon et al. 2017). However, annual fisheries statistics from the Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches collected since 2010, indicate that this species is not recorded in artisanal fisheries (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). Little information is available on fishing pressure throughout the rest of its range (south through the Gulf of Guinea). It is reported that the sea floor is  not trawlable at depths greater than 75 m in the Gulf of Guinea, and demersal stocks in offshore waters (i.e., 75–200 m) therefore remain under-exploited (Williams 1968, Martos et al. 1991, Mensah and Quaatey 2002). However, this species may be susceptible to fisheries operating further offshore and in deeper waters, especially as deep-water fisheries expand in response to declining fish stocks in heavily exploited coastal areas. In artisanal fisheries monitoring, while other species of skates have been reported, this species has not been detected in landing site surveys in The Gambia, Bijagos Archipelago in Guinea-Bissau, Côte d'Ivoire, Western Ghana, Nigeria (through regular fisheries monitoring and research trawl surveys mostly at <50 m depth), Cameroon, and Gabon from trawl fisheries observer data and artisanal fisheries operating in Mayumba (Moore et al. 2019; G. De Bruyne, E. Chartrain, G.H.L. Leurs, K. Metcalfe, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020).

Although little information is available on fisheries operating in the central and southern parts of the range of the Whitedapple Skate, some depths remain unexploited which might provide a refuge for this species from trawl fisheries. However, further information on fisheries operating in the Gulf of Guinea is urgently needed to determine the level of impact on this species, particularly as deep-water fisheries expand. Considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its northern range, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Whitedapple Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20-29% over the past three generation lengths (18 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Whitedapple Skate is found in the Eastern Central Atlantic Ocean from Mauritania to Gabon (Last et al. 2016). It has not been recorded from the Cape Verde Archipelago or São Tomé and Príncipe (Wirtz et al. 2007, Wirtz et al. 2013).
useTrade: The Whitedapple Skate is not known to be used or traded. However, other skate species are known to be utilized for their meat in West Africa. While little-species specific information is available, the meat of skates is consumed fresh across many coastal communities in the region as an important source of protein. It is also dried or dried and smoked and exported across West Africa to supply countries such as Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria, Mali, and Burkina Faso (P. Doherty, R.W. Jabado, I. Seidu, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across its range have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the Whitedapple Skate are generally unmanaged, and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future. 

A number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing a National Plan of Action (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure, and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Other countries such as Gabon, the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are in the process of expanding their marine protected areas coverage, however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Spinytail Round Ray (Urotrygon aspidura) is a small (to at least 42 cm total length) ray that occurs from Baja California and central Mexico to northern Peru in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific. It inhabits shallow inshore and continental shelf waters at depths of 5–100 m. This species is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries across its range and is one of the most abundant elasmobranch bycatch species. It is generally discarded although round rays may be used as bait or fishmeal by artisanal fishers. Tropical Eastern Pacific round rays have life history parameters including very early age-at-maturity (2.3 years for the Spinytail Round Ray) that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality. The Spinytail Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge. However, its continued abundance despite high overlap with fisheries suggests that the population may not have declined as much as the declines suspected for some other tropical Eastern Pacific round rays. Indeed, trend data available from Colombia showed that the catch-per-unit-effort of this species remained relatively stable between 1995 and 2007. Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, balanced with high biological productivity and stable trends in Colombia, it is suspected that the Spinytail Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Spinytail Round Ray inhabits shallow inshore and continental shelf waters at depths of 5–100 m (Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 42 cm total length (TL) and size-at-maturity is ~24–25 cm TL (Last et al. 2016, Torres-Palacios et al. 2019). Reproduction is viviparous. Female age-at-maturity is 2.3 years; female maximum age is 7.5 years (Torres-Palacios et al. 2019); and, generation length is 4.9 years.
threats:
This round ray is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries across its range and is one of the most abundant elasmobranch bycatch species. In Costa Rica (Clarke et al. 2016, Clarke et al. 2018, Espinoza et al. 2018), Colombia (Navia and Mejía-Falla 2016), and Ecuador, it is one of the most abundant, if not the most abundant, elasmobranch caught in industrial shrimp trawling fisheries; in Colombia (Mejía-Falla et al. 2014), it is the second most abundant species caught in small-scale trawling fisheries. Within the Gulf of Panama there are fisheries for small pelagic fishes (anchovies, herrings etc.) that operate on soft-benthic coastal habitats and which catch several species of ray as bycatch, including Rogers’ Round Ray (Urotrygon rogersi) (CeDePesca 2016). This indicates that the Spinytail Round Ray would also be susceptible to capture in these fisheries. 

Overall, there is high spatial overlap with fisheries (which generally lack management or effective enforcement of regulations across most of its range), and given the geographic and depth range of the species, it has no refuge from fishing activities that operate across its range. Its life history however, may allow it to withstand significant levels of fishing mortality (Torres-Palacios et al. 2019).
population:
The Spinytail Round Ray is an abundant species; in Costa Rica, Colombia, and Ecuador, it is one of the most abundant, if not the most abundant, elasmobranchs caught in industrial shrimp trawl fisheries (Clarke et al. 2016, Navia and Mejía-Falla 2016, Espinoza et al. 2018). In Colombia, it is the second most abundant elasmobranch caught in small-scale trawl fisheries (Mejía-Falla et al. 2014). In Guatemala, it made up a relatively small proportion of the ray catch in industrial trawl research surveys (Ixquiac-Cabrera et al. 2010).

Trend data available for the Spinytail Round Ray from Colombia showed that the catch-per-unit-effort of this species remained relatively stable (0.79 to 1.32 individuals/hour between 1995 and 2007; Navia and Mejía-Falla 2016).

In the Tehuantepec Gulf, Mexico, demographic models suggest population declines of the related Chilean Round Ray (Urotyrgon chilensis) under some scenarios, but not under other scenarios; overall the model results were not conclusive to ascertain population trend (Guzmán-Castellanos 2015).

Biological data from tropical Eastern Pacific round rays show life history parameters, including very early ages-at-maturity (2.3 years for Spinytail Round Ray; Torres-Palacios et al. 2019), that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality.

The Spinytail Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge, and a population reduction is suspected due to levels of exploitation (bycatch). However, its continued abundance despite high overlap with fisheries and a stable trend in Colombia suggests that the population may not have declined as much as that suspected for some other tropical Eastern Pacific round rays. Overall, it is suspected that the Spinytail Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years).
range: The Spinytail Round Ray occurs from Baja California and central Mexico to northern Peru in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Round rays are of little commercial value due to their small size. They are often discarded when caught, although there may be some retention in small-scale (artisanal) fisheries for meat, fish meal, or bait.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific measures in place for the Spiny-tail Round Ray. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki pers. comm. 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Benthic trawling and mechanized beach seines have been prohibited in the coastal zone of Peru (to 5 nm from shore) since 2001 (Regulation: DS-012-2001-PE) and manual beach seines from 2009 (Regulation: RM-112-2009-PRODUCE). This has likely reduced the catch of inshore elasmobranchs in Peruvian coastal waters.

Further research is needed on life history, the level of mortality due to fisheries, and population size and trend. Both small- and large-scale fisheries should be monitored for bycatch at the species level.

rationale: The Eremo Skate (Bathyraja trachouros) is a medium-sized (to 102 cm TL) deep-water skate found in the Northwest Pacific Ocean in Japan, from northern Hokkaido to Sendai in northern Honshu and the southern Kuril Islands, near Iturup, and Kunashir Islands in Russia. It occurs on continental shelves and slopes at depths of 100–800 m, within reach of most demersal trawl and longlines fisheries across its geographic range. This species is suspected to be caught as part of a target skate fishery off Hokkaido and as bycatch of Japanese demersal trawl fisheries targeting Sailfin Sandfish (Arctoscopus japonica) and Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus) and Russian fisheries east of the Kuril Islands. Demand for skates is increasing from Korean markets, driving increased landings from the target skate fishery in Hokkaido. Risk is further increased because skate landings data have not been collected in Japan since 2006. Most of the population occurs within the depth range and spatial extent of current fisheries, that are unmonitored, unsustainable, and without catch limits. It is suspected that Eremo Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (41 years) due to actual and potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Eremo Skate is demersal on insular shelves and slopes at depths of 100–800 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 102 cm total length (TL), males mature at 88 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous, size-at-birth is unknown but egg capsules measure 11–13 cm in length (Last et al. 2016). Female age-at-maturity is suspected to be 10 years and maximum age is 17 years; generation length is therefore 13.5 years, based on the Alaska Skate (Bathyraja parmifera) (Matta and Gunderson 2007).
threats: This species may be taken by directed fisheries targeting skates around Hokkaido Prefecture and skates are taken as bycatch of longline and demersal and mid water trawl fisheries for Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus) down to a depth of 350 m (H. Ishihara unpubl. data 2019) and demersal set gillnets (Y. Semba unpubl. data 2019) and therefore this species has some refuge at depth. Pacific Cod have been overfished since the 1970 throughout all regions of Japan and overfishing is currently occurring, or probably occurring, in all regions (Chen 2014). This species may derive some benefit of reduction in fishing mortality as a result of fisheries closures following the Great East Japan Earthquake, and resultant tsunami, on 11th March 2011, resulting in restrictions for Pacific Cod fisheries at least until the last day of 2014 (Narimatsu et al. 2016). Skates are taken as bycatch of demersal and mid water trawl fisheries targeting Alaskan Pollock (Theragra chalcogramma), Pacific Herring (Clupea pallasii), and Greenland Halibut (Reinhardtius hippoglossoides) (I.V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). The demersal trawl fishery occurs from 50 to 500 m, the Greenland halibut fishery usually operates down to 650 m and therefore this species has some refuge at depth. Historically, there were deep-water longline fisheries for grenadiers down to 1,000 m with the bulk of catches (up to 95% and more) consisting of grenadiers with minor bycatch of snailfishes, morids, sculpins, and skates (A. Orlov pers. obs. 2007). In the past 2–3 years, there are occasional experimental fisheries that fish down to 2,500 m (I.V Volvenko unpubl. data 2019) and thus may constitute an ongoing threat if continued or expanded into the future.
population: The Eremo Skate has a deep depth range (100–800 m) that lies within partial reach of demersal trawl and longlines fisheries within its distribution off eastern Honshu and Hokkaido. This species is caught as bycatch of Japanese demersal trawl fisheries targeting Sailfin Sandfish (Arctoscopus japonica) and Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus) (H. Ishihara unpub. data 2019) and Russian fisheries east of the Kuril Islands. The partial intersection of these fisheries with the depth and geographic distribution of this species lead to a suspected population reduction of 20-29% over the past three generation lengths (40.5 years).
range: The Eremo Skate is found in the Northwest Pacific Ocean in Japan, from northern Hokkaido to Sendai, northern Honshu, and the southern Kurils Islands, near Iturup and Kunashir Islands (Last et al. 2016, Dyldin and Orlov 2018).
useTrade: In Russia, skate bycatch have been landed since 2000 and wings are most likely exported to the Republic of Korea (I.V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). In Japan, skates are of low value and while there is some domestic consumption, skate wings are most likely exported to the Republic of Korea (H. Ishihara unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation actions for this species. Research is required on its population size, distribution and trends, life histories and ecology, interaction with fisheries, including species-specific monitoring of catches. Training in species identification is needed, along with awareness and communications of status and need for research and management, to support national policy and compliance, including livelihoods and market forces.

rationale:
The Japanese Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium umbratile) is a small (to 115 cm total length) deep-water swellshark endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean where it occurs in Japan, Republic of Korea, China, and Taiwan. It is demersal and epi-pelagic on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 18–790 m. The species is a bycatch of demersal trawl, longline, and possibly gillnet fisheries and is retained in some fisheries and discarded in others. Where discarded, it likely has high post-release survival.

There are no data on the population trends for this species. However, previously it was considered to be locally abundant in Japan and Taiwan, despite fishing pressure. It is still common in Taiwan, which indicates some resilience to fishing pressure, but the current abundance in Japan, Republic of Korea, and China is unknown. Similar species of deep-water swellsharks are sensitive to fishing pressure and where they are heavily fished they have undergone severe declines (99%) over the past three generation lengths (45 years). This species may have refuge at depth in parts of its range and fishing pressure has declined in Japan, where most of the species range occurs. Elsewhere, fishing pressure is high, ongoing and is of concern. A precautionary approach leads to it being suspected that the Japanese Swellshark is close to reaching the population reduction threshold due to high actual or potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Japanese Swellshark is demersal and epi-pelagic on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 18–790 m (Nakabo 2013, Weigmann 2016, I. V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). Four individuals of 75–80 cm total length (TL) were captured in 1983 in three separate mid-water trawls, all at depths of 660–790 m (I. V. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). It reaches a maximum size of 114.5 cm total length (TL), males mature at 86 cm TL and females mature at 92 cm TL (Taniuchi 1988, Horie and Tanaka 2002). Reproduction is oviparous with egg cases apparently laid year-round and size-at-birth of 18 cm TL (Taniuchi 1988, Ebert et al. 2013a). Nothing else is known of its biology. Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from a related species, the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) that has a female age-at-maturity of 9.1 years and a maximum age of 20.9 years, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011).
threats:
The Japanese Swellshark is a bycatch of demersal trawl, longline, and possibly gillnet, fisheries. In Japan, in Nagasaki, Kyushu, and Mie Prefectures it is usually caught on longline and retained as it is a valued food (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). It may also be captured by a deep-water dropline fishery for Splendid Alfonsino (Beryx splendens) that operates around the islands and seamounts south of Sagami Bay at depths of 400–800 m and an Alaska Pollock (Theragra chalcogramma) fishery that operates off the northeast coast of Hokkaido to depths of 500 m (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019, Y. Dyldin unpubl. data 2019). It is possibly captured in Suruga Bay, where demersal gillnets target fish and crustaceans in the winter at depths of 100–500 m. Elsewhere in Japan, it is mostly taken by demersal trawl fisheries that operate at depths of 200–800 m and it is discarded (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). The species has been observed to be still alive after 1–2 days in the fish market, hence it is likely to have high post-release survival (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). The fishing effort within the Japanese Exclusive Economic Zone has declined by approximately one-third since the 1950s (Antimacara et al. 2011). Across Japan, demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019).

The species is a possible bycatch of deep-water trawl fisheries that operate off the northeast coast of Taiwan at depths of 300–700 m; these fisheries target multiple species of shrimp with all the incidental catch retained (D. Ebert pers. comm. 28/08/2019). It may be taken by commercial deep-water longlines on the eastern coast of Taiwan that operate to a depth of 300 m where all incidental catch is also retained (H. Ho and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The species may be caught by Chinese trawlers that operate to a maximum depth of 300 m (X. Chen pers. comm. 28/08/2019), and is likely captured by South Korean fisheries.
population:
There are no population trend data for the species. The Japanese Swellshark was previously noted as locally abundant, even in areas heavily fished by trawlers (Iglésias et al. 2009). It is still considered very common in north Taiwan (Ebert et al. 2013b) but its current abundance in Japan, South Korea, and China is unknown. The species was rarely captured in Russian research deep-water trawl surveys off Japan with five individuals recorded from 1982–1983 (I. Volvenko unpubl. data 2019). Fishing pressure across Japan has declined by approximately one-third since the 1950s with dramatic declines in trawl fishing pressure over the past three decades. Line fishing pressure still exists in Japan, albeit at lower levels than historically, and fishing pressure in the Republic of Korea, Taiwan, and China is high with the species retained (Anticamara et al. 2011, Kuo and Booth 2011, Liang and Pauly 2017).

Other deep-water swellsharks are sensitive to fishing pressure; even when fisheries management is implemented, intensive fishing can lead to significant declines. In the Southwest Pacific, the standardized catch-per-unit-effort for the Whitefin Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium albipinnum) in the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery, Australia, decreased by 73% from 1994–2006 (Walker and Gason 2007). This decline was equivalent to a ~99% population reduction over the past three generation lengths of the Whitefin Swellshark (45 years) (Pardo et al. 2019). The Japanese Swellshark was considered to be locally abundant across Japan and Taiwan despite fishing pressure. It is still common in Taiwan which indicates some resilience to, or depth refuge from, fishing pressure. Fishing pressure has declined in Japan, where most of this species range occurs. Declines in similar species exposed to high fishing pressure, and ongoing high fishing pressure on this species in the southerly parts of its range are cause for concern. A precautionary approach leads to it being suspected that the Japanese Swellshark is close to reaching the population reduction threshold for Vulnerable A2d.
range: The Japanese Swellshark is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean where it occurs in the Sea of Japan, Yellow Sea, and the East China Sea off Japan, Republic of Korea, China, and Taiwan (Ebert et al. 2013a, Nakaya et al. 2013, Dyldin 2015, K. Nakaya pers. comm. 27/08/2020). Fricke et al. (2020) noted it occurs in Viet Nam and Malaysia, but this range is not confirmed (K. Nakaya pers. comm. 27/08/2020).
useTrade: In Japan, the species is highly valued for its meat in Nagasaki, Kyushu, and  Mie Prefectures but is not preferred in the Prefectures of the Sea of Japan (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). In Taiwan, and likely China and South Korea, it is used for meat with smaller individuals possibly used for fish meal. Several aquaria in Japan commonly exhibit this species (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the Yellow Sea and East China Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). In 2018, this seasonal closure was extended to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 27/08/2019). In Taiwan, since the mid–2000s, gillnets have been banned within 3 nautical miles (nm) in parts of five counties with a policy of gradual removal of gillnets from within 3 nm of the entire coast and government assistance to transition to line and troll fishing (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Munda Round Ray (Urotrygon munda) is a small (to at least 25 cm total length) ray which occurs from central Mexico to northern Peru in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific. It inhabits soft substrates in shallow coastal and continental shelf waters at depths of 5–50 m. This is a rare and poorly-known species with some uncertainty regarding its population status. This species is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries and probably in a variety of other artisanal fisheries across its range. There are very few records from Ecuador and Colombia and in Costa Rica, four years of monitoring of demersal trawl bycatch recorded only a single specimen. Tropical Eastern Pacific round rays have life history parameters including very early age-at-maturity (1–4 years) that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality. Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, balanced with the high biological productivity of tropical Eastern Pacific round rays, it is suspected that the Munda Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Munda Round Ray inhabits soft substrates in shallow coastal and continental shelf waters at depths of 5–50 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 25 cm total length (TL), males mature at ~20 cm TL, and size-at-birth is ~9 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is viviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Age data are not available for this species, but generation length is estimated to be 5 years based on Rogers’ Round Ray (Urotrygon rogersi) and the Spinytail Round Ray (Urotrygon aspidura) (Mejía-Falla et al. 2014, Torres-Palacios et al. 2019). These species are larger (46 and 42 cm TL, respectively) than the Munda Round Ray, and therefore this is likely to be an overestimate of generation length.
threats:
This round ray is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries and probably in a variety of other artisanal fisheries across its range. In El Salvador, catches are low in the industrial trawl fishery (Fuentes and Hernández 2004). In Costa Rica, four years of monitoring of demersal trawl bycatch recorded only a single specimen (Clarke et al. 2016). There are very few records from Ecuador and Colombia (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2019).

Overall, there is high spatial overlap with fisheries (which generally lack management or effective enforcement of regulations across most of its range), and given the geographic and depth range of the species, it has no refuge from fishing activities that operate across its range.
population:
The Munda Round Ray appears to be an uncommon species as it is rarely-encountered or only encountered in low numbers in surveys and research (including in El Salvador, Costa Rica, Colombia, and Ecuador).

In the Tehuantepec Gulf, Mexico, demographic models suggest population declines of the related Chilean Round Ray (Urotyrgon chilensis) under some scenarios, but not under other scenarios; overall the model results were not conclusive to ascertain population trend (Guzmán-Castellanos 2015).

Biological data from tropical Eastern Pacific round rays show life history parameters, including very early ages-at-maturity (1–4 years; Mejía-Falla et al. 2014, Guzmán-Castellanos 2015, Torres-Palacios et al. 2019), that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality.

The Munda Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge. Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, balanced with the high biological productivity of Eastern Pacific round rays, it is suspected that the Munda Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years).
range: The Munda Round Ray occurs from central Mexico to northern Peru in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Round rays are of little commercial value due to their small size. They are often discarded when caught, although there may be some retention in small-scale (artisanal) fisheries for meat, fish meal, or bait.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific measures in place for the Munda Round Ray. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki pers. comm. 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Benthic trawling and mechanized beach seines have been prohibited in the coastal zone of Peru (to 5 nm from shore) since 2001 (Regulation: DS-012-2001-PE) and manual beach seines from 2009 (Regulation: RM-112-2009-PRODUCE ). This has likely reduced the catch of inshore elasmobranchs in Peruvian coastal waters.  

Further research is needed on life history, the level of mortality due to fisheries, and population size and trend. Both small- and large-scale fisheries should be monitored for bycatch at the species level.

rationale: The Bigtail Skate (Dipturus macrocauda) is a medium-sized (to 130 cm total length) skate endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from southern Japan to Taiwan, including South Korea and China. It is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 150–850 m. The species is likely a bycatch of deep-water demersal trawl and longline and is retained in Taiwan and possibly South Korea for human consumption and fish meal, and is likely discarded in Japan. There is no species-specific population trend data. The species is rarely captured in Japan, infrequently captured in Taiwan, and possibly taken in part of South Korea, and some Chinese fisheries. Medium-sized to large Dipturus species are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity, which is of concern for the Bigtail Skate. However, this species has significant refuge from fishing pressure at depth and although historic fishing pressure was high, the fishing pressure has declined over the past 15–30 years across most of its range where it is commercially encountered. It is suspected that the Bigtail Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (51 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Bigtail Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope on sandy and muddy substrates at depths of 150–850 m (Nakabo 2013, Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 130 cm total length (TL); males are mature at 100 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Ages are inferred from two large deep-water skates; the Yellownose Skate (D. chilensis) and Bight Skate (D. gudgeri) which have female ages-at-maturity of 14 years and 16 years and maximum ages of 21 years and 18 years, resulting in generation lengths of 17.5 years and 17 years, respectively (Licandeo et al. 2006, Treloar 2008). Thus, the generation length of the Giant Skate is inferred as 17 years, though this should be used with caution as the two skates are larger (158 cm TL and 184 cm TL) than the Bigtail Skate.
threats:
The Bigtail Skate is subject to fishing pressure across its spatial range. It is a rare and infrequent bycatch from deep-water demersal trawl and longline fisheries and retained for human consumption or fish meal in Taiwan and possibly South Korea, and is likely discarded in Japan. Records of this species are rare in Japan. It may be captured by demersal trawl fisheries that operate at depths of 200–800 m (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). It may also be captured by a deepwater dropline fishery for Splendid Alfonsino (Beryx splendens) that operates around the islands and seamounts south of Sagami Bay at depths of 400–800 m (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019).

In South Korea, it may be captured in trawl and longline fisheries. However, most of the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) is too shallow for this species, with its occurrence limited to an area off the east coast that extends beyond a depth of 300 m. Fishing effort in South Korea increased markedly in the 1990s, when the number of fishing boats increased to 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean EEZ (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014). It may be encountered in Chinese trawl fisheries that operate to a depth of 300 m (X. Chen pers. comm. 28/08/2019), which is at the upper depth limit of the Bigtail Skate.

In Taiwan, the species is observed infrequently at Da-xi fish market in the northeast (Ebert et al. 2013). It is presumed to be taken as bycatch of deep-water trawl fisheries that operate off the northeast coast of Taiwan at depths of 200–700 m; these fisheries target multiple species of shrimp with all the incidental catch retained (D.A. Ebert pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Although there are no detailed effort data, the number of trawl vessels operating in the northeast of Taiwan has remained fairly stable from 1999 to 2008 (H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The deep-water longline fisheries on the east coast of Taiwan operate at depths of 100–300 m (H. Ho and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28/08/2019) and thus would not interact with this species, which occurs deeper.
population: There are no species-specific population trend data for this species. It appears to be rare and is infrequently encountered in commercial fisheries; interactions in Japan are rare, it is caught occasionally in Taiwan, it may be captured in part of South Korea, and is some Chinese fisheries. Medium-sized to large Dipturus species are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity, as evidenced by population reductions of up to 75% in response to intense fishing pressure over 20–30 years (see Red List assessments: Yellownose Skate (D. chilensis) and Bight Skate (D. gudgeri)). The Bigtail Skate is also likely to have low biological productivity which is of concern, however it has significant refuge from fishing pressure at depth across its range. Historical fishing pressure was intense, but has declined over the past 15 and 30 years in South Korea and Japan, respectively. It is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (51 years).
range: The Bigtail Skate is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from southern Japan to Taiwan including South Korea and China (Ebert et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: No information is available on use and trade; similar skates are retained in Taiwan for human consumption or fish meal.
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the East China Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen pers. comm. 28/08/2019). In Taiwan, since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catches should be monitored.

rationale:
The Highfin Dogfish (Centroscyllium excelsum) is a small (to 68 cm total length) poorly-known deep-water shark endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean with a highly restricted distribution. It occurs only on the Emperor Seamount Chain and is demersal on seamounts at depths of 642–1,000 m. The species is a bycatch of deep-water demersal trawl, longline, and gillnet fisheries and is likely discarded with poor post-release survival. Most of the fisheries operate at 300–500 m and would not interact with the Highfin Dogfish however it may be caught by some fisheries that operate to a depth of 1,300 m.

Historically, during the 1960s to 1980s, fishing pressure across its range was intense and unregulated however fishing effort has since reduced, is voluntarily regulated, and is mostly in the southern part of this species range. The species is likely susceptible to overfishing and its highly restricted distribution and capture is of concern. It is suspected that the Highfin Dogfish has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (45 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Highfin Dogfish is demersal on seamounts at depths of 642–1,000 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016, A. Orlov pers. comm. 20/10/2020). It reaches a maximum size of 68.2 cm total length (TL), males mature at 52 cm TL and females mature at 53 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013, A. Orlov pers. comm. 20/10/2020). Reproduction is viviparous with a litter size of ten pups found in one female and size-at-birth estimated as 8-9 cm TL (McCormack et al. 2009, Ebert et al. 2013). Nothing else is known of its biology. Generation length is inferred from two other lanternshark species of similar size and depth range and is suspected to be 15 ranging from 14–16 years. Generation lengths are estimated as 14 years and 16 years for the Smooth Lanternshark (Etmopterus pusillus) and Southern Lanternshark (Etmopterus granulosus), respectively (Irvine et al. 2006, Coelho and Erzini 2007). Even though these are small species, they have relatively low growth rates, are late maturing, and long-lived, which makes them susceptible to overfishing (Irvine et al. 2006, Coelho and Erzini 2007).
threats: The species may be taken as bycatch in demersal trawl, longline, and gillnet fisheries on the Emperor Seamounts. In 2019, half of the total number of recorded specimens (23 individuals) were captured by demersal trawl surveys at Lira Seamount at depths of 642–653 m (A. Orlov pers. comm. 20/10/2020). The Highfin Dogfish has been reported as bycatch by some members of the North Pacific Fisheries Commission (NPFC), however it is unknown if it is retained or discarded (J. Curtis, Scientific Committee, NPFC pers. comm. 10/09/2020). If it is discarded, post-release survival is unknown, but is possibly low (Nakaya et al. 2009). The fisheries have operated since 1967 and fished heavily during the 1960s to 1980s mostly at depths of 300–600 m (Baco et al. 2019). The fisheries currently operate mostly in the Southern Emperor seamounts, which encompass the southern part of the known range of this species and mostly operate at depths of 300–500 m. However, some Japanese gillnets may operate at 300–1,300 m and an exploratory South Korea longliner operated at depths of 250–1,050 m in the mid-2000s (CHM 2016, Shotton 2016, NPFC 2020). The demersal trawl fisheries mainly target North Pacific Armourhead (Pentaceros wheeleri) that do not occur below depths of 800 m and Splendid Alfosino (Beryx splendens) that occurs at depths of 25–1,300 m (Froese and Pauly 2019, NPFC 2020). The North Pacific Armourhead fisheries are unlikely to fish to the depths at which this species occurs, but the fisheries for Splendid Alfosino may interact with this species. The main fisheries for Splendid Alfosino in the Southern Emperor/Northern Hawaiian Ridge are on seamounts slightly further south than the range of this species, that is from 36°N (Yoko seamount) to ~30°N (Hancock seamounts) (Shotton 2016).
population: The species is known from only 44 adult individuals reported from deep-water trawls (Shirai and Nakaya 1990, A. Orlov pers. comm. 20/10/2020). It has been recently reported as bycatch of the current fisheries on the Emperor Seamounts. Historically, in the 1960s to the 1980s, there was intense and unregulated fishing pressure on the Emperor Seamounts (Baco et al. 2019) that may have caused a population decline. The fisheries still operate but fishing effort has declined, is voluntarily regulated, and is mostly in the southern part of this species range. Due to the highly restricted distribution of this species and the susceptibility to overfishing, the capture of this species is of concern. It may have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (42–48 years). A precautionary approach leads to it being suspected the species is close to reaching the population reduction threshold.
range: The Highfin Dogfish is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean, where it is known from a restricted distribution at the Kuril Islands and on the Emperor Seamount Chain east of Japan at the type locality, 38–50°N, 170–171°E (McCormack et al. 2009, Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The use of this species is unknown, but based on other Centroscyllium species it is likely of no commercial interest to fisheries (Ebert et al. 2013), and thus is likely not used.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Highfin Dogfish. Demersal fisheries in the Emperor Seamount Chain are managed by interim conservation measures of the North Pacific Fisheries Commission (NPFC) and voluntary measures of NPFC Members, including time-area closures, effort controls, and capacity limits (CHM 2016). Japan limits the capacity of demersal fishing vessels in the NPFC Convention Area to 80% of the effort of the 1996–2006 level with no fishing to be conducted north of 45°N. South Korea limits the number of demersal vessels to the 2016 level (CHM 2016). Research is required to better define the species' distribution and life history, population size and trend, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Bluntnose Spurdog (Squalus acutipinnis) is a small (to 85 cm total length) dogfish that inhabits the continental shelf and slope in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans from Cape Town to KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, as well as Mauritius. Its depth range is uncertain but this species likely occurs at depths of 0–1,500 m. The species is suspected to have low biological productivity. It is captured frequently as bycatch in demersal trawl fisheries in South Africa, and may be exhibiting a range shift due to climate change. Trend analysis of research trawl data in South African commercially fished areas estimated a population reduction of 33% over three generation lengths (70.5 years), with the highest probability of a <20% reduction over three generation lengths. This species may be recovering off the east coast of South Africa outside the research trawl area, where fishing pressure has decreased substantially in the last two decades. Overall, due to estimated reductions in population size over most of its range and decreasing fishing pressure in other areas, it is suspected that the Bluntnose Spurdog has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (70.5 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The Bluntnose Spurdog is benthopelagic on the continental shelf and slope. The exact depth range is unknown, but congeners that the species was previously assigned to in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans occur between 0–1,500 m (Viana and Carvalho 2016, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 85 cm total length (TL) (Viana and Carvalho 2016). Size- and age-at-maturity is available for 'Shortnose Spurdog Squalus megalops' from South Africa (Watson and Smale 1999), which represents Bluntnose Spurdog together with other members of the megalops-cubensis group: female size-at-maturity is 49 cm TL; male size-at-maturity is 40 cm TL; female age-at-maturity is 15 years; male age-at-maturity is 9 years; maximum age is 32 years (Watson and Smale 1999). Generation length, based on these ages, is 23.5 years.
threats: The Bluntnose Spurdog is captured frequently as bycatch in demersal trawl fisheries targeting hake in South Africa (da Silva et al. 2015). Trawl fisheries operate throughout its range, but effort has decreased over the past two decades, particularly off KwaZulu-Natal (S. Fennessy pers. comm. 20 April 2018). This species has shown evidence of a southward range shift over three decades from 1981–2016 in South Africa from the wide shelf area of Agulhus Bank to waters approximately 30 m deeper to the south, possibly as a result of climate change (Currie et al. 2019). Although not definitively known, this may represent a significant loss of habitat to this species that has a restricted southern African distribution.
population:
There are no estimates of population size for the Bluntnose Spurdog. Population trend data of annual density estimates (kg per nm² area swept) were available from demersal research trawl surveys conducted over 27 years in commercially fished areas of South Africa during summer along the west coast (1991–2017) and autumn and spring along the south coast (1991–2016) by the Fisheries Branch of the South African Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF unpubl. data 2018). The trend data were analysed over three generation lengths (70.5 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Winker and Sherley 2019). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

The trend analysis revealed an annual rate of reduction of 0.6% over the trawl grounds, consistent with an estimated reduction of 33.0% over the past three generation lengths (70.5 years), with the highest probability (47.2%) of a <20% reduction over three generation lengths. This species may be recovering off the east coast of South Africa outside the research trawl area, where fishing pressure has decreased substantially in the last two decades. Overall, due to estimated reductions in population size over most of its range and decreasing fishing pressure in other areas, it is suspected that the Bluntnose Spurdog has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (70.5 years).
range: The Bluntnose Spurdog occurs in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans from Cape Town to KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, as well as Mauritius (Viana and Carvalho 2016). Records from Mozambique and Reunion require confirmation.
useTrade: The utilization of the Bluntnose Spurdog is unknown. Squalus dogfishes are typically of high value for their meat, liver oil, fins, and occasionally, leather (Ebert et al. 2013).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place. Recreational anglers in South Africa are restricted to one shark per species per day (maximum of 10 individuals per day) (da Silva et al. 2015), although enforcement is an ongoing issue. Further research is needed on distribution, population size and trend, life history, use and trade, and catch rates.

rationale: The Natal Sleeper Ray (Heteronarce garmani) is a small (to 30 cm total length), rare demersal ray endemic to southern Africa in the Western Indian Ocean where it occurs from Algoa Bay, South Africa to southern Mozambique and southwestern Madagascar. It occurs on the continental shelf and upper slope, and in canyons, at depths of 70–330 m. Little is known of its biology. The species is a bycatch in demersal trawl fisheries and is likely discarded as it is not utilized. There are no population trend data, however it is exposed to trawl fishing pressure across its range. This pressure has decreased substantially in parts of its range and the species likely has refuge in canyon habitats and marine protected areas. Small electric rays are not susceptible to capture in longline fisheries. Overall, it is suspected that the Natal Sleeper Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (15 years) due to levels of exploitation (bycatch), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Natal Sleeper Ray is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 70–330 m (Last et al. 2016). It likely occurs over soft substrate and has been recorded from canyons (100–200 m depth) near Sodwana Bay, KwaZulu-Natal (Heemstra et al. 2006, Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 30 cm total length (TL), males mature at ~17 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous, but nothing else is known of its biology. Age-at-maturity and maximum age are unknown and lacking for all sleeper rays. Ages are inferred from the known ages of a species of numbfish which is from a family of small to medium-sized electric rays that resemble sleeper rays. Female age-at-maturity is 6 years and maximum age is 15 years for the Cortez Numbfish (Narcine entemedor); resulting in a generation length of 10.5 years (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000). The Cortez Numbfish is larger than the Natal Sleeper Ray (75 cm vs 30 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 5 years for the Natal Sleeper Ray.
threats: The Natal Sleeper Ray is a bycatch of demersal trawl fisheries in South Africa (da Silva et al. 2015). These fisheries have decreased in effort in South Africa over the last decade, particularly the trawl fishery off KwaZulu-Natal (S. Fennessy, pers. comm., 20 April 2018); they have captured less than 1 t annually of Natal Sleeper Ray from 2010–2012 (da Silva et al. 2015). The species is likely discarded as it is not utilized; nothing is known of post-release mortality of this family of rays (Ellis et al. 2017). There may be some refuge from fishing for this small ray off the KwaZulu-Natal coast where there is now limited trawl effort and well-enforced marine protected areas. Intense small-scale trawl fishing in southern Mozambique (Jacquet et al. 2010, Benkenstein 2013) may threaten this species, however it has not been noted from trawl fisheries in Mozambique (S. Fennessy, pers. comm., 25 April 2018). Deep-water trawling effort is increasing in Madagascar waters (Cripps et al. 2015, R. Bennett, unpubl. data, 2018). Small electric rays are not susceptible to capture in longline fisheries.
population: There are no population size or trend estimates for the Natal Sleeper Ray. Very few specimens have been caught in research surveys, despite extensive sampling on the shelf and upper slope within its known range, and this species is considered rare (Compagno and Heemstra 2007). The fisheries in South Africa have decreased in effort over the last decade, however, the Natal Sleeper Ray population may be affected by trawl fisheries operating off southern Mozambique and Madagascar. Overall, the majority of the species range is exposed to trawl fishing pressure, though this has recently decreased in some areas, it is not captured in longline fisheries, and it likely has refuge in marine protected areas. Therefore, it is suspected that a population reduction of 20–29% has occurred over the past three generations (15 years) as a result of actual levels of exploitation (bycatch).
range: The Natal Sleeper Ray is a southern African endemic occurring from Algoa Bay, South Africa to southern Mozambique and southwestern Madagascar in the Western Indian Ocean (Last et al. 2016, D. Ebert, unpubl. data, 2018).
useTrade: The Natal Sleeper Ray has not been recorded in trade, and is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this species. A number of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) occur across its range, including: iSimangaliso MPA and the uThukela MPA in South Africa, and Ponta do Ouro Partial MPA in southern Mozambique. Further research is needed on population size and trends, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Dwarf Round Ray (Urotrygon nana) is a small (to at least 26 cm total length) ray which occurs from central Mexico to Panama in the Eastern Central Pacific. It inhabits shallow inshore waters and mangroves at depths of 2–15 m. Trawl surveys in Mexico have shown it to be abundant. Little information is available on catches in the southern part of its range but monitoring of demersal trawl bycatch in Costa Rica recorded only a few individuals. Round rays are generally discarded although they may be used as bait or fishmeal by artisanal fishers. The considerable loss of mangrove habitat in the tropical Eastern Pacific is suspected to have had a significant impact on the occurrence of the Dwarf Round Ray given its association with mangroves. Tropical Eastern Pacific round rays have life history parameters including very early age-at-maturity (1–4 years) that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality. The Dwarf Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge. However, its continued abundance despite high overlap with fisheries and habitat loss suggests that the population may not have declined as much as that suspected for other tropical Eastern Pacific round rays. Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range and a decline in habitat quality and area of occupancy, balanced with the high biological productivity of tropical Eastern Pacific round rays, it is suspected that the Dwarf Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years), and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2cd).
habitat: The Dwarf Round Ray inhabits shallow inshore waters and mangroves at depths of 2–15 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 26 cm total length (TL), males mature at 15–17 cm TL, and size-at-birth is ~6 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is viviparous and litter size is reported to be 1 pup (Last et al. 2016). Age data are not available for this species, but generation length is estimated to be 5 years based on Rogers’ Round Ray (Urotrygon rogersi) and the Spinytail Round Ray (Urotrygon aspidura) (Mejía-Falla et al. 2014, Torres-Palacios et al. 2019). These species are larger (46 and 42 cm TL, respectively) than the Dwarf Round Ray, and therefore this is likely to be an overestimate of generation length.
threats:
This round ray is taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries and probably in a variety of other artisanal fisheries across its range. In Mexico, it was recorded in ~50% of demersal trawl surveys during 2009–2010; it appears to be an abundant species there and is a frequent bycatch of shrimp trawling (Valle-Esquivel and Zollet 2017).

Little information is available on catches in the southern part of its range but monitoring of demersal trawl bycatch in Costa Rica recorded only a few individuals (Clarke et al. 2016). Overall, there is high spatial overlap with fisheries (which generally lack management or effective enforcement of regulations across most of its range), and given the geographic and depth range of the species, it has no refuge from fishing activities that operate across its range.

The tropical Eastern Pacific is subject to very high levels of mangrove clearing for coastal development and aquaculture (e.g. 39% mangrove loss in Costa Rica and 68% in Panama; López-Angarita et al. 2016). This is suspected to have had a significant impact on the occurrence of the Dwarf Round Ray given its association with mangroves.
population:
There are no available data on population trend of the Dwarf Round Ray. This is an abundant species in Mexico (Valle-Esquivel and Zollet 2017). 

In the Tehuantepec Gulf, Mexico, demographic models suggest population declines of the related Chilean Round Ray (Urotyrgon chilensis) under some scenarios, but not under other scenarios; overall the model results were not conclusive to ascertain population trend (Guzmán-Castellanos 2015).

Biological data from tropical Eastern Pacific round rays show life history parameters, including very early ages-at-maturity (1–4 years; Mejía-Falla et al. 2014, Guzmán-Castellanos 2015, Torres-Palacios et al. 2019), that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality.

The Dwarf Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge. Furthermore, the considerable loss of mangrove habitat in the tropical Eastern Pacific (López-Angarita et al. 2016) is suspected to have had a significant impact on the occurrence of the Dwarf Round Ray given its association with mangroves. 

The continued abundance of the Dwarf Round Ray despite high overlap with fisheries and habitat loss suggests that the population may not have declined as much as that suspected for other tropical Eastern Pacific round rays. Overall, it is suspected that the Dwarf Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generations (15 years).
range: The Dwarf Round Ray occurs from central Mexico to Panama in the Eastern Central Pacific (Miyake and McEachran 1988, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Round rays are of little commercial value due to their small size. They are often discarded when caught, although there may be some retention in small-scale (artisanal) fisheries for meat, fish meal, or bait.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Dwarf Round Ray. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki pers. comm. 2019). <span class="msoins0">Further research is needed on life history, the level of mortality due to fisheries, and population size and trend. Both small- and large-scale fisheries should be monitored for bycatch at the species level.

rationale: The Marbled Stingray (Dasyatis marmorata) is a medium-sized (to 75 cm disc width) ray that occurs in the Mediterranean Sea and the Eastern Central Atlantic ranging from the Levantine Basin and North African coast to the Republic of the Congo. It is demersal on the continental shelf from the surface to a depth of 100 m. This species is taken as incidental catch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple demersal fishing gears, including trawl, line gear, gillnet, and set net across its range. In the Eastern Central Atlantic, it is retained for its meat which is consumed locally and traded regionally salted-dried or dried and smoked. In the Mediterranean Sea, it is considered rare with records limited to Tunisia, Israel, Lebanon, Cyprus, Turkey, and Greece and little data available to determine catch levels or trends. Elsewhere, there are no species-specific time series, although it is still commonly reported in landings. Despite this abundance, there is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across most of the range of this species which are a cause for concern. Overall, considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its lack of refuge at depth, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Marbled Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (32 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Marbled Stingray is demersal on sandy and muddy substrates in shallow coastal waters at depths of 0–100 m depth (Carpenter and De Angelis 2016, Last et al. 2016b). It reaches a maximum size of 75 cm disc width (DW), males mature at ~ 27–35 cm DW and females mature at ~ 32–41 cm DW (Valadou et al. 2006, Carpenter and De Angelis 2016, Last et al. 2016b). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with litter sizes of 1–6 pups, a gestation length of 2–4 months, and size-at-birth of ~ 16 cm DW (Valadou et al. 2006, Carpenter and De Angelis 2016). There is no information on this species' age-at-maturity and maximum age, hence, generation length was inferred based on age parameters for the similar sized Blue Stingray (Dasyatis chrysonota) which has an age-at-maturity of 7 years and a maximum age of 14 years; resulting in a generation length of 10.5 years (Cowley 1990).
threats:
The Marbled Stingray is taken as bycatch in artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is retained for human consumption. It is also likely taken in industrial fisheries operating trawls in coastal areas. In the Mediterranean Sea, the Marbled Stingray is sometimes landed in demersal trawl fisheries as bycatch (Bradai 2000). This region has been subject to extensive and intensive fishing across much of the species' known depth and spatial distribution with trawl fisheries operating over a wide bathymetric range (50–800 m) and targeting a variety of species (Lleonart and Maynou 2003, Tsikliras et al. 2015). Following two centuries of fisheries development, target shark and ray fisheries developed in the 1950s, with catches peaking until the 1970s, after which a decreasing trend was reported along with a decline in diversity of species (Cavanagh and Gibson 2007, Davidson et al. 2016). A number of shark and ray species are now considered to be locally extinct due to overexploitation (e.g., Ferretti et al. 2008).

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West African coastal waters and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (e.g., False Shark Ray (Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis) from the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin and the African Wedgefish (Rhynchobatus luebberti) from the Sine-Saloum Delta) (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many important commercial coastal, demersal, and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977 to 2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of demersal resources and deep sea pelagic catches of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 - these were mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region and which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world, and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed the reported legal catch by more than 40% (Pauly and Zeller 2016).

The shallow, inshore soft-substrate habitats preferred by rays are threatened by habitat loss and environmental degradation (Stobutzki et al. 2006, White and Sommerville 2010, Jabado et al. 2017).
