Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation, conversion of coastal lagoons and mangrove deforestation for agriculture (e.g., rice and salt) and aquaculture (e.g., shrimp, fish culture and fish production); extensive oil and gas exploration, drilling, and production; the effects of rapid urban expansion from growing coastal populations and unplanned tourism development; pollution (unregulated sewage effluents, agricultural runoff, hydrocarbon, and heavy metals); sedimentation and siltation; and changes to the hydrological cycle from the building of dams leading to dramatic levels of habitat loss evident across the region (GCLME 2006, FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016). In West Africa, mangroves are harvested for fuel wood, construction timber, and charcoal with an overall mangrove forest area decline of up to 70% in some countries over the last 20 years. The highest losses recorded from are from Côte d'Ivoire (67%), Liberia (65%), Guinea (60%), Sierra Leone (40%), and Ghana (30%) (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016, CCLME 2016).
population:
There are a number of relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to calculate population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with high increases in the Mediterranean Sea and Eastern Central Atlantic regions (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013, Belhabib et al. 2018).

First, in the Mediterranean Sea, surveys indicate that the Marbled Stingray is relatively uncommon and mostly recorded from the eastern region of the basin, although it is important to note that it has been confused and misidentified with the Common Stingray (Bradai et al. 2012, Last et al. 2016, Serena et al. 2020). It is reportedly recorded as abundant in Tunisian waters in the Bahiret El Biban, the Lagoon of Bizerte, and the Gulf of Gabes (El Kamel et al. 2009, Bradai et al. 2012). In the Lagoon of Bizerte, 12 individuals were captured during fisheries surveys between 2006 and 2007 (El Kamel et al. 2009). Off the coast of Israel, two individuals (as Blue Stingray, Dasyatis chrysonota) were the first records for the Levantine basin, although another record exists from Lebanese waters (Golani and Capapé 2004, Serena et al. 2020). Off the coast of Turkey, between 2009 and 2010, 21 individuals were captured in 116 hauls by commercial demersal trawl in the Gulf of Antalya; and two individuals were captured in 2013, and 143 individuals between 2014 and 2015 in commercial trawl operations in Iskenderun Bay (Erguden et al. 2014, Özgür Özbek et al. 2015, Yeldan and Gundogdu 2018). In Greece, one specimen was recently recorded during a survey in 2019 by trammel net targeting cuttlefish in the central Aegean Sea (Maliakos Gulf) (Chatzispyrou et al. 2020).

Second, both catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria, and Ghana, and consequently population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but this does indicate rising fishing pressure. There are no other estimates of population reduction available from this region. The greatest fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries in the whole of Africa were the West African countries of Nigeria (13,238 t), Senegal (10,757 t), and Ghana (1,902 t) (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Nevertheless, given the lack of reporting in artisanal fisheries and the large number of nations fishing in African waters, actual landings are likely to be much higher. 

Overall, across the West Africa region, the average elasmobranch catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) has decreased by 71% over 1970–2015. The average elasmobranch CPUE in the region was 0.68 t/kW in 1970 and declined to 0.20 t/kW by 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch catch has increased by more than 2.5 times (250%) from 1970 to 2015. The average elasmobranch catch in the region was 3,312 t in 1970 and increased to 8,329 t in 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). This implies a dramatic increase in fishing effort as the elasmobranch catch volume has increased but the CPUE has decreased. Within countries, catches have historically increased but have peaked and begun to decline in recent years. More specifically, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates showed a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline, over 15 years from 2001 to 2016. Catches gradually rose from 3,644 t in 1950 to 20,180 t in 1972 then declined to 4,211 t in 1981 (80% decline), then rose steeply to a peak of 23,194 t in 2001 followed by a fluctuating decline to 4,734 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Cameroon, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1960s but showed a 96% decline over the years 2007–2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 391 t in 1950 to 2,881 t in 1974 then showed a decline to 712 t in 1986 (75% decline). Elasmobranch catch then rose to a peak of 7,516 t in 2007 followed by a steep decline to 303 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Nigeria, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1970s but showed a 19% decline over the years 2010–2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 2,419 t in 1950 to 25,144 t in 1980 then rose to a peak of 31,273 t in 2010 followed by a fluctuating decline to 25,396 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be used to infer reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has remained stable during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). This steep increase in landings coincides with a steep rise in fishing effort and an overall 44% reduction in elasmobranch CPUE from 0.107 t/kW in 1981–1983 to 0.060 t/kW in 2013–2015.

Third, contemporary patterns of landings indicate that the Marbled Stingray is still landed across most of the portion of its range across the Eastern Central Atlantic region. This species was in the five dominant species recorded during fish landing site surveys in the Parc National du Banc d'Arguin between 1998 and 2002 (Valadou et al. 2006). It was still regularly reported in regular monitoring of fisheries landings between 2006–2018 undertaken by the Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches (IMROP) in the Parc National du Banc d'Arguin (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). It was also one of the most common shark and ray species recorded in experimental trawl fishing surveys between 2000–2006 in the Parc, with a 17% frequency of occurrence (Y. El Vally, M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). During extensive landing site surveys across the Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission region between 2004 and 2011, this species was only recorded in Guinea (Diop and Dossa 2011). It was also recorded in trawl surveys undertaken in Guinea from 1985 to 2012 (Camara et al. 2016). In the Gambia, only two individuals was recorded during landing site surveys conducted annually between 2010 and 2018 although other species of rays with similar catchability were reported in large quantities (Moore et al. 2019). In surveys across the Bijagos Archipelago in Guinea-Bissau undertaken in 2019, this species was not detected, although it is listed on the national fish species list (G.H.L. Leurs unpubl. data 2020). It was also recorded frequently in 2019 in Côte d'Ivoire during landing site surveys (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). It has been reported from Nigerian research surveys, however catch quantities are not available (A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). It was also listed in cruise reports from the "Dr. Fridtjof Nansen" surveys and represented up to 2.2% of catches with up to 11 individuals in one trawl haul in the Gulf of Guinea (Krakstad et al. 2008). Landing sites surveys in Western Ghana in 2019–2020 indicate that this species represented 11% of ray landings with 68 individuals recorded, mostly captured using demersal set gillnets (I. Seidu unpubl. data 2020). In Cameroon, three individuals have been recorded over two years of landing site surveys representing 0.13% of all shark and ray records (A. Tamo unpubl. data 2020). In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, this species is still captured regularly but not in large quantities (one per set) and it is still also recorded in artisanal fisheries landings operating in Mayumba using demersal-set gillnets although in small numbers (G. De Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). In the Republic of the Congo, 23 individuals were recorded during landing site surveys in January–December 2019, with most records limited to spring and summer (April to September) (P. Doherty unpubl. data 2020).

Overall, in the Mediterranean Sea, this species is considered rare with records limited to Tunisia, Israel, Lebanon, Cyprus, Turkey, and Greece and little data are available to determine catch levels or trends. Elsewhere, there are no species-specific time series, although it is still reported in landings. Despite this abundance, there is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across most of the range of this species which are a cause for concern. Overall, considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its lack of refuge at depth, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Marbled Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (32 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation.
range: The Marbled Stingray is found in the Mediterranean Sea (but absent from the Black Sea) and Eastern Central Atlantic from the Levantine Basin and North African coast to the Republic of the Congo (Last et al. 2016b, Chatzispyrou et al. 2020, Serena et al. 2020). It has not been recorded from the Cape Verde Archipelago or São Tomé and Príncipe (Wirtz et al. 2007, Wirtz et al. 2013). In the Mediterranean Sea, the species might be more widespread and has been subject to frequent misidentifications with the Common Stingray (Dasyatis pastinaca) (Last et al. 2016b, Serena et al. 2020).
useTrade: The Marbled Stingray is utilized for its meat. While little-species specific information is available, the meat of rays is consumed fresh across many coastal communities in the region as an important source of protein (Walker et al. 2005). It is also salted-dried or dried and smoked and exported across West Africa to supply countries such as Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria, Mali, and Burkina Faso.
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across the region have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the Marbled Stingray are generally unmanaged throughout large parts of the species’ range, and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future. 

In West Africa, a number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing one (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Whilst Gabon have recently expanded marine protected area coverage to 26% of their Exclusive Economic Zone, other countries such as the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are still in the process of expanding their marine protected area networks, however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The California Butterfly Ray (Gymnura marmorata) is a medium-sized (to 125 cm total length) benthic ray that inhabits sandy, silty, and muddy bays, channels, and estuaries to a depth of 95 m in the Eastern Central Pacific from Point Conception, California to Mazatlan, Mexico including the Gulf of California. It is captured in artisanal gillnets, beach seines, and longlines, and in industrial demersal trawl fisheries that target shrimp and hake. Gillnetting and trawling pressure is intense in the Gulf of California, off southwest Baja California, and off Mazatlan, and species declines and management issues have been highlighted in these fisheries. Landings of Gymnura species (G. crebripunctata and G. marmorata) in the Gulf of California have generally been stable between 1997 and 2014, although effort has been steadily increasing. There may be some refuge from fishing off the Pacific coast in southern California where there are no major threats. This ray may also have life history traits that make it productive enough to withstand some fishing. Overall, given the level of exploitation occurring across much of its range balanced with some refuge and stable landings in the Gulf of California (although with increasing pressure), it is suspected that the California Butterfly Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (45 years) based on levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The California Butterfly Ray is a coastal benthic ray that inhabits sandy, silty, and muddy bays, channels, and estuaries to a depth of 95 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 125 cm disc width (DW); females mature at 62 cm DW and males at 41 cm DW (Davila-Ortiz 2002). Females aggregate inshore to pup, mainly from May to September, to produce litters of 4–16 pups that are 21–26 cm DW (Villavicencio-Garayzar 1993, Davila-Ortiz 2002, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is matrotrophic viviparous, and generation length is suspected to be similar to that of the Diamond Ray (Gymnura natalensis) at 15 years (Wintner 2006).
threats: The California Butterfly Ray is captured in artisanal gillnets, beach seines, and longlines, and in industrial demersal trawl fisheries that target shrimp and hake. Gillnetting in the Gulf of California has caused substantial declines in several species such as pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004), and this species makes up a large component of the catch in these fisheries (Bizzarro 2005, Bizzarro et al. 2007). There is a hake trawl fishery operating in the northeastern Gulf of California. Shrimp trawling is prevalent in Mexico off the southwest coast of Baja California Sur and south of the Gulf, and management issues such as overcapacity and declining catches have been cited in some of these fisheries (Foster and Vincent 2010). Although all of this species' range is subject to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure, it is still relatively commonly encountered and may be productive enough to withstand some fishing pressure. There is some refuge from fishing in the northern portion of its Pacific range (the United States) where there are no major threats.
population: In the artisanal gillnet fishery on the Pacific Coast of Baja California Sur, catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) between 2000 and 2010 was 0.59 rays per vessel per fishing trip (Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2013). In the Almejas Bay artisanal gillnet fishery, this species was the fourth most important ray landed with 2–13 individuals caught per boat per day depending on the season (Bizzarro 2005). Landings of Gymnura species (G. crebripunctata and G. marmorata) in the Gulf of California steadily decreased from ~ 500 t in 1997 to ~250 t in 2006, but then steadily increased back to ~500 t in 2014, indicating an overall stable trend (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016) although effort has been steadily increasing. Gillnetting in the Gulf of California has caused substantial declines in several species such as pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004), and this species makes up a large component of the catch in Gulf of California fisheries (Bizzarro 2005, Bizzarro et al. 2007). It is the third most captured ray in the Gulf of California (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016). Given the level of fishing pressure in the Gulf of California and on the Pacific Coast of the Baja peninsula, balanced with some refuge in southern California, it is suspected that this ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (45 years).
range: The California Butterfly Ray occurs in the Eastern Central Pacific from Point Conception, California to Mazatlan, Mexico, including the Gulf of California (Smith et al. 2009, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Flesh of the California Butterfly Ray is typically consumed fresh or dried and sold locally for human consumption in Mexico. It is also caught occasionally by commercial and recreational fishers in southern California, but is of no commercial importance in this region. There is no national or international trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this ray.  In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing   from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O.   Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). Management measures are needed to ensure this species does not become threatened in the near future. Further research is needed on life history and population size and trends. Species-specific monitoring is needed in artisanal gillnet and industrial trawl fisheries.

rationale: The Mazatlan Butterfly Ray (Gymnura crebripunctata) is a medium-sized (to at least 81 cm disc width) benthic ray that occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from the Gulf of California to Peru. It inhabits sandy and muddy substrates and estuaries on the continental shelf to a depth of 30 m. This ray is captured in artisanal gillnets, beach seines, and longlines, and in industrial demersal trawl fisheries that target shrimp and hake. Artisanal fishing pressure is intense throughout most of its range, and there are trawl fisheries operating in the Gulf of California and off Pacific Mexico, in Costa Rica, and in Colombia. Landings of Gymnura species (G. crebripunctata and G. marmorata) in the Gulf of California have generally been stable between 1997 and 2014, although effort has been steadily increasing. There are no data on population trends further south, but intense fishing pressure and a lack of management are suspected to be leading to reductions, although this species is still relatively common in landings, and may have life history traits that make it productive enough to withstand some fishing. Overall, given the intensity of fishing pressure across its range and the stability in Mexican landings (although with increasing pressure), it is suspected that the Mazatlan Butterfly Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (45 years) based on levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Mazatlan Butterfly Ray is a benthic coastal ray that inhabits sandy and muddy substrates and estuaries over the continental shelf to a depth of 30 m (Last et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 81 cm disc width (DW); female maturity is unknown and males mature at about 30 cm DW (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is matrotrophic viviparous, and generation length is suspected to be similar to that of the Diamond Ray (Gymnura natalensis) at 15 years (Wintner 2006).
threats: The Mazatlan Butterfly Ray is captured in artisanal gillnets, beach seines, and longlines, and in industrial demersal trawl fisheries that target shrimp and hake. Gillnetting in the Gulf of California has caused substantial declines in several species such as pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004), and this species makes up a large component of the catch in these fisheries (Bizzarro 2005, Bizzarro et al. 2007). There is a hake trawl fishery operating in the northeastern Gulf of California. Shrimp trawling is prevalent in Mexico off the southwest coast of Baja California Sur and south of the Gulf, and management issues such as overcapacity and declining catches have been cited in some of these fisheries (Foster and Vincent 2010). Whether retained or discarded, mortality is considered to be high in these fisheries, especially in the shrimp trawl fishery (Márquez-Farías 2002). Intense and inadequately managed artisanal fishing occurs in the southern portion of its range. In Costa Rica and Colombia, shrimp trawl fisheries have declined to the point of being unprofitable, indicating overfishing. Although there is intense fishing pressure across its range, this species is still relatively common in landings, and may have life history traits that make it productive enough to withstand some fishing.
population: Landings of Gymnura species (G. crebripunctata and G. marmorata) in the Gulf of California steadily decreased from ~ 500 t in 1997 to ~250 t in 2006, but then steadily increased back to ~500 t in 2014, indicating an overall stable trend (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016) although effort has been steadily increasing. Gillnetting in the Gulf of California has caused substantial declines in several species such as pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004), and this species makes up a large component of the catch in Gulf of California fisheries (Bizzarro 2005, Bizzarro et al. 2007). Fishers in La Paz Bay, Baja California Sur, Mexico, report that prior to 2005 this species was relatively common, but that it has since declined. In landing surveys from 2013 to 2017, only 10–15 specimens were recorded (I. Burgos-Vazquez unpubl. data 2019). Information about population trends further south in their range is not available, but fisheries are intense and unmanaged. Overall, given the intensity of fishing pressure across its range and the stability in Mexican landings (although with increasing pressure), it is suspected that the Mazatlan Butterfly Ray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (45 years).
range: The Mazatlan Butterfly Ray occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from the Gulf of California, Mexico to Peru (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Flesh from the Mazatlan Butterfly Ray is typically dried and sold locally for human consumption in the Gulf of California. Use and trade elsewhere is unknown, but the meat is likely utilized in artisanal fisheries throughout its range.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in  place for this ray.  In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing   from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O.   Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Additionally, targeted industrial fishing of sharks and rays is prohibited in Colombia, with set bycatch limits (up to 35% of bycatch in the national territory; Resolution 1743 of 2017); however, surveillance and compliance requires strengthening.Management measures are needed in order to ensure this species does not become threatened in the near future. Further research is needed on life history and population size and trends. Species-specific monitoring is needed in  artisanal gillnet and industrial trawl fisheries.

rationale: Limia caymanensis is restricted to coastal habitat on Grand Cayman Island. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 249-370 km2. The number of threat based locations where this species occurs cannot be estimated with accuracy, given uncertainty regarding the scope and magnitude of habitat loss. However, mangrove forest losses on Grand Cayman are severe, with an estimated loss of 27.9% cover from 1965-2013, and continued losses associated with development of tourism and residential infrastructure are anticipated. As such, L. caymanensis is assessed as Near Threatened under criterion B1b(iii). Additional research regarding population size, population trend, and the direct impact of regionally pervasive threats is urgently needed to clarify the conservation status of this species.
habitat: This species occurs in brackish water, coastal mangrove lagoons, and freshwater limestone depressions on Grand Cayman Island (Lee et al. 1983). This species is syntopic with Gambusia caymanensis throughout its range (Rivas and Fink 1970). It is a midwater swimmer and diet is comprised of mud and detritus (Rivas and Fink 1970). Maximum reported body size is 3.2 cm and 2.8 cm standard length (SL) for females and males, respectively (Lee et al. 1983).
threats:
The primary threat to this species is mangrove forest destruction and conversion associated with coastal development (Bradley et al. 2006, Echternacht et al. 2011, Jurn et al. 2018), and potential future losses resulting from severe weather events (Abney et al. 2005). The human population on Grand Cayman has increased substantially in recent years (Echternacht et al. 2011). Additionally, the need for infrastructure to support a burgeoning tourism industry has resulted in the destruction of coastal habitat throughout Grand Cayman (Echternacht et al. 2011). Mangrove forest loss on Grand Cayman between 1965-2013 is estimated at 27.9%, and future projections suggest that mangrove habitat outside of protected areas could be lost by 2108 (Jurn et al. 2018). Losses have been especially severe around the western and southern sides of North Sound (Jurn et al. 2018). Land-use change has considerably increased the turbidity of coastal environments (Giglioli 1996).

Habitat degradation and loss associated with rising sea level and increased incidences of severe storms are anticipated future threats to L. caymanensis and other species that utilize lowland coastal habitat (Echternacht et al. 2011).
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. This species is known from a fairly large number of specimens, suggesting that it is relatively common throughout its range (Rivas and Fink 1970).
range:
Limia caymanensis is endemic to Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands (Rauchenberger 1988, Lucinda 2003). It has been collected at several localities on Grand Cayman, including Doctor’s Cave Pond, Fish Pond, Meager Bay Pond, Sea Pond, Least Grebe Pond, Pease Bay Pond, small brackish water holes near Town Hall (West Bay), in freshwater depressions northwest of Northside Village, and in marl pits at Georgetown Airport (Rivas and Fink 1970, Abney and Rakocinski 2004). Additional records of Limia have been reported from Malportas Pond, Betty Bay Pond, Collier's Pond, and Governor's Pond (C. Rakocinski pers. comm. 2020). The type locality of this species is a coastal lagoon 3.2 km west of Old Man Bay (Lee et al. 1983). This species has not been reported from Little Cayman or Cayman Brac, despite extensive sampling on these islands (Rivas and Fink 1970).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 249-370 km2, with a lower estimate based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around all georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020), and an upper estimate based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around the entire land mass of Grand Cayman Island. The primary threat to this species is habitat loss associated with land-use change and coastal development (Bradley et al. 2006, Echternacht et al. 2011, Jurn et al. 2018). However, the scope, magnitude, and direct impacts of this threat on L. caymanensis have not been evaluated in detail, and therefore the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs cannot be determined with accuracy. Furthermore, the range of this species probably includes a number of protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), which may exclude these localities from future coastal development.
useTrade: This species is maintained in captive stocks at the University of Colorado (Rodriguez-Silva and Weaver 2020).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards L. caymanensis. The range of this species probably extends into coastal protected areas throughout Grand Cayman (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), which may provide indirect protection against habitat loss and degradation. Additional research regarding population size, population trend, and the direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the extinction risk of this species.

rationale: Sciaena umbra is found in the eastern Atlantic from the English Channel to Mauritania, including the Canary Islands, occasionally in Senegal. This is an iconic species that is captured by both commercial and recreational fishing throughout its range and has experienced dramatic population declines as a result. The species is also impacted by the loss of important nursery estuarine habitat, as well as disturbance from divers and spear fisherman in some parts of its range. It was regionally assessed as Vulnerable for the Mediterranean in 2007. This species has been shown to benefit from in-place conservation actions including no-take zones and marine protected areas. It has experienced dramatic declines in the past. FAO catch statistics indicated an increase in landings from a peak of 735 t in 1988, followed by steady fluctuating declines to 161 t in 2005, with an average of 148 t in the period 2001 to 2005 in the Mediterranean. This indicated an approximate 70% decline in landings over 25 years (~1.5 generation lengths) from 1980-2005 for part of its range with an overall inferred decline between 30-50% for the Mediterranean. This indicated an approximate 70% decline in landings over 25 years (~1.5 generation lengths) from 1980-2005 for part of its range with an overall inferred decline between 30-50% for the Mediterranean. More recent catch statistics fluctuated over the past two decades but show an overall increasing trend, suggesting that the species has undergone some degree of recovery since it was assessed at the regional scale in 2007. However, landing data has to be treated with caution as no fishery effort data are available. Population increases are inferred from the FAO landings data but require confirmation, and are likely to be conservation dependent as significant declines could result from removal of any conservation actions or management protection. Therefore this species is listed as Near Threatened and conservation dependent. Ongoing monitoring of population trends is recommended.
habitat:
This is a demersal species that occurs in shallow coastal waters mainly on rocky and adjacent sandy substrata to 200 m deep. Younger individuals often enter estuaries and become more active at night. It is generally a nocturnal fish but it can sometimes be encountered during the day among seagrass beds, on rocky bottoms close to caves or large crevices in which it can shelter. It lives in small groups and is a sedentary species with strong site-fidelity and low mobility (Alós and Cabanellas-Reboredo 2012). It feeds on small fishes and crustaceans (Chao 1986). Spawning occurs near estuaries and the reproductive period for this species is May-July. The maximum size for this species is 75 cm (Dieuzeide et al. 1955) but more recently individuals that exceed 60 cm are very rare (Harmelin-Vivien et al. 2015). 

This species can live to 31 years of age (Morat et al. 2017) and age at maturity is 3-4 years for males and females (Fiorentino et al. 2001, Ragonese et al. 2002, Grau et al. 2009). Size at first maturity is ~25 cm total length for males and ~30 cm for females (Grau et al. 2009). 

Generation length for this species is about 17 years. This was calculated using the following equation: Age at first maturity + (maximum age - age at first maturity)/2
threats: Over-exploitation by fisheries is a major threat to this species. It is heavily exposed to fisheries during spawning aggregations at the mouth of estuaries. As well as direct fishery exploitation, the species may also be disturbed by divers and spear fishermen, forcing the animals to be less concentrated and much more dispersed in small coastal caves and below rocks (A. Di Natale pers. comm. 2007). In addition to fishing pressure at its spawning grounds, degradation of estuaries from coastal development threatens the nursery grounds of this species. The subpopulation on the east side of the Marmara Sea was reduced due to pollution (Artüz 2006).
population: Population data are not available from across most of this species' range, with most detailed information available for the Mediterranean Sea. It is present but uncommon to rare in the eastern Atlantic. This species is naturally more abundant in the north-western Mediterranean and less abundant on the southern coasts. On the northern coasts, this species has been greatly reduced due to habitat degradation and fishing pressure (Harmelin 1991, Chater et al. 2018). This species is slightly overexploited in the Gulf of Tunis (Chater et al. 2018). It has experienced dramatic declines in the past. FAO catch statistics indicated an increase in landings from a peak of 735 t in 1988, followed by steady fluctuating declines to 161 t in 2005, with an average of 148 t in the period 2001 to 2005 in the Mediterranean. This indicated an approximate 70% decline in landings over 25 years from 1980-2005 for part of its range with an overall inferred decline between 30-50% for the Mediterranean. More recently, FAO catch statistics from 10 countries across its range show fluctuating landings but the overall trend shows a gradual increase in landings since the early 2000s (FishStat 2019).
range: Sciaena umbra is found in the eastern Atlantic from the English Channel to Mauritania, including the Canary Islands and throughout the Mediterranean Sea in all coastal areas and is also present in the Black Sea and the Sea of Azov. It occurs occasionally to Senegal, and questionably as far south as Ghana or Gabon. The depth range is 5-200 m.
useTrade:
This species is caught by artisanal and sport fisheries throughout its range. It is an iconic species and is targeted by small-scale professional and recreational fisheries, particularly spearfishing (Morales-Nin et al. 2005, Lloret et al. 2008, Font et al. 2012). it is an esteemed food fish and a candidate for aquaculture development in Mediterranean Sea. This species is often found in the community tank of public aquariums in Europe (L.N. Chao pers. obs. 2005). This species is currently being researched for potential use in aquaculture (Chatzifotis et al. 2006, Triantaphyllidis 2012). In Turkey, otoliths are ground to a powder and used as remedy for urinary tract infections (Frimodt 1995).

The fish is heavily targeted in its north African range where it is over-exploited by artisanal, semi-industrial and recreational fishing, and the fish is highly susceptible to spear fishing as it is slow moving and accessible (Grau et al. 2009).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention and on Annex III of the Barcelona Convention. The Bern Convention Appendix III requires Parties to protect listed species, but a certain amount of exploitation is permitted if population levels allow. The Annex III listing on the Barcelona Convention also requires the exploitation of these species to be regulated (Abdul Malak et al. 2011). This species has responded well to protection including marine protected areas (MPAs) and no-take zones in the region (Di Franco et al. 2009, Forcada et al. 2009). In a study conducted off Corsica, numerical abundance, biomass, and individual size were found to increase with increasing levels of protection and were significantly lower in areas without protection. This highlights the benefit provided by these protected areas as well as the susceptibility of the species to fishing activities (Harmelin-Vivien et al. 2015). 

There was a moratorium on spear fishing in Corsica for this species. Since 2004, Montenegro included the species in the prohibited list for juvenile fishes, the limits was 30 cm total length (MAFWM 2004).

The species was assessed as Vulnerable for the Mediterranean regional assessment in 2007 (Biszel et al. 2011).

rationale: This species is found in the East Atlantic from Guinea to Angola. It is the second most common sciaenid in most of this region. It represents 20% of surveyed sciaenid biomass based on trawl surveys from the RV Fridjoft Nansen. These surveys from 1999-2006 have reported a 37% decline in mixed sciaenid biomass. Since the 1990s, fishing effort, including the switch to large pair-trawling fleets with increasing trawling range in most of the surveyed region, has substantially increased due to previous declines in catch. Given that this species is found primarily from 80 m to 160 m (although can be found to as deep as 350 m), which is mostly below the average trawling depth of 25 to 75 m, it is estimated that there has been less than 30% decline over the past 10 years (since 1999). Given that fishing effort is increasing and this species is heavily targeted in at least two countries within its range, it is listed as Near Threatened based on A2bd.
habitat: This species spawns often spawns in estuaries (F. Nunoo pers. comm.).  It is found in muddy, sandy and rocky substrates in deeper shelves from 50 m to 350 m, but is most common between 80 m and 160 m. It feeds on worms, fish and small invertebrates, including shrimps. Age at first maturity and longevity is not-well known, but given the maximum potential size of this species, individuals to 40 cm may live less than five years (N.L. Chao pers. comm.). Generation length is therefore estimated to be approximately two to three years.
threats:
As technology and demand have increased in western Africa, the fishing mechanisms have evolved from dugout canoes, to motor boats and large trawling ships. Nigeria, Senegal, Ghana and Cameroon have the largest fleets in the West African region. In Ghana the sciaenids are exploited by the artisanal, semi-industrial and industrial fishing sub-sectors. According to a 2006 survey, there are about 11,213 canoes in the artisanal sector, 230 locally built wooden hulled vessels (using trawls and purse seines) in the semi-industrial sector and 100 industrial vessels out of which 64 are trawlers.

The trawlers fish very close to shore (less than 30 m depth) in competition with the artisanal fishers, using huge trawl boards and metal bobbins. However, due to the nature of the continental shelf and the poor state of most of the vessels, they rarely exceed 100 m from shore at depths not exceeding 75 m. The resulting habitat degradation, over-harvesting from bad fishing practices such as fishing with light; as well as use of small meshed sized nets and excessive demand (all sizes of fish finds market in West Africa), contribute to the observed over-exploitation of fish resources.

Demersal species in the region are noted to be over-exploited mainly from high fishing effort and export demand. Landings have probably decreased due to a shift in dominance of gears from gill net / beach seine to trawling / pair trawling, as well as an increase in number of boats/permits.

The most common of the sciaenids on the market in the region are P. senegalensis, P. mbizi, P. typus, P. elongatus and P. senegallus, in that respective decreasing order; with the rest forming a total of less than 10% by weight in landings. The flesh of the sciaenids is popular to consumers, especially in the hospitality industry. The large sized sciaenids are exported for foreign exchange. As a result of this demand, prices of croakers on the market are relatively high, falling behind that of highly prized species like the groupers, snappers, seabreams and cephalopods.
population: This species is the second most common Sciaenidae species observed (estimated to form about 20% of catch by weight as surveyed by the RF Fridjoft Nansen) in Western Africa (F. Nunoo pers. comm.). This species is more common in Nigeria and Cameroon, where it is heavily targeted and therefore is more commonly seen in markets in these two countries than P. senegalensis. In Angola, this species represents 4% of all sciaenids in trawl surveys reported from 2004. Records from RV Fridjoft Nansen stock assessment survey for all sciaenids in the Guinea Current Large Marine Ecosystem (GCLME) from 2000 to 2006 show a reduction in biomass from 1,046 t to 664 t (a 37% reduction in biomass). The CPUE is variable during this same time with a peak of 4.4 and a low of 1.7. As effort is expected to increase, biomass is projected to decline further. Landings have likely decreased due to change in gears from gill net to trawling, as well as an increase in number of boats/permits. Croakers are important food fish for Nigeria as they constitute about 40% of the total landings on the Nigerian coast (Gaffer 1994).
range: This species is found from Guinea to southern Angola, but is especially abundant in Nigerian and Cameroonian waters. The depth range is 50-350 m (Chao 2016).
useTrade: This is an important commercial species and is consumed as food.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measure in place.  It is important to research towards establishing marine protected areas (MPA) in the GCLME. General conservation regulations for demersal and pelagic fishes not well enforced in the region. This species needs further studies on biology and ecology to aid in conservation decisions.

rationale:
This species is currently known from the lower reaches and coastal waters of the northwestern Black Sea, with a relatively restricted range (extent of occurrence estimated to be about 25,000 km²). It is likely to be impacted by increasing levels of salinity as the water flow in the major rivers continues to be reduced, changing the salinity of the coastal waters and lagoons where the species breeds. The species is therefore assessed as Near Threatened as it is believed it may be close to meeting A3 (30% decline in the next three generations or 10 years).

For the European Union 27 region, this species is assessed as Endangered (EN B1ab(iii)). Within the European Union the species has a restricted range, being found only in the lower reaches and coastal waters of the Danube in Romania. Its extent of occurrence in this region is less than 5,000 km² and it is threatened by increasing levels of salinity which is impacting the species breeding areas (see above).
habitat: This fish occurs in fresh and brackish waters with salinity up to 7%. It is abundant at depths around 5 m over black mud.
threats: The species may become threatened by increasing salinity due to reduced flow in all  the large rivers within the species range which are now dammed.
population: The species is more or less abundant in the lower reaches of rivers and coastal lagoons.
range: This species occurs in the northwestern Black Sea basin in the estuaries and coastal lakes, and the rivers Danube, Dniestr, South Bug and Dniepr and their lower reaches.
conservationActions: No information available.

rationale: The Bristly Catshark (Bythaelurus hispidus) is a small (to 37 cm TL) benthic deep-water shark found on the upper continental slope at depths of 200–800 m. It has a patchy distribution in the Western and Eastern Indian Ocean, from off Kenya, Socotra Island (Yemen), Oman, southern India, the Andaman Islands, and Myanmar. This small shark is viviparous with a low fecundity of two young per litter, suggesting it has low biological productivity. It is a relatively rare bycatch in the deep-water shrimp trawl fishery off southwest India, and there are concerns that the regional population may have been impacted by this intense fishery, though this species may have some refuge in depths outside of the current operations of the trawl fishery (200–500 m). The Bristly Catshark is also likely caught in the Sri Lankan deep-water handline fishery and the new and growing deep-water shark fishery in the Andaman Islands. Given the low productivity of the species and the overlap with fishing pressure across large parts of its range, together with potential refuge in deeper waters, it is suspected that a population reduction approaching 30% has occurred over the past three generations (30 years); therefore, the Bristly Catshark is assessed as Near Threatened, nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d. This species may meet thresholds for being threatened in the near future.
habitat: The Bristly Catshark is a small species found on the upper continental slope at depths of 200–800 m (Weigmann et al. 2018). The maximum size is 37 cm total length (TL) with size-at-maturity reported at 24–26 cm TL for females and 21–28 cm TL for males (Akhilesh et al. 2013, Weigmann et al. 2018). The species is lecithotrophic viviparous, with embryos developing in thin membranous egg cases in utero and pregnant females having one embryo per uterus (Akhilesh et al. 2013). Size-at-birth is ~12–13 cm TL. Catsharks are difficult to age and the most reliable age estimates to date are from the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) that has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and maximum age of 21 years, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011). The Blacktip Sawtail Catshark is larger than the Bristly Catshark (48 cm vs 37 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 10 years for the Bristly Catshark.
threats: The main threat to this species is the commercial deep-water shrimp trawl fishery operating in the Arabian Sea off southwest India in which the Bristly Catshark is a relatively rare component of the chondrichthyan bycatch (Akhilesh et al. 2011, 2013). That fishery developed in 1999 and expanded rapidly with trawler numbers peaking soon thereafter in 2000–2001 before dropping significantly, although there are still some 300–400 boats operating in the fishery (Fernandez et al. 2015). The fishery is intense and operates on the Quilon Bank and Wedge Bank areas off southwest India at depths of 200–500 m. Targeted shark fisheries are beginning to appear in the Andaman Islands, where commercial and artisanal longlines fish for Centrophorus species. Deep-water trawl fisheries for slipper lobsters (Scyllaridae) are also active in the area. The depths at which these fisheries operate are unknown but are suspected to be 200–400 m (S. Advani, pers. comm., 13 January 2019). Fisheries in Kenya are thus far not interacting with the Bristly Catshark, but the situation there should be monitored. Any expansion of Kenyan fisheries into deeper waters would likely affect the population. Steep population reductions have been observed in deep-water shark fisheries where data are available (e.g. Graham et al. 2001).
population: Currently there is no information on the population size or structure of the Bristly Catshark. Formerly this species was common; for example, Nair and Lal Mohan (1973) reported 130 specimens in a single haul in the Gulf of Mannar, whereas Akhilesh et al. (2013) reported this species as a relatively rare component of the southwest Indian deep-water shrimp trawl fishery in 2010 and 2011. It is exposed to unmanaged fisheries in other parts of its range, including the Gulf of Aden and the Andaman Islands. Overall, given existing fishing pressure over part of its range, combined with some likely refuge areas in deeper waters, it is suspected that this species has undergone a population reduction of at least 20–29% over the past three generations (30 years).
range: The Bristly Catshark has a patchy distribution in the Indian Ocean, where it is known from Kenya, Socotra Island (Yemen), Oman, southern India, the Andaman Islands, and Myanmar (Weigmann et al. 2016, 2018).
useTrade: No utilization or commercial trade of this species is currently known to exist.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place. India has a seasonal trawl ban in June and July (45 days) that might benefit the species. Research is needed to determine distribution, population size, life history, and trends in abundance. More data are needed regarding the degree to which fisheries interact with this species

rationale: The Arabian Smoothhound (Mustelus mosis) is a small (to 150 cm total length) houndshark that occurs in the Western Indian Ocean from KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa to Tanzania, and from the Red Sea to India and Sri Lanka at depths of 20–250 m. This species is captured in multiple gears (bottom trawls, gillnets, and line gear) and is retained for human consumption in most of its range. Inshore fishing pressure is generally intense within its range, although no data are currently available on population trends. It remains one of the dominant species in landings in parts of the northern Indian Ocean. Although it is likely to be a relatively productive species, it is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (33 years) based on levels of exploitation in largely unmanaged fisheries. Therefore, the Arabian Smoothhound is assessed as Near Threatened, nearly meeting the threshold for threatened under A2d. Further research and catch monitoring are needed to ensure this species does not become threatened in the near future.
habitat: The Arabian Smoothhound is a benthic shark found inshore and offshore at depths of 20–250 m, sometimes in association with coral reefs (Ebert et al. 2013). The species is reported to reach a maximum size of 150 cm total length (TL) but is rarely seen above 100 cm TL (Jabado et al. 2016, Moore et al. 2016). Males mature at 65–78 cm TL and females mature from ~73 cm TL. Reproduction is viviparous, and the species gives birth to 2–16 pups per litter (Moore et al. 2016). Size-at-birth is reported as 26–28 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). No age or growth data are available for this species, but generation length can be estimated as 11 years based on the Dusky Smoothhound (Mustelus canis) from the Western Atlantic which has a similar latitudinal distribution and maximum size (Conrath et al. 2002).
threats: The Arabian Smoothhound is caught in bottom trawls, fixed bottom and floating gillnets, and line gear throughout its range (Jabado et al. 2015, Moore et al. 2016).
population:
There have been no dedicated surveys, nor are there population size or trend estimates for this species. The Arabian Smoothhound is patchily distributed, but often is captured in large numbers when encountered. Few data are available to determine changes in abundance over time. 

This species is a rare catch in the KwaZulu-Natal shark control nets, and it is caught in Mozambique (S. Fernando, unpubl. data, 2018) and Zanzibar (R. Bennett, unpubl. data, 2018). It was reported from the Gulf of Suez and Hurghada (Egypt) during landing site surveys in 1999 and 2001, representing 5% of shark landings by number (Bonfil 2003) but it was not recorded in more recent landing site surveys from the Saudi Red Sea coast (Spaet and Berumen 2015). In Yemen (Gulf of Aden), they make up 22.4% of shark landings by number (Shaher 2007) but surveys in the Gulf of Aden in the winter months of 2013 and 2014 recorded only a few specimens (I. Elhassan, unpubl. data, 2017). This may suggest a decline in abundance, but may also reflect seasonal changes in abundance related to reproductive migrations as suggested by Shaher (2007). Further surveys will be required to resolve this question. 

Few catches are reported from Oman (Henderson et al. 2007) and this species represented <1% of sharks traded by number in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) that originated in Oman (Jabado et al. 2015b). In the UAE, it is the sixth most commonly observed shark in market surveys, representing 1.6% of shark landings by number (Jabado et al. 2015a). This species represented less than 2% of elasmobranch landings by number in Kuwait (Moore et al. 2012) but was the second most common shark recorded in Bahrain representing 12.5% of elasmobranch landings by number (Moore and Peirce 2013). Previous surveys around Bahrain recorded it as common (Herdson 1981), suggesting it remains an important species in the region. This species is rarely caught as incidental take in trawl fisheries in India and Pakistan and is not caught in fisheries in Iran (Arabian/Persian Gulf). In India, it represented less than 1 t of trawl catches off the southwest coast between 2003 and 2004 (Raje et al. 2007). In recent landing site surveys on the coast of Gujarat and Maharashtra, this species was also uncommonly recorded in landings (R.W. Jabado, unpubl. data, 2017). 

Overall, although this species is moderately productive, a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (30 years) is suspected based on levels of exploitation.
range: The Arabian Smoothhound is widespread in the Indian Ocean, from KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa to Tanzania, and from the Red Sea to India and Sri Lanka (Ebert et al. 2013, R. Bennett, unpubl. data, 2018).
useTrade: The meat of this species is often sold fresh for human consumption at local markets. Fins are not considered valuable due to their small size but are still traded internationally (Jabado et al. 2015b). In India, offal is sometimes processed into fishmeal.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place. Some countries across its range have banned the targeted fishing for sharks (e.g. Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Sudan, Kuwait). There are some local and seasonal trawl bans that might benefit the species. Recreational anglers in South Africa are technically restricted to one shark per species per day (maximum of 10 individuals per day), although enforcement is an ongoing issue. Further research is needed on life history, population size and trends, and threats. Fisheries catch monitoring at the species level is needed.

rationale: Baraka's Whipray (Maculabatis ambigua) is a medium-sized (to 90 cm disc width) coastal inshore species that inhabits shallow soft sediment habitats in the Western Indian Ocean from the Red Sea to Tanzania to 60 m depth. This species is targeted and taken as incidental bycatch in inshore trawl fisheries, bottom-set gillnets, and beach seines. It is often discarded in the Red Sea and it is unlikely to be heavily exploited in Somalia, but in Kenya and Tanzania it is targeted for meat and liver oil and sometimes traded domestically. It is suspected that unmanaged bycatch and increasing target fisheries in parts of its range have led to a global population reduction of 20–29% due to actual levels of exploitation. Therefore, Baraka's Whipray is assessed as Near Threatened, nearly meeting the threshold for Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: Baraka's Whipray occupies inshore and coastal soft sediment habitats to a depth of 60 m. It attains a maximum size of at least 90 cm disc width (DW), and its size-at-birth is just less than 20 cm DW (Last et al. 2016a, 2016b). This species' generation length is estimated to be 9.5 years (A. Temple, pers. comm., 2018)
threats: Baraka's Whipray is taken as targeted and incidental catch of inshore trawl fisheries, bottom-set gillnets, hook and line fisheries, and in artisanal beach seines. In Sudan, it is seasonally captured in trawl fisheries by Egyptian vessels. In Tanzania, whiprays are also caught in inshore trawl fisheries, and are increasingly targeted in artisanal fisheries for their meat and liver oil (Matiku 2018).
population: This species was recently described in 2016, and historically may have been confused with other similar species. Hence, there is little knowledge of population size or trends in abundance. This species is still commonly landed in some parts of the Red Sea (I. Elhassan, pers. comm., 07 February 2017), suggesting no significant population decline there. Targeted and unmanaged fisheries for whiprays in Kenya, Tanzania, and Zanzibar, are however, likely to be leading to a population reduction. Surveys of fishers in Zanzibar show that most considered shark and ray  numbers in general to have decreased on their fishing grounds,  concomitant with an increase in the sale value of meat (Jiddawi  and Shehe 1999). An ecological risk assessment identified whiptail stingrays as susceptible to South West Indian Ocean small-scale fisheries and this species is the main catch in Kenyan elasmobranch fisheries (A. Temple, pers. comm., 2018). Overall, it is suspected that Baraka's Whipray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generations (30 years) due to actual levels of exploitation.
range: Baraka's Whipray occurs in the Western Indian Ocean from Zanzibar, Tanzania, to the Northern Red Sea (Last et al. 2016a, 2016b).
useTrade: Whiprays are consumed fresh locally or salted and dried and traded domestically in Tanzania (Matiku 2018). Offal is used in soups and liver oil is used on vessels for waterproofing and anti-fouling (Matiku 2018). This species is generally not utilized and is discarded in the Red Sea.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Further research on this species' distribution, ecology, and population size and trends is needed. Harvest control rules are needed where the species is exploited.

rationale: Sardinella lemuru is a marine pelagic-neritic, oceanodromous species that is relatively widely distributed throughout the eastern Indian and western Pacific oceans. This species is known to form large schools in coastal waters and can be found in sheltered bays and lagoons. This species is abundant in parts of its range (i.e., the Philippines and Indonesia) and contributes significantly to industrial and commercial sardine fisheries throughout a majority of its range. It is also an important resource for subsistence fishers. It has experienced overfishing in the past and is currently considered overfished in parts of its range (i.e., east Java, Indonesia and the Philippines). It is considered a superior fish commodity in some areas (e.g., eastern Java), and effort and value have increased in recent years. For example, an uncontrolled increase in the number of purse seine vessels in Indonesia has been attributed with the overfishing of this species in the region as this method targets a large proportion of juveniles and small individuals (~70%). Furthermore, much of this species' geographic range is within areas subjected to heavy exploitation and little regulation (i.e., the East China and Sulu-Celebes Sea); however given its wide range, we suspect that there are small areas of its range where it is not exploited. Landings reported to the FAO and reconstructed catches are available but likely under-represent true catches; however, available evidence suggests that the population is declining. Based on an exponential regression, the landings have declined by 32% over the past 10 years (thought to represent three generation lengths). Given that this species has been, and currently is being, overfished in parts of its range (i.e., increase in gear efficiency, the number of vessels and market value), but is well regulated in some areas (e.g., Zamboanga Peninsula, Philippines) and is likely not exploited in small parts of its range, it is suspected that the global population decline is at least approaching 30%, and therefore, Sardinella lemuru is assessed as Near Threatened under criterion A2bd. More research and population stock assessments are recommended to better understand the population of this species. Likewise, increased monitoring and regulation of fisheries catches is needed to prevent further population decline of this commercially important species.
habitat: Sardinella lemuru is a marine pelagic-neritic, oceanodromous species (Riede 2004) that is strongly migratory (Munroe et al. 1999). The adult species form large schools in coastal waters, and they are found in sheltered bays and lagoons (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). This species feeds on phytoplankton and zooplankton (Ghofar and Mathews 1995), but mostly copepods (Munroe et al. 1999). Individuals reach maturity between 14-15 cm (Whitehead 1985). The spawning season has been predicted to occur between September to November in the southern Bali Strait off eastern Java (Wujdi et al. 2013); juveniles and small individuals dominate catches between February and March (Simbolon et al. 2017). In the East China Sea, spawning peaks in late March through May, but continues through August (Munroe et al. 1999). Spawning off Western Australia takes place from December to March, with a peak in January to February (Gaughan and Mitchell 2000). Spawning and major migrations appear closely linked with hydrological conditions, especially temperature (Munroe et al. 1999) and chlorophyll-a concentrations (Simbolon et al. 2017). This species has a maximum standard length of 23.0 cm, but it is more commonly 20.0 cm (Whitehead 1985). Its maximum longevity has been estimated between 6 and 7 years (Gaughan and Mitchell 2000).
threats: This species is one of the most important commercially targeted species in parts of its range with indications of overfishing in the Philippines and Indonesia (Luceño et al. 2014, Setyohadi et al. 2016). The overfishing of small pelagic fisheries has been reported in the Sulu-Celebes Sea due to an increase in the improved efficiency of fishing gears and an increase in the number of vessels (Pedrosa-Gerasmio et al. 2015). A large proportion (~70%) of juveniles can be caught in eastern Java due to the increased use of purse seines (Simbolan et al. 2017). It is possible that overfishing in the Philippines may pose a threat to this species (Giducos et al. 2015); however, a recent report (Rola et al. 2018) suggests that local subpopulations respond well to fisheries management practices (e.g., annual closures). Other major threats to this species are unknown.
population:
Sardinella lemuru is widely distributed throughout the Philippines and is the most abundant species of Sardinella (Willette and Santos 2013). It is also highly abundant in Indonesian waters, specifically the Bali Strait, contributing and estimated 80% to total production between 1976 and 2007 (Simbolon et al. 2017). In the Bali Strait, this species reaches peak landings during cold periods and dominates during the southeast monsoon season (Sartimbul et al. 2016).

Globally, landings of Sardinella lemuru are reported to the FAO from Indonesia and averaged about 56,900 tonnes annually between 1950 and 2014 (FAO 2016). Overall, landings have increased throughout the time series (1950 – 2014) but have declined by approximately 57% since the highest peak of approximately 154,000 tonnes in 1998 to 66,500 tonnes in 2014. Landings were not reported from Indonesia in the Western Pacific during the years 2005 – 2011 (FAO 2016); however, it is unlikely that this species was not landed given its long term commercial importance in the region. It is possible that this species was included in mixed landings or misidentified during these years, but this cannot be quantified. Reconstructed catches, driven by Indonesia (Pauly and Zeller 2015), have fluctuated but remain relatively stable in the most recent years (2001-2010). Small quantities (<1,000 tonnes per year) are reconstructed from Australia and Timor Leste (Pauly and Zeller 2015). Overall, the reconstructed catches are higher than landings reported to the FAO, averaging just over 71,700 tonnes (1950 – 2010). However, catches were not reconstructed from some countries where this species is abundant and commercially important (i.e., the Philippines and China: Munroe et al. 1999, Willette and Santos 2013, Luceño et al. 2014, Pedrosa-Geramio et al. 2015). Therefore, the reconstructed catches and the landings reported to the FAO likely under-represent the true catches of this species.

Despite the discrepancies between the landings and reconstructed catch data, and the lack of data from some presumably important countries, there are indications that this species is declining. As this species probably has a highly fluctuating population, calculating long-term trends in population status can be more representative if more data are used. Therefore, an exponential regression was applied to a time period beginning where a decline in landings reported to the FAO can be attributed to exploitation (1990 - 2014), resulting in a decline of 32% over the most recent ten years available (2005-2014), thought to represent three generation lengths for this species. 

We suspect there are small parts of this species range where it is not exploited and therefore, a 32% decline probably represents a slight overestimate. Furthermore, reports show that this species is fished sustainably in the Zamboanga Province (Region IX) of the Philippines (E-value = 0.5: Barut et al. 2017) following the successful implementation of annual fishery closures in 2011 (Rola et al. 2018). However, based on an inferred decline of 32% in landings reported to the FAO and existing evidence that this species has been, and currently is being, overfished in parts of its range (i.e., increase in gear efficiency, the number of vessels and market value: Purwanto 2011, Pedrosa-Gerasmio et al. 2015, Setyohadi et al. 2016, Simbolon et al. 2017) but likely not all of its range, it is suspected that the true population decline is at least approaching 30%.
range: Sardinella lemuru is found in the Eastern Indian Ocean, specifically from Phuket, Thailand; along the southern coasts of East Java and Bali, Indonesia (Willette and Santos 2013); Timor-Leste (Pauly and Zeller 2015); and Western Australia (Kailola et al. 1993, Gaughan and Mitchell 2000). It is also found in the Western Pacific, specifically from northern Viet Nam, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and southern Japan (Willette and Santos 2013), excluding the Ryukyu Islands (H. Hata pers. comm. 2017). This species is found at a depth range between 15 to 100 m (Whitehead 1985).
useTrade: This species is commercially and economically important to fisheries throughout its distribution including the East China and Sulu-Celebes Seas, specifically off the Fujian and eastern Guandong provinces of China, the Philippines and Indonesia (Munroe et al. 1999, Luceño et al. 2014, Pedrosa-Geramio et al. 2015, Baum et al. 2016, Simbolon et al. 2017). Reports indicate that this species has been overfished in parts of its range (i.e., the Philippines and East Java: Purwanto 2011, Luceño et al. 2014). The FAO Yearbook of Fishery Statistics reported a yearly catch range of around 106,700 to 13,800 tonnes from Indonesia between 1990 to 1995 (Munroe et al. 1999). This species is a superior fish commodity in eastern Java and has been increasing in price (Setyohadi et al. 2016). It is also the second most important subsistence and commercial fish commodity in mainland Jarkarta (Baum et al. 2016). This species is important nutritionally to subsistence fishers (Baum et al. 2016), economically to local artisanal fishers and commercially as a raw fish material for processing industries in Indonesia (Simbolon et al. 2017). It is utilized on a national scale and is exported internationally to the U.S., Europe, and parts of the Middle East (Simbolon et al. 2017). Catches within the Strait of Bali are dominated by this species and can make up as much as 81.85% of total catch (Simbolan et al. 2017). Individuals less than 15 cm are regarded as juvenile and are considered to be an illegal size for capture (Simbolon et al. 2017). A large proportion (~70%) of juveniles can be caught in eastern Java due to less size selective fishing gears (i.e., purse seines: Simbolan et al. 2017). An uncontrolled increase in the number of purse seine vessels has led to the over exploitation of this species in the Bali Strait (Purwanto 2011). In the Philippines, this species is one of the most important commercially targeted species and has experienced overfishing along with other species of Sardinella (i.e., S. gibbosa and S. fimbriata: Luceño et al. 2014); however, recent conservation measures (e.g., annual fishery closures: BFAR 2014) where this species is most heavily targeted (off the Zamboanga Peninsula - Region IX) have resulted in an increase in the local population in recent years (Rola et al. 2018), which suggests this species responds well when regulated. This species is sold fresh and dried at the market. It is also sold canned and as "bottled sardine.” Sardinella lemuru is primarily caught by bag-net, beach seine, modified Danish seine, drift and bottom-set gillnet, fish corrals, ring-nets, multiple hand-line, purse seine, reel and rod, push net, and trawl.
conservationActions: Species-specific conservation measures are in place for this species in parts of its range (e.g., the Philippines). For example, closed fishing seasons have been implemented for sardines (including Sardinella lemuru) in the Philippines since 2011 (BFAR 2014), particularly in the Zamboanga Peninsula (Region IX where the E-value is 0.5), and have proven to be very successful (Rola et al. 2018). Additionally, its known geographic range overlaps with multiple existing marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2016), such as the Palaui Island Marine Reserve off the coast of the Philippines. As this species is highly commercially important and targeted, conservation recommendations have been made. For example, in Indonesian waters, the development of policy and stock monitoring programs have been suggested to reduce fishing efforts and avoid catching illegal sizes of this species (Setyohadi et al. 2016, Simbolon et al. 2017). More research and population stock assessments are recommended to better understand the population of this species. Likewise, increased monitoring and regulation of fisheries catches is needed to prevent population decline of this commercially important species.

rationale: Tenualosa macrura is a marine pelagic species that forms schools in coastal areas and also uses estuarine habitats. This species is a protandrous hermaphrodite, spawning periodically in estuarine areas. This species historically had a large, stable population but has suffered from range contractions and population decline due to over-fishing of spawning females as well as environmental degradation. The contraction of this species' geographic range and large decline in its fishery is similar to other tropical clupeids of the genus, including T. toli, T. thibaudeaui and T. reevesii. Currently, only two regions exist in which this species is fished (Riau Province, Sumatra and Sarawak, Malaysia) and catches have significantly declined. Based on its' known distribution and knowledge of available spawning grounds, the area of occupancy (AOO) was estimated to be about 3,000 km². This species is known from two primary locations (Riau Province, Sumatra and Sarawak, Malaysia) and is threatened by the heavy exploitation of spawning aggregations and a continuing decline of the quality of spawning habitat. No conservation measures are in place for this species at this time, though it has been advised that seasonal fisheries closures be put in place. This species appears extremely susceptible to over-fishing and has been severely impacted by these activities. Given the contraction and continued exploitation of available spawning grounds, and continued degradation of necessary habitat by large scale oil production, and logging activities, this species is, therefore assessed as Near Threatened based on criterion B2ab(iii). Increased and expanded protection and enforcement of fishing regulations, especially during peak spawning aggregations is strongly recommended.
habitat: Tenualosa macrura is a coastal, marine, pelagic, schooling species. This species moves into rivers to breed and is presumed to have similar biology to T. ilisha although this species likely feeds on larger organisms, due to having fewer gill rakers. Males and females regularly move between the Strait of Malacca (salinity of 28 - 30 ppt) and the spawning grounds of the sheltered straits (salinity of 20 - 28) of the Riau Province on each new and full moon (Blaber et al. 1999). Peak spawning in Bengkalis waters takes place between September and November, for 3 - 5 days during peak bright and dark periods each month (Suwarso et al. 2017). This species grows to a maximum standard length of 52 cm (Whitehead 1985). This species is a protandrous hermaphrodite and changes from male to female between 14 and 20 cm (SL) at around 6 months to 1 year of age after the males has spawned (Blaber et al. 1999, Allsop and West 2003). Females become sexually mature at around 13 cm and fecundity ranges from 60 000 to 200 000 eggs (Blaber et al. 1999). Almost all individuals in the second year class are female (Blaber et al. 1999). Maximum longevity is estimated to be 2 years (Blaber et al. 1999).
threats: The contraction of this species' geographic range and large decline in its fishery is similar to other tropical clupeids of the genus, including T. toli (Blaber et al. 1996), T. thibaudeaui (Roberts 1993, Navy et al. 2009) and T. reevesii (Wang 1996: Blaber et al. 1999). The main threat to this species is exploitation of its spawning grounds (Riau Province, Sumatra and estuaries is Sarawak, Malaysia). Catches for this species have purportedly declined drastically in recent decades as a result of intensive fishing in areas of aggregated spawning females, with most being caught before having the chance to spawn (Blaber et al. 1999). It is possible that the protandrous habit of this species has made it vulnerable to overfishing (Blaber et al. 1999). Large scale oil-industry and logging developments have also diminished the estuarine and coastal environments. Individuals of this species were found to have ingested large quantities of sawdust and this likely impacts survival (Brewer et al. 2001). In Thailand, habitat loss is directly associated with the decline of this species (Vidthayanon 2005).
population:
Limited population information is available for this species, though it has reportedly been declining for decades (Blaber et al. 1999). For example, this species and the sister species, T. toli were included in lucrative fisheries along the east coast of Sumatra until the 1970's (Blaber et al. 1999). Catches of this species along the coast declined and became confined only to the Bengkalis region of the Riau Province (Blaber et al. 1999). Merta et al. (1999) reported that in the 1950's, population densities were much higher than in the late 1990's (averaging 3 - 57 fish caught per trip).  In Thailand, this species has declined due to loss of habitat (Vidthayanon 2005).

During a research experiment in the Riau Province, Sumatra, 1203 individuals of this species were caught between August 1996 and February 1998 (Blaber et al. 1999). A further 450 were caught between January 1997 and December 2003 along the South China Sea coasts of Sarawak, though monthly sampling efforts indicate that this species was relatively rare, when found, and was not found at many localities (Blaber et al. 2005). Sarawak is the only locality in Malaysia this species is taken from; In 2015, this species made up about 2,244 tonnes in total catches in 2015 (Department of Fisheries Malaysia 2015).

In a more recent study from Sumatra, Suwarso et al. (2017) reported that this species is heavily degraded due to high exploitation in the Riau Province, despite fishery limitations (i.e., seasonal closures). In 2016, there was an increase in effort for this species in Bengkalis but this is due to illegal fishing within closed areas; overall effort for this species is declining (Suwarso et al. 2017). However, this species is still one of the most commonly caught species, representing roughly 15 % of total gill net fishery catches (Suwarso et al. 2017).
range: Tenualosa macrura is known from Sarawak, Malaysia and Sumatra, Indonesia (Whitehead 1985, Blaber et al. 1999). It is also listed on the Red Data Book of Thailand (Vidthayanon 2005) but no verified records exist. As this species breeds in estuaries where is is heavily fished and has only been verified from two localities (Riau Province of Sumatra and Sarawak, Malaysia), the number of locations is inferred to be two; at least two threatening events must occur to rapidly affect all individuals present. Based on the area of the breeding estuaries of this species, the area of occupancy (AOO) was calculated by converting the estuaries in Sarawak, Malaysia and Sumatra, Indonesia to a 4 km² grid and was estimated to be about 3,000 km². This species occupies waters at least as deep as 23 m (Blaber et al. 1999).
useTrade: There is a drift gill net fishery for T. macrura that operates in the Riau province of Sumatra as well as in Sarawak. This is the only remaining fishery for this species, though in the past several existed (Blaber et al. 1999). Fishing pressure intensifies in the inshore sheltered straits when this species is present to spawn; large females are targeted and taken most often prior to spawning (Blaber et al. 1999). Sometimes, juveniles are taken as bycatch in prawn trawl fisheries in the coastal waters of Malacca Strait (Blaber et al. 1999). In Malaysia, this species is a highly regarded table fish (M. Arshaad pers. com. 2017).
conservationActions: No known species-specific conservation measures are in place. This species is listed as Endangered in Thailand on the Red Data list of Fishes (Vidthayanon 2005). In the Bengkalis region of Sumatra (Riau Province), fishery closures are in place between September and November (thought to be this species peak spawning time: Suwarso et al. 2017) However, despite these fishing bans, effort is still high and spawning individuals are still exploited during closures. Increased and expanded protection measures and enforcement of fishing regulations, especially during peak spawning aggregations has been strongly recommended (Suwarso et al. 2017, Blaber et al. 2005).

rationale:
