There is a long history of overfishing of inshore populations and fishing pressure may be rising and extending offshore into deeper waters across the species’ entire range. Trawl surveys undertaken by the Norwegian research vessel 'Dr Fridtjof Nansen' in 1978–80 and 2013 showed a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs between surveys. This small species may have refuge at depth and in two Marine Protected Areas in the Andman and Nicobar Islands. Overall, it is suspected that the Magnificent Catshark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (45 years) due to actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Magnificent Catshark is presumably demersal on the edge of the outer continental shelf at depths of 141–300 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Kumar et al. 2015, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 49 cm total length (TL), males mature at 41–48 cm TL and females mature at 39 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is presumably oviparous. Nothing else is known of its biology. There are no age estimates from the family Proscylliidae and related families (i.e. catsharks of the families Scyliorhinidae and Pentanchidae) are difficult to age. The most reliable age estimates to date are from the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) (family Pentanchidae) that has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and maximum age of 21 years, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011). This should be treated with caution and as an estimate only as the two species are in different families.
threats:
In Myanmar, the Magnificent Catshark is caught in demersal trawl at depths <100 m and by longlines at depths of 70–200 m, although longline captures are rare (A. Maung unpubl. data 2020). In the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, it has been caught in deep-water trawls targeting shrimp (Plesionika spp. and Heterocarpus spp.) at depths of 300 m off South Sentinel Island (Kumar et al. 2015). This species is likely either a discarded bycatch or is retained as a 'trash' fish for animal feed mills in Myanmar, but was landed for sale in the Andaman Islands (Kumar et al. 2015). Post-release survival rate is unknown.

More generally, sharks and rays are captured by a wide range of gears in Myanmar. The inshore fisheries are relatively small-scale and include many subsistence level fishers. At times since 1950, significant numbers of foreign vessels have operated in Myanmar waters targeting fish and shrimp. These vessels have operated in both inshore and offshore areas. Offshore fishing that incidentally catches sharks and rays is carried out by a large commercial fleet of mostly trawlers, purse seiners, and longliners. The International Labour Organisation (2015) estimated the number of vessels participating in the small-scale inshore fishery to be about 26,000 in 2013, with about 50% of them unpowered. The number of locally operated larger offshore vessels numbered 2,846 in 2013, having increased nearly 30% since 2009. Foreign fishing vessels numbered 153 in 2013, but had historically been much higher. Foreign vessels were banned in 2014.

In the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, this is one of the small uncommon sharks caught as bycatch in longline fisheries at depths of 80–300 m (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). Very few individuals, less than ten, were encountered during surveys from 2016 to 2019 (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). This species may also have been captured in an artisanal deep-water vertical handline fisheries targeting the deepwater gulper and dogfish sharks (Centrophorus spp. and Squalus spp.) for their liver oil. This deep-water fishery operated intermittently between 1988–1992 and used 300–450 hooks per vessels at depths of 200–400 m (Soundrararajan and Roy 2004). Intensive longline and handline fishing pressure targeting groupers and snappers at depths of 50–150 m may catch higher numbers of individuals than the fisheries targeting deep-water sharks (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020).
population:
There are limited species-specific landings data available from Myanmar, and the nation provided no landings data to FAO on landings between 1956–1972, making specific inference on the state of populations difficult. However, reconstructed marine fisheries landings data are available from 1950, including estimates of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing (Booth and Pauly 2011). In general, fisheries catches (all species, not just sharks) increased steadily from about 200,000 t in 1950 to about 700,000 t in the late 1990s. From the late 1990s a rapid increase in landings from offshore fishing saw an increase in annual landings to almost 1.3 million t by 2008 (Booth and Pauly 2011). Estimates of shark and ray landings from 1950 to the late 1990s varied between 15,000 t to 35,000 t with no substantial trend. However, from the late 1990s landings increased to around 40,000 t per year. This increase in landings is assumed to reflect the increase in offshore fishing that occurred during this period. These are substantial catches (this level of catch places then in the top 20 shark fishing nations globally) for a nation with a relatively small Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). Despite the increase in shark and ray landings during the period since 1950, this increase is concurrent with an increase in fishing effort which infers there has been no significant reduction in the shark and ray populations as landings have increased as effort has increased, yet surveys in recent years have revealed reductions in some shark and ray populations and there are significant concerns for the status of many species. Trawl surveys undertaken by the Norwegian research vessel Dr Fridtjof Nansen in 1978–80 and 2013 showed a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs between surveys (Krakstad et al. 2014), with a noted shift from larger long-lived species to smaller short-lived species. Declines in ray species catch rates declined more than for shark species.

This is a small species that may have refuge at depth from intense inshore and trawl fisheries, and in Marine Protected Areas in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. Actual levels of exploitation are high across the range of this species and declines in sharks and rays can be considered representative of population reduction of the shallower portion of this species. Overall, it is suspected that the Magnificent Catshark has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (45 years) and it is assessed as is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Magnificent Catshark is poorly known and occurs in the Eastern Indian Ocean in the northern Andaman Sea off Myanmar, Thailand, and the Andaman Islands and Nicobar Islands (India) (Last and Vongpanich 2004, Ebert et al. 2013, Tyabji et al. 2018, Krajangdara 2019). The paucity of knowledge may be because this species may be confused with other similar species in the area (Psomadakis et al. 2019).
useTrade: There is no local consumption of this species due to its small size (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020) but it may be used as a 'trash' fish for animal feed mills (A. Maung unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions: There has been limited management of shark and rays in Myanmar. In 2004, the government established two shark reserves in the Myeik Archipelago where targeting sharks is prohibited (Notification 2/2004) (Howard et al. 2015). In 2008, a nationwide ban on the targeting of sharks was announced. Despite the nationwide ban, sharks and rays continue to be captured in large numbers, partly because there is little or no enforcement, and little knowledge of it in fishing communities (T. MacKeracher pers. comm. 2020). In Thailand, all commercial fishing vessels greater than 10 gross t are prohibited to fish within three nautical miles from the shore (DoF 2015). The species may have refuge inside the two Marine National parks (Mahatma Gandhi Marine National Park and Rani Jhansi Marine National Park) in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Indonesian Wobbegong (Orectolobus leptolineatus) is a small (to 120 cm total length) shark known from the Eastern Indian and Western Central Pacific Oceans off Indonesia, Timor-Leste, and Malaysia (Borneo). There are unconfirmed specimens from the Philippines, Taiwan, and Honshu in Japan, and there is taxonomic confusion between this species and the Japanese Wobbegong (O. japonicus). It inhabits shallow coastal inshore and coral reef habitats and the depth range is uncertain, but like other coastal wobbegongs, it is assumed to range from the surface down to 100 m depth. The species is a bycatch of a range of artisanal and industrial gears including demersal trawl and gillnet and is retained and sold fresh or salted for local consumption in Indonesia. Despite the lack of species-specific trend data, landings data from 1950 to 2014 are available for shark and ray species (to represent the range of possible gears the wobbegong might be caught in) from fisheries within the Indonesian Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). These landings data indicate declines that represent reductions of 36–95% when scaled to three generation lengths (27 years) of the Indonesian Wobbegong. These catch trends are not species-specific or directly from southern Java and Lesser Sunda Islands and the potential occurrence of Indonesian Wobbegong on rocky and coral reef habitats and nocturnal behaviour likely provide refuge from fishing pressure in most areas of its range. Nevertheless, this species is still captured occasionally in trawls is Borneo and artisanal trawl and gillnet fisheries off Bali and Lombok, hence, it is suspected the population has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (27 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Indonesian Wobbegong is demersal on the insular and continental shelves (Last et al. 2010b, Ebert et al. 2013). The depth range is uncertain, but like other coastal wobbegongs we assume the depth range is 0–100 m. It was photographed underwater at a depth of 20 m at Silayakuti Point, Bali, but may have a much deeper depth range as it was observed in fish market in Indonesia landed along with Squalus and triakid species presumably caught by longliners (Last et al. 2010a). In Lombok it has been recorded from depths of >60 m (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020) and it has been caught by trawlers in Sabah, which typically operate at 60–100 m depth (A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020). It reaches a maximum size of at least 120 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016), males mature at ~90 cm TL and females mature at 94–104 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is viviparous with at least 4 mid-term embryos observed in one pregnant female and size-at-birth estimated as 20 cm TL (Last et al. 2010b, Ebert et al. 2013). Nothing else is known of its biology. There are no age estimates for wobbegongs and the only data are available from another member of this order, the Whitespotted Bambooshark (Chiloscyllium plagiosum), which in the wild, has an age-at-maturity of 4.5 years, and maximum age estimated at 12.6–14.2 years (Chen et al. 2007), and generation length is thus estimated at 9 years.
threats: This species is captured as bycatch of trawl and possibly gillnet fisheries and retained. Four specimens caught by trawl were landed in Kota Kinabalu, Sarawak (A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020). In Indonesia, most fisheries in Lombok fish deeper than 60 m, but this species is caught by very small boats and usually caught together with rays, and typically fishing at < 60 m deep (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). This species is regularly landed in Lombok with several individuals landed each month (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). In Indonesia, small-scale fisheries comprise most (~90%) of fisheries production (Tull 2014). In some regions, effort by these small-scale fisheries has tripled when taking population growth into account (Ramenzoni 2017). Sharks and rays are an important resource in Indonesia and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). Fishing pressure in Indonesia is intense with the largest chondrichthyan fishery globally, and substantial catches of target and bycatch chondrichthyans (White et al. 2006). Indonesia has been among the top shark fishing nation for over 20 years (Oakes and Sant 2019) and the catch of rays is rising as shark fisheries collapse. In the South China Sea, there has been degradation of significant areas of coral reef habitat due to climate change and destructive fishing (Heileman 2009).
population:
The population trend of the Indonesian Wobbegong is difficult to ascertain, as there is confusion with another species, the Japanese Wobbegong (Orectolobus japonicus) (Last et al. 2010a). This species has been found on coral reefs and, like other wobbegongs, presumably it occurs on rocky and coral reef habitats and exhibits nocturnal behaviour, which likely provides considerable refuge from fishing pressure in most areas of this species distribution. The consequent reduced interactions with fisheries may account for its reported and possible rarity in some areas.

There is no population estimate for this species. Despite the lack of species-specific trend data, landings data from 1950 to 2014 are available on combined whipray species from fisheries within the Indonesian Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. While not a whipray, the Indonesian Wobbegong is in a similar depth range and may be susceptible to the same trawl gears as whiprays once outside their coral reef habitat. However, Indonesian Wobbegong is more likely to be caught with longlines and gillnets (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020) and the catch of carcharhinid species is also considered.

Catch of whiprays increased throughout Indonesia starting in the 1960s. In central Indonesia, whipray catch increased by 550% throughout the early-1970s to 2000, from 30 t to >200 t per year (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Catch decreased 45% since the early 2000s (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Research surveys from 1976 to 1997 shows more than a 90% decline in ray catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) throughout the Java Sea in 20 years (Blaber et al. 2009). With the increased catch through parts of Indonesia there has also been increased effort and therefore, CPUE is likely decreasing, suggesting an overall decrease in the population of chondrichthyans (White and Dharmadi 2007). When these inferred and suspected declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Indonesian Wobbegong (27 years), they represent declines of 74% and 95% in Central Indonesia. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline of ‘flatsharks’ in the region, though we caution that the wobbegong is more likely to be captured in longline and gillnet gears.

In Indonesia, reconstructed catch data shows catches of carcharhinids increased throughout the mid to late 1900s. In Eastern Indonesia, carcharhinid catch increased by 5,640% from 1970 to the late 1980s before it rapidly decreased ~325% in the mid 1990s to 11,500 t, where catch has since remained relatively stable (Zeller and Pauly 2016). In Central Indonesia, catch of carcharhinids began increasing in the early 1960s before reaching a peak in 1983 and remaining stable between 15,000 and 17,500 t until 2004. After which, carcharhinid catch was between 5,600 and 14,000 t until 2014 (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Catch of carcharhinids in the Indonesian EEZ of the Indian Ocean began increasing in the 1960 and steadily increased until 1994 at ~47,500 t. Catch has since decreased to ~33,000 t per year despite continually increasing effort. When these inferred and suspected declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Indonesian Wobbegong (27 years), they represent a reduction of 36% based on carcharhinid catches.

These catch trends are not species-specific or directly from southern Java and Lesser Sunda Islands. Nevertheless, this species is still captured occasionally in trawls is Borneo and artisanal trawl and gillnet fisheries off Bali and Lombok and hence, it is suspected the population may have undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (27 years) based on actual fishing pressure and is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Indonesian Wobbegong is known from the Eastern Indian and Western Central Pacific off Indonesia, Timor-Leste, and Malaysia (Borneo) (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016, A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020). In Indonesia, this species is recorded on the Indian Ocean side from Aceh province Sumatra, Java, and the Sunda Islands to Timor-Leste. It has also been recorded in Sulawesi from the Makassar Strait (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). This species is known from a few specimens collected off southeastern Sabah (Semporna) and Sarawak (Last et al. 2010b). There are unconfirmed specimens from Taiwan and Honshu Japan, and there is taxonomic confusion between this species and the Japanese Wobbegong (O. japonicus) (Last et al. 2010a). Further, the occurrence of this species in the Philippines remains to be confirmed due to confusion between this species and Japanese Wobbegong (O. japonicus) (J. Utzurrum unpubl. data 2020).
useTrade: This species is sold fresh or salted for local consumption in Indonesia (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020) but does not tend to appear in fish markets in Borneo (Last et al. 2010a, A. Bin Ali 2020). The type specimens were collected at fish landing sites at Kendonganan in Jimbaran Bay, southwest Bali and Tanjung Luar in southeast Lombok demonstrating that it is captured nearby and available for sale and local consumption (Last et al. 2010a).
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. Throughout Indonesia there are 196 Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) making up 239,428 km² and in Malaysia there are 51 MPAs making up 5,462 km² (CTI 2020). The species may occur in some of these MPAs, however, most MPAs in the region are not well enforced and unlikely to provide any tangible relief from fishing pressure. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Bali Numbfish (Narcine baliensis) is a small (to 31 cm total length) numbfish with a small distribution in Indonesia on the south coast Java and the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is currently known to be demersal on the continental shelf at depths of 60–62 m, but is presumably found from the surface down to this depth. The species is a discarded bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and longline. It is mostly discarded due to its small size and likely has a low post-release survival rate. Inferred and suspected declines from central Java and are not species-specific and range from 42–70% over three generation lengths (11 years). Based on inferred declines across most of its range, it is suspected that the Bali Numbfish has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (11 years) due to levels of exploitation, and is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Bali Numbfish is demersal on the inner continental shelf and is currently known from depths of 60–62 m, but is presumably found from the surface down to this depth (Carvalho and White 2016, Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 31 cm total length (TL) (Carvalho and White 2016, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is presumably histotrophic viviparity, but relatively little is known of the biology of the species. Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from the only species of numbfish with age data. The Cortez Numbfish (Narcine entemedor) has a female age-at-maturity of 6 years and a maximum age of 15 years, resulting in a generation length of 10.5 years (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000). The Cortez Numbfish is larger than the Bali Numbfish (93 vs 31 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 3.5 years for the Bali Numbfish.
threats: In Indonesia, small-scale fisheries comprise most (~90%) of fisheries production (Tull 2014). In some regions, effort by these small-scale fisheries has tripled when taking population growth into account (Ramenzoni 2017). Sharks and rays are an important resource in Indonesia and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). Indonesia catches the highest number of chondrichthyans in the world with the catch of rays rising as shark fisheries collapse. In 2003, rays comprised over 50% of chondrichthyan landings, up from 32% in 1981 (White et al. 2006).
population:
There is no population estimate for this species. Despite the lack of species-specific trend data, landings data from 1950 to 2014 are available on combined whipray species from fisheries within the Indonesian Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. While not a whipray, the Bali Numbfish occurs in a similar depth range and is susceptible to the same fishing gears as whiprays, thus the catch trends of whiprays are suspected to be similar to that of numbfishes.

Catch of whiprays increased throughout Indonesia starting in the 1960s. In central Indonesia, whipray catch increased by 550% throughout the early-1970s to 2000, from 30 tonnes to >200 tonnes per year (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Catch decreased 45% since the early 2000s (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Research surveys from 1976 to 1997 shows more than a 90% decline in ray catch per unit effort throughout the Java Sea in 20 years (Blaber et al. 2009). With the increased catch through parts of Indonesia there has also been increased effort and therefore, catch per unit effort (CPUE) is likely decreasing, suggesting an overall decrease in the population of chondrichthyans (White and Dharmadi 2007).

In general, there are not many fish landings along the south coast of Java. There are some areas where there is very low or no fishing pressure along the south coast of Java that may be refuge areas for the species (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020).

When these inferred and suspected declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Bali Numbfish (10.5 years), they represent reductions of 42% and 70% in Central Indonesia. These levels of decline are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historic and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across most of the range of the Bali Numbfish. Dramatic declines have been documented in populations of similar species, where they are heavily fished. Considering these catch trends are not species-specific or directly from southern Java and Lesser Sunda Islands, the suspected population reduction of the Bali Numbfish in Indonesia is 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (10.5 years).
range: This species occurs in the Eastern Indian Ocean off southern Java and the Lesser Sunda Islands (Carvalho and White 2016, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Numbfishes are not consumed as human food and are presumably discarded due to their small size (Last et al. 2016).
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Indonesia in 1980, trawls were banned, however, large numbers of mini or baby trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country (Chong et al. 1987). In 2015, an additional ban on seine nets (Cantrang) was to be fully implemented in February 2020 (Ambari 2019). There are currently plans in place to lift both these bans in the near future, where the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (MMAF) plan will allow the operation of the fishing gear with restrictions on the area of fishing pressure (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2020).

rationale: The Indian Fanray (Platyrhina psomadakisi) is a small (to 38 cm total length) poorly-known ray that occurs in eastern Indian Ocean off Myanmar and Thailand in the Andaman Sea. It is only known from four specimens. It is demersal on the continental shelf at depths of 60–160 m. The species is likely a bycatch of multiple fishing gears including demersal trawl and gillnets and is likely retained for human consumption. There is a long history of overfishing of inshore populations and fishing pressure remains high, and may be rising, across the species’ entire range. Trawl surveys undertaken by the Norwegian research vessel Dr Fridtjof Nansen in 1978–80 and 2013 showed a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs between surveys, with steeper declines in rays than for shark species. This small species may have some refuge at depth and may also benefit from mesopredator release and hence it may not have declined as steeply as larger species. Overall, it is suspected that the Indian Panray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (36 years) due to actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Indian Fanray is presumably benthic on the continental shelf at depths of 60–160 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 38 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is presumably lecithotrophic viviparous, but relatively little is known of the biology of the species (Last et al. 2016). It may have an annual reproductive cycle and litter sizes of 1–12, similar to its close relative, the Yellow-spotted Fanray (Platryhina tangi) (Yamaguchi and Kume 2009). Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from the Yellow-spotted Fanray that, in Taiwan, has a female age-at-maturity of 4.1 years and maximum age of 20 years, resulting in a generation length of 12 years (Hsieh 2011).
threats: Sharks and rays are captured by a wide range of gears in Myanmar. This species is captured using demersal trawl and gillnets (Psomadakis et al. 2019). In coastal waters prior to a nationwide ban on targeting sharks in 2004, large sharks were targeted by pelagic longlines up to 3 km in length. Since 2004, sharks are largely taken as incidental catch in coastal gillnets, trawls (for fish or shrimp), longlines targeting mackerels, and hookah divers spearing at night (mostly catching rays and carpet sharks) (Howard et al. 2015, Mizrahi et al. 2020). These inshore fisheries are relatively small-scale and include many subsistence level fishers. At times since 1950, significant numbers of foreign vessels have operated in Myanmar waters targeting fish and shrimp. These vessels have operated in both inshore and offshore areas. Offshore fishing that incidentally catches sharks and rays is carried out by a large commercial fleet of mostly trawlers, purse seiners and longliners. International Labour Organisation (2015) estimated the number of vessels participating in the small-scale inshore fishery to be about 26,000 in 2013, with about 50% of them unpowered. The number of locally operated larger offshore vessels numbered 2,846 in 2013, having increased nearly 30% since 2009. Foreign fishing vessels numbered 153 in 2013, but had historically been much higher. Foreign vessels were banned in 2014.
population:
There is limited species-specific landings data available from Myanmar, and the nation provided no data to FAO on landings between 1956–1972, making specific inference on the state of populations difficult. However, reconstructed marine fisheries landings data are available from 1950, including estimates of illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing (Booth and Pauly 2011). In general, fisheries catches (all species, not just sharks) increased steadily from about 200,000 t in 1950 to about 700,000 t in the late 1990s. From the late 1990s a rapid increase in landings from offshore fishing saw an increase in annual landings to almost 1.5 million t. Estimates of shark and ray landings from 1950 to the late 1990s varied between 15,000 t to 35,000 t with no substantial trend. However, from the late 1990s landings increased to around 40,000 t per year. This increase in landings is assumed to reflect the increase in offshore fishing that occurred during this period. These are substantial catches (this level of catch places them in the top 20 shark fishing nations globally) for a nation with a relatively small Exclusive Economic Zone (Davidson et al. 2016). Despite the increase in shark and ray landings during the period since 1950, this increase is concurrent with an increase in fishing effort which infers there has been no significant reduction in the shark and ray populations as landings have increased as effort has increased, yet surveys in recent years have revealed reductions in some shark and ray populations and there are significant concerns for the status of many species. Trawl surveys in Myanmar undertaken by the Norwegian research vessel Dr Fridtjof Nansen in 1978–80 and 2013 showed a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs between surveys (Krakstad et al. 2014), with a noted shift from larger long-lived species to smaller short-lived species. Declines in ray species catch rates declined more than for shark species.

This small species may have some refuge at depth from more intense inshore fisheries and may also benefit from mesopredator release and hence it may not have declined as steeply as larger species. Actual levels of exploitation are high across the range of this species and declines in rays can be considered representative of population reduction of the Indian Fanray. Overall, it is suspected that the Indian Fanray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the last three generation lengths (36 years) and it is assessed as is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Indian Fanray is poorly-known from four specimens from the Eastern Indian Ocean off Myanmar and Thailand in the Andaman Sea (Last et al. 2016, White and Last 2016, Psomadakis et al. 2019, T. Krajangdara unpubl. data 2020).
useTrade: The flesh of the Indian Panray is presumably used fresh or salted and dried for human consumption throughout its range.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures. In 2004 in Myanmar, the government established two shark reserves in the Myeik Archipelago where targeting sharks is prohibited (Notification 2/2004) (Howard et al. 2015). Rays are protected from targeting by the shark reserves. In 2008, a nationwide ban on the targeting of sharks was announced. Despite the nationwide ban, sharks and rays continue to be captured in large numbers, partly because there is little or no enforcement, and little knowledge of the ban in fishing communities (T. MacKeracher, Dalhousie University, pers. comm. 2020). In Thailand, all commercial fishing vessels greater than 10 gross t are prohibited to fish within three nautical miles from the shore (DoF 2015). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
Anguilla bicolor is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

This shortfin eel species has a widespread distribution, although is not the most abundant species in many of these localities. There are a variety of documented threats within the range of A. bicolor that may be affecting the population, although there is limited information on the scale of the impact. Possible threats include barriers to migration (Wasserman et al. 2011), and associated turbine mortality (Arai et al. 2012a), habitat loss, poor water management, mining (Ame et al. 2013), pollution (Muhammad et al. 2012, Abbas et al. 2017, Octaviano 2017), and unsustainable exploitation (Gollock et al. 2018). 

Due to declines in the abundance and availability of both A. japonica and A. anguilla - species which have traditionally been used for farming and consumption - A. rostrata, and A. bicolor are currently the next preferred species, with interest in, and demand for, A. bicolor in East Asia having increased over the last decade. Although there are little data available for estimating population changes in this species, based on the ready supply of glass eels, other life stages and products on online trading platforms and reported by Southeast Asian researchers, it is believed that the eels found in this region may be under considerably greater threat from increased exploitation.

Anguilla bicolor is assessed as Near Threatened (NT) based on a suspected reduction in population size of close to 30% over the next 21 years (3 generations). Should it continue increasing, exploitation of the species may pose a significant threat to the population at a global scale. It is necessary to note, however, that there is no formal monitoring data for relative abundance of this species. It is therefore strongly advised that monitoring for A. bicolor be conducted across its range to better determine population status. As with all anguillids, co-ordination of the management across this species’ range will also be pivotal in conservation.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th of November, 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

Anguilla bicolor has been suggested to have two spawning locations in the Indian Ocean, one to the west of Sumatra (Jespersen 1942, Aoyama et al. 2007, Kuroki et al. 2007), and another to the east of Madagascar (Robinet and Feunteun 2002, Robinet et al. 2003, Kuroki et al. 2007, Nguyen et al. 2018). A. bicolor in the Pacific Ocean is thought to spawn somewhere in the North Equatorial Current region (Aoyama et al. 2018, Chen et al. 2018). The growth rate of A. bicolor leptocephali collected in the eastern Indian Ocean, west of Sumatra, was slower than other tropical eels, such as A. celebesensis or A. borneensis, suggesting that this subpopulation have a longer leptocephalus stage during oceanic migration (Kuroki et al. 2007). Year-round spawning has been suggested to occur for A. bicolor in the Indian Ocean (Arai et al. 2016, Arai and Kadir 2017a) and almost throughout the year in the Pacific (Sugeha et al. 2001, Sugeha et al. 2008). Individuals recruiting to Indonesia are thought to be coming from two or three different spawning seasons and/or sources, possibly including North and South Pacific spawning locations (Sugeha et al. 2001, Sugeha and Suharti 2008, Sugeha et al. 2008, Aoyama et al. 2018).

This species has been observed to have elongate nostrils of a yellow/orange colour, that have been hypothesised to act as lures for prey (Tweddle and Skelton 2016). A. bicolor spends most of its life in estuaries, brackish waters, freshwater lakes, streams, pools and small rivers, preferring marshy habitats but can also be found over rock bottoms and in deeper pools (Pethiyagoda 1991). Chino and Arai (2010) found two patterns of habitat residence in eels from Segara Anakan, central Java Island in Indonesia. No eels were found to display solely freshwater residence, whilst 25% solely existed in either brackish or sea waters. The other 75% displayed habitat shifting between freshwater and either brackish or sea waters. In Africa this species is noted as preferring lowland coastal reaches of river systems (Skelton 1993) and in the Arabian Peninsula to wadis, estuaries and the coastal habitat (EPAA 2002). Similarly, in the Cagayan River, Philippines, it is thought that A. bicolor is found more commonly to reside in tributaries closer to the mouth of the river (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2018). In Vietnam, A. bicolor were found to show no freshwater residency during growth phase after analysis of Sr:Ca ratios suggesting either sea water or estuarine residency or migrating between brackish to sea (Arai et al. 2013). In a lagoon in Indonesia, individuals tended to migrate between freshwater and sea water with no constant freshwater residence (Arai et al. 2017). Hamzah et al. (2015) found most of the sampled A. bicolor in Peninsular Malaysia to display high gonadosomatic indices, suggesting they were ready to begin the spawning migration. This possibly indicates that they might remain entirely in freshwater before migration to the ocean to breed. However, Arai and Kadir (2017b) found A. bicolor to be widely distributed in both upstream to downstream areas of rivers in Peninsular Malaysia. Most recently, Arai and Chino (2019) investigated migratory history of A. bicolor collected in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam. A. bicolor in Indonesia and Viet Nam were found to be either marine or brackish resident, whereas in Malaysia, it was freshwater resident (Arai and Chino 2019). Overall A. bicolor appears to show opportunistic, flexible habitat use and migration strategy during the growth phase, possibly in response to local conditions.

Anguilla bicolor can grow to a maximum size of 1.1 m (Gomon and Bray 2017). However, while this species can live for up to 20 years, the average age of silvering is younger than those of temperate eels, suggesting that growth is faster (Arai et al. 2011). A variety of studies have examined the reproductive ecology of A. bicolor in Peninsular Malaysia. Arai et al. (2011) found age of female silver eels ranged between four and six years, with a total length of 497 to 636 mm, and weight ranging from 205 to 497 g. Another study found age at maturation of females ranged between 5.5 and 8.5 years, with body length and weight ranging from 411 to 720 mm and 126 to 1125 g, respectively (Chai and Arai 2018). On Penang Island off Peninsular Malaysia, migrating female silver eels were found to have an average total length and body weight of 651 mm, and 593 g respectively (Kadir et al. 2017). Glass eels of A. bicolor recruiting to Réunion Island in the western Indian Ocean were found to be 54 ± 2.1 mm long (Robinet et al. 2003).

From research conducted on the Pacific subpopulation of A. bicolor in the Dumoga River, North Sulawesi Island, Indonesia, the ages of glass eels at recruitment to the coast ranged from 124 to 202 days, with hatching being estimated as having occurred between November and March (Arai et al. 1999). The duration of metamorphosis was estimated as 20 to 40 days (Arai et al. 1999). In the Poigar River, North Sulawesi, A. bicolor was only present in samples in January, March, April, October and December (Arai et al. 2001). Mean age at metamorphosis and recruitment was estimated to be 141 ± 20.9, and 173 ± 20.9 days, respectively (Arai et al. 2001). Based on year-round recruitment of glass eels at the Poigar River mouth, and age at recruitment remaining constant throughout the year, year-round spawning may exist for A. bicolor (Arai 2000, Arai 2001).

Average total length of A. bicolor glass eels recruiting to Mindanao, Philippines was 48.8 mm (45–52.3 mm) (Shirotori et al. 2016). Two specimens of metamorphosing leptocephali - 42.6 and 46.3 mm - were reported off the Indonesian Archipelago and their ages were estimated as 106 and 112 days, respectively (Kuroki et al. 2006). During a sampling survey from Sumatra in 2003, A. bicolor leptocephali were collected west of Sumatra in the Mentawai Trench (Kuroki et al. 2007). Otolith microstructure of these larvae revealed size and age ranges of 44.1–55.5 mm and 114–158 days respectively (Kuroki et al. 2007). The transport of A. bicolor larvae is likely to be heavily influenced by the South Equatorial Current (SEC), the South Equatorial Counter Current (SECC) and the South Java Current (SJC) (Kuroki et al. 2007).

Kadir et al. (2017) estimated the fecundity range (millions of eggs) for A. bicolor to be 0.6 to 5 and relative fecundity (millions of eggs per kilogram of body weight) was 3.1.

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla bicolor, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are potentially less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments.

To date, few studies or surveys have considered the threats facing this species. Across the range of A. bicolor, there are documented threats affecting all anguillid eels. In Northern Luzon, Philippines, there is concern over pollution resulting from agricultural run-off, sediment erosion and mining (Ame et al. 2013). Farming practices occur along the Cagayan River, and run-off may well be affecting eels in this aquatic system (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2018). In Sulawesi, mining for gold takes place, possibly affecting anguillid species in this area through mercury pollution (Muhammad et al. 2012, Abbas et al. 2017, Octaviano 2017). Anguillid eels have been suggested as reliable indicators of contaminant concentrations within surface waters (Arai et al. 2012b). In a study on A. bicolor from Malaysia, cadmium, copper, nickel and zinc were found below the acceptable limits of heavy metal pollution in fish and shellfish, although lead was higher than the global standard (Arai et al. 2012b). Even at low levels, heavy metals are toxic (Arai et al. 2012b), and can impact anguillids metabolism, in some cases leading to mortality (Le et al. 2009).

Major impoundments and weirs are barriers to upstream eel movement in all countries within A. bicolor’s range (Wasserman et al. 2011) and mortalities can occur during the downstream passage of silver eels through turbines and pumps, and impingement on intake screens. For example, an irrigation dam in the Karau River, Malaysia, may prevent upstream/downstream movement of yellow stage A. bicolor (Arai et al. 2012a). In the Poso river watershed in Indonesia, dams for hydropower and unsustainable harvest of glass and larger eels are two reported threats (Watupongoh and Krismono 2015). Non-native species now found in many systems in South Africa, such as the predatory bass (Micropterus spp.) and catfish (Clarias spp.), present a threat to eels and other recruiting fish (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

Climate change has been proposed to play a role in fluctuations of abundance in anguillid species – particularly larval transport and glass eel recruitment – however, understanding of these processes, and the scale of their influence, if any, is very limited. The Philippines are significantly affected by typhoon activity, which has been increasing, most likely as a result of climate change (Holden and Marshall 2018) and may have the potential to reduce habitat quality. Significant localised damage caused by typhoon activity has been observed in some tributaries of the Cagayan River system (M. Gollock pers. comm.).

Parasitic infection by the invasive swim bladder nematode Anguillicola crassus has also been observed in A. mossambica, A. bicolor and A. marmorata from Reunion (Sasal et al. 2008). Two A. marmorata (n = 80), one A. bicolor (n = 23) and one A. mossambica (n = 15) were infected (Sasal et al. 2008). While the infection prevalence was low in these samples, this parasite is known to spread extremely quickly (Kirk 2003).

A major concern for A. bicolor, is believed to be the growing exploitation of this species across much of its range, particularly for glass eels (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). Over the last decade A. bicolor has been fulfilling some of the demand for eels for consumption in East Asia driven by declines in other species (Jacoby et al. 2015, Nijman 2015, Shiraishi and Crook 2015). Increasing exploitation is expected to continue due to the reduced availability of A. japonica and A. anguilla in particular, and there are concerns over illegal trade from several countries in Southeast Asia where glass eel exports are not permitted (see Conservation). In a study investigating illegal trade in the Philippines, A. bicolor made up 87% (20 out of 23) of randomly selected elvers identified after confiscation - the remaining three were identified as A. marmorata (Asis et al. 2016).
population:
There is little quantitative information available to infer the population status of Anguilla bicolor. It is reasonable to assume that there will have been some effects as a result of the identified threats, although considerably more information would be necessary to determine accurate estimates and associated changes.

In historic studies conducted in southern Sri Lanka, the population was stated to be relatively stable as reflected in the catch per unit effort (Wickström and Enderlein 1988, Wickström 2006). Population densities of this species are very low in the Arabian Peninsula (EPAA 2002). In the Philippines, multiple species of glass eels, including A. bicolor, recruit to the coast and abundances appear to fluctuate annually and regionally (Aoyama et al. 2015, Shirotori et al. 2016).

Sugeha et al. (2001) studied the inshore migration of glass eels to the Poigar River estuary (North Sulawesi, Indonesia) over a three-year period from 1997–1999. A. bicolor was found to recruit almost year-round, although in the lowest abundance compared to A. celebesensis, and A. marmorata (Sugeha et al. 2001). A. bicolor made up only 2.7, 1.7, and 0.3% of the annual catch, respectively (Sugeha et al. 2001). In contrast, A. bicolor was recorded to be the dominant species recruiting to the estuary of Palu River (West Sulawesi, Indonesia) from 2006 to 2007, compared to A. marmorata and A. celebesensis (Sugeha et al. 2008). Aoyama et al. (2015) sampled glass eels in the Cagayan River, Philippines, from 2008 to 2009, and again in 2011 to 2012. In 2008–2009, A. bicolor made up only 3.9% (of 8,643 glass eels), which increased to 29.5% (of 23,535 glass eels) in 2011–2012 (Aoyama et al. 2015). Another study in the Cagayan River system conducted monitoring over a twelve-month period from May 2015 to May 2016 and found A. bicolor to make up only 10% of recruitment in a mixed system with A. marmorata (44%), and A. luzonensis (46%) (Zoological Society of London, unpub. data.) In the Pangi River, Maitum Sarangani Province, Philippines, A. marmorata was dominant, making up ~97% (4,118 of 4,262 eels) of catch, whereas A. bicolor was less common, only making up ~3% (139 of 4,262 eels) (Valdez and Castillo 2016). In Southern Mindanao, Philippines, glass eels were collected over a year period between April 2014 and May 2015, A. bicolor was the second most abundant species, making up 19.5% of catch (Shirotori et al. 2016).

In Palabuhan Ratu, Indonesia, eel catch and effort data (CPUE) has been recorded since November 2013 (SEAFDEC 2018). This data is not species specific, however it has been suggested that the dominant species caught in the Cimandiri River is A. bicolor (SEAFDEC 2018). Although there is no overall trend across this time series, there are three periods where CPUE peaked; October 2014 to September 2015, October 2015 to September 2016, and January to April 2017 (SEAFDEC 2018). In a study of glass eels recruiting to Palu River in Sulawesi, A. marmorata was dominant, constituting just over half of catch (51%), A. bicolor made up 36% (Serdiati et al. 2013).

In Réunion, A. bicolor, as well as other recruiting anguillid eels (A. bengalensis, A. marmorata and A. mossambica), are classified as ‘Critically Endangered’ under the regional Red List (Fricke et al. 2009). Listed threats include fisheries (target species and bycatch), habitat loss, construction of barriers to migration, and parasites (Fricke et al. 2009).
range:
Anguilla bicolor has diverged between the Indian and Pacific Oceans giving rise to two subpopulations (Ege 1939). The subpopulation found in the Indian Ocean (sometimes referred to as A. bicolor bicolor) is genetically homogeneous in this ocean, but significantly different from that in the Pacific Ocean (sometimes referred to as A. bicolor pacifica) (Minegishi et al. 2012). There is also continued debate about whether the Indian Ocean subpopulation might also be considered as two separate management units (K. Tsukamoto pers. comm. 2014). Watanabe et al. (2014) suggested each spawning population “should be considered a distinct ecological unit for conservation and sustainable management”.

The Pacific subpopulation is native to the coasts of mainland China (hereafter China), Taiwan, Province of China (hereafter Taiwan), Viet Nam (Quang Binh, Quang Tri, Hue, Binh Dinh, Phu Yen, Nha Trang (Nguyen 2018)) (Arai et al. 2011), Philippines (Shirotori et al. 2016) and the islands of Borneo, Sulawesi Island, New Guinea, and the Marianas (Tesch 2003 in Nguyen 2018). In Taiwan, it has been suggested to be an occasional species with low abundance (Leander et al. 2012). Hong et al. (2017) recently identified one specimen in the Republic of Korea (hereafter South Korea) waters. A study by Sugeha and Suharti (2008) conducted around the Indonesian Archipelago, found A. bicolor to be distributed along the archipelago from the west to the east. A. bicolor recruited in Sulawesi, Halmahera, and West Papua Islands of eastern Indonesian archipelago (Sugeha and Suharti 2008).

The Indian Ocean subpopulation is distributed from the east coast of Africa, the Arabian Peninsula (Oman and Yemen, including Socotra, in coastal drainages of the Gulf of Oman, Arabian Sea, and Gulf of Aden (EPAA 2002)), it is widespread in the tropical Indian Ocean (Seychelles, Madagascar and Mascarenes), east to India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Myanmar. It is found across to northwestern Australia but known only from streams in the Kimberley regions of northwestern Western Australia and Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory (Allen et al. 2002). In Indonesia, A. bicolor has been found to recruit to Sumatra and Java Islands of the western Indonesian archipelago (Sugeha and Suharti 2008, Sugeha and Genisa, 2015, Muchlisin et al. 2017, Suryati et al. 2018). A number of recent studies also support the occurrence of A. bicolor from the Indian Ocean subpopulation in the Malaysian Peninsula (Arai et al. 2012a, 2015; Hamzah et al. 2015, Arai and Wong 2016, Arai and Kadir 2017b). In Africa, it is widespread but relatively uncommon along the east and southeast African coast from South Africa to Tanzania and Madagascar, including the Lower Shire River System of the Lower Zambezi in Malawi (Tweddle and Willoughby 1979) and Tana River in Kenya (Copley 1958). In a study identifying eels from Madagascar and surrounding islands, A. bicolor was the only anguillid species collected in the Seychelles archipelago (Robinet et al. 2008).

The exact spawning locations of Anguilla bicolor are unknown. Studies have long thought the spawning location of A. bicolor in the Indian Ocean lies to the west of Sumatra above the Mentawai Trench (Jespersen 1942, Robinet and Feunteun 2002, Aoyama et al. 2007, Kuroki et al. 2007). A second western spawning location has been hypothesised to exist to the east of Madagascar (Robinet and Feunteun 2002, Robinet et al. 2003, Kuroki et al. 2007, Nguyen et al. 2018). Although, the utilisation of a single spawning area is supported by a population structure showing this species to be genetically homogenous throughout the Indian Ocean (Minegishi et al. 2012, Fahmi 2013). It is therefore likely that eels in the southwest Indian Ocean may be coming from the same spawning area as those recruiting to Sumatra (Robinet et al. 2008). A. bicolor in the Pacific Ocean is thought to spawn somewhere in the North Equatorial Current region, near the Mariana Ridge, possibly overlapping or near to that of A. japonica (Aoyama et al. 2018, Chen et al. 2018).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, South Korea and China. A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global Anguilla production has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 tonnes (t)), with China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). Anguilla bicolor was increasingly used to stock farms in East Asia from 2010 onwards (after A. anguilla was listed in CITES Appendix II in 2009 and the EU banned all trade in A. anguilla from and to the EU), and in particular when the price of A. japonica glass eels increased dramatically due to shortages in 2011–2013.

According to East Asian Customs data, between 2008 and 2017 East Asian countries/territories imported ~220 t of live eel fry for farming (glass eels and larger juveniles) from eight countries in south-east/south Asia (>70% from the Philippines), reaching a peak of around 64 t in 2013, and 14 t from Africa (99% from Madagascar, see below). China and South Korea farming input data includes some specific records of “A. bicolor +” (believed to include mainly A. bicolor, but also some other tropical species): in mainland China “A. bicolor +” input gradually increased from 0.3 t in 2008–2009, reaching a peak of 13.5 t in 2013–2014; South Korea also began to use A. bicolor in 2010–2011, input reaching a peak of 6.7 t in 2012–2013. Both trade and farming input data suggest that the demand for A. bicolor and other tropical eels in East Asia has declined since 2014 as successful farming techniques for A. bicolor and other species have not yet been fully developed (Fan and Qin 2016, Back and Park 2017). However, there appears to have been an increase in A. bicolor farming in Indonesia and the Philippines in recent years (SEAFDEC 2018). It should also be noted that exports of glass eels from most south-east Asian countries are not currently permitted (see Conservation).

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. 

Anguilla bicolor is found in subsistence and commercial fisheries and in international trade, however as its range overlaps with many other anguillids, species specific data is very limited. At best it is reported as an approximate percentage of catch/trade and only available for part of its range. Within south-east Asia, Indonesia and the Philippines are currently the principal Anguilla catching, farming and trading nations (SEAFDEC 2018). Annual catches of “River eels nei” (other eel species not included elsewhere in FAO fishery statistics) in Indonesia and the Philippines fluctuated between 1355 and 6125 t between 2008 and 2017, averaging over 3000 t per year. According to national surveys coordinated by SEAFDEC, in 2017 total Indonesian glass eel catch (a mix of A. bicolor and A. marmorata) was ~20 t, and annual elver and yellow eel catches in 2015 and 2016 (no data available for 2017) was ~700 t (SEAFDEC 2018). The mouth of the Cimandiri River in Sukabumi Regency is considered to be one of the largest glass eel fishing grounds in Indonesia, with more than 1,500 part-time fishermen active in the peak season (Honda et al. 2016). Fahmi and Hirnawati (2010) concluded that 86% of the glass eel caught in the Cimandiri River was A. bicolor.  There are 12 eel farms currently operating in Java, and 90% of total production (354 t in 2015 and 511 t in 2016) is reportedly A. bicolor (SEAFDEC 2018).

In the Philippines, the main target species for fisheries is A. bicolor, however the main species caught in Luzon and Mindanao is A. marmorata (85–90% of all glass eels, 95% of yellow eels). 2017 glass eel catches were reported as 2.2 t in Luzon and 10.3 t Mindanao. There are 28 eel farms currently operating in the Philippines and in 2016 they produced 114 tonnes - 20% A. marmorata (exported to China, South Korea and Taiwan) and 80% A. bicolor (exported to Japan, South Korea and Taiwan). Apparently, farmers are specifically looking for species mixes with a high percentage of A. bicolor, glass eels are sorted and most of the A. marmorata is released back into the wild. In other south-east Asian nations, anguillid eel catch and use is small in comparison, and in many cases only as bycatch species, e.g. yellow eel bycatch in Myanmar was reported as 12 t in 2017 (90% A. bicolor, 10% A. marmorata or A. bengalensis). Due to the high diversity of tropical fish in south-east Asia and the perception that anguillid eels look like snakes and/or have mythical status (Mekong Fisheries Network 1999) domestic consumption is minimal, apart from in Viet Nam, which uses 50% of its anguillid production (95% A. marmorata and 5 % A. bicolor farmed from domestic glass eel catch, ~0.6–0.75 t a year) for domestic consumption (SEAFDEC 2018). In some parts of its range, such as Sri Lanka, A. bicolor is also reportedly used in the aquarium trade (Pethiyagoda 1991).

International trade in Anguilla commodities is reported from much of A. bicolor’s range, however, the species composition of shipments is unknown and could contain many different Anguilla species including A. marmorata, A. bengalensis and A. mossambica. According to UN Comtrade, exports of eel commodities (live, fresh, frozen and prepared eel) from south-east and south Asian countries increased from ~8,420 t in 2008 to 32,640 t in 2016, with live and frozen eels being the main commodities for export. However, live eel exports from south-east Asian countries in particular are known to include non-Anguilla eel species such as Monopterus albus (Swamp Eels) and Pisodonophis spp. (Gollock et al. 2018, SEAFDEC 2018). For example, verified exports from the Philippines in 2016 were only 48 t (all apparently identified as Anguilla bicolor pacifica), compared to the 8,423 t reported to UN Comtrade. Madagascar, South Africa, Tanzania and Mauritius also exported Anguilla commodities between 2008 and 2017, with most exports being live and frozen eels from Madagascar (273 t) and South Africa (129 t). According to UN Comtrade, exports of live eels (all life stages) from Madagascar increased gradually from 4.6 t in 2004 to 8.8 t in 2009 and then in 2010 there was a dramatic increase in exports to over 45 t. From 2011 to 2015 annual exports fluctuated between 16t and 26 t, and in 2016 and 2017 they declined again to ~11 t. Companies trading in the southern and east Africa region declare that their glass and adult live eels are A. mossambica and that they are able to differentiate between species and control harvesting as glass eel recruitment is asynchronous, however exports to East Asia of live eels caught in Madagascar, Mozambique and South Africa have been reported to include other species (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). 

Internet searches reveal that live, frozen and processed products (such as shirayaki and kabayaki) of A. bicolor can be easily purchased in bulk online; this species sometimes being referred to as just “black eels”. In May 2019, A. bicolor was being offered for sale on national and global B2B trading platforms by over 40 different suppliers, over 50% based in Indonesia.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific policies in place for Anguilla bicolor. In May 2012, as a precautionary measure by the Philippine Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (BFAR) legislation was enacted to prohibit the export of juvenile anguillid eels of a size less than 15 cm from the Philippines, (Crook 2014). In the Cagayan River, located in the north of Luzon island in the Philippines, an eel management plan has been developed (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2019). This has been proposed as a model for replication in other islands/regions, and even nationally (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2019).

Indonesia has legislation relating to export of glass eels that dates back to 1973; in October 2012 a new regulation came into force (Nijman 2015). The “Regulation on the Export of Glass Eels (Anguilla spp.) from the Republic of Indonesia (PP 19/2012)” stipulates that the individual mass of eels exported from Indonesia must equal or be larger than 150 g, and so despite its title, encompasses glass eels, elvers, and some yellow eels (Nijman 2015). In Vietnam Anguilla eel export is banned except for farmed eels (Gollock et al. 2018).

In 2018, a nine-year conservation and management plan for Anguillid eels in Réunion was produced (Valade et al. 2018). The plan covers the three species of eels found in this territory (A. mossambica, A. bicolor, A. marmorata) and aims to combat the impacts of poaching, fisheries, river habitat quality, and connectivity (Hanzen et al. in press).

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states (AMSs) have, since 2015, established management initiatives for anguillid eels, which includes developing policy and research (SEAFDEC 2018). In 2016, a workshop was held by the Inland Fishery Resources Development and Management Department/South Asian Fisheries Development Center (IFRDMD/SEAFDEC). This was held to address issues on data collection for eels in Southeast Asia, exchange existing fisheries information, and discuss recommendations to improve the sustainability of anguillid eel fisheries across this range (SEAFDEC 2016). A number of recommendations were suggested, which included harmonising data collection methods, and strengthening regulations on eel trade (SEAFDEC 2016). More recent workshops held by SEAFDEC have taken place in 2019, on both “Statistics of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” and “Aquaculture of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” (SEAFDEC 2019).

A scientific meeting on the “3rd International Symposium on the Tropical Eels Genus Anguilla (ISTEGA)” was held in Manado, North Sulawesi, Indonesia, from 1–3 August 2019. The international symposium held by the Indonesian Society of Tropical Eels (ISTES) and supported by the Indonesian Institute of Science as Indonesian Scientific Authority, and two national universities: Sam Ratulangi University of North Sulaewesi, and Tadulako University of Central Sulawesi. The theme of the 3rd ISTEGA 2019 was “science, conservation, and management of the tropical eel genus Anguilla for sustainable use”.

In South Africa in 1994, the River Health Programme (RHP) was established to monitor the health and ecosystem services provided by riverine habitats and, where necessary, establish protected areas to rejuvenate ecosystems and minimise human impacts (River Health Programme 2003). Native Anguilla spp. are to be included in the South African National Biodiversity Institute (SANBI) National Biodiversity Assessment (NBA) 2018 (Skowno et al. 2019). This species is also likely to benefit from plans to enhance downstream river connectivity by linking adjoining sub-catchments in South Africa in an attempt to aid migration (Rivers-Moore et al. 2011). Eels and eel pathways / migratory routes are also implicit in the Environmental Water Requirement (EWR) and Resource Directed Measures (RDM) methods in South Africa.

As there is little information regarding the population status of this species, it is clear that more research is needed to determine distribution, harvest levels, abundance trends, as well as information on plausible threats. It will be necessary for management and policy to be developed appropriately.

rationale:
Anguilla mossambica is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

Anguilla mossambica is found in fresh and saline water habitats of East Africa, Madagascar and other West Indian Ocean island chains. Documented threats to this species include barriers to migration (Mafuca and Bills 2012), parasites (Sasal et al. 2008, Weyl et al. 2013, McHugh et al. 2017), and the growing exploitation of this species in Madagascar and South Africa, for export to Asia and Europe (Robinet et al. 2008, Gollock et al. 2018). In KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, a decline in range of ~50% over three generations (30 years) has been estimated in some rivers in the province (C. Hanzen unpub. data). Elsewhere in South Africa, there is anecdotal evidence of declines in the Eerste River catchment in False Bay due to poor water quality, and the Rietvlei-Diep system in Table Bay where recent records have only been of dead A. marmorata individuals with visible lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). In Réunion Island, this species occurs frequently in some rivers, whereas in Mayotte, A. mossambica are considered scarce (Valade et al. 2018, DEAL and OCEA 2019). Dam construction has also thought to have led to declines in Tanzania (Tamatamah 2012). In the Cahora Bassa Lake, Mozambique, eels (A. marmorata, A. mossambica, and A. bengalensis) were found to be absent where historical studies had reported them as extant prior to dam construction (Mafuca and Bills 2012).

If observed range declines in some areas are reflected in other regions across the distribution of this species, there would be significant cause for concern. This, coupled with growing interest and demand for this species for farming and consumption, has led to A. mossambica being assessed as Near Threatened (NT). The listing for this species is based on inference from limited data across a small range and it is therefore strongly advised that monitoring for this species be conducted to better determine population status. As with all anguillids, co-ordination of the management across this species’ range will also be pivotal in conserving the population.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th of November, 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

In South Africa this species inhabits a broad ecological niche, being found in rivers from the headwater to lower reaches (Lin et al. 2012, 2015; Kadye and Booth 2019). Similar to other anguillids, Anguilla mossambica is catadromous, whereby a proportion of the growth phase (yellow eel) reside in freshwater and the other remaining in sea, coastal, or brackish habitats (Tsukamoto 1998, Lin et al. 2015). Elvers in the Eastern Cape, South Africa arrive in considerably higher numbers in the summer (November/December) than during the winter (June/July) or spring months (Wasserman et al. 2012). Although yellow eels are usually fairly sedentary, otolith microchemistry suggests that some individuals in South Africa are inter-habitat migrants that move between freshwater and saline habitats (Lin et al. 2012). In a later study using otolith Sr:Ca ratios, Lin et al. (2015) found 16.7% (n = 5) of individuals in the Maningory River, Madagascar, to exhibit freshwater residency, and 13.3% to be habitat-shifters (n = 4).

Females can attain lengths of up to 120 cm and are generally longer and heavier than males (Froese and Pauly 2011). This species is thought to remain in the yellow stage for 8–18 years before metamorphosing into the silver stage, prior to beginning the spawning migration (McEwan and Hecht 1984, Bruton et al. 1987 in Lin et al. 2012, 2015).

It has been suggested that spawning of this species occurs continuously between June and November in an area north-east of Madagascar and west of the Mascerene Ridge in the Indian Ocean (Robinet et al. 2008). The age of leptocephali increases as they are found further south of the proposed spawning area and it is suggested that individuals are transported by the South Equatorial Current (SEC) (Réveillac et al. 2009b). The present continental range suggests a migration of 1,000 to 2,000 km from the proposed spawning area (Réveillac et al. 2009b). Of the three species that inhabit the Malagasy area (A. mossambica, A. marmorata and A. bicolor), A. mossambica have the slowest otolith growth rate due to its southernmost distribution (Robinet et al. 2008).

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla mossambica, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are potentially less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments.

Barriers to migration appear to be problematic in Mozambique and Zimbabwe with dams such as the Cahora Bassa and Kariba dams preventing migration (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Mafuca and Bills 2012). A study investigating fish diversity in the Cahora Bassa Lake, found eels (A. marmorata, A. mossambica, and A. bengalensis) to be absent (Mafuca and Bills 2012). Historic studies had previously reported these species in this area prior to the construction of the Cahora Bassa Dam (Mafuca and Bills 2012). However, in both the Sundays River (Wasserman et al. 2011) and Baakens River (Muller et al. 2015) in South Africa, A. mossambica was found upstream of the obstructions, and in both studies was the only species able to transverse the weirs.

In South Africa, poor water quality is anecdotally suggested to have caused eel species to become rare in some localities, such as the False Bay catchments, and few specimens remaining in this area have been observed to have severe skin lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Non-native species now found in many systems in South Africa, such as the predatory bass (Micropterus spp.) and catfish (Clarias spp.), may also have contributed to the decline (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

Fisheries for eels based in Madagascar, Mozambique, and South Africa appear to be increasing, and over the last 15 years, glass eels have been increasingly exported directly from Madagascar to East Asia (Robinet et al. 2008, Gollock et al. 2018). There are also concerns over illegal fishing and trade in the region (see Use and Trade). Weyl et al. (2013) cautioned that the trade of live A. mossambica may result in parasitic introductions into other regions, as a result of its rich parasitic fauna. In the Eastern Cape of South Africa this species is particularly vulnerable to a parasitic gill worm (Pseudodactylogyrus anguillae) (Parker et al. 2011, McHugh et al. 2017). This parasite has been shown to cause damage to gills resulting in impaired respiration (McHugh et al. 2017). Under aquaculture conditions, where fish are kept in high numbers, infection has led to mortalities (McHugh et al. 2017). Parasitic infection by the invasive swim bladder nematode Anguillicola crassus has also been observed in A. mossambica, A. bicolor and A. marmorata from Reunion (Sasal et al. 2008). Two A. marmorata (n = 80), one A. bicolor (n = 23) and one A. mossambica (n = 15) were infected (Sasal et al. 2008). While the infection prevalence was low in these samples, this parasite is known to spread extremely quickly (Kirk 2003).

Climate change has been proposed to play a role in fluctuations of abundance in anguillid species – particularly larval transport and glass eel recruitment – however, our knowledge of these processes, and the scale of their influence, if any, is very limited (Jacoby et al. 2015).
population:
There is little quantitative information available to infer the population status of Anguilla mossambica. It is reasonable to assume that there will have been some effects as a result of the identified threats, although considerably more information would be necessary to determine accurate estimates and associated changes.

A study investigating niche patterns in native and non-native fish within The Great Fish River (South Africa) described A. mossambica as having broad environmental niches and being widespread (Kadye and Booth 2019), which is similar to what has been found in the Sundays River, Eastern Cape (Wassermann et al. 2012). In a study of 4099 glass eels sampled between April 2005 and February 2006 from rivers in Reunion, Mauritius, Mayotte, and Madagascar, 3790 A. mossambica, 246 A. marmorata, and 63 A. bicolor were identifiable (Réveillac et al. 2009a), indicating the latter was a small proportion of the recruitment to these islands at the time.

Other recent monitoring data has been collected from South Africa between 2015 and 2019, predominantly in KwaZulu-Natal (C. Hanzen unpub. data.). A comparison of historical (Scott et al. 2006, GBIF 2018) and current data from the samples collected across this province was carried out. Using this method, the decline in extent of occurrence (EOO) was 51% over three generation lengths, and 59% over the full time series (1959-2019). These records indicate a decline in distribution – and very likely abundance – of this species in some rivers of KwaZulu-Natal. This pattern, if reflected in other areas across the range of this species, would be significant cause for concern.

In some areas in South Africa, such as the Eerste River catchment in False Bay, eels were historically considered a problem species, and recruiting elvers caused blockages in irrigation pumps (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Since the 1970s, eels are no longer common in False Bay catchments; this has been suggested to be due to poor water quality (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). In Tanzania, the decline in native eels (A. bengalensis and A. mossambica) is thought to have begun in the 1980s, as a result of dam construction (Tamatamah 2012). Fishing surveys carried out over the past decade only found a few individual eels in comparison to pre-impoundment fish studies (Tamatamah 2012). A. marmorata and A. mossambica once occurred in the Rietvlei-Diep system in Table Bay, although recent records have only been of dead A. marmorata individuals with visible lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

In Réunion, A. mossambica, as well as other recruiting anguillid eels (A. bengalensis, A. marmorata and A. bicolor), are classified as ‘Critically Endangered’ under the regional Red List (Fricke et al. 2009). Listed threats include fisheries (target species and bycatch), habitat loss, construction of barriers to migration, and parasites (Fricke et al. 2009).

Anguilla mossambica yellow eels occur frequently in some rivers of Réunion Island (Valade et al. 2018). The size structure of the population in these areas indicate high mortality, and therefore rivers may produce few silver eels (DEAL and OCEA 2019). In Mayotte, A. mossambica are considered scarce (OCEA 2014).
range:
This species is endemic to countries bordering the southwest Indian Ocean. Along the east coast of Africa, Anguilla mossambica is found in rivers from Kenya south to Table Bay (South Africa), also found on Madagascar and other western Indian Ocean islands (Mascarene: Réunion and Mauritius Islands, Comoros: Mayotte Island and the Seychelles: Mahé and Praslin Islands). Anguilla mossambica, is also the most common anguillid species in the Eastern Cape, South Africa and in eastern Madagascar (Robinet et al. 2008).

Spawning is thought to occur in an area north-east of Madagascar and west of the Mascerene Ridge in the Indian Ocean (Robinet et al. 2008).
useTrade:
