The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, The Republic of Korea (hereafter South Korea) and mainland China (hereafter China). A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global production of Anguilla has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 tonnes (t)), with China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). Being a plain-coloured eel, there has been an increase in interest in A. mossambica to stock farms in East Asia and elsewhere from 2010 onwards (after A. anguilla was listed in CITES Appendix II in 2009 and the EU banned all trade in A. anguilla from and to the EU), and in particular when the price of A. japonica glass eels increased dramatically due to shortages in 2011–2013.

According to East Asian Customs data, the first known records of imports of live glass eels into Asia from Africa are from 2005, and between 2008 and 2017 East Asian countries/territories imported ~14 t of live eel fry for farming (glass eels and larger juveniles) from Africa (99% from Madagascar). Live eel fry imports from Madagascar (believed to be mainly composed of A. mossambica) reached a peak of 5.6 t in 2013, after which they dropped to less than 600 kg in 2014 and 2015, with no imports recorded in 2016–2017. South Korea reported farming input 0.5 t of A. mossambica in 2012–2013 (Gollock et al. 2018); South Korea tried farming A. mossambica and A. bicolor when the price of A. japonica glass eels increased dramatically due to their shortage during 2011–2013, most of which was reportedly unsuccessful (Fan and Qin 2016, Back and Park 2017).

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. 

Anguilla mossambica is found in subsistence and commercial fisheries and in international trade, however as its range overlaps with many other anguillids, species specific data is very limited. No country from the species’ range has reported eel catch or farming data to FAO, however in recent years there has been a reported increase in interest in commercial harvesting of eels (all life stages) from South Africa, Mozambique and Madagascar, with a focus on A. mossambica for export to Europe and Asia. Illegal fishing and trade of glass eels has been reported from the region, and this has been linked to several applications for setting up eel farms in South Africa mainly using A. mossambica imported from Madagascar, all of which have been rejected by national authorities over concerns of disease, introduced parasites and population status (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). An increase in investment into fisheries and farming of eels in Madagascar and Mauritius, in particular of A. mossambica, has been reported over the last decade (FIS 2010, Farm Africa 2015) and Malagasy eel farmers are advertising their products on B2B marketplaces/trade platforms such as Alibaba. There has also recently been a proposal to farm A. mossambica in aquaculture facilities in Michigan, USA (Wyam-Grothem et al. 2018).

International trade in Anguilla commodities is reported from A. mossambica range states, however, the species composition of shipments is unknown and could contain many different Anguilla species including A. marmorata, A. bengalensis and A. bicolor. According to UN Comtrade, Madagascar, South Africa, Tanzania and Mauritius exported Anguilla commodities between 2008 and 2017, with most exports being live and frozen eels from Madagascar (273 t) and South Africa (129 t). Exports of live eels (all life stages) from Madagascar increased gradually from 4.6 t in 2004 to 8.8 t in 2009 and then in 2010 there was a dramatic increase in exports to over 45 t. From 2011 to 2015 annual exports fluctuated between 16t and 26 t, and in 2016 and 2017 they declined again to ~11 t. Companies trading in the southern and east Africa region declare that their glass and adult live eels are A. mossambica and that they are able to differentiate between species and control harvesting as glass eel recruitment is asynchronous. However, exports to East Asia of live eels caught in Madagascar, Mozambique and South Africa have been reported to include other species (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific policies in place for Anguilla mossambica. In South Africa in 1994, the River Health Programme (RHP) was established to monitor the health and ecosystem services provided by riverine habitats and, where necessary, establish protected areas to rejuvenate ecosystems and minimise human impacts (River Health Programme 2003). In South Africa, however, there are plans to try to increase river connectivity by linking adjoining sub-catchments in an attempt to aid fish migration (Rivers-Moore et al. 2011). Eels and eel pathways / migratory routes are also implicit in the Environmental Water Requirement (EWR) and Resource Directed Measures (RDM) methods in South Africa. Native Anguilla spp. are to be included within the South African National Biodiversity Institute (SANBI) National Biodiversity Assessment (NBA) 2018 (Skowno et al. 2019).

In 2018, a nine-year conservation and management plan for anguillid eels in Réunion was produced (Valade et al. 2018). The plan covers the three species of eels found in this territory (A. mossambica, A. bicolor and A. marmorata) and aims to combat the impacts of poaching, fisheries, river habitat quality and connectivity (Hanzen et al. in press). As a French department, Réunion operates under EU regulations, including following the EU Water Framework Directive (Hanzen et al. in press). The Red List of Réunion (IUCN France et al. 2013 in Hanzen et al. in press) lists A. mossambica as Critically Endangered.

As there is little information regarding the population status of this species, it is clear that more research is needed to determine distribution, harvest levels, abundance trends, as well as information on plausible threats. It will be necessary for management and policy to be developed appropriately.

rationale:
Anguilla bengalensis is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

Anguilla bengalensis is widely distributed from east and southeast African water systems, across the Indian Ocean to mainland India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Indonesia and Malaysia, and is an occasional vagrant to the Arabian Peninsula. Although there is some evidence to suggest its range may have declined as a result of barriers to migration in various localities (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Attaala and Rubaia 2005, Tamatamah 2012, Mafuca and Bills 2012, Freyhof et al. 2015, Mzuza et al. 2017). For example, two large dams in the Zambezi (Kariba and Cahora Bassa) block the migration of elvers, posing a threat to future escapement and the spawning stock (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Mafuca and Bills 2012). Throughout India too, declines have been observed in the area of occupancy possibly as a result threats such as reduced habitat availability (Shrestha 2003, Islam 2015). The species is reported as almost absent from some regions, such as the Western Ghats (J. Freyhof pers. comm. 2014). Anguilla bengalensis is exploited for consumption and is being offered for sale on business-to-business (B2B) trade platforms, however, metrics of catch or effort are not available.

While there areno quantitative time-series data relating to declines in the species, there is some evidence indicating that both range and abundance of the species are shrinking. The species has been assessed as Near Threatened (NT); it is suspected that a reduction of close to 30% is likely to have occurred over the last 3 generations (36 years), based on reports of declines across its range. It is strongly advised that monitoring for this species be conducted to better determine population status. As with all anguillids, co-ordination of the management across this species’ range will also be pivotal for conservation.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th of November 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

Anguilla bengalensis juveniles feed on insects and other aquatic invertebrates while adults feed on fishes (including trout in the streams of the eastern highlands of Zimbabwe) and crabs (Okeyo 1998). This species inhabits various niches in river systems from quiet undisturbed areas containing mud substrate to deep water, fast-flowing rock pools of rivers (Bell-Cross and Minshull 1988). In Malaysia A. bengalensis has been found to reside in upper/mid-stream areas at higher elevation with cooler water temperatures (Arai and Kadir 2017a). Length estimates for this species range between 80–200 cm (Shrestha 2003) and Pantulu (1957) found there to be strong positive length/weight relationships. Further, a close linear relationship between fecundity and total length has been observed (Kadir et al. 2017). Total length and body weight at silvering has been found to range from 487 to 1295 mm, and 257 to 5100 g, and age at silvering has been found to range from 5.5 to 10.5 years (Chai and Arai 2018). In a study of 47 specimens from Malaysia, seaward spawning migration occurred in individuals displaying high gonadosomatic indices between April and September (Arai and Kadir 2017b). This suggests their spawning season may extend for at least six months of the year (Arai and Kadir 2017b).

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla bengalensis, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are potentially less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments.

In India and Bangladesh in particular, harvesting of this species occurs, but it is not known what impact fishing is having on the overall population. As a mottled species, A. bengalensis is perhaps less desirable to the East Asian market, where plain coloured eels are generally preferred. There is, however, a growing market for mottled eels, although to date this is mainly for A. marmorata (Shiraishi and Crook 2015). 

The Conservation Assessment and Management Plan (CAMP) report on the freshwater fishes of India (Molur and Walker 1998) declared A. bengalensis as ‘Endangered’ according to IUCN criteria. In Bangladesh, A. bengalensis was assessed as ‘Vulnerable’ resulting from population decline attributable to “habitat loss and perceived over-exploitation for export” (Islam 2015). Threats reported to be affecting this species in both localities, were damming, fishing, loss of habitat, invasive species, disease, pollution, climate change, overexploitation and domestic trade (Molur and Walker 1998, Shrestha 2003, IUCN Bangladesh 2015). In Nepal specifically, most dams do not have fish and/or eel ladders, and loss of freshwater habitat is a significant problem (Shrestha 2003).

Barriers to migration appear to be problematic in Mozambique and Zimbabwe with dams such as the Cabora Bassa and Kariba dams preventing migration (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Mafuca and Bills 2012). A study investigating fish diversity in the Cahora Bassa Lake, found eels (A. marmorata, A. mossambica, and A. bengalensis) to be absent (Mafuca and Bills 2012). Historic studies had previously reported these species in this area prior to the construction of the Cahora Bassa Dam (Mafuca and Bills 2012). In Malawi, Nkula Dam is located on the Shire River (Mzuza et al. 2017), which may limit available habitat and movement. In Tanzania, the construction of large dams is also thought to have contributed to eel declines (Tamatamah 2012) Within the Arabian region, vagrant individuals of this species are known from a single location in the Wadi Hajr river, which is dammed 3–4 km from the mouth, possibly blocking upstream access for eels (Attaala and Rubaia 2005, Freyhof et al. 2015).

In South Africa, poor water quality is anecdotally suggested to have caused eel species to become rare in some localities, such as the False Bay catchments, and few specimens remaining in this area have been observed to have severe skin lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Non-native species now found in many systems in South Africa, such as the predatory bass (Micropterus spp.) and catfish (Clarias spp.), may also have contributed to the decline (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

In 2012 a new species of parasitic nematode was discovered in the intestines of A. bengalensis collected from the freshwater bodies of Kerala State in southern Indian (Moravec et al. 2012). In some parts of India, this species has also been found to contain levels of pollutants that could be toxic to humans. In the Ganges River, West Bengal for example, A. bengalensis specimens that were caught contained methyl mercury concentrations that were higher than the limits set by the PFA (Provention of Food Adulteration Act) for human consumption (Pal et al. 2012). 

Climate change has been proposed to play a role in fluctuations of abundance in anguillid species – particularly larval transport and glass eel recruitment – however, our understanding of these processes, and the scale of their influence, if any, is very limited (Jacoby et al. 2015).
population:
There is little quantitative information available to infer the population status of Anguilla bengalensis. It is reasonable to assume that there will have been some effects as a result of the identified threats, although considerably more information would be necessary to determine accurate estimates and associated changes.

Anguilla bengalensis is the most common eel in Indian freshwater systems, and in particular in Nagaland and Assam. In 1998, this species was classified as ‘Endangered’ in India in accordance with a decline in AOO (area of occupancy) and a decline in the extent and/or quality of habitat (Molur and Walker 1998). During a systematic sampling survey carried out between 2004 and 2006 in the Periyar Tiger Reserve (a large river system in Kerala), its relative abundance was deemed 'rare' across the ten sampling locations (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010). The IUCN Red List of Bangladesh assessed A. bengalensis as ‘Vulnerable’ within its regional assessment (Islam 2015). This is due to a suspected population decline of 30% over the last ten years, resulting from habitat-loss and unsustainable exploitation (Islam 2015).

For other localities, there is limited information. There is some anecdotal evidence for localised extirpation in Africa, for example in Lake Kariba, Zimbabwe where fisherman, in 1998, reported no freshwater eel had been found since the construction of a large hydroelectric dam in 1959 (S. Watanabe pers. comm. 2014). In Manyame River, Zimbabwe, A. bengalensis was described as “formerly more numerous”, with individuals having not been collected or caught more recently, possibly indicating decline as a result of dams (Gratwicke et al. 2003). In Tanzania, the decline in native eels (A. bengalensis and A. mossambica) is thought to have begun in the 1980s, also as a result of dam construction (Tamatamah 2012). Fishing trials carried out over the past decade have only found a few individual eels in comparison to pre-impoundment fish studies (Tamatamah 2012).

In some areas in South Africa, such as the Eerste River catchment in False Bay, eels were historically considered a problem species, and recruiting elvers caused blockages in irrigation pumps (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Since the 1970s, eels are no longer common in False Bay catchments; this has been suggested to be due to poor water quality (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). In KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, river surveys for anguillid eels combined with historical distribution data found A. bengalensis not to be present in areas where they were previously extant (C. Hanzen unpub. data). Since 2000, A. marmorata and A. bengalensis have disappeared from longline sample catches in some catchments in Western Cape. One example is the Breede River, home to the invasive catfish (Clarias spp.), and so this may be a result of predation (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Similar to A. marmorata and A. mossambica, A. bengalensis may have once occurred in the Rietvlei-Diep system in Table Bay, although recent records have been of dead A. marmorata individuals with visible lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

In Réunion, A. bengalensis (listed under the redundant synonym A. labiata), as well as other recruiting anguillid eels (A. bicolor, A. marmorata and A. mossambica), are classified as ‘Critically Endangered’ under the regional Red List (Fricke et al. 2009). Listed threats include fisheries (target species and bycatch), habitat loss, construction of barriers to migration, and parasites (Fricke et al. 2009).
range:
Anguilla bengalensis is found in Pakistan, India (Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, Arunanchal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya, Orissa, Tamil Nadu, Assam, and Nagaland (Tsurang River)), Bangladesh, Nepal (Gandaki, Koshi, Karnali, Mahakali), Sri Lanka, Myanmar, South Africa (Sympatric with A. marmorata in the Western Cape), Kenya, Mozambique, Tanzania, Eswatini (Komati river system), Lake Kariba, Middle Zambezi and its larger tributaries on the plateau, Limpopo (Umzingwane River and Inyankuni Dam), Pungwe, Buzi, Upper and Lower Save/Runde systems in Zimbabwe. It is also found in Lake Malawi and its catchment area as well as the Shire River and its tributaries and the eastward flowing Athi and Tana drainages (Seegers et al. 2003). In Ethiopia A. bengalensis has been reported from the middle reaches of the Genale River catchment in the southwest of the country and is currently the only anguillid species found in the country (Golubtsov et al. 2012). An electrofishing study conducted in upper estuaries of the Seychelles, Mayotte, Mauritius, Reunion and the east coast of Madagascar recorded no A. bengalensis out of 4,172 collected eels (Robinet et al. 2008). Most recently, this species’ range has been extended to Aceh in Indonesia (Muchlisin et al. 2017), and north-western Peninsular Malaysia (Arai 2014, Arai et al. 2015, Arai and Wong 2016, Arai and Kadir 2017a,b). There are also occasional records of vagrant individuals in the Arabian Peninsula (Wadi Haj in Yemen; Ataala and Rubaia 2005).

There remains some uncertainty surrounding where freshwater eels including A. bengalensis spawn in the Indian Ocean. Indeed, compared to other species, very few leptocephali have been gathered for A. bengalensis and it is still not known whether this species has a single, or multiple spawning locations, or whether spawning location overlaps with other anguillids (see Robinet et al. 2008, Watanabe et al. 2014 for discussion).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, the Republic of Korea (also known as South Korea) and mainland China (hereafter China). A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global Anguilla production has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 tonnes (t)), with China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). According to East Asian Customs data, between 2008 and 2017 East Asian countries/territories imported ~14 t of live eel fry for farming (glass eels and larger juveniles) from Africa (99% from Madagascar) and 7.6 t from Bangladesh (all in 2014). There is, however, no information suggesting that A. bengalensis is currently used (or there are plans to use it) in eel farms in East Asia.

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. 

Anguilla bengalensis is found in subsistence and commercial fisheries and in international trade, however as its range overlaps with many other anguillids, species specific data is very limited and no catch data has been reported to FAO by any of its main African or Asian range States. Anguilla bengalensis is the most common eel in Indian inland waters and is of considerable commercial value in India and the Andaman Islands. On local markets in both India and Bangladesh A. bengalensis is only sold during the yellow or silver eel stage; live eels (greater than 100 g) of this species, originating in Bangladesh, are being offered for sale on B2B marketplaces/trade platforms. Anguilla bengalensis is harvested in small quantities (on average between one and six specimens a day per fisherman) in the Ganale Dawa river basin in Ethiopia (Abelti et al. 2014). Yellow eel bycatch in Myanmar was reported as 12 t in 2017 with 10% of this believed to be A. marmorata or A. bengalensis (SEAFDEC 2018). Other uses of the species include treatment of arthritis, piles and meningitis in India (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Chanu et al. 2014). In addition, A. bengalensis is considered a 'pristine rare ornamental species of the Himalayan drainage' often being preserved in temple ponds for religious purposes (Shrestha 2003).

International trade in Anguilla commodities is reported from much of A. bengalensis’s range, however, the species composition of shipments is unknown and could contain many different Anguilla species including A. bicolor, A. marmorata and A. mossambica. According to UN Comtrade, exports of eel commodities (live, fresh, frozen and prepared eel) from south Asian countries increased from ~1,330 t in 2008 to ~5,170 t in 2015 (however, data is incomplete and this may be an underestimate), with live (from Bangladesh) and frozen eels (from India) being the main commodities for export. Myanmar reported exports live eels in 2010, 2014 and 2016, totalling ~10,900 t, however, live eel exports in the region are known to include other non-Anguilla eel species such as Monopterus albus (Swamp Eels). Madagascar, South Africa, Tanzania and Mauritius also exported Anguilla commodities between 2008 and 2017, with most exports being live and frozen eels from Madagascar (273 t) and South Africa (129 t). Exports of live eels (all life stages) from Madagascar increased gradually from 4.6 t in 2004 to 8.8 t in 2009 and then in 2010 there was a dramatic increase in exports to over 45 t. From 2011 to 2015 annual exports fluctuated between 16t and 26 t, and in 2016 and 2017 they declined again to ~11 t. Companies trading in the southern and east Africa region declare that their glass and adult live eels are A. mossambica and that they are able to differentiate between species and control harvesting as glass eel recruitment is asynchronous, however exports to East Asia of live eels caught in Madagascar, Mozambique and South Africa have been reported to include other species (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific policies in place for Anguilla bengalensis. In South Africa in 1994, the River Health Programme (RHP) was established to monitor the health and ecosystem services provided by riverine habitats and, where necessary, establish protected areas to rejuvenate ecosystems and minimise human impacts (River Health Programme 2003). There are also plans to try and increase upstream and downstream river connectivity in South Africa, by linking adjoining sub-catchments in an attempt to aid migration (Rivers-Moore et al. 2011). Eels and eel pathways / migratory routes are also implicit in the Environmental Water Requirement (EWR) and Resource Directed Measures (RDM) methods in South Africa. Native Anguilla spp. are to be included within the South African National Biodiversity Institute (SANBI) National Biodiversity Assessment (NBA) 2018 (Skowno et al. 2019).

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states (AMSs) have, since 2015, established management initiatives for anguillid eels, which includes developing policy and research (SEAFDEC 2018). In 2016, a workshop was held by the Inland Fishery Resources Development and Management Department/South Asian Fisheries Development Center (IFRDMD/SEAFDEC). This was held to address issues on data collection for eels in Southeast Asia, exchange existing fisheries information, and discuss recommendations to improve the sustainability of anguillid eel fisheries across this range (SEAFDEC 2016). A number of recommendations were suggested, which included harmonising data collection methods, and strengthening regulations on eel trade (SEAFDEC 2016). More recent workshops held by SEAFDEC have taken place in 2019, on both “Statistics of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” and “Aquaculture of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” (SEAFDEC 2019).

A scientific meeting on the “3rd International Symposium on the Tropical Eels Genus Anguilla (ISTEGA)” was held in Manado, North Sulawesi, Indonesia, from 1–3 August 2019. The international symposium held by the Indonesian Society of Tropical Eels (ISTES) and supported by the Indonesian Institute of Science as Indonesian Scientific Authority, and two national universities: Sam Ratulangi University of North Sulaewesi, and Tadulako University of Central Sulawesi. The theme of the 3rd ISTEGA 2019 was “science, conservation, and management of the tropical eel genus Anguilla for sustainable use”.

rationale:
The Pacific Angel Shark (Squatina californica) occurs off the coast of North America from Alaska to Baja California, Mexico (including the Gulf of California), where it is associated with soft bottom habitats. It grows slowly and matures late in life (8-13 years), has an estimated generation length of 11.7-17.0 years, and produces an average of six pups per year. Based on these life history characteristics and the potential for isolation due to patchy habitat distributions and restricted movement patterns, resident stocks of Pacific Angel Shark may be vulnerable to heavy localized fishing pressure.

This species was commercially harvested in California beginning in the late 1970s. In response to a decline in landings, management measures (including a ban on nearshore gillnets and minimum size limits) significantly reduced the landings in California and these landings have stabilized at low levels over the past decade (2005-2014). In Mexico this species is still fished, and logbooks have been required in targeted shark fisheries since 2006. The population trend remains unknown, but reported landings data (2003-2015) from Baja California suggest that landings declines of >99% may occur within three generations if current trends continue. While landings data cannot be equated with population declines, fishing pressure in Mexico has likely remained relatively stable over time. Given that this species is taken in targeted elasmobranch fisheries in Mexico, and that landings have declined under stable fishing pressure, this species is globally assessed as Near Threatened, with a suspected population decline approaching 30% over three generations. In the United States, however, this species is considered Least Concern, as the threat of targeted commercial fishing has ceased, and ground fisheries along the west coast of the United States are managed.
habitat:
Pacific Angel Shark are relatively small, benthic elasmobranchs, that are commonly found in soft bottom habitats, including shallow bays and estuaries, as well as around rocky reefs and kelp forests (Feder et al. 1974, Ebert 2003). It lives in relatively shallow waters to depths of 100 m, but it is much more abundant in nearshore, coastal waters (Eschmeyer et al. 1983). They are fairly residential, restricting their movements to a small geographic area, possibly on the order of 150 ha or 375 acres, with the potential to make longer distance movements (Ebert 2003, Love 2011). For example, one Pacific Angel Shark tagged in Catalina Island was recaptured three and a half years later at Santa Cruz Island, a distance of approximately 100 km (Leet et al. 2001). They are generally quiescent during the day, often remaining buried in the sediment, but become quite active and hunt during the night (Pittenger 1984, Leet et al. 1992, 2001; Castro 2011). They appear to exhibit a high degree of site fidelity, with reports of sharks having preferred foraging and resting locations (Standora and Nelson 1977, Love 2011).

Numerous techniques of ageing and age verification have been used on Pacific Angel Shark, but none except tag-recapture have been successful at estimating their growth rates or age-specific processes (Natanson and Cailliet 1990, Cailliet et al. 1992). These tag-recapture data, however, allowed an estimate of von Bertalanffy growth and demography parameters that predicted relatively slow growth and moderate fecundity, with maturity occurring relatively late in life. Off California, males and females begin to mature between 90-100 cm total length (TL), with an average reproductive age of 8-13 years (Cailliet et al. 1992, Cortes 2002, H. Mollet unpublished data 2005). All males and females larger than 103 cm and 112 cm, respectively, are mature (Natanson and Cailliet 1986). In the Gulf of California, Pacific Angel Shark mature at a smaller size, 75.6 cm for males and 77.7 cm for females (Romero-Caicedo et al. 2016). Age at maturity of the Pacific Angel Shark in California is around 10 years, but ranges from 8 to 13 years (Natanson and Cailliet 1986, Cailliet et al. 1992). The reproductive mode of this angelshark is aplacental viviparity. Females give birth to 1-13 pups (average six) after a 10 month gestation with pupping occurring between March and June (Natanson and Cailliet 1986, Ebert 2003). Size at birth is approximately 25 cm TL (Natanson and Cailliet 1986). Maximum reported length is 152 cm TL for females and 118 cm for males (Natanson 1984), and maximum length in the Gulf of California was estimated at 99 cm TL (Romero-Caicedo et al. 2016). Maximum age is around 22-35 years (Natanson 1984, Cailliet et al. 1992, Cortes 2002, H. Mollet unpub. data 2005). Generation length is estimated to be 11.7-17.0 years (Cailliet et al. 1992, Cortes 2002, H. Mollet unpub. data 2005).
threats:
Historically, the Pacific Angel Shark was discarded at sea or used as bait, but in the 1970s a commercial fishery in California began targeting this species. A rapid increase in Pacific Angel Shark landings between 1983-1986 occurred in California (Richards 1987), leading to concern that stocks could be overexploited. Even though a minimum size was proposed for the gillnet fishery targeting both California Halibut (Paralichthys californicus) and Pacific Angel Shark, this measure proved not to be effective at reversing the declining population levels along the Santa Barbara/Ventura coast and Channel Islands areas, California (Richards 1987, Cailliet et al. 1993). Additionally, it was observed that declines in landings were occurring prior to the implementation of these management strategies indicating the over-exploitation of the species within the region (Leet et al. 2001).

In Mexico this species is caught in fisheries targeting elasmobranchs. Fishing effort in Mexico is challenging to quantify, as some fishers hold licenses but are inactive, while others may share a single license among multiple vessels (Sosa-Nishizaki, pers. comm. 2016). This species is now absent from regions in Baja California Sur where it was historically found in catches (Laguna San Ignacio and Bahia Magdalena), and there is also evidence for depensation in this region (Ramirez-Amaro et al. 2013).
population:
No information on stock size or structure has been documented for the species. However, three genetically distinct populations have been described off of the west coast of the United States within the California Channel Islands (Northern Channel Islands, Southern Channel Island, and along the mainland) that are most likely separated by deepwater channels (Gaida 1997). It has also been suggested that populations on the Pacific side of Baja California are distinct from that of the Gulf of California (Ebert 2003). Currently, support for these possibly divergent lineages has not been provided and the existence of distinct genetic subpopulations from throughout the eastern Pacific distribution of the species has not been assessed. Because of its rather limited geographical range and evidence of only limited exchange among regional stocks within this range, resident stocks near large population centres may be particularly vulnerable to heavy localized fishing pressure.

This species was commercially fished in California beginning in the late 1970s. In 1977 landings totalled 0.15 metric tones (mt), and during the expansion phase of the commercial fishery for this species, landings rose dramatically to 117 mt in 1981, and to 277 mt in 1984. Landings peaked and began to decline from 426 mt in 1987 to 112 mt in 1990. While declines were observed around this time, these declines were not strictly a reflection of population declines, as a minimum size limit was proposed in 1987 and became law in 1989 (Leet et al. 2001). In 1991, a 50% decline in effort occurred in response to bans on gill and trammel nets in California. This also had a dramatic effect on the landings, which dropped to 8.62 mt in 1995 and 8.16 mt in 1997, but then increased to 15 and 24 mt in 1997 and 1999, respectively. At the same time that landings were dropping in California, a Mexican gillnet fishery began targeting Pacific Angel Shark in 1997, with estimated landings of close to 163 mt in 1999 (Leet et al. 2001). More recently, landings in California have stabilized at around 6.81 to 4.04 mt from 2005 to 2014 (California Department of Fish and Wildlife 2000-2014).

Little is known about the effect of fisheries on the population of the Pacific Angel Shark in Mexico, but landings in some areas have declined and researchers have detected changes in size composition. Fisher interviews conducted along the coast of Baja California also suggest that catches have declined over time (Sergio Ramirez, pers. comm., 2 December 2016). Logbook data from the demersal trawl fleet in San Felipe, Baja California report catches of 663 to 6,375 kg from 2009-2013. Data on landed weight of the Pacific Angel Shark from Baja California reported to Bahia de Los Angeles are available over twelve years (2003-2015; CONAPESCA). These data suggest that landings have declined steadily from a peak of 83,778 kg in 2012 to 16,173 kg in 2015, representing a decline in landings of >99% over three generations (2003-2057) if fishing continues at the same rate (CONAPESCA). Changes in Mexican fishing effort are difficult to detect, but effort is estimated to be relatively stable. Species-specific landings data are also available for Sonora state, but no trends in landings are yet clear (CONAPESCA).

A survey of landings of artisanal fishers targeting elasmobranchs was conducted in Sonora, Mexico (Gulf of California) from 1998-1999. Pacific Angel Shark constituted 1.3% of the total chondrichthyan landings, increasing to 3.3% in winter, which was considered "a notable contribution" by the authors (Bizzarro et al. 2009a). Surveys were also conducted on the Gulf of California side of the Baja peninsular and found Pacific Angel Shark to constitute 11.6% of the total chondrichthyan landings (Bizzarro et al. 2009b). Along the Pacific coast of the Baja peninsula, an artisanal fishing community survey conducted between 2006 and 2008, determined that this species made up 1.86% of the total elasmobranch landings (Cartamil et al. 2011). In a survey focusing on the Pacific coast of Baja California Sur, this species was found to make up 5.6% of the elasmobranch catch (a catch-per-unit-effort of 1.82 individuals per vessel per trip; Ramirez-Amaro et al. 2013).
range: The Pacific Angel Shark occurs off the coast of North America from Alaska to the tip of Baja California, Mexico (including the Gulf of California), and is particularly abundant in central and southern California (United States) waters, especially off the coast of Santa Barbara (Natanson and Cailliet 1986, 1990; Leet et al. 1992, 2001) and off El Barril, Baja California (Castro 2005). It was previously reported that the South Pacific Angel Shark (Squatina armata) was a possible synonym of this species, but this has largely been confirmed to be a separate species (Stelbrink et al. 2010). Further evidence to support that Pacific Angel Shark does not occur in Chile was provided in a recent checklist for elasmobranchs in Chilean waters, where South Pacific Angel Shark but not Pacific Angel Shark was reported to occur (Bustamante et al. 2014).
useTrade: This species is valued for its meat.
conservationActions:
The northeast Pacific population of the Pacific Angel Shark appears to have stabilized, at least in the waters of California. A ban on gillnet fisheries that targeted the California Halibut (Paralichthys californicus) was voted into law by Californians in 1990 (Proposition 132). Through this ban, the fishery is indirectly regulated (Cailliet et al. 1992, Leet et al. 1992). Additionally, a minimum retention size limit became law in 1989, which decreased the juvenile catch and overall harvest on exploited stocks. Drift gillnet fisheries are also prohibited off the coast of Washington state.

Further north, along the United States west coast (Washington, Oregon and California), ground fisheries are managed by a federal Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Although this species is not a focal species of the plan, and no species-specific data on the Pacific Angel Shark will be collected, other chondrichthyans are being managed under this program.

In Mexico, some fisheries are required to record species-specific data under the category of "angelito" (Pacific Angel Shark) in logbooks. While not all fisheries have established a logbook system, in fisheries targeted sharks they have been required since 2006. Additionally, in 2012 Mexico implemented a seasonal fishing closure from May 31 to July 31 for fisheries targeting elasmobranchs on the Pacific Coast.

rationale: The Maculate Panray (Zanobatus maculatus) is a small (to 30 cm total length) ray that occurs in the Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic Oceans ranging from Côte d'Ivoire to Angola. It occurs in shallow coastal waters to a depth of 30 m. This species is taken as incidental catch in demersal trawl, set net, and trammel net fisheries across its range. Panrays have low economic value and while locally consumed in some countries (e.g., Nigeria), they are discarded in others and not utilized because even though their meat is edible, they are hard to skin and small in size (e.g., Gabon). They are often landed still alive and therefore are likely to have high post-release survival. There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across most of the range of this species. There are few records of this species despite ongoing fisheries monitoring surveys, however, this might reflect a high level of discards in both artisanal and industrial fisheries as well as identification challenges with its congener, the Striped Panray (Z. schoenleinii). The Maculate Panray is a small species and may be relatively biologically productive compared to larger sharks and rays, thus able to sustain higher levels of exploitation. However, considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its lack of refuge at depth, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Maculate Panray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (17 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: The Maculate Panray is demersal on sandy and muddy substrates in shallow coastal waters to 30 m depth (Last et al. 2016, Séret 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 36 cm total length (TL). Little else is known of its biology. There is no information on this species' age-at-maturity and maximum age, hence, generation length was inferred based on data for the Chinese Fanray (Platyrhina sinensis). The Chinese Fanray has an age-at-maturity of three years and a maximum age of 12 years and, thus, a generation length of 7.5 years (Kume et al. 2008). The Chinese Fanray has a larger maximum size than the Maculate Panray (50 cm vs 36 cm TL), and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred to be 5.5 years for the Maculate Panray.
threats:
The Maculate Panray is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is likely discarded or retained for human consumption. It is often landed alive and therefore, is likely to have high post-release survival (R.W. Jabado unpubl. data 2020).

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West African coastal waters and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (e.g., False Shark Ray (Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis) from the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin and the African Wedgefish (Rhynchobatus luebberti) from the Sine-Saloum Delta) (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many important commercial coastal, demersal, and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977­–2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of demersal resources and deep sea pelagic catches of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 (mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch) (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region, which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed more than 40% of the reported legal catch (Pauly and Zeller 2016).

The shallow, inshore soft-substrate habitats of this species are threatened by habitat loss and environmental degradation (Stobutzki et al. 2006, White and Sommerville 2010, Jabado et al. 2017). Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation, conversion of coastal lagoons and mangrove deforestation for agriculture (e.g., rice and salt) and aquaculture (e.g., shrimp, fish culture, and fish production); extensive oil and gas exploration, drilling, and production; the effects of rapid urban expansion from growing coastal populations and unplanned tourism development; pollution (unregulated sewage effluents, agricultural runoff, hydrocarbon, and heavy metals); sedimentation and siltation; and changes to the hydrological cycle from the building of dams leading to dramatic levels of habitat loss evident across the region (GCLME 2006, FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016). In West Africa, mangroves are harvested for fuel wood, construction timber, and charcoal with an overall mangrove forest area decline of up to 70% in some countries over the last 20 years with the highest loses recorded from Côte d'Ivoire (67%), Liberia (65%), Guinea (60%), Sierra Leone (40%), and Ghana (30%) (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016, CCLME 2016).
population:
There are no species-specific time-series data available for the Maculate Panray that can be used to estimate population reduction. Despite the lack of species-specific data, there are a number of relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with high increases in the Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic regions (Anticamara et al. 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018, Watson et al. 2013).

First, in the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic, both catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark fishing countries of Nigeria and Ghana, and while population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, this does indicate rising fishing pressure. The greatest fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries in the whole of Africa were the West African countries of Nigeria (13,238 t), Senegal (10,757 t), and Ghana (1,902 t) (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Nevertheless, given the lack of reporting in artisanal fisheries and the large number of nations fishing in African waters, actual landings are likely to be much higher. Overall, across the West Africa region, the average elasmobranch catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) has decreased by 71% over 1970–2015. The average elasmobranch CPUE in the region was 0.68 t/kW in 1970 and declined to 0.20 t/kW by 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch landings have increased by more than 2.5 times (250%) from 1970 to 2015. Average elasmobranch landings in the region was 3,312 t in 1970 and increased to 8,329 t in 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). This implies a dramatic increase in fishing effort as the elasmobranch landings volume has increased but the CPUE has decreased. Within countries, landings have historically increased but have peaked and begun to decline in recent years. More specifically, in Cameroon, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1960s but showed a 96% decline over the years from 2007 to 2016. Historically, landings quickly rose from 391 t in 1950 to 2,881 t in 1974 then showed a decline to 712 t in 1986 (75% decline). Elasmobranch landings then rose to a peak of 7,516 t in 2007 followed by a steep decline to 303 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Nigeria, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1970s but showed a 19% decline over the years from 2010 to 2016. Historically, landings quickly rose from 2,419 t in 1950 to 25,144 t in 1980 then rose to a peak of 31,273 t in 2010 followed by a fluctuating decline to 25,396 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has remained stable during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020).

Second, contemporary patterns of landings indicate that this species is still relatively abundant across its range. The pattern of retention and discarding of panrays varies between countries across this region and therefore species occurrence or absence in landings need to be carefully considered at the national scale. The Maculate Panray has only been recently described and records are likely to be aggregated with, and undifferentiated from, the Striped Panray (Zanobatus schoenleinii). In fact, records across its known range are limited despite ongoing fisheries monitoring surveys investigating shark and ray landings. However, this is also likely due to discard patterns since this species is very small, difficult to skin, and therefore unlikely to be retained for local consumption. In Western Ghana, approximately 10 individuals were landed per day at sites visited during surveys in 2019 and 2020, representing 7% of ray landings, although these records are likely aggregated with Striped Panray (Zanobatus schoenleinii) records (I. Seidu unpubl. data 2020). It has not been detected in recent surveys in Côte d'Ivoire during landing site surveys in 2019; in Nigeria during research surveys; in Cameroon in over two years of landing site surveys (although there are records of the Striped Panray there); in the Republic of the Congo from surveys between January and December 2019; and from Angola during opportunistic landing site surveys in 2018 (P. Doherty, K. Metcalfe, A.L. Soares, A. Tamo, A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). This lack of records could either be due to biogeographic absence, its poorly known status (the species was only described in 2016), or species depletion, although the latter seems unlikely given the small size of the species and the low interest in its utilization. Therefore, the real reason for this lack of records cannot be determined at this point and further monitoring is warranted. In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, panrays are relatively commonly captured, and they are also infrequently recorded in artisanal fisheries landings operating in Mayumba using demersal-set gillnets, but these records might also be aggregated with the Striped Panray which are mostly discarded alive (G. De Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020).

Overall, there are few data from most countries in the region, likely reflecting a high level of discards in both industrial and artisanal fisheries. Considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its lack of refuge at depth, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Maculate Panray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (17 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
range: The Maculate Panray is found in the Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic Oceans from Côte d'Ivoire to Angola (Last et al. 2016, Séret 2016). It has not been recorded from São Tomé and Príncipe (Wirtz et al. 2007).
useTrade: Information on the use and trade of the Maculate Panray is not available. However, its congener, the Striped Panray (Zanobatus schoenleinii) is either discarded or retained as utilized bycatch across its range. In some countries like The Gambia, it is often found discarded on the beach and not utilized because even though their meat is edible, it is small and difficult to skin (Ishihara and Kimoto 2006, Last et al. 2016, Moore et al. 2019). However, in Mauritania, it is processed (salted and dried) for export to Nigeria where it is used for local consumption (R.W. Jabado unpubl. data 2020). In Senegal, interviews with fishers indicate that the Striped Panray is always landed because its meat is in demand. It is considered tender and is consumed fresh or dried and salted and more expensive than other species of rays (e.g., Fontitrygon spp.) (L. Badji unpubl. data 2020). Considering the smaller size of the Maculate Panray, it is likely that it is mostly discarded across its range.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across its range have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the Maculate Panray are generally unmanaged throughout large parts of the species’ range and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future. Countries such as Gabon, the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are in the process of expanding their marine protected areas coverage, however, financial and technical support will be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
The African Brown Skate (Raja parva) is a small (to at least 63 cm total length) skate found in the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic Ocean ranging from Mauritania to Angola. It is demersal on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 10–300 m. The species is taken as bycatch in artisanal and industrial fisheries operating trawl, longline, and net gears, and similar to other skates in the region, is either retained for consumption or discarded.

Currently, there are a number of European and Chinese distant-water vessels using trawls and longlines to target demersal fish and shrimp species that reach the depth limit of this species, especially in the northern part of its range in Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia, and Guinea-Bissau. While species-specific data are not available, declines in landings of combined skates and rays have been documented in the northern portion of its range. However, species-specific population trend data from relative abundance in Mauritania reveal a stable trend and no major population reductions over the past three generation lengths (20 years). This species seems to prefer shallow water habitats and is frequently reported in artisanal fisheries monitoring across its range. However, little information is available on fishing pressure south through the Gulf of Guinea. In this region, the sea floor is reported to be not trawlable at depths of 75–200 m and demersal stocks in these waters therefore reportedly remain unexploited which might provide a refuge for this species from trawl fisheries throughout the central and southern parts of its range.

Further information is urgently needed to determine the level of impact on this species, particularly as deep-water fisheries expand in response to declining fish stocks in heavily exploited coastal areas. Skate species, including the African Brown Skate, are susceptible to overfishing due to their relatively low biological productivity. However, this species may have some refuge from fishing pressure across some of its range. Considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its likely preference for shallow water habitats, stable trends in parts of its range, and noted declines in landings of rays across its range, it is suspected that the African Brown Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (20 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
habitat: The African Brown Skate is demersal on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 10–300 m (Last and Séret 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 63 cm total length (TL) with males mature at ~32–37 cm TL (Last and Séret 2016, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous with a size-at-birth of ~9 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Little else is known of its biology. There is no information on this species' age-at-maturity and maximum age, hence, generation length was inferred based on age parameters for the Rough Skate (Raja radula). The Rough Skate has an age-at-maturity of 6 years and a maximum age of 12 years, resulting in a generation length of 9 years (Kadri et al. 2013). The African Brown Skate is smaller than the Rough Skate (63 cm vs 80 cm TL), and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred to be 6.5 years for the African Brown Skate.
threats:
The African Brown Skate is likely taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with mainly trawl, and multiple fishing gears including gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is retained for human consumption. Information on discards and associated mortality is not available and although there is no direct measure of mortality due to fishing for the African Brown Skate, the descriptions below indicate an increasing threat to this species.

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). This has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West Africa and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many commercial demersal and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977 to 2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 (mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch) (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

There are currently three active mixed fishery bilateral agreements between the European Union and the West African nations of Morocco, Mauritania, and Guinea-Bissau (European Commission 2020). These agreements, known as Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (SFPAs) involve payments to third party countries in exchange for access to marine resources and sectorial support aimed at promoting sustainable fisheries development in the partner countries. Under SFPAs, there are a number of European distant-water industrial vessels using demersal trawls to capture deep-water shrimps at depths of 150–850 m in Guinea-Bissau (Sobrino et al. 2017). As part of their tuna SFPA, The Gambia also allows three deep-water demersal trawls to fish for hake species at depths of 150–850 m (European Commission 2020). 

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region and which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world, and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed more than 40% of the reported legal catch (Pauly and Zeller 2016).
population:
Species-specific population trend data are available from relative abundance from Mauritania (Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches, unpubl. data 2020). The trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths (20 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information). The trend analysis of standardized abundance estimates from demersal experimental trawl surveys conducted along coast of Mauritania (1982–2018) revealed an annual rate of reduction of 4.8%, consistent with an estimated median increase of 10.4% over three generation lengths (20 years), with the highest probability of no major reductions in population over three generation lengths (20 years).

Elsewhere across the species range, there are no species-specific time-series data available that can be used to estimate population reduction. Despite the lack of species-specific data, there are a number of relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. There is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase substantially in the Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic regions (Anticamara et al. 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018, Watson et al. 2013).

Contemporary patterns of landings indicate that this species is still relatively abundant across its range. Compared to other species of skates (family Rajidae) that also occur in this region and which have largely gone undetected, the occurrence of this species in artisanal catches likely reflects its preference for shallow water habitats across its range. Between 2004–2011, this species was recorded during extensive landing site surveys in all countries (Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia, Guinea, and Guinea-Bissau) except Cape Verde and Sierra Leone (as Brown Skate (Raja miraletus)) and was common (Diop and Dossa 2011). Demersal trawl surveys in 2005 off the coast of Mauritania and Senegal indicated that this was one of the most common shark and ray species captured (as Brown Skate) (Gulyugin et al. 2006). In Mauritania, landings of all skates from the Spanish trawl fishery for black hake operating in depths of 140–750 m, including the African Brown Skate, fell from 18 t in 1992 to 9 t in 2001 (Fernández et al. 2005). This would equate to a 75% population reduction over the past three generation lengths (20 years), at fishing locations, although this represents only a small portion of its northern range. Furthermore, it is important to note that these declines could be attributed to changes in the fishing fleet, economics, and likely overexploitation of both the target and bycatch species (Fernández et al. 2005). 

Annual fisheries statistics from the Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches collected since 2010, indicate that this species is not recorded in artisanal fisheries which may indicate that it is discarded in these fisheries (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). However, it is frequently recorded from shark and ray processing sites in northern Mauritania (R.W. Jabado unpubl. data 2020). In The Gambia, only two individuals were recorded during landing site surveys conducted annually between 2010–2018 (Moore et al. 2019). It was the most common ray species based on weight from scientific demersal trawl surveys conducted in Guinea-Bissau (G.H.L. Leurs, unpubl. data 2020). It was also recorded in trawl surveys undertaken in Guinea from 1985 to 2012 (as Raja miraletus) (Camara et al. 2016). Cruise reports from demersal trawl surveys in Togo in 1983–1984 indicate up to 36 individuals were captured per 30 minute set representing up to 1.8% of catches (Lhomme 1984, 1985). This species was listed in cruise reports from the "Dr. Fridtjof Nansen" trawl surveys with up to 341 individuals representing 7.7% of catches in one haul off Nigeria and Cameroon in 2004, and 101 individuals representing 1.2% of catches in one haul captured in Angola in 2012 (Krakstad et al. 2004, Krakstad et al. 2012). In Nigeria, it was reported as one of the most common species caught as bycatch on commercial shrimp trawlers and research trawl surveys between 1970–1980 (Ajayi and Adeyato 1982). THere, it remains relatively common and is still recorded through regular fisheries monitoring and research trawl surveys (mostly at <50 m depth) (A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, this species represented 80.9% of ray catches in 2018 and 73.1% of ray catches in 2019 along with the Biscuit Skate (Raja straeleni) while there were no records of this species from the artisanal fisheries operating in Mayumba using demersal-set gillnets (G. De Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). Landing sites surveys in Western Ghana in 2019 and 2020 indicate that this species represents 27% of ray landings (I. Seidu unpubl. data 2020). In Cameroon, this species represents 0.5% of all sharks and rays recorded during landing site surveys in 2019 and 2020 (A. Tamo unpubl. data 2020). In the Republic of the Congo, this species was very common with 521 individuals recorded during landing site surveys from January 2019 to December 2019 (P. Doherty unpubl. data 2020). In Angola, four individuals were recorded during opportunistic landing site surveys in 2018 (A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020). However, this species has not been detected in landing site surveys in 2019 in the Bijagos Archipelago, Guinea-Bissau and in Côte d'Ivoire (G.H.L. Leurs and K. Metcalfe, unpubl. data 2020). 

Many trawl fisheries operate throughout most of this species' range, especially in Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia, and Guinea. Little information is available on fishing pressure from industrial fisheries throughout the rest of its range (south through the Gulf of Guinea). It is reported that the sea floor is not trawlable at depths greater than 75 m in the Gulf of Guinea, and demersal stocks in offshore waters (i.e., 75–200 m) therefore remain under-exploited (Williams 1968, Martos et al. 1991, Mensah and Quaatey 2002). However, this species may be susceptible to fisheries operating further offshore and in deeper waters, especially as deep-water fisheries expand in response to declining fish stocks in heavily exploited coastal areas. 

Although little information is available on fisheries operating in the central and southern parts of the range of the African Brown Skate, some depths remain unexploited which provide a refuge for this species from trawl fisheries. However, further information on fisheries operating in the Gulf of Guinea is urgently needed to determine the level of impact on this species, particularly as deep-water fisheries expand. Considering the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its likely preference for shallow water habitats, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the African Brown Skate has undergone a population reduction of 20-29% over the past three generation lengths (20 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
range: The African Brown Skate is found in the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic Ocea from Mauritania to Angola (Last and Séret 2016). It has not been recorded from the Cape Verde Archipelago or São Tomé and Príncipe (Wirtz et al. 2007, Wirtz et al. 2013).
useTrade: <span lang="EN-CA">The African Brown Skate is utilized for its meat which is consumed fresh across many coastal communities in the region as an important source of protein. It is also dried or dried and smoked and exported across West Africa to supply countries such as Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria, Mali, and Burkina Faso (P. Doherty, R.W. Jabado, I. Seidu, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across its range have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the African Brown Skate are generally unmanaged and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future. 

A number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing a National Plan of Action (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Other countries such as Gabon, the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are in the process of expanding their marine protected areas coverage, however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: Boretz's Dogfish (Squalus boretzi) is a small (to 95 cm total length) poorly-known deep-water shark endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean with a highly restricted distribution. It occurs only in the High Seas off the southern Emperor Seamount Chain (south of 35°N) and is demersal and epi-pelagic on seamounts at depths of 100–525 m. The species is a likely bycatch of deep-water demersal and pelagic trawl, longline, and gillnet fisheries, and possibly retained for its meat and liver oil. Historically, fishing pressure across its range was intense and unregulated during the 1960s to 1980s, however, fishing effort has since reduced and is now managed by the North Pacific Fisheries Commission. The species is likely susceptible to overfishing and its highly restricted distribution and capture is of concern. However, over the past two generation lengths of the Boretz's Dogfish (42 years), fishing effort has declined and is managed. It is suspected that Boretz's Dogfish has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (63 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2d).
habitat: Boretz's Dogfish is demersal and epi-pelagic on seamounts at depths of 100–525 m (Dolganov 2019). It reaches a maximum size of 95.2 cm total length (TL), males mature at 61 cm TL and females mature at 77 cm TL (Dolganov 2019). Reproduction is viviparous with pregnant females observed with 2–3 near full-term embryos and size-at-birth estimated at 23 cm TL (Dolganov 2019). Nothing else is known of its biology. Generation length is inferred from a closely-related species, the Japanese Spurdog (Squalus japonicus), which has a female age-at-maturity of 19.3 years and a maximum age of 22 years, resulting in a generation length of 21 years (Siao 2010).
threats: The species may be taken as bycatch in demersal and pelagic trawl, longline, and gillnet fisheries on the Emperor Seamounts.
